abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -We think it would pay to set all the cavalry in the West, all the gunboats, and a good part of the infantry, white and black, in pursuit of FORREST and his audacious raiders, who have been, and, we suppose, still are, plundering, burning and slaughtering in Western Tennessee and Kentucky. If ten thousand men and all the Generals between Memphis and Cairo be not enough, let there be sent fifty thousand and some of the Generals at Chattanooga. It would pay, by any means and at any cost, to settle the case of these fellows at once. There were something like forty or fifty thousand men, twenty Generals and thirty gunboats after JOHN MORGAN last Summer. As a consequence, he was caught, and we have had no more trouble from him or in that direction. Had he not been caught he would probably have kept an army active in Kentucky all last Autumn and Winter. Let FORREST be caught at all hazards, or he and other like scoundrels will give us endless trouble this year.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon several men, partially intoxicated, became involved in a quarrel in a lagerbier saloon, a No. 259 Bowery, in regard to the payment of some drinks. During the altercating a young man named PATRICK DOOLEY drew a revolver and fired at one of his antagonists. The ball missed its mare and took effect in the right side of the neck of Mr. WEINBERGER. It extended some distance inward, and inflicted a wound so serious that no hopes are entertained of his recovery. Officer BADENHOP, of the Chief Clerk's Office at Police Headquarters, happened to be passing at the time, and seeing DOOLEY rushing out of the premises followed by the crowd, he joined in the chose and after running several blocks, the officer, aided by others, succeeded in effecting his capture, not however, until DOOLEY had made three or four ineffectual attempts to shoot his pursuers. His revolver missed fire every time. He was taken before Justice DOWLING at the Tombs Police Court, where, after a preliminary examination, he was committed to await the result of WEINBERGER's injuries. The latter resided at No. 21 Christie-street. It is reported that he kept a billiard saloon and a shooting gallery at the place where he was shot.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the following were among the bills reported: Against granting the Staten Island Ferry Company a new slip; to amend the charter of the Fire Department of the Eastern District of Brooklyn; against authorizing the Harlem and Spuyten Duyvel Canal Company to reduce its capital stock; amending the charter of the New-York Sixpenny Savings Bank; permitting gas companies to lay main pipes in turnpike roads; authorizing the Commissioners of the Land Office to lease to SHNPARD KNAPP the title to certain lands under water in Kings County. The bill for the improvement of Grand-street, Brooklyn, was passed.

abstract: -In a letter to the author, Mr. Secretary CHASE thus writes of the new novel, Cudjo's Cave: "The inflamed condition of my right eye has prevented my reading or writing much lately. Cudjo's Cave I could not help reading, however, it interested and impressed me profoundly." In a letter, giving permission to the publishers to use the above Mr. CHASE adds: "The book merits higher praise, and I have heard it more highly spoken of by discerning judges." -- Boston Transcript.

abstract: The steamship Fulton, from Port Royal, March 27, arrived here last evening. Matters in the Department of the South were generally quiet. A naval expedition up the St. John's River captured at Lake George, the rebel steamer Hattie Brock, laden with 100 bales of cotton and a quantity of rice, tobacco and other articles. Brig.-Gen. J.P. HATCH had gone to Jacksonville to relieve Gen. SEYMOUR, who was expected at Hilton Head within a short time. The rebels are supposed to have taken a portion of their forces from our front at Jacksonville and Pilatka.

abstract: His Reelection and Rebel Discouragement
lead_paragraph: In a speech just delivered in Portland, Gen. NEAL Dow, who for nine months has been a prisoner at Richmond and other points, detailing his personal observations, made the statement that "at present the rebels are looking anxiously at movements at the North in relation to the next Presidential election, and their hope is that some other man than Mr. LINCOLN may be nominated and elected." He testified that they would regard the election of any other person as a sure indication that the loyal North tires of the war and means to change its policy. This special spite of the rebel press against President LINCOLN, has long indicated the same thing. His "tyranny," as it is termed, is uniformly treated as the special motive power of the war. Their fixed idea is, that if an end could somehow be made of that, the war itself would speedily come to an end.
headline: {'main': "Mr. Lincoln's Re-election and Rebel Discouragement.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Mr. Lincoln's Re-election and Rebel Discouragement.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An adjourned meeting was held yesterday afternoon, at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, in aid of the suffering Union men of East Tennessee. Mr. SETH B. HUNT presided, and Mr. JOHN AUSTIN, Jr., acted as Secretary. A donation of $100 was received from PETER COOPER, Esq. A letter received from the Provost-Marshal-General of Knoxville, describing the sufferings and wants of the people of East Tennessee, and the necessity of immediate relief, was read by the Secretary. Col. TAYLOR, of East Tennessee, then, on motion of Gen. STRONG, took the floor.

abstract: Skilled Workmen Wanted
lead_paragraph: It is greatly to be regretted that there is not some organization, either governmental or private, on a scale sufficiently large, and composed of persons sufficiently prominent in character and standing to give it credit and influence abroad, to aid in promoting the immigration from Europe of skilled workers. We are receiving immense numbers of unskilled laborers, invaluable, no doubt, for agricultural and other purposes, but all branches of industry are suffering severely, and likely to suffer still more, from the want of mechanics and artisans. There are thousands of such, both in England and on the Continent, in a half-starving condition, who would be only too glad to get over here if they got a chance. The most desperate efforts are being made by the Secessionist Press, and persons working in the Secessionist interest, to prevent emigration to America, by the circulation of the grossest misrepresentations as to the condition of the country, and the effect of the war on the laboring classes. General statements in our newspapers are not sufficient to counteract this. They do not reach the persons whom it is desirable to influence, and if they did would not remove their doubts or difficulties. What is wanted is personal and well accredited agency, and funds to help the movement. And it ought not to be confined to England. If anything of this kind were attempted on a great scale, the habits and intelligence of the class of persons from which the immigrants would be drawn, ought to be duly considered. With our system of Government, the moral and mental condition of those who come to settle in the country is of the highest importance. It ought not to be forgotten that they are to be fellow-citizens, as well as fellow-laborers, and that their character, therefore, is of full as much importance to us as their skill.

abstract: The monopoly of Camden and Amboy propose to succeed by foul means, if they cannot succeed otherwise. Much indignation was caused at Trenton yesterday, among those who are not carried in the pockets of the monopoly, at the introduction of a bill by Mr. BENSON, of Hudson, to repeal the charter of the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad Company.
lead_paragraph: The monopoly of Camden and Amboy propose to succeed by foul means, if they cannot succeed otherwise. Much indignation was caused at Trenton yesterday, among those who are not carried in the pockets of the monopoly, at the introduction of a bill by Mr. BENSON, of Hudson, to repeal the charter of the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad Company. The bill was referred to the Committee on Corporations; Mr. MCMICHAEL, Chairman, without consulting his associates on the committee, reported it back favorably in ten minutes, and it was printed and placed upon the members' desks at the opening of the afternoon session. The following is the bill:

abstract: The steamer Fulton, which arrived from Port Royal yesterday, when about 65 miles from Cape Henry, on the night of March 29, spoke a two-masted propeller firing signal guns. A heavy gale and the high sea prevented any effectual efforts to relieve her, although the Fulton spoke her and endeavored to lay by her through the night. On the next morning the propeller was not in sight.

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner WILDEY at the Eighth Precinct Station-house, on the body of PETER P. LATOPIE, a soldier lately attached to the Forty-seventh Regiment N.Y.S.V., who died suddenly at No. 21 Greene-street, at a late hour on Wednesday night. Dr. GEORGE B. BOUTON made a post mortem examination, when it was ascertained that death was caused by the rupture of an anuerism of the ascending aorta. The jury rendered a verdict accordingly. Deceased was 27 years of age and a native of Louisiana. He enlisted in the Hawkins' Zouaves soon after the breaking out of the rebellion. After serving for some time in that regiment, he was discharged, and subsequently enlisted in the regiment known as the Entans Perdus, (Lost Children,) from which he was transferred to the Forty-seventh New-York Volunteers.

abstract: Piracy. Alexandra Case Before House of Lords
snippet: Piracy. Alexandra Case Before House of Lords
lead_paragraph: -We see that the case of the Alexandra has been argued before the House of Lords, and the final decision therein has probably been rendered before this. It seems a pity that a case which has been of so much importance should have so insignificant an ending as this is likely to have, for our readers may understand that this famous case, which was to give the world the authoritative decision of the highest tribunal in England, upon the grave questions of neutrality that were involved in it, and have been so much debated, will at last decide nothing whatever but a petty point of practice.

abstract: Disturbances and Forrest's Advance
lead_paragraph: It was thought a curious fact last Summer that LEE's advance North, should have been so quickly followed by an insurrection here in New-York. It is just as curious that FORREST's advance to the Ohio, and his attack upon Paducah, should be so quickly followed by an outbreak in Southern Illinois. We are not prepared to say that there was an understanding, in either case, between any of the Copperhead leaders and the rebels, for a joint movement. The secret society of the Golden Circle, which is known to have extensive ramifications all through the North, and which is also known to be in the interest of the rebellion, might doubtless furnish great facilities for such concurrence of action against the Government; yet, there being no proof, we make no charge.
headline: {'main': 'The Illinois Disturbances.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Illinois Disturbances.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: White vs Allis. Breach of Contract; Philidelphia Steam Propeller Co. vs. Steamship George Washington; Barge Sunk in Slip
snippet: White vs Allis. Breach of Contract; Philidelphia Steam Propeller Co. vs. Steamship George Washington; Barge Sunk in Slip
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Steam Propeller Company vs. The Steam Propeller George Washington. -- This was an action of a somewhat novel character. The facts of the case were as follow: The George Washington, a large screw steamer, was, on the 24th of November, 1862, lying on the north side of Pier No. 9 in the North River. She was a new vessel and was in process of completion, and for the purpose of trying her machinery she had been turning her screw through the day. Her screw was a large one, 13 feet in diameter, and the effect of its revolution was to cause a powerful current to set toward the screw from the other side of the slip. On this opposite side of the slip lay the libelant's barge, Fair Lady, and the barge Garibaldi -- the Garibaldi being outside. Another propeller lay ahead of them nearer the end of the pier. During the day it became necessary to move the Fair Lady out toward the end of the pier, which could not be done safely while the screw of the George Washington was in motion. The engineer of the George Washington was therefore requested to stop it, while the barges were being moved. He stopped it accordingly, and the barge Garibaldi was moved out, and made fast near the end of the pier. The Fair Lady was then breasted out from the pier to be moved forward. While she was so being moved, and when she was about two-thirds of her length past the screw of the George Washington, her engineer started her engine and set her screw in motion. The current caused by its motion at once sucked the Fair Lady over to the stern of the George Washington, where one arm of the screw as it revolved, struck the bottom of the barge and cut a hole in her, from the effects of which she sunk, causing about $20,000 damage to her and the goods on board of her, for the recovery of which this suit was brought.

abstract: -- LAWRENCE W. PEYTON, one of MORGAN's officers, son of Ex-Congressman PEYTON, was shot at Camp Lookout, by Sergt. YOUNG, an Assistant of the Provost-Marshal, a few days ago. The circumstances are related by a correspondent of the Baltimore American, as follows: "The rebel asked YOUNG to go and get him a bottle of whisky, and when he refused, saving it was contrary to orders, PEYTON denounced him as a fit companion to the negro guard, a coward who did not dare to shoot, etc. The Sergeant pulled out his revolver and started toward the gate. PEYTON attempted to kick him, and he turned and shot him dead. PEYTON was about thirty-five years old, a private belonging to Company I. Second Kentucky Cavalry. The shooting occurred when the prisoners were being assigned to their quarters."

abstract: The Trenton Gazette of April 1, says: "The most important part of the proceedings of the House of Assembly on Thursday, was the introduction of a bill, by Mr. BENSON, to repeal the act incorporating the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad Company. The bill was referred to the Committee on Corporations, and will probably come up for action next week. Of course it would be idle at this time to speculate as to the action of the Legislature upon it; but that the Legislature possesses the right to repeal the charter, would appear to be indisputable."

abstract: FOR THE FAIR. -- Mr. WILLIAM H. ASPINWALL has given notice that his fine gallery of pictures at his residence, University-place, corner of Tenth-street, will be opened to the public during the continuance of the Metropolitan Fair, and that the entire proceeds will be given to the Sanitary Commission. This gallery contains some of the finest and most valuable works of the Old Masters ever brought to this country. In addition to his own collection of fine pictures, Mr. WOOLSEY, of Astoria, has kindly loaned to Mr. ASPINWALL, for the occasion, his large picture, by HERRING, of the "Farm-Yard," one of the most notable works by this artist. Mr. BELMONT has also decided to open his gallery, in Eighteenth-street, corner of Fifth-avenue, to the public, during the same time and for the same purpose.

abstract: In the House of Lords, on Friday, the 18th, Earl RUSSELL said, seeing that the noble Earl opposite (ELLENBOROUGH) has given notice of his intention on the emotion for adjournment, to call the attention of the House to the actual state of affairs in Germany and Denmark, I rise on public grounds to request that the noble Earl will not at present proceed with the discussion of that question. I do not think that anything that could fall from the noble Earl would tend to increase the difficulties which surround the settlement of this question, and for my own part, I must say that I should have been very glad to have rendered the fullest explanation respecting the conduct of the Government in reference to the affairs of Denmark and Germany; but there are reasons of public policy which make it desirable that no discussion should take place at this moment. In the first place I have to present, by command of Her Majesty, various papers in continuation of those which were laid on the table a few weeks ago. These papers contain the further correspondence that has taken place very recently. In the next place, there has been a correspondence lately carried on with regard to the holding of a conference and to the proposed armistice, and I have goods hopes that the Danish Government will agree to the conference. If that should be the case. I hope that an armistice will, on the grounds of humanity and on the basis already proposed, be acceptable to all parties. But that matter is still in doubt, and your Lordships will see that a discussion of the subject at a time when these matters are still in doubt is very undesirable. I do, therefore, trust that the noble Earl, on the grounds of public policy, will postpone the discussion until all the papers which have been presented are in your Lordships' hands; although, as I have state, I have no fear that anything which the noble Earl might say could interfere with the settlement of the question, yet any discussion might be liable to misapprehension by the parties now engaged in war, and might thus tend to the public injury, and prevent the success of the negotiations which are now being earned on. [Hear, hear.]

abstract: The steamships Cahawba and Yazoo, from New-Orleans, March 24, arrived at this port yesterday. They bring news of a handsome little engagement at Natchitoches, La., sixty miles above Alexandria, between our forces, under command of Gens. LEE and MOWER, and the rebels, in which we captured four pieces of artillery and 210 prisoners. Gen. BANKS had left New-Orleans for the front. Franklin, La., the western terminus of the Opelousas Railroad, had been evacuated by our forces. The political excitement in Louisiana had subsided. Affairs in Texas were quiet.

abstract: -A fortnight since we gave an account of the trial by Lynch law and the hanging of some twenty robbers and murderers in our Western Territory of Idaho. A correspondent from whom we quoted, stated that "it was probable, from present appearances, that twenty or thirty more would soon be executed by the same process." It appears by a telegram we gave yesterday from the Pacific Coast, that the work is going on remorselessly. We are told that dispatches from Idaho announce the hanging by Vigilance Committees of "eleven men at Virginia City, five at Big Hole, one at Deer Lodge, and seven at Briar Rat." It is cheering to be told, immediately after this announcement that the "rush of emigration to Idaho is immense." We should think that the rush of emigration would need to be immense to keep up the supply of fodder for so many gallows. But why are some people so fond of being hung? Ho! for Idaho!

abstract: The establishment of a Zoological Garden at Central Park on an extensive scale, is a measure in which the public feel a great interest, and renewed efforts are being made to have it perfected. Property-owners in the vicinity of Manhattan-square, and a number of gentlemen of scientific tastes, are uniting in an attempt to have the control of the square transferred by the Legislature to the Central Park Commissioners for the purpose of making a grand Zoological Garden of it. Manhattan-square adjoins the Park, is bounded by Seventy-seventh and Eighty-first streets and Eighth and Ninth avenues. It was taken for a park some twenty years since, the adjacent property was assessed for it, and the assessments were paid. The owners of property adjacent, therefore, are just the ones to take the initiative in a movement which will be eminently popular.

abstract: THE MATCH FOR THE CHAMPIONSHIP. -- Mr. TIEMAN, accompanied by a delegation from Cincinnati, arrived here on Wednesday afternoon, and at once proceeded to KAVANAGH's Broadway and Tenth-street establishment, which he will make his headquarters during his stay in this City. On Thursday the contestants visited the manufactory of Messr. PHELAN & COLLENDER, and selected the table which is to be used for the contest. It was at once removed to a private room at KAVANAGH's, where it is now employed to practice upon. Our reporter has witnessed several tilts by these experts since that time, and in a match of 250 points up, KAVANAGH, for the first time in several months, exhibited the full scope of his well-known brilliant manipulation, and reassured his numerous friends that his chances of winning are equal to their expectations. TIEMAN was travel-weary, and although there was a decided improvement over the play he displayed here in October last, yet there was evidence that he wanted to get over his journey before he would be able to show his full prowess. On Thursday, Messrs. PHELAN and TIEMAN played five games of 500 points each. TIEMAN won three of them; his highest run was 104; PHELAN's, 87. The average of the whole was about 15. Every game TIEMAN plays is an improvement on the last, and he is rapidly arriving at his best speed. Betting is not as active as was anticipated, the Western men holding off in hopes of getting odds; but while the friends of KAVANAGH readily cover all even amounts, they decline allowing a percentage. Of course the great amount of the betting will be left for the day and evening of the match.

abstract: "Who is to publish Her Majesty's new book? The first publication from the royal pen was issued, we believe, in 1834, when the Princess ALEXANDRINA VICTORIA was in her sixteenth year. It was a small volume of poetry -- a mere pamphlet -- and was only distributed amongst the immediate members of the royal circle. A copy was sold at the sale of the library of the Princess ELIZABETH about two years since. That Her Majesty is engaged upon a literary undertaking connected with the history of her reign has certainly been stated in various continental journals, which, upon all matters relative to the proceedings of royalty in this country, appear to possess some secret sources of information not open to the home journals.
lead_paragraph: "Who is to publish Her Majesty's new book? The first publication from the royal pen was issued, we believe, in 1834, when the Princess ALEXANDRINA VICTORIA was in her sixteenth year. It was a small volume of poetry -- a mere pamphlet -- and was only distributed amongst the immediate members of the royal circle. abstract: System, Reforms proposed
lead_paragraph: A bill, making some important changes in the School Law of this City, has been reported in the Assembly by Hon. ERASTUS C. BENEDICT. The most material change is in the manner of appointing and removing the teachers employed in the Ward Schools. The total number of these teachcrs is about two thousand. They are now appointed and may be removed by the uncontroled action of a majority of the trustees of the ward in which the school is located, and it is notorious that the power has often been grossly abused. It is proposed by the new bill, that hereafter the principals and vice-principals of these schools shall be appointed and removed only by the concurrent action of the Board of Education of the City, and the Board of Trustees for the ward. Assistant teachers are to be appointed, as heretofore, by the Board of Trustees for the ward; but the more reliable tenure of office secured to the principals of the schools, upon whom the main responsibility for their management actually rests, will give to them such a degree of courage that they will apply to be relieved from the imposition of useless assistants. The means for removing teachers, though guarded by careful checks, are so fully provided that there will be little probability of the retention of teachers who are incompetent, inefficient or otherwise unworthy. Assistant teachers may be removed by concurrent action of the trustees and inspectors; but in such case the teacher removed has a right of appeal to the Board of Education, which body, after hearing the trustees, may reinstate the teacher. The Board of Education is to have an absolute power of removal, not only upon the recommendation of a majority of either the inspectors or trustees having the school in charge, but also upon that of the City Superintendent of Schools.

abstract: The Tax Levy Bill which has been forwarded to Albany is exciting the strongest opposition from citizens. As we have stated, it estimates the expenses of the year at $15,000,000. The dissection which will be given it will reveal startling facts and the most profligate designs for the expenditure of the public monies.
lead_paragraph: The Tax Levy Bill which has been forwarded to Albany is exciting the strongest opposition from citizens. As we have stated, it estimates the expenses of the year at $15,000,000. The dissection which will be given it will reveal startling facts and the most profligate designs for the expenditure of the public monies. The bill was hurried off to Albany without receiving the concurrence of the Board of Councilmen or the sanction of the Mayor. The swindling designed was too flagrant, the fleecing too enormous. The Committee of the Citizens' Association, of which reference has been made, visit Albany to protest against it, and to show incontrovertibly the swindles contemplated and the unnecessary burden sought to be imposed upon the City. The Legislatived Committee before whom it is, cannot evade the truths which will be presented them, and there is a confident belief that they will not favorably report upon the bill as presented. Every Ward of the City will be represented at Albany, and the true feeling of our citizens indicated.
headline: {'main': 'The Enormous Tax Levy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Enormous Tax Levy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. MEYERBEER'S grand opera "Robert le Diabie," was produced here last evening, with a degree of success which will insure its repetition on many occasions during the present season. It is pleasant to know that there is one opera at least that "Faust" has not staled.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- MEYERBEER's grand opera "Robert le Diabie," was produced here last evening, with a degree of success which will insure its repetition on many occasions during the present season. It is pleasant to know that there is one opera at least that "Faust" has not staled. The distribution, last night, was exceedingly strong, and, in fact, introduced most of the leading artists of Mr. MARETZEK's splendid company. Beyond placing the success of the entertainment on record, we have, at the late hour at which we write, no opportunity of speaking of the individual efforts of the artists. It must suffice for the moment that the performance was generally good. We shall return to the subject on Monday.

abstract: -- We this day present our readers with the first of a series of very brilliant articles now being published in the NEW-YORK TIMES, and intended as an analysis and review of Gen. MCCLELLAN's history of his military career. These articles have been called forth by the recent report of Gen. MCCLELLAN, evidently intended as a political manifesto, and giving so partial and incorrect a view of the merits of that much overrated officer that it is necessary, for the cause of truth, to investigate the other side of the question. These articles in the TIMES are written with excessive clearness and truth, and in the total absence of anything like bitter invective or partisanship. A more unanswerable argument against the fulsome pretensions that have been set up in favor of the "Little Napoleon," has never yet been laid before the public, and we defy any unprejudiced mind to follow closely the reasonings in those papers without coming to the conclusion that never were more splendid opportunities thrown away, or more dazzling chances of fame neglected than by Gen. GEO. B. MCCLELLAN, while commanding the Army of the Potomac. -- New-Orleans Times, March 18.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Vice-President laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Navy, in reply to a resolution of Mr. GRIMES, as to the number of men transferred from the military to the naval service, etc.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Vice-President laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Navy, in reply to a resolution of Mr. GRIMES, as to the number of men transferred from the military to the naval service, etc. It was referred to the Naval Committee and ordered to be printed. Mr. NESMITH called up the bill to establish assay offices at Carson City, Nevada, and Dalles City, Oregon, and moved an amendment establishing a branch mint at Portland, Oregon, instead of an assay office at Dalles City, and advocated it at length, making some caustic references to the course of the Director of the Philadelphia Mint in regard to it. After some unimportant conversation on various matters, an Executive Session was ordered, and a large number of military nominations confirmed.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were reported for the safe-keeping of old records in the public offices of the City of New-York, and incorporating the Long Island City Water Works Company. abstract: HOMICIDE ON SHIPBOARD -- THE PERPETRATOR ARRESTED. -- An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN, on board the ship Albert Gallatin, lying in the harbor, opposite Bedloe's Island, on the body of WM. HENDERSON, a sailor, who died from injuries received on Thursday evening at the hands of a shipmate named PATRICK CLARK. The testimony given in the case tended to show that the Albert Gallatin cleared from this port, on Thursday afternoon, for Liverpool, and that after going down the bay a short distance she anchored for the night. The crew, who had just been shipped, were for the most part intoxicated. Between 8 and 9 o'clock in the evening they became involved in a serious quarrel among themselves, during which HENDERSON was knocked down, beaten and kicked about the head and face by CLARK. The injuries were so serious that the victim died in a few minutes afterward. The evidence disclosed the fact, however, that deceased had made a deadly assault on CLARK, and that the latter, to some extent, acted in self-defence. The jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that WM. HENDERSON came to his death by blows at the hands of PATRICK CLARK; and we think, from the evidence, that it was partly justifiable." Deceased was 37 years of age, and a native of Scotland. CLARK was arrested by the Harbor Police, and upon the rendition of the verdict he was committed by the Coroner to await the action of the Grand Jury. He is 26 years of age, and was born in Ireland. He does not deny having inflicted the injuries, but he says that the act was done purely in self-defence.

abstract: Secretary STANTON, in a letter to the Senate Military Committee to-day, called their attention to the importance of at once considering the military nominations of Major and Brigadier Generals before them. In the reorganization of the army, it was found that a very large number of brigades were commanded by Colonels, and this was owing to the fact that some forty or fifty were before the Senate for confirmation. Executive session was at once ordered, when a large number of these officers were confirmed.

abstract: Seamen for Our Navy
lead_paragraph: -- The Secretary of the Navy has sent to the Senate a very able and earnest letter upon the deficiency of men in our naval service, the causes of the deficiency, and the legislation required to remedy it. There are thirty-four thousand seamen in the naval service; there are thirty-five vessels-of-war now awaiting crews, and the number is increasing; and the immediate and imperative wants of the naval service require the transfer of twelve thousand seamen from the army. No transfers of sailors from the army to the navy have been effected thus far; but many sailors have been drafted into the army, or drawn thither by bounties and other causes, and are now serving as soldiers. While experienced men are thus misemployed, or, at least, not employed to the highest advantage, the enlistments into the navy during the last year have been mostly of inexperienced landsmen. "A sailor," says the Secretary, "is an expert, educated to his profession by years of training, and, when withdrawn from his proper duty, no inexperienced person can make good his place."
headline: {'main': 'SEAMEN FOR OUR NAVY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'SEAMEN FOR OUR NAVY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Campbell, Rev. Dr., of Albany; Van Rensselaer, Col. H., Ex-Congressman
snippet: Campbell, Rev. Dr., of Albany; Van Rensselaer, Col. H., Ex-Congressman
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL, a well-known divine of Albany, has just died in that city. The Albany Evening Journal sketches the main points of his history as follows: "Dr. CAMPBELL was a native of the City of Philadelphia. His pastoral life commenced, we believe, in Petersburgh, Va. He subsequently accepted a call at Newbern, N.C., from whence he went to Washington. Gen. JACKSON was a member of his congregation. During the Mrs. Eaton imbroglio, which occasioned a breaking up of the Cabinet. Dr. CAMPBELL, who spoke as plainly, to the President as he would have done to the humblest citizen, incurred Gen. JACKSON's displeasure. In 1830, the late Chief Justice SPENCER, then a member of Congress, attended Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL's Church, and became much interested in him. This circumstance led to his call and settlement in Albany -- a circumstance auspicious alike to pastor and people, and out of which endearing relations grew up and have existed for thirty-four years. Dr. CAMPBELL will be most missed, outside of his family and church, in the Board of Regents, and at the State Library, where for many years his knowledge, judgment, diligence, taste and tact, have been invaluable."

abstract: We are authorized to announce that Mr. [???] [???] [???], of New Haven, (whose endowment of a Professorship of Modern Languages in Yale College, was made public not long ago,) has offered to make another important donation to that institution. He proposes to erect upon the College square, at the corner of Chapel and High streets, if the College corporation will consent, a building adapted for receiving collections in the various departments of the Fine Arts, and also for giving instruction in the history, principles and methods of art. Such a foundation will be of great value to the College, not only from the refining and elevating influence of well selected collections of works of art, but also from the important aid which they render in historical archaeological and literary studies. Such a generous and unexpected addition to the resources of the College will give new confidence to its friends, that the future of the institution will be not less useful and honorable than the past. We congratulate our entire community on this munificent gift. -- New-Haven Palladium, March 28.

abstract: In the House yesterday, Mr. PENDLETON, of Ohio, called up his motion to reconsider the vote by which the House disagreed to the Senate's amendment to the Montano Territory Bill, and asking a committee of conference. He argued that the Senate's amendment striking out "white," was to give "negroes" the right to vote in the Territory. Mr. PENDLETON's resolution was tabled. The House then resumed the consideration of the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad Bill. Mr. SWEAT, of Maine, spoke against the bill, believing it had no warrant in the Constitution of the United States or laws of the country.

abstract: SUICIDE OF A WEALTHY CITIZEN. Justice AVERY, of Hoboken, held an inquest this week upon the body of CORNELIUS BOGERT, a wealthy and respect able gentleman, 63 years of age, residing at No. 234 Washington-street, Hoboken, who committed suicide  by cutting his throat.
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE OF A WEALTHY CITIZEN. Justice AVERY, of Hoboken, held an inquest this week upon the body of CORNELIUS BOGERT, a wealthy and respect able gentleman, 63 years of age, residing at No. 234 Washington-street, Hoboken, who committed suicide by cutting his throat. It appeared in evidence that Mr. BOGERT had disposed of the dwelling in which he resided, which no afterwards regretted and endeavored to purchase it back, offering a bonus of $500. The offer not being accepted, he became despondent, and one night after retiring to bed, advised his wife not to sleep with him thereafter, fearing that he would murder her and then destroy his own life. On the 24th ult. he cut his throat with a common pocketknife, and, after lingering several days, died of the injuries inflicted. The jury rendered a verdict that deceased came to his death by suicide, while laboring under temporary insanity.

abstract: Strategy, a Military Correspondent on
lead_paragraph: A military correspondent -- not very military -- forwards us a labored defence of an officer of our army, who, it seems, in a certain instance, rushed pell-mell upon the rebels, and got murderously defeated. He defends the pell-mell style of warfare upon a great variety of grounds. "In the first place," says he, "it showed a proper spirit of bravery before the armed foe; it showed them that our army were not afraid or unwilling to fight." Farther on, he argues that "to wait, and parry, and manoeuvre for some advantage of ground, at an expense of millions per day is simply to confess our inability to crush the rebellion, and that the rebels will fight better against our Government than we will for it." It is melancholy to find any man who has had sufficient brains and pluck to right and bleed for his country, writing thus. War is not merely a trial of brute strength, with the object of crushing or killing an enemy, nor is it a trial as to which of two combatants will come out best or display most bravery in a "straight, standing-up, knock-down fight" The proper object of war is to discomfit the enemy in his aims and in the field, and to do this with the least possible loss to your own side. To this end, intellect plays as prominent a part as muscle and skill subserves equally with strength Nothing in the course of this was illustrates finer the value of consummate strategical ability than the operations of Gen. GRANT immediately prior to the investment of Vickbburgh. When he crossed his forces to this side of the Mississippi, had he Simply stood his ground until PEMBERTON's army came up, and had he then entered upon a simple trial of brute strength, there can be little doubt that he would have been defeated and the war on the river have been postponed indefinitely, at an "expense of millions per day." But by the most brilliant series of strategical manoevres that have been witnessed for the last half century, he succeeded in completely circumventing the enemy, dividing their forces, making their conjunction impossible, defeating them in detail, discomfiting them in their purposes, opening the Mississippi River, and ending the war in the Great Valley. Had the critic whom we are now criticising been in command, instead of GRANT, on that occasion, the army of the Union would have suffered the fate which Gen. Jo. JOHNSTON excoriates PEMBERTON for not administering to it. From this illustration our correspondent will see the value of "parrying and manoeuvering" more clearly than probably he would from a column of reasoning; and had the officer whom he praises for fighting pell-mell possessed and exercised the genius for strategy, his battle might have been a victory instead of a bloody defeat.

abstract: The privileges of French citizens under the Second Empire, are not of a very enviable character. The most insignificant meetings in relation to politics, cannot be held without the sanction of the imperial authorities, and ...
lead_paragraph: The privileges of French citizens under the Second Empire, are not of a very enviable character. The most insignificant meetings in relation to politics, cannot be held without the sanction of the imperial authorities, and even with that sanction, they are not secure from interruption. In France, every man's house is by no means his castle. A case illustrative of French freedom under the BONAPARTES, has lately occurred in Paris. The Prefect of the Police having intimated to the candidates for the unrepresented districts that they were at liberty to hold assemblies of their friends, provided they convoked them by personal letters of invitation, M. GARNIER PAGES, one of the candidates for the Fifth District availed himself of the license, and addressed a circular to his supporters, inviting them to meet at his residence to discuss the prospects of his election. The object of the meeting being perfectly lawful, one should have concluded that the sanction of the Prefect would have saved it from annoyance. Despite authorization, however, M. GARNIER PAGES and his friends were not allowed to close their proceedings in peace. Monsieur PAGES had rendered himself obnoxious to the present regime by publishing a History of the Revolution of '48, and, especially, by inserting therein the text of a letter written by M. FOULD, in republican times, in which that now notable Imperialist financier recommended national bankruptcy as a convenient method of escaping from the burden of public debt. The manuscript of this letter, and other papers very compromising to some of the prominent actors on the political stage, being in the possession of Mons. PAGES, it occurred to the police authorities that if any pretext could be found for the outrage, this would be an excellent opportunity for seizing the coveted documents and clearing scores with the opposition candidate. An inadvertence on the part of M. PAGES afforded the wished-for pretext. The circulars had unfortunately been signed by his son-in-law, instead of by himself. This irregularity was pronounced subversive of the gentleman's right to hold the meeting, and an ample justification for police interference. A raid on the domicile of M. PAGES was accordingly determined on, and while the host and his guests were engaged in the discussion of electioneering affairs, a bevy of gendarmes suddenly rushed into No. 45 Rue St. Roch, dispersed the company, and instituted a general search for the documents referred to. The outrage, however, proved as unprofitable as it was shameful. The dispersion of a meeting, composed of about one hundred in offensive civilians, could not have been the real object of the raid, and the search for the papers turned out fruitless, since, though in the possession of M. PAGES, they were not there.

abstract: on Slavery; Bible View of Slavery
snippet: on Slavery; Bible View of Slavery
lead_paragraph: We understand that there are some persons who think the tone of our comments upon the exertions of the "Society for the Diffusion of Political Information," to "put down amalgamation," was somewhat too jocular for the gravity of the subject. They feel as the Irishman felt, who, on listening to the small jokes of an irreverent Englishman upon the enormous consumption of potatoes in Ireland, remarked with solemnity and dignity, that "there was some things too sarey-us to joke about, an' praties was won of 'em." There is no doubt that there is something in this view of the matter. When an association is formed in a metropolis like New-York, in the middle of the nineteenth century, and in a country like America, which has achieved great distinction in the science as well as in the art of government, with pretensions to education, and even what is called "culture," and found capable of contributing to its "papers" such productions as Prof. MORSE's "Argument on the Ethical Position of Slavery in the Social System," and Bishop HOPKINS' "Bible View of Slavery" -- the propriety of laughing over their performances does, we admit, seem somewhat doubtful. We confess that we rise from the perusal of these two "papers" a good deal nearer crying than laughing -- not, Heaven knows, for the poor negro, but for the poor white man; for it is unfortunately our race, and not the black one, that will suffer all the damage they will ever do.

abstract: New-Liberty, Ky., Nearly Destroyed
lead_paragraph: We regret to state that one of the most destructive conflagrations it has ever fallen to our lot to record occurred in New-Liberty, Owen County, on Sunday. The alarm was given about noon, and letters received from there state that in less than three hours the entire business portion of the town was in ashes. New-Liberty was very compactly built on Main-street, which comprises all the business houses, principal residences, and public houses, all brick structures but two. Eighteen families have been rendered houseless and penniless. In almost every instance all their wordly possessions were embraced in their houses and contents, and very few saved anything beyond the clothes on their persons. They have all been kindly received in the homes of the farmers in the immediate vicinity for the present, until more substantial relief can be extended to them by a generous public. The estimated loss is not less than $150,000. The Female Academy, a superb structure, was entirely destroyed. But for the timely and indefatigable exertions of the men of Capt. KELLY's command, Co. I, of the Fortieth Regiment of Kentucky Mounted Infantry, who were camped near the town, the loss would have been much greater. The following is a list of the sufferers: C.C. Chowhing, Dr. Layton, C.J. Bradford, Sarah Furnish, J.C. Walden, W. Crawford, Mrs. E.J. Reville, Mrs. Hunt, Jas. Bradney, H. Barker, Dr. Payton, J. Vanpelt, Isaac Foster, Ellis & Orr, J.P. Orr, Sr., Mrs. Carlett, Henry Blanton, Blanton &Tune. -- Louisville Journal, March 31.
headline: {'main': 'Destructive Fire in Owen County, Ky.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Destructive Fire in Owen County, Ky.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Clanricarde, Lord, a Personal View of
snippet: Clanricarde, Lord, a Personal View of
lead_paragraph: Mr. ROEBUCK, so far from being the embodiment and type of pure native Bullism, is to all intents a colonist, and a North American colonist at that. His exquisite notions of monarchical and class government were first picked up neither in the smoky purlieus of his Yorkshire constituency, nor in the balmy regions of St. James. Whatever he owes to his early training the Canadian Provinces may claim the credit of. Brought first into public view in the town of Montreal, he got his position subsequently in England by being accredited to the lobby of the House of Commons as the agent of the patriotic or "rebel" party of Lower Canada, then all but in arms against the Imperial Government. Espousing, with the ardor and enthusiasm of youth, the cause of the insurgent minority, Mr. ROEBUCK achieved the distinction of being one of the foremost of the rising Democratic politicians that the Reform Act of 1832 ultimately made room for in the House of Commons.

abstract: -- Yesterday afternoon, a volunteer Surgeon, went to the ordinance office of the yard to exhibit a torpedo, of which he claims to be the inventor, when, finding that some alterations were necessary to insure its success, he was directed to the plumbers' department, where Mr. HARLEY T. HICKS was set to work upon it, and while in the act of applying the solder, the torpedo, which was ascertained afterward to be filled with chloride of potash and nitric acid, exploded. Mr. HICKS' arm, face and neck were badly burnt, and the inventor was also badly burnt about the face. Some of the workmen had their clothes scorched. The injured men were at once taken to the dispensary, where their wounds were dressed. Mr. HICKS was so badly burnt that it was requisite to take him to his home on Eleventh-street East, near G-street South, in a carriage. He is, however, much better this morning, and will recover. The injured inventor was able to proceed to his quarters without assistance. We understand that Mr. HICKS, before setting to work on the missile, was informed that there was no danger in handling it. -- Washington Star, April 1.

abstract: In the Seventh Ward a mission has been conducted for eight years; circumstances, more than once, have rendered a change of location desirable; at present the mission room is in the basement of the dwelling-house No. 327 Madison-street, an eligible place, but hardly commodious enough to meet the wants of a neighborhood so depleted of Protestant churches.
lead_paragraph: In the Seventh Ward a mission has been conducted for eight years; circumstances, more than once, have rendered a change of location desirable; at present the mission room is in the basement of the dwelling-house No. 327 Madison-street, an eligible place, but hardly commodious enough to meet the wants of a neighborhood so depleted of Protestant churches. A female assistant missionary here labors with signal success among the poor and ignorant, and the neglectors of religion, giving bread for the body and food for the soul to every needy one she finds. She persuades those who had long forsaken the house of God to come to the Mission Station. Lately a woman who had not been to church for twenty-five years, was brought in; she listened attentively to the simple story of the cross, and heard with joy the invitation from the Friend of sinners, "Come unto me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest."

abstract: Soon after one o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in an unoccupied two-story building, situated in Eighty-fourth-street, between Fourth and Fifth avenues. The building where the fire originated, owned by Mrs. A. CLANCY, was speedily destroyed; loss, $150; insured for $500 in the Greenwich Fire Insurance Company. The fire also extended to a row of frame dwellings, four in number, owned by WILLIAM WADSWORTH, and occupied by a number of poor families. The dwellings were entirely destroyed, and several of the tenants lost all their household furniture, while others succeeded in saving a small quantity of their goods. A two-story frame cottage adjoining, owned by JOHN H. LEE, was also damaged. The fire is believed to have been the work of an incendiary.

abstract: The new submarine boat, invented as a means of operating at sea in the way of blowing up the vessels of an enemy, was tested yesterday afternoon at Wallabout, in this harbor. The old sloop Extra was the vessel operated upon. She was towed down from South First-street, Williamsburgh, by a steam-tug, at full speed, and was intercepted by the submarine boat, to which a 50 lb. torpedo had been attached. The torpedo sprung her percussion-cap, and this not being successful in blowing up or damaging the Extra, a 100 lb. torpedo was brought into use; but the wire this time run off the spool, causing no explosion. These two being the only torpedoes aboard, no further trial was practicable, and the Extra was towed to Bushwick Creek, where she now lies with both torpedoes under her bottom, which can be seen any day at low tide. The submarine boat, after this trial, went back to her moorings, and the company for which she was built have accepted her.

abstract: King LOUIS II., of Bavaria, has notified to his subjects his accession to the throne by a proclamation dated the 11th March, and countersigned by his Ministers. In this document the young king takes the title of King of Bavaria, Count Palatine of the Rhine, and Duke of Bavaria, Franconia, and Suabia. He orders that all the functionaries of the kingdom should continue their functions until he may decide otherwise.
lead_paragraph: King LOUIS II., of Bavaria, has notified to his subjects his accession to the throne by a proclamation dated the 11th March, and countersigned by his Ministers. In this document the young king takes the title of King of Bavaria, Count Palatine of the Rhine, and Duke of Bavaria, Franconia, and Suabia. He orders that all the functionaries of the kingdom should continue their functions until he may decide otherwise. Prince ADALBERT of Prussia, and Prince CHARLES of Hesse, have arrived at Munich, where the Archduke LOUIS VICTOR of Austria, and a deputation of Austrian cuirassiers, of whom the late King MAXIMILIAN was Colonel, were also expected to attend the funeral.

abstract: The common impression, both in England and Australia, seems to be that the Maorian war is virtually over, and that little now remains to be done save to dispose of the vanquished, and reap the fruits of victory. Facts, however, do not quite justify this sanguine conclusion.
lead_paragraph: The common impression, both in England and Australia, seems to be that the Maorian war is virtually over, and that little now remains to be done save to dispose of the vanquished, and reap the fruits of victory. Facts, however, do not quite justify this sanguine conclusion. For, though the power of the Waikatos is broken, that of an allied tribe the Potos, is still intact. The territory of these people they are determined to defend to the last, and they have constructed three formidable forts, or pahs, in order to be the better prepared to oppose their enemies. Before the British commander, Gen. CAMERON, can report that the war is ended, he must advance through a country hard to penetrate, and capture these aboriginal strongholds. The enterprise is, of course, quite possible of accomplishment; but if the pahs are erected on streams which the British gunboats cannot enter, their reduction will be found some what more difficult than those formerly reduced.

abstract: COUNTERFEIT BILL. Mr. E.M. HODGES, of the Bank Note Reporter, informs us that counterfeit $100 United states Treasury Notes are in circulation. On the counterfeit the number of the note is larger and less brilliant in color than the genuine. On the right end of the back of the bill, the "100" in the circles ...
lead_paragraph: COUNTERFEIT BILL. Mr. E.M. HODGES, of the Bank Note Reporter, informs us that counterfeit $100 United states Treasury Notes are in circulation. On the counterfeit the number of the note is larger and less brilliant in color than the genuine. On the right end of the back of the bill, the "100" in the circles are inverted thus "001." In the genuine the "100" in the circle on the left end read thus "001," in the counterfeit they are thus "100." The outside circle of the "100" in the lower left corner of the genuine touches the lower border, in the counterfeit it does not come within one sixteenth of an inch. Mr. HODGES has shown us the bad bill, and by close inspection, the counterfeit is apparent.

abstract: The prize steamer Ceres, which was captured some weeks ago by our blockaders off Wilmington, N.C., and taken to Washington, where she was sold, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. Mr. HORACE JOHNSON, one of the owners, makes the following report: "Left Hampton Roads Thursday, March 31, for New-York, in tow of steamtug Northerner, Capt. HAZZARD; experienced a continuation of strong gales throughout the passage; 2d inst., 1 o'clock A.M., the wind continued to increase in violence until it became evident to all on board the prize that she must cut loose from the tug, or both steamers would be lost. About 4 o'clock A.M., Capt. HAZZARD attempted the difficult task of taking those on board the prize off, which was accomplished without any serious injury to any one.

abstract: Surgeon A.W. KELLY, Health Officer of Vicksburgh, makes a novel report of the sanitary condition to his chief. Under date of March 16, he writes: "A very cozy house on Pine-street was found to be occupied by a widow lady, three daughters, and seven handsome little pigs. The compatibility of feeling between the families was surprisingly good.
lead_paragraph: -- Surgeon A.W. KELLY, Health Officer of Vicksburgh, makes a novel report of the sanitary condition to his chief. Under date of March 16, he writes: "A very cozy house on Pine-street was found to be occupied by a widow lady, three daughters, and seven handsome little pigs. The compatibility of feeling between the families was surprisingly good. I don't know that they all ate from the same platter, yet they shared the same room. In anticipation of a quarrel between them, I politely suggested the propriety of an immediate separation. The mother sternly refused to shed a tear at the parting, but furiously ripped open a bed-tick and threw the feathers all over me, and but for the opportune assistance of her daughters, who seemed to appreciate my official capacity, and the realities of the occasion, the scene might have been greatly aggravated Thirty-two carcasses of mules and horses have been buried, and the bodies of nine deceased contrabands. Fourteen sewers opened and rebuilt. One hundred and twenty loads of filth removed from the streets and alleys. Dispersed the inmates of one house of ill-repute. Sent to contraband encampment ninety-five idle or illegitimately employed nogroes. Vaccinated one hundred and thirty soldiers, and eighteen citizens. Sent to pest hospital twenty-nine cases of small-pox, which is only about one-third the number for the fifteen days ending February 29."

abstract: Yesterday the Metropolitan Fair Buildings in Fourteenth-street and on Union square were the scenes of confusion, bustle, excitement and business. In the former, beyond the Fire Department, the New-Jersey Department, the Floral Temple, the Curiosity shop and the Indian Department, none, ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the Metropolitan Fair Buildings in Fourteenth-street and on Union square were the scenes of confusion, bustle, excitement and business. In the former, beyond the Fire Department, the New-Jersey Department, the Floral Temple, the Curiosity shop and the Indian Department, none, late last evening, were ready, although bales, boxes, barrels and goods miscellaneous, profusely incumbered all sections. It was carpenters, painters, paper-hangers, decorators, machinists, and hundreds of willing hearts and busy hands were engaged in the work, busy as bees, and if good-will and the most active kind of industry will effect it, to-morrow noon will find everything in "apple-pie order." There are more goods contributed than the space will at one time allow the disposing of. At the Union square building was the same condition of matters. The work of preparation has been huge, and the time, as it has turned out, too limited. Still, every thing will be ready, by dint of hard work, to-morrow. At 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon the first rehearsal was had by the band and the choir. The "Star-Spangled Banner" was the first given, and with fine effect; after which the opening hymn was attempted, and comparatively well done. Of course it will be superlatively well done to-morrow, with other of the vocal efforts, for it was evident that all needed was a familiarity with the acoustic peculiarities of the building by those whose voices were so harmoniously engaged.

abstract: Intelligence has been received at Police Headquarters, that on the 21st ultimo, as the ship Norway, Capt. MOSIER, from Liverpool to New-York, was several hundred miles from port, a difficulty took place between two of the sailors named WM.H. YOUNG and a man named "Friday." During the altercation " the man Friday" seized a cut lass, and with it inflicted a terrible gash in YOUNG's abdomen. The desperado, after the infliction of this wound, ran to the hold of the ship and sought to apply a match to the magazine. "Friday's" object was discovered in time, and Capt. MOSIER ordered his mate to shoot him on the spot. A bullet from the mate's revolver instantly penetrated "Friday's" brains, and immediate death was the result. The Captain regarded this as the best way to save the lives of his passengers and crew, also to insure the safety of his ship. "Friday's" body was afterward consigned to the ocean. The ship Norway arrived at this port on Friday night, and is now lying at pier No. 50 East River. YOUNG was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where he now lies in a very critical condition. The facts of the case were reported to Inspector CARPENTER by Capt. JAMIESON, of the Seventh Precinct.

abstract: The wind during yesterday was from the northeast, and quite fresh, accompanied with rain. We have not heard of any disasters on the rivers. There were a great number of vessels in the rivers and bays outward bound, but unable to proceed on account of the storm. The steamships City of Washington, Germania and Evening Star left the City, and are probably anchored in the Bay. The Sound steamers left at the usual time, but would hardly proceed further than Flushing Bay last night. Vessels arriving reported a heavy gale from east northeast outside. The ship Guardian, while attempting to come in the Hook, struck on the outer middle, where she remained several hours, but subsequently got off and anchored in the Lower Bay.

abstract: Emancipation in
lead_paragraph: The Anti-Slavery agitation has fairly commenced in Kentucky. The venerable Dr. BRECKINRIDGE, who exercises more influence than any man in the State, has lately taken strong ground for emancipation, and has had more than one "deliverance" upon the subject. He made a speech, a few days since, at an excited meeting in Danville, in which he confessed himself an "Emancipationist, though a large slaveholder, and could not understand why people could not exercise an ordinary amount of common sense upon the negro question as well as upon any other." His speech, we are told, had a wonderful effect. The Hon. GREEN CLAY SMITH, also a member of Congress from Kentucky, delivered a speech the other day, at Lexington, in his own State, in which he not only took Anti-Slavery ground, but argued ably in favor of drafting negroes, slave as well as free, into the army, for the purpose of crushing out the slaveholder's rebellion. The Hon. LUCIEN ANDERSON, another Kentucky Congressman, takes essentially the same position, and gives it a practical enforcement.

abstract: Post-office Delivery of Letters
lead_paragraph: -- The Postmaster deserves credit for the success which has attended his efforts to amplify and perfect the arrangements for the house-delivery of letters in this City. Three prompt and correct daily deliveries is a vast improvement on the slow-coach and uncertain system of former years. And the people generally are learning to depend, as they do in nearly all the English and European cities, upon the regularity of the postman's calls, instead of chancing it at the wicket of the Post-office, and blocking up the way for the transaction of of thee proper business of the department.

abstract: Why Pemberton Surrendered on 4th July
lead_paragraph: We find the following in the Richmond Examiner: So far from Vicksburgh having been surrendered on account of a scarcity of supplies, it now appears officially that PEMBERTON had, at the time of the surrender, about 40,000 pounds of pork and bacon, which had been reserved for the subsistence of his troops in the event of his attempting to cut his way out of the city. Also, 51,241 pounds of rice, 5,000 bushels of peas, 112,234 pounds of sugar, 3,240 pounds of soap, 527 pounds of tallow candles, 27 pounds of star candles, and 428,000 pounds of salt. If curiosity insists upon knowing the real cause of the surrender of Vicksburgh, it must satisfy itself us well as it can with the words of Pemberton's own official report. He says:

abstract: Extirpation of Guerrillaism
lead_paragraph: The Lower Mississippi -- he one thousand miles of the river which the rebels claimed the control of, not a great while ago -- is now not only navigable, but is navigated by large numbers of commercial steamers. Boats with heavy freight and crowded with passengers are constantly passing to and fro between New-Orleans, Natchez, Vicksburgh, Memphis, etc; and from the last-named point diverge to St. Louis and Louisville, of course, safely as ever. In the long stretch of hostile country from the Delta up o Cairo, the rebel interruptions and eruptions, which were foreshadowed as something so terrible as well as effective, have never amounted to very much, since the fall of Vicksburgh, and of late months have hardly amounted to anything. Boats are rarely fired upon by guerrillas, and still more rarely damaged. We do not think that there have been two dozen commercial steamboats attacked since the opening of the year, although many hundreds have passed down and up. Traveling on the river is certainly, taking all things into account, not nearly as dangerous now-a-days as in the old times of high-pressure engines.

abstract: On this, the fourth day of April, one thousand eight hundred and sixty-four, is to be opened, in this City, the great Metropolitan Fair, in aid of the United States Sanitary Commission.
lead_paragraph: On this, the fourth day of April, one thousand eight hundred and sixty-four, is to be opened, in this City, the great Metropolitan Fair, in aid of the United States Sanitary Commission. According to the printed pamphlet issued by the committees, it is designed that this exhibition shall be "something much larger than a fair in the modern acceptation of the term;" and to judge by the amount of money contributed, the number and variety of goods to be exhibited and sold, the design will be much more than accomplished. The similar fair at Chicago realized $60,000; at Boston, $140,000; at Cincinnati, $250,000. At New-York, it is hoped there will be realized $1,250,000.

abstract: MARYLAND. -- Eight or nine regiments of slave blacks -- over eight thousand men in all -- have been raised for our army in Maryland. Some of these regiments have been sent down as far as South Carolina, and others will soon follow. These eight thousand men were nearly all slaves, and were enlisted voluntarily, mainly from the plantations. Very few of the free negroes of Maryland have entered the ranks. Our enlistments already must comprise three-fourths of the able-bodied slaves of the State. The remainder are enlisting as rapidly as they can find opportunity. The State Convention which meets day after to-morrow will doubtless adopt measures providing for the entire and speedy abolition of the Slavery institution. Such a step is advocated by Senator HICKS, Hon. WINTER DAVIS, the Baltimore American, and nearly all the prominent public men and journals of the State.
lead_paragraph: MARYLAND. -- Eight or nine regiments of slave blacks -- over eight thousand men in all -- have been raised for our army in Maryland. Some of these regiments have been sent down as far as South Carolina, and others will soon follow. These eight thousand men were nearly all slaves, and were enlisted voluntarily, mainly from the plantations. Very few of the free negroes of Maryland have entered the ranks. Our enlistments already must comprise three-fourths of the able-bodied slaves of the State. The remainder are enlisting as rapidly as they can find opportunity. The State Convention which meets day after to-morrow will doubtless adopt measures providing for the entire and speedy abolition of the Slavery institution. Such a step is advocated by Senator HICKS, Hon. WINTER DAVIS, the Baltimore American, and nearly all the prominent public men and journals of the State.

abstract: King LOUIS II, of Bavaria, has notified to his subjects his accession to the throne by a proclamation dated the 11th March, and countersigned by his Ministers. In this document the young King takes the title of King of Bavaria, Count Palatine of the Rhine, and Duke of Bavaria, Franconia, and Suabia.
lead_paragraph: King LOUIS II, of Bavaria, has notified to his subjects his accession to the throne by a proclamation dated the 11th March, and countersigned by his Ministers. In this document the young King takes the title of King of Bavaria, Count Palatine of the Rhine, and Duke of Bavaria, Franconia, and Suabia. He orders that all the functionaries of the kingdom should continue their functions until he may decide otherwise. Prince ADALBERT of Prussia, and Prince CHARLES of Hesse, have arrived at Munich, where the Archduke LOUIS VICTOR of Austria, and a deputation of Austrian cuirassiers, of whom the late King MAXIMILIAN was Colonel, were also expected to attend the funeral.

abstract: Government Officials, their Training, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Secretary SEWARD'S letter to the Chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance, on our Consular system, and the necessity for "Consular pupils," appointed by the Government, and trained to their duties, suggests some considerations with regard to the whole public service that are well worthy of attention. It appears that the want in our Consular service of respectable young men, specially selected for it, for the performance of its subordinate duties, leads to the appointment of foreign clerks, often men of little or no education, indifferent character, and without any responsibility to anybody but the Consul, who, in times past, has too often been very little better than they. One fact cited by Mr. SEWARD furnishes a good illustration of what this system may and often does lead to:

abstract: The past week was one of almost unexampled prosperity at the Academy of Music, and if the weather had not been unpropitious in the early part of it, Mr. MARETZEK would certainly be able to show the largest returns ever known at his prices in the Fourteenth-street establishment.
lead_paragraph: The past week was one of almost unexampled prosperity at the Academy of Music, and if the weather had not been unpropitious in the early part of it, Mr. MARETZEK would certainly be able to show the largest returns ever known at his prices in the Fourteenth-street establishment. The performance of "Robert le Diable" on Friday was witnessed by an audience that, in point of numbers, has hardly been surpassed. The same opera will be repeated to-night, and with better ensemble, we may safely conclude, than on the occasion previously referred to. These grand works require several performances before they run smoothly. To-morrow, "Faust" is to be given, and toward the end of the week "Ione" will be repeated for the last time. We are therefore to have a perfect gala week -- nothing but the largest and most important works of the modern grand opera repertoire. Our readers, under these circumstances, would do well to secure their seats in time, or they mind that an energetic and eager crowd has seized the golden opportunity, and that even standroom will be denied to them, as on Friday evening.

abstract: Wishes Union National Convention Postponed
lead_paragraph: We hear from Washington that a tremendous "pressure" is brought to bear upon the Union National Committee, to induce them to postpone the National Convention for nominating a Union Presidential candidate. We observe, also, in sundry newspapers, urgent appeals to the same effect, which are probably part of the machinery of the "pressure" referred to. The time for meeting this year is the 7th of June -- considerably later, we believe, than these conventions have been usually held. In 1860 the Chicago Convention met on the 15th of May, without objection from any quarter that it was too early.

abstract: The best of the reviews in England and this country, are very warm in favor of this volume -- "Dreamthorp." English reviewers rank it with GOLDSMITH's "Deserted Village" and "Vicar of Wakefield." -- Boston Transcript.

abstract: The steamers Matanzas, from New-Orleans March 25, and the Columbia, from same port, March 26, arrived at this port yesterday. There was little additional news. The army was still advancing, but more slowly than it had been, because it was getting farther away from its supplies.
lead_paragraph: The steamers Matanzas, from New-Orleans March 25, and the Columbia, from same port, March 26, arrived at this port yesterday. There was little additional news. The army was still advancing, but more slowly than it had been, because it was getting farther away from its supplies. The troops sent by Gen. BANKS to form a junction with Gen. SMITH's forces, had reached Alexandria on the 14th of March, having made the unparalleled march of one hundred and seventy miles in five days. A steamer had arrived at New-Orleans from the Red River, bringing twenty-eight rebel officers, captured in the fight at Bayou Rapides. Among them was Gen. DICK TAYLOR's Chief-of-Staff.

abstract: Sanitary Fair; Programme of Arrangements
lead_paragraph: The building erected at the north end of Unionsquare rapidly approaches completion. Carpenters, painters, gilders, decorators, masons, plumbers, ar tisans of all sorts, work like beavers from 3 in the morning until 12 at night; but the heavy rains have interfered so much with the progress of the work, that this department of the great fair will not be opened until Tuesday morning. The building consists of two wings, one on Broadway, the other on Fourth-avenue, each 90 feet by 90, connected by a low centre on Seventeenth-street, 156 feet in length; the whole facing south, with entrances and ticket offices in the wings on Broadway and Fourth-avenue. The lower windows are glazed; the upper ones are fitted with frames covered with canvas, upon which it is intended to paint various ornamental designs. The Fourth-avenue wing will be devoted to the Children's Department, and is fitted up with a stage at the rear end. Adjoining this wing is the Music Room; in the centre, the Knickerbocker Kitchen, and in the Broadway wing are the International and Floral Departments. A profusion of gas jets, arranged in various fanciful forms, will illuminate the rooms at night in the most brilliant manner.

abstract: In the House Saturday, Mr. PENDLETON, of Ohio, called up his motion to reconsider the vote by which the House disagreed to the Senate's amendment to the Montano Territory Bill, and asking a committee of conference. He argued that the Senate's amendment striking out "white," was to give "negroes" the right to vote in the Territory. Mr. PENDLETON's resolution was tabled. The House then resumed the consideration of the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad Bill. Mr. SWEAT, of Maine, spoke against the bill, believing it had no warrant in the Constitution of the United States or laws of the country.

lead_paragraph: We have called attention before to the clear and conclusive arguments of a distinguished publicist of Boston, Hon. C.G. LORING, on questions at issue between England and America. Nothing more able in the recent discussions upon international law has appeared, in our judgment, on this side of the Atlantic. Mr. LORING, in a new pamphlet upon the important question of "England's Liability for Indemnity," discusses especially the letters which have appeared from "Historicus" in the London Times, upon this subject. The position of "Historicus," it should be remembered, was the following, as appears in Mr. LORING's clear analysis:

abstract: Alleged Conspiracy--Dr. Breckinridge's Speech
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. BRECKINRIDGE, who probably knows Kentucky as well as any other man in it, in his recent speech at Danville, declared that there had lately been a scheme for "an emeute of the Kentucky troops, in consequence of WALFORD's arrest, and a general rising in the State, strengthened by a cotemporaneous invasion by a portion of the rebel army." He asseverated that "the proof of such a conspiracy was overwhelmingly strong." Its failure he attributed to the patriotic proclamation of Gov. BRAMLETTE.

abstract: Memphis dates of the 1st inst. state that Gen. CHALMERS, with a rebel force of 2,500, was at Grand Junction, Tenn., on the 29th ult., and that Gen. FORREST was at Trenton when last heard from. It is reported that the Sixth Tennessee Cavalry, Col. MARSH, about 600 strong, had a fight near Somerville, Tenn., on the 30th ult., with about 1,500 rebel cavalry, supposed to be part of Gen. MCCULLOUGH's command. Our forces, after fighting three or four hours, and finding themselves largely outnumbered, fell back, leaving fifty or sixty killed and wounded in the hands of the rebels.
