abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, offered a resolution to the effect that the Committee on Foreign Relations be instructed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the neutrality laws as to make them reciprocal to each Government, extending entire neutrality to those which return the same, and to others the exact measure of neutrality which they extend to us. The resolution was agreed to. Mr. SUMNER reported a bill to establish a bureau of emancipation, which was ordered to be printed. The Vice-President laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of War, denying that any order had been given by Gen. DIX to the Provost-Marshal of Baltimore in November, 1861, prior to the November election. Mr. SUMNER reported a bill for the satisfaction of spoliations committed by the French prior to 1801. It authorizes the expenditure by Commissioners of five millions of dollars. The bill providing that any loyal State may recruit in a rebellious State and receive credit on its own quota for men so recruited, was taken up and discussed, but no progress was made. The joint resolution for an Anti-Slavery amendment to the Constitution was taken up, and Mr. HOWE spoke at length, when the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, offered a resolution to the effect that the Committee on Foreign Relations be instructed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the neutrality laws as to make them reciprocal to each Government, extending entire neutrality to those which return the same, and to others the exact measure of neutrality which they extend to us. The resolution was agreed to. Mr. SUMNER reported a bill to establish a bureau of emancipation, which was ordered to be printed. The Vice-President laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of War, denying that any order had been given by Gen. DIX to the Provost-Marshal of Baltimore in November, 1861, prior to the November election. Mr. SUMNER reported a bill for the satisfaction of spoliations committed by the French prior to 1801. It authorizes the expenditure by Commissioners of five millions of dollars. The bill providing that any loyal State may recruit in a rebellious State and receive credit on its own quota for men so recruited, was taken up and discussed, but no progress was made. The joint resolution for an Anti-Slavery amendment to the Constitution was taken up, and Mr. HOWE spoke at length, when the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Sanitary Fair; Opening Ceremonies
lead_paragraph: A memorable day was yesterday in the history of the City and of the country. Parades, pageants, holidays have been witnessed and enjoyed, but here never one of either like unto this. Anniversaries have been observed, heroes honored, princes and potentates acclaimed, great public events commemorated, but when before did one million of people, old and young, all sexes, ages and conditions, unite heart and hand in an ovation to CHARITY, and with one record say "God-speed" to her divine mission! Thus was it yesterday. The people came from their counting-rooms, their stores, their factories, workshops and dwellings, and the Great Heart of New-York beat warmly and encouragingly toward a purpose consecrated by humanity and patriotism to the sick and suffering soldier. Although the suggestion that the day should be a holiday was made but on Sunday, it was eagerly accepted and promptly observed. All public offices were closed, and at noon there was a general cessation of business. Early in the morning the City had put on her holiday attire. Flags waved from every building where there was a flag to wave, and the shipping in the harbor were gaily decked. The day was beautiful, auspiciously so, and when the time for the moving of the military approached, the streets and buildings along the route were packed with spectators, while the City Hall Park was the centre for the assembling of thousands.

abstract: In view of the appointment of this officer, by Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, as the successor of Major-Gen. PLEASANTON, in command of the Cavalry Corps of the Army of the Potomac, we propose to respond to the desire of the public to learn something of his antecedents, by giving in our columns a brief sketch of his history. In the old Army of the Mississippi and the gallant Army of the Cumberland, Gen. SHERIDAN has a most enviable reputation as a brave and skillful leader, both of infantry and cavalry. At the East his name and services are less familiar, and many people seem to have been taken by surprise by the selection of an officer, to them, so apparently unknown as Gen. SHERIDAN, for a most important command in connection with the Army of the Potomac, on whose success depends, in a great measure, the final triumph of the national cause.

abstract: Philadelphia, Margaret Baer shot in box of Theatre by Maguire
snippet: Philadelphia, Margaret Baer shot in box of Theatre by Maguire
lead_paragraph: -- MARGARET BAER, reputed to be a young and handsome German woman, was shot on Saturday evening, while sitting in a private box at the Continental Theatre, by WILLIAM MAGUIRE, a young man known to many as William Howard Mitchell, from Wilmington, Del. The parties had been acquainted for some months, and MAGUIRE had, it is said, manifested considerable fondness for her. They had met often at a drinking saloon, corner of Chesnut-street and Hudson's alley, called the Red Robin Saloon, and they had been together so often to the Continental Theatre as to be well-known to the frequenters of that house. Lately she had rather avoided him, and this had caused him to make threats to take her life. On Saturday they met at the Red Robin Saloon, but nothing occurred there to induce the belief that he intended to carry his threats so soon into execution. He drank freely and passed the time at card playing. After dark he went to the Continental Theatre, where she was seated in a private box. He was observed to be excited, and to the officer of the house he remarked that he was going to New-York, and bade him good bye, saying he would not see him again. To his request to go to the back part of the theatre the officer objected, but he was finally permitted to go. He went directly to the private box in which MARGARET BAER was sitting, and going toward her in an excited manner, said, loud enough to be heard by all in the box, "MAGGIE, are you going to do what I asked you?" She made no reply, and he repeated it. A companion sitting at her side said, "Say yes, for if you don't it may cost you your life," and she then replied "Yes." In the meantime, however, MAGUIRE had drawn a revolving pistol from his pocket and commenced to fire. There were three discharges of the weapon in rapid succession, and it snapped at the fourth attempt. Three bails entered her body, two proving fatal wounds, the third a slight one. One ball passed through the brain, and one through the lungs and aorta -- the latter causing death almost instantaneously. MAGUIRE gave himself up at once, saying that he had loved her and was ready to die for her. He was removed to the Central Station, where he many times repeated the remark that he loved her and was ready to die for her. Coroner TAYLOR held an inquest on the body yesterday, when the above facts were disclosed by persons who were acquainted with the prisoner and deceased, some of whom were in the theatre when the shooting took place.

abstract: The steamships Hecla, City of London and Teutonia arrived at this port yesterday, with news to March 24 -- and the Hibernian was telegraphed from Portland, with advices to the 25th. The news is interesting, though not especially important. The pirate Florida was at Santa Cruz, Teneriffe, March 4, and coaled and left on the 5th. The United States sloop-of-war St. Louis arrived in pursuit on the 6th. A decision had been made in the Pampero case, which sends it to trial on its merits, and refuses the motion for an appeal to the House of Lords. Four new and very swift blockade runners were on the point of leaving Liverpool to engage in the nefarious business. The Emperor MAXIMILIAN would embark for Mexico on the 13th of April. It was rumored that a line of policy, embracing entire neutrality as regards American affairs, had been agreed upon between NAPOLEON and MAXIMILIAN. A new Mexican loan of $25,000,000 had been placed in London at 6 cent. interest. Rumors prevailed that Denmark had accepted the proposal for a conference, on the basis of the treaty of 1851, without an armistice. A telegram from Vienna states that the proposal had been accepted by Austria and Prussia. At the latest advices the siege of Fredericia had been abandoned, but the bombardment of Duppel continued. GARIBALDI had embarked from Caprera on the 22d of March, and was expected at Southampton shortly. In the elections in the fourth and fifth Conscriptions of Paris, the Opposition candidates were chosen by large majorities. The health of the Pope was said to be improving.

abstract: Repudiation and Rebel Currency
lead_paragraph: The Southern press is quite jubilant over the result of the late rebel financial operation, by which all holders of Government notes, over a certain value, have been compelled to convert them into four per cent. bonds, on pain of forfeiting a third of its value, on the 1st of April, and the entire value on the 1st of January, 1865. Under the gentle pressure thus applied, of course, the greater portion of what of it there is in the country has been funded; whilst some hundreds of millions, (there are $700,000,000 of it in all,) which are at the North or abroad, and cannot get back in time, will be a dead loss to the owners, although, we need hardly say, no more a loss than if they had been at home, and secured their bonds for it. The consequence is that prices are tumbling all over the Confederacy. There being less paper in existence, of course, less paper is required in payment for goods, and the Richmond editors chuckle over the phenomenon with barbarian simplicity, evidently looking on it as just as valuable as if it had been brought about either by the redemption of the Government paper in specie, or the voluntary purchase of its bonds by the holders of its notes.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was introduced appropriating $5,000,000 for enlarging the locks of the Erie and Oswego Canals to gunboat capacity. The concurrent resolution to proceed to the election of two Regents of the University on the 12th inst. was adopted.

abstract: Smiles, Samuel. Industrial Biography; Kirkland, Mrs. C. M. School-girls' Garland; Furness, Rev. W. H. The Veil Partly Lifted; Biography of; Lee Holme; Annie Warleigh's Fortunes
snippet: Smiles, Samuel. Industrial Biography; Kirkland, Mrs. C. M. School-girls' Garland; Furness, Rev. W. H. The Veil Partly Lifted; Biography of; Lee Holme; Annie Warleigh's Fortunes
lead_paragraph: Any new book of Mr. SMILES as scarcely needs critical recommendation to insure its meeting with thousands of readers. The happy discernment that led him to select a class of subjects strangely neglected until his day, is only equaled by the felicitous treatment that makes the annals of mechanical inventions, and the struggles and sufferings of their originators, in his hands, hardly second in interest to the exciting scenes of fictitious romance. He has put on record in one of his works the doubts entertained by men, the most thoroughly acquainted with mechanics and engineering, as to the possibility of making them the themes of books that should command the attention of the public, but these doubts were finally and effectually solved by the production of the series of works that includes the present volume of Industrial Biography. It is an off-shoot, or continuation of Mr. SMILES' Lives of the Engineers, his most important contribution to industrial history, but not yet (we regret to say) reprinted in this country. While engaged in the preparation of that work -- Iron -- the material that enabled his heroes to carry out their vast conceptions, and its workers -- the men who founded the modern industry of Great Britain -- were always before him, and their tracks were constantly crossing the field of view embraced in his general survey. He has consequently chosen, as the subject of a separate volume, the history of the production of that metal in England, with biographical sketches of the most eminent men connected with the progressive improvements of its manufacture. Starting with the aboriginal stone age in Britain, he traces the first appearance of metallic arms and implements, shows the close connection existing between the use of iron and civilization, and accounts for the curious fact that the most useful and indispensable of the metals should be the last to come into general use. All through the middle ages the importance of a supply of iron in war, was daily felt, and became still more essential after the discovery of artillery. What little is known of the mediaeval history of the manufacture is well related by Mr. SMILES; but it was not until near the commonwealth period that the records of individual discovery are preserved, which add a biographical interest to the historic detail. The eventful and romantic history of "Dud Dudley," the first man who attempted to smelt iron ore with pit coal, and thereby laid the foundation of England's future greatness in the manufacture, when the gradual scarcity of wood and charcoal threatened its extinction, will be new to most readers. His name is the first of a long series, occurring from the year 1600 to the well-known living ones of MUSKET, HEATH and BESSEMER, all of whom are identified with processes of the utmost importance in cheapening the cost, and, consequently extending the use of metal as an industrial agent. The second portion of the work deals with the well-known names of BRAMAH, MANDSLAY, FAIRBAIRN, NASMYTH, and others of equal eminence. The details of the careers of these self-made men are derived from original sources, and have never before been published; in fact, Mr. SMILES was fortunate in commencing his work while the memory of these men is yet cherished by their pupils and successors, and thus preserving to future generations facts so full of encouragement and instruction to their fellow workers of every age and clime. Mr. SMILES' books present to us the real essence of history -- compared to which the story of Kings and battles is a mere external plating on the surface of society that only distracts attention from what underlies it -- the actual life of the people and all that constitutes true human progress.

abstract: -The Copperheads will doubtless be very jubilant over the State election in Connecticut yesterday. For they will learn that their candidate for Governor was defeated by but about ten thousand majority; that they elected no less than three out of twenty-one members of the State Senate, not to speak of several members of the Assembly. If the Copperheads of Connecticut have achieved such astounding results this time, why should they not sweep the State at the elections in the Fall?
lead_paragraph: -The Copperheads will doubtless be very jubilant over the State election in Connecticut yesterday. abstract: A letter dated Fuh Chau, China, Jan. 22, which we find published in the Times of India, gives an account of some serious difficulties which had just occurred in that city. The trouble originated in the natives making noisy demonstrations against the missionaries by interrupting the religious services. Some of those guilty of these outrages were arrested at the instance of the missionaries, and the natives, excited at this action, attacked a native missionary, and maltreated him outrageously. Afterward they attacked the chapel of the Methodist Mission, then that of the Episcopal Mission, and afterward that of the American Board. No injury seems to have been done to the persons of the foreign missionaries, although the wives of the native missionaries were outraged.
lead_paragraph: A letter dated Fuh Chau, China, Jan. 22, which we find published in the Times of India, gives an account of some serious difficulties which had just occurred in that city. abstract: -The Metropolitan Fair which opened last evening, was an immense success -- such a success as can be achieved only in the City of New-York. It was a success as regards the display, which was truly magnificent, and as regards the receipts, which were sublime. It was a success as regards the numbers present, which were as great as possible, and as regards the management and arrangements, which were nearly perfect. The brilliant display of dresses and diamonds was as grand as any other department of the fair. The buildings are a success, and each of the departments is a success that can only find its parallel in the others. The visitors on the opening night were almost entirely from the City, as was proper and to be expected; but we anticipate that our country cousins, will to-day and henceforth make their appearance in their natural charms and in gorgeous array. New-York never does anything by halves, but she will do the Fair in a style that will astonish the natives.

abstract: By a purposed omission of the members of the Common Conncil to attend the meeting yesterday, neither Board had a quorum. The Board of Councilmen stand adjourned by rule to Thursday, at 2 o'clock P.M., and the Board of Aldermen are adjourned without day. The failure to meet was designed in order to contribute to the general observance of the day as a holiday, in commemoration of the opening of the Metropolitan Fair, and to enable the members of the two boards to participate in the ceremonies attending the opening. Actuated by the same patriotic motives, the heads of the several City Departments closed their doors and suspended all business for the day at noon.

abstract: Pres. Lopez's Intended Empire
lead_paragraph: -We shall probably have a large crop of Emperors on the American continent, if MAXIMILIAN gets himself firmly enthroned in Mexico. It seems that in South America, in the Republic of Paraguay, one is about to be added to the stock. Our correspondent at Buenos Ayres writes that President LOPEZ will soon proclaim the Empire. The crown and purple intended for his coronation as Emperor of Paraguay have arrived in Buenos Ayres, and the ceremony, we are informed, is speedily to come off. The scandalous story is told that the robe and crown are the same articles as were used in the coronation of the negro Emperor of Hayti, FAUSTIN I., now an exile in Jamaica, and whose wife is said to take in washing. It will be remembered that FAUSTIN was crowned a dozen years ago with great pomp, imitating on the occasion the ceremonial at the coronation of NAPOLEON I.; and as the Emperor LOPEZ is to wear his old garb, we suppose he will also follow his style.

abstract: London Times; Prospects of the War--Future Peace Party; Pampero Case, Decision at Edinburgh Court of Sessions
snippet: London Times; Prospects of the War--Future Peace Party; Pampero Case, Decision at Edinburgh Court of Sessions
lead_paragraph: The Times reviews the present aspects of the war, declares that "its importance has in no degree declined," but that "if any point of the case is clearer than it was two years ago, it is this -- that the contest will be a long one, and that the end is as yet not so much as foreshadowed." It then reviews the progress that our arms have made, and says that our successes "are gratifying to the feelings of the North, and they enable Mr. SEWARD to expatiate with complacency in his diplomatic circulars on the ubiquitous presence of the Union flag. But they have effected very little toward the subjugation of the South, or the termination of the war."

abstract: -- A MAN FOUND DEAD IN AN ALLEY-WAY. -- Yesterday morning a man named JOHN DUPY, who resided at No. 36 Cherry-street, was found lying dead in an alley-way adjoining the premises, under circumstances that excited suspicions of foul play. The body was taken to the Fourth Precinct Station, and the Coroner notified. A partial examination was made, when it was discovered that his skull had been very much fractured, but whether it was caused by violence or by a fall has not been ascertained. An inquest will be held to-day, when it is believed the case will be more fully explained.

abstract: Niagara, Steamship;Perilous Voyage of
lead_paragraph: The United States steam frigate Niagara returned on Sunday, having left this port March 18, to go in search of the Italian frigate Re Galantuomo, and has therefore been absent fifteen days. The Niagara has experienced very severe weather the whole time. On Wednesday, 23d, in latitude 40 45' north, longitude 33 27' west, her situation was appalling. The whole of the day was exceedingly rough; a severe rain-storm and a heavy gale. About 11 P.M., the storm increased, and the gale assumed still greater violence; the waves were mountains high, the ship rolled franticly and labored heavily. In the middle watch, the scene on this vessel beggars description; cutlasses, mess-chests, muskets, and, in fact, every movable thing were tossing about the decks promiscuously, and it required much courage to pass from one part of the ship to the other. At 1 1/2 A.M., her situation was so critical that the officers deemed it necessary to call all hands. At this time, the vessel was shipping heavy seas, and the main deck had some four feet of water upon it. This immense body of water would roll from side to side, carrying all with it; it had washed the ashes in the bilges, which rendered the pumps useless, and all momentarily expected it would extinguish the fires; two of her boats, the third and sixth cutters, were torn from their davits and carried away by the angry sea; for a while, her situation seemed utterly hopeless; at each roll of the ship her lower yard-arms dipped the water. But even more was to be endured, as two of the guns were broken adrift by the great violence of the winds and water, were rolling about the deck, and all were fearful of being crushed; great apprehensions were felt lest they would break down the engine hatch, and be precipitated upon the engine. At the risk of their lives, some noble fellows succeeded in lashing the guns fast; the gun-carriages were mashed to pieces. After hours of danger and suffering, and by the energetic and untiring exertions of both officers and crew, the hatches were battened down, the ship rid of much water, all hands made sail, and the Niagara safely rode the storm, but with a great amount of damage to the vessel. About daylight on the morning of the 24th, one watch was relieved, and the fury of the storm was somewhat abated. On the succeeding morning, the topgallant masts, maintopsail sheet and main-trysail were carried away. On the night of the 28th, in lat. 42, lon. 53, the Niagara again experienced a severe storm of hail, rain and sleet, and an intensely violent gale, and but for having a fair wind it would have been more terrible than the one above described; the vessel shipped heavy seas over her gangways, and the violence of the waves were such that some of her ports were stove in; nearly all her sails were literally torn in shreds, and flying at the mercy of the winds; at this time the vessel had all canvas spread, was running before the wind, which as it sent the info to New-York made all hands feel cheerful. On the morning of the 20th the Niagara presented a sorry picture on deck. On the 30th every one on board was pleased to see the sunshine, the first since the ship left port. On the days succeeding the trying scenes described the Chaplain summoned all hands to render thanks for their safe delivery from the very jaws of death; this was indeed a solemn time; the officers, the hardy sons of Neptune, young and old, all devoutly united in gratitute to the Almighty for His merciful protection while the storm-king reigned with such fearfulness. Indeed it seems almost a miracle that this ship has returned, or that one lives to tell the tale. The terrible scenes through which she and her noble crew have passed cannot be adequately described. All honor to the noble fellows who, while upon an errand of mercy, have so bravely encountered perils, and so miraculously escaped.

abstract: Method of Receiving
lead_paragraph: -The method by which the soldiers' vote shall be sent from the field, and deposited in the ballot-box at his home, proves a puzzle to our Legislature. A bill has been reported by a select committee, which provides that the ballots shall be enclosed in envelopes marked on the outside "Soldier's Vote," and that such envelopes may be sent by mail to the inspectors of election, in the district where the soldier resides, any time within sixty days before an election. This proposition seems very much like offering a chance to corruption. Why should the soldiers' vote be thus advertised, or exposed to such risk from mail carriers, Post-office officials, or election inspectors? Would he be willing to thus hazard his money? Certainly not; he would demand it as his right to send it to a friend whom he could trust, if he wished to deposit it in bank, and the Legislature could not deprive him of this right. Is a citizen's vote of less value than money, or is it less his own or less under his control? It strikes us that our legislators need to remember that it is his (the soldier's) vote, and not their own, that they are dealing with.
headline: {'main': "THE SOLDIERS' VOTE", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "THE SOLDIERS' VOTE", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Advices from Alexandria to the 27th ult. say that the main body of Gen. FRANKLIN'S army arrived there the day before, meeting no opposition. The country through which it passed was deserted by whites and male blacks, they having gone to Texas. The indications are that Gen. BANKS' army will remain there some time.

abstract: the
lead_paragraph: The Connecticut election bas resulted in a magnificent triumph for the Union cause and the Administration. It is a clear, distinct verdict in favor of the general course which has been pursued in putting down the rebellion. Less effort was put forth on both sides than for many years past. All parties seemed disposed to leave the people for once to the free, unbiased exercise of their own judgments. The press was active in its discussions, -- a good many public meetings were held and addresses made: but there was far less of the bustle and stir of an active political canvass than usual. Yet the State gives a larger majority for the Administration than it has given for many years to any political party. The majority for BUCKINGHAM will exceed 8,000. Last year the Republicans considered themselves lucky to carry the State by 1,500.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. ANTHONY submitted an amendment, intended to be proposed to the bill for the relief of the Justices of the Supreme Courts and District Courts at the age of seventy, if they desire it, giving Justices of the Supreme Court $4,000 to $6,000, according to the length of their official service, and three-fourths of their salaries to Justices of the District Courts, provided such salaries shall not be less than $2,000 each, in cases where the service has exceeded fifteen years. The Anti-Slavery Constitutional Amendment came up in regular order, and Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, spoke at length and with much force in faver of the amendment. Mr. SAULSBURY obtained the floor, and the Senate then adjourned.

abstract: A Popular Establishment. -- We have before aluded to the success which has attended the enterprise of Mr. J.T. Ellis, in establishing, at Nos. 937 and 939 Broadway, a great central emporium for the sale of Wheeler & Wilson's celebrated Sewing-machines. The fact that the proprietor exhibits so much liberality toward the poor working-women of the metropolis, in enabling them to supply themselves with sewing-machines on the most easy terms, commends his enterprise to the support and patronage of the public at large. We are always ready to commend and encourage such laudable and deserving enterprise. -- Sunday Mercury.

abstract: U. S. Congress--Anti-Maximilian Declaration
lead_paragraph: The unanimous declaration of the popular branch of Congress that the United States will not assent to any monarchical Government in Mexico, erected under the auspices of any European Power, is but the expression of the universal feeling of the people. We are glad the resolution was couched in the simplest form -- that it was kept entirely free from the high-flown rhetoric which usually overlays such Congressional manifestoes, as if there were something imposing in the mere accumulation of words. A fixed purpose, in common life, always announces itself in brief terms. A man who is really determined not to submit to a wrong act never declaims. The more in earnest he is, the briefer he is apt to be. There is no reason why public deliverances should not follow the same natural method. It may not, in fact it would not, tell quite as forcibly in the way of buncombe, but so much the better. The prime motive of such a declaration is that it is meant for the calm consideration of statesmen abroad, and not for domestic buncombe. If it carried on its face that it was prompted by the latter, it would neither receive nor deserve respect. The conciseness and simplicity of that resolution, though not agreeable to such flamboyant Democrats as Mr. COX, will only give it consequence abroad.

abstract: Depot, House Refusal of, Exploring Committee
snippet: Depot, House Refusal of, Exploring Committee
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that the House of Representatives has laid on the table a request from the Naval Committee for leave of absence to explore the Mississippi River, in order to discover a proper site for a naval depot. The members of Congress are wanted just now in Washington. They have business of importance which should keep them there. Besides, these explorations of traveling committees rarely result in any important discoveries. The members seldom come back any wiser than when they went away, at least on the ostensible subject of their inquiries. These expeditions are usually little more than protracted sprees, in which the business in hand plays a very subordinate and unimportant part. If they really want trustworthy information, in order to guide their action, they would do well to send some person familiar, from actual experience, with the requirements of the service, entirely disinterested in the decision of the question, and who will act upon his own judgment, and not upon the representations of interested parties. One such man, who will give the requisite time and study to the matter, is worth all the committees in Congress.

abstract: Soon after 12 o'clock, yesterday, a fire was discovered on the first floor of the five-story brick building No. 73 Robinson-street. These premises, and also No. 71, on the same street, were occupied as a distillery by Messrs. J.C. DAYTON & CO. Owing to the combustible nature of the material -- spirits, whisky and other liquors -- the entire establishment and contents were destroyed in a very short time after. No. 69, which was mostly unoccupied, was also destroyed as to the woodwork and the internal structure.

abstract: On a "Faust" night there is nothing to do except to repeat the stereotyped statements that the house was filled with an exceedingly brilliant audience, and that the performance went off well. The Sanitary Fair, so far, has not had its anticipated effect on the various places of amusement. Why should it?
lead_paragraph: On a "Faust" night there is nothing to do except to repeat the stereotyped statements that the house was filled with an exceedingly brilliant audience, and that the performance went off well. The Sanitary Fair, so far, has not had its anticipated effect on the various places of amusement. Why should it? With our limited supply of theatres and unlimited population to go to them, it would be strange indeed if our meritorious and glorious undertaking were by its deserved popularity to work such dire mischief and confusion. This might happen in a small town, but it is barely possible in a city of New-York's proportions. Indeed, it is more reasonable to expect that the Fair -- by bringing many thousands to the Metropolis who might not otherwise visit it at this season -- will in the end be of great advantage to all places of popular resort. No one will miss so favorable an opportunity of visiting the principal lyric establishment of the New World, especially at this moment, when the the best operas only are being performed, and performed, too, by a company that has not been equaled for many years. With such houses as Mr. MARETZEK has had for the past week, the season can be extended far into the merry and moving month of May.

abstract: In the senate, yesterday, Mr. LAIMBEER presented a petition from Mayor GUNTHER, asking that the petitions of the Taxpayers' Association be granted. Among the reports made was one against granting Laight-street Pier, New-York, to the marketmen. Agreed to. And another providing for the sale of Quarantine lands.
lead_paragraph: In the senate, yesterday, Mr. LAIMBEER presented a petition from Mayor GUNTHER, asking that the petitions of the Taxpayers' Association be granted. Among the reports made was one against granting Laight-street Pier, New-York, to the marketmen. Agreed to. And another providing for the sale of Quarantine lands. Bills were introduced to repeal the two per cent. per mile passenger fare restriction on the Central Railroad, and to amend the General Gas-light Law, by providing that all gas-light companies shall furnish metres and supply service-pipes from the mains to the buildings free of expense; also that the bonds of a any gas company may be converted into its stock. The bill for the State monument at Gettysburgh was reported favorably. The bill incorporating the Corn Exchange Warehouse and Security Company was ordered to a third reading.

abstract: Major, to Legislature on Tax Levy
snippet: Major, to Legislature on Tax Levy
lead_paragraph: His Honor, Mayor GUNTHER, has addressed the following communication to the Legislature, relative to the Tax Levy. It deserves their serious attention, for three millions of dollars, which it proposes to save, to a sum too stupendous for them to saddle upon our citizens unnecessarily. Mayor GUNTHER'S proposition is a frank one, based on the knowledge that it can be sustained, and on facts which the Legislature, are doubtless ere this made fully aware of.

abstract: Thirteen thousand four hundred and eighty-seven people visited the Metropolitan Fair yesterday, and forty-three thousand dollars were taken at the door for tickets alone. On Monday night the buildings were crowded; yesterday they were jammed. Monday night individuals had a chance of moving around by their own powers of propulsion -- yesterday visitors had the privilege of being carried around in mass. The price of admission yesterday was a dollar, and it will be the same to-day; but to-morrow it will be reduced to fifty cents, so that twice the number of yesterday's visitors will have to be gotten in to make the receipts equal. How this is to be done will be one of the most interesting sights of the fair, and we advise everybody to be there to see. By the way, we would inform Boston that the 13,487 individuals at the fair yesterday were not by any means, all policemen. On the contrary, there were but one hundred and one (101) knights of the locust present, all told, and these were not counted in.

abstract: The interest in the great Fair increases; early yesterday morning long lines of carriages filled Fourteenth-street from Sixth to Seventh-avenue, and the number of persons seeking to gain admission was even greater than on the opening day. At 10 o'clock the doors were opened, and before 11 the halls were filled to their utmost capacity, the greater portion of the immense assemblage being composed of ladies.
lead_paragraph: The interest in the great Fair increases; early yesterday morning long lines of carriages filled Fourteenth-street from Sixth to Seventh-avenue, and the number of persons seeking to gain admission was even greater than on the opening day. At 10 o'clock the doors were opened, and before 11 the halls were filled to their utmost capacity, the greater portion of the immense assemblage being composed of ladies. Owing to the excellent arrangement for the sale of tickets there was no confusion, and everything moved in a very orderly and systematic manner. The various departments were all very well filled. The Art Gallery was one of the great features, and was continually filled with an admiring crowd. The Department of Arms and Trophies, and the Indian Department, were also great points of attraction. In the latter several performances were given during the day and evening, at each of which the room was so crowded as to leave not even standing room. The Indians appear in their full Indian dress, and are ornamented and painted the same as when living in their forest homes. The ladies and children particularly viewed this scene with great interest, giving them, as it does, so good an idea of the habits and customs of the original owners and inhabitants of this land. The sword surrendered by Gen. BURGOYNE to Gen. GATES at the battle of Saratoga, in 1777, and an autograph letter of Gen. LYON, both of which are exhibited in the department of arms and trophies, received much notice. The machinery department is not yet complete, but one or two machines are in operation; they, however, are very perfect, some of them very novel in their construction, and are both instructing and interesting. The Roman department is not yet ready, the goods not having arrived; they are, however, expected daily. The Fire Department continues to be one of the great points of attraction. The goods here exhibited are very handsome and in great variety.

abstract: Boston is mad about the great Metropolitan Sanitary Fair. We expected it. For what sort of an affair was the Boston Fair when compared with ours? No sort of an affair at all. The Boston Advertiser has been studying up the accounts of the great Fair published in the New-York papers on the day of its opening, and declares that it has "formed the opinion that there will be quite a large display of policemen, flowers, scissors, chicken salad and other things." Now, why this cruel fun? Is it because Boston policemen, Boston flowers, Boston scissors and Boston chicken salad are so much inferior to Metropolitan policemen, flowers, scissors and chicken salad? If so, we are sorry for Boston, for, though we might give it some of our spare scissors and salad, we cannot part with our policemen or other flowers.

abstract: Why do not the City authorities take up the posts and clear away the other obstructions that disfigure and encumber the City Hall Park? They might, with a very little care and expense, make it a very serviceable plaza, instead of the useless nuisance that it is now. Its day as an ornamental park has gone. Grass will never again grow on it. But if the trees were removed and the whole area flagged, or kept hard and smooth, like the Place de la Concorde in Paris, it would make a most admirable place for reviews and military displays generally.

abstract: Some wag nominated the "O.P.F." for Constable of Lancaster Township, at the recent election. But the ex-President obtained only a small vote from his neighbors for that responsible office.
lead_paragraph: Some wag nominated the "O.P.F." for Constable of Lancaster Township, at the recent election. But the ex-President obtained only a small vote from his neighbors for that responsible office. The ballot resulted as follows: HERNEY, Republican, 67; BUCHANAN, Anti-Coercionist, 19; MANCHIE, Moderate Copperhead, 7.

abstract: An official document dated at the "Imperial Palace at Mexico, Department of Foreign Affairs, March 4, 1864," states that the Regency of the Empire having been informed that certain persons coming from ports on the Pacific have taken possession of lands in Mexico, under contracts made with President JUAREZ, announces that "all such contracts are void and of no effect."

abstract: Lecture in Reply to Miss Dickenson
snippet: Lecture in Reply to Miss Dickenson
lead_paragraph: Miss EMMA WEBB, who will, perhaps, be better recognized as one of the Webb Sisters, of east-side theatre celebrity, delivered a lecture last evening at Cooper Institute, in answer to Miss ANNA E. DICKINSON'S "Lessons of the Hour." The audience was small, numbering not over four hundred. Promptly at 8 o'clock, however, Miss WEBB was introduced by Mr. THEO MARHINE, and commenced her lecture. Although a woman, she had been studying politics; she had been forced into the study by this cruel and fratricidal war. She was interested only in that she had friends on both sides; but she felt it her mission to show that our armies and the armies of the enemy marched, not only over the graves of brave men, but over the hearts of the widow and orphan. Was not such a war a curse? The ancients, threw captured works of art into the Tiber -- were we not doing worse?

abstract: The interest in the great fair seems to be steadily increasing. Early yesterday morning, the crowd commenced to assemble, and long before the hour for opening the doors the street was filled with an eager assemblage, waiting impatiently for admission. At 11 o'clock the doors were opened, and in an hour from that time the building was well filled, and by 3 o'clock the halls were completely jammed.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. CONNESS presented the joint resolutions of the California Legislature, indorsing the policy of President LINCOLN. Mr. GRIMES presented a bill repealing the joint resolution authorizing the transfer of men from the army into the navy, which, after debate, was referred to the Naval Committee. The AntiSlavery amendment to the Constitution was then taken up, and advocated by Messrs. HARLAN, HALE and TRUMBULL, and opposed by Messgr. SAULSBURY, DAVIS, MCDOUGALL and POWELL. After the rejection of sundry proposed amendments, the bill passed to a third reading.

abstract: Confiscation of Rebel Property
lead_paragraph: Our courts have hitherto been but little troubled with questions arising under the confiscation laws. Those questions would naturally be more frequent in the Border States, where there were more men who had left their property within reach of the process of the United States Courts, while they themselves had gone to take an active part in the rebellion. Still there have been some men from this City of New-York who have placed themselves in this situation, and there have accordingly been some cases before our courts, though by no means so many as there should have been, we are certain.

abstract: -- The Ceylon Times, of Feb. 7, tells of the following disaster to a Government immigration vessel, on the ferry between Paumben and the Coast: "The Audy Letchemy, a bark of 150 tons, was bound from Vengalle to Paumben, having on board 120 coolles and a crew numbering 14. At 7 o'clock on the morning of the 5th inst., the tindall noticed a large waterspout about 10 miles to the northeast, but as he was steering due N.W., its presence did not occasion him any uneasiness, and he went below. There was a good breeze blowing at the time, and there had been a little rain in the early morning, confining the coolies to the hold. It seems that shortly before 8 o'clock the waterspout was seen rapidly approaching the vessel, and the tindal accordingly put her about to try and avoid it. However, all his efforts proved fruitless; the spout came nearer, and from the whirling motion at its base lifted the doomed ship about three feet out of the water and instantly capsized her. All this had occurred so rapidly that the result was wholly unexpected on board, and most of the coolies were still below. Out of the 120, only 7 escaped, by holding on to floating pieces of timber until 2 o'clock in the afternoon, when a passing ship picked them up. One of the crew was also drowned. The vessel became a total wreck, and sank in 31 feet of water.
lead_paragraph: -- The Ceylon Times, of Feb. 7, tells of the following disaster to a Government immigration vessel, on the ferry between Paumben and the Coast: "The Audy Letchemy, a bark of 150 tons, was bound from Vengalle to Paumben, having on board 120 coolles and a crew numbering 14. All this had occurred so rapidly that the result was wholly unexpected on board, and most of the coolies were still below. Out of the 120, only 7 escaped, by holding on to floating pieces of timber until 2 o'clock in the afternoon, when a passing ship picked them up. One of the crew was also drowned. The vessel became a total wreck, and sank in 31 feet of water.

abstract: Life Assurance by Government; Chenango Canal Bill
snippet: Life Assurance by Government; Chenango Canal Bill
lead_paragraph: A social reform of more than common interest and importance is under discussion in the British House of Commons, in the form of a measure to enable the Government to provide Deferred Annuities or issue policies of Life Assurance for that large industrial class now dependent on minor, ill-managed offices, or so-called Friendly Societies. The justification of this seeming attempt to trench on the domain of private enterprise, is found -- first, in the fact that the Government has already, by authority of Parliament, recognized the principle of interference with the enterprise of ordinary assurance companies or loan associations, in exempting friendly societies from taxation, and in having established, through the post-office department, national savings banks in nearly every parish of the kingdom. A second justifying plea is found in the fact, that large and safe companies do not want the kind of business offered by the industrial poor; but on the contrary, as a rule, favor the intervention of the Government. Still another argument is supplied by the startling report of the Government Commissioner on the actual condition of those minor assurance companies and friendly societies which employ agencies to tout up subscribers.
headline: {'main': 'Life Assurance by Government An English Scheme.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Life Assurance by Government An English Scheme.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Persia at this port, yesterday, we have two days later news from Europe. The news from England is unimportant. A large meeting had been held near London, in favor of English intervention in Polish affairs. The report by previous steamers that the pirate Florida was at Teneriffe on the 4th of March, is confirmed. She left on the 6th. The pirate Georgia put into Bordeaux, March 25. The Archduke MAXIMILIANwould embark for Mexico on the 30th of March. GARIBALDI was expected in England on the 2d of April. There was nothing new from the seat of war in Denmark. Copenhagen telegrams state that the bombardment of Fredericia had ceased on the 21st. Part of Fredericia had been set on fire by the bombardment. When summoned to surrender, the Commander refused. According to latest advices the Germans had Abandoned the siege and also their position before the town. It was announced that the German allies accepted the proposition for a Conference without basis or armistice.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Ocean Queen at this port, yesterday, we have advices from Panama to March 27. The news is interesting, though not specially important. Capt. PIM'S British railroad project had been rejected by the Nicarauguan House of Deputies. SAMUEL WARD, Esq., who came a passenger in the Ocean Queen, brings the contract ratified by the Nicaraguan Government for inter-oceanic transit. President MURILLO, of the United States of Colombia, arrived at Carthagena on the 16th, in the United States war steamer Glaucus. He would reach Bogota five days before the inauguration. Diplomatic relations have been broken off between Chili and Bolivia, and the Minister of the latter has left the former country. Peru and the United States Minister had offered their intervention. The difficulty grows out of the Mejillones boundary question.

abstract: This court was opened yesterday morning. A quorum of the Grand Jury not being present, they were discharged until this morning at 11 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: This court was opened yesterday morning. A quorum of the Grand Jury not being present, they were discharged until this morning at 11 o'clock. The grand jurors who failed to answer were ordered to pay a fine of $25. The panel of petit jurors then being called, and only thirty-five answering to their names. His Honor directed that a fine of $25 be imposed upon each of the absentees, and that the delinquents be notified that, if they did not appear this morning, they would be imprisoned for contempt, and fined $25 for each and every day of the term.

abstract: U. S. vs. Levy, Judge Betts' decision; U. S. vs. Levy. Confiscation Case
snippet: U. S. vs. Levy, Judge Betts' decision; U. S. vs. Levy. Confiscation Case
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. 1,756 Shares of the Capital Stock of "the Great Western Railroad of 1859," belonging to Leroy M. Wiley This was a proceeding to forfeit the property in question, under the Act of Congress of July 17, 1862, which forfeit "the estate and property, money, stocks, credits and effects" of any person "who owning property in any loyal State, shall assist or give aid and comfort to the rebellion." The libel was filed in August last, and process was issued, under which the Marshal seized the property. An answer was put in on behalf of Wiley, which was on motion stricken out by the court, on the ground that he being an enemy, could have no standing in court. An answer was also put in, in behalf of the Railroad Company, and a motion was made on the part of the United States, to strike that out also. The following is the opinion of the court granting the motion:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The relapse from the grand opera of the German school -- and in that category we class GOUNOD's "Faust" -- to the more lyric drama of the Italian, does not, at the present moment, appear to be acceptable to the public. Without referring to the matter of taste, which so far as the public is concerned, may often be questioned, but in this particular instance is true to great artists and great composers, we may state briefly that the attendance last evening was not equal to that which witnessed the performances of "Robert le Diable," and of "Faust" on the two preceding evenings. The performance, however, was excellent, and met with that hearty meed of applause which the few more often bestow judiciously than the many. The leading artists were in excellent voice. Mme. MEDORI, indeed, as a singer and an actress, surpassed herself. In the poison scene of the second act she was perfectly grand and was most happily supported by Signor MAZZOLENI, who gave the madre mia with an earnestness and tender appreciation of its relation to the scene, that was thoroughly enjoyable. Signor BELLINI sang the music of the Duke with fine intelligence and success. It is, however, a little too low for his voice. Mlle. SULZER was the Orsini, and won the customary honors in the Brindisi.

The performance, however, was excellent, and met with that hearty meed of applause which the few more often bestow judiciously than the many. The leading artists were in excellent voice. Mme. SULZER was the Orsini, and won the customary honors in the Brindisi.

abstract: Diplomatists; Who and What they are; and other Rebel Commissioners to Europe; Rost, Judge, and Other Rebel Commissioners to Europe, Sketch of; and Other Rebel Commissioners to Europe; and other Rebel Commissioners to Europe; and other Rebel Commissioners to Europe
snippet: Diplomatists; Who and What they are; and other Rebel Commissioners to Europe; Rost, Judge, and Other Rebel Commissioners to Europe, Sketch of; and Other Rebel Commissioners to Europe; and other Rebel Commissioners to Europe; and other Rebel Commis...
lead_paragraph: The ability, the perseverance, the faith, the single-heartedness and honesty of purpose displayed by our early diplomatic agents, will ever be to the true American a subject of admiration and pride. The ability, the perseverance, the faith, the single-heartedness and honesty of purpose displayed by our early diplomatic agents, will ever be to the true American a subject of admiration and pride. To some half dozen men was confided the foreign relations of a new people struggling for national independence. And these men, ever sustained by an earnest conviction in right, succeeded against the wiles of trained diplomatists and the influence of a colossal power, in building up a credit that carried us, triumphantly, through the war for independence. Subsequently, on the signature of the treaty of peace, 1783, when we were pressed by an enormous domestic and foreign debt, without navigation or commerce, without credit, with the whole commercial power of Great Britain arrayed against us, and a doubt prevailed very generally in Europe how far Congress could bind the States in their foreign relations, our diplomatists overcame all these difficulties and secured treaties on the most favorable terms. They were, without exception, men of high personal character and unquestioned patriotism; and the student of history, when he reads with admiration their elaborate and able correspondence, will note, with a feeling of reverence, the integrity and devotion to the public interest exhibited by them all.

abstract: We have dates from Bogota, the capital, to the last of February. In Congress the excitement produced by the debates upon the question of bringing the rebellious State of Antioquia to terms by making war on her, has ceased, and a general expectation existed that matters would be arranged in a pacific manner. Gen. MOSQUERA himself, who is still absent from the capital, and who everybody thought would be for making immediate war on that State, in a letter to its rebel Governor BERRIO, seems to be averse to an appeal to the bayonet. The new President, Senor MURILLO, will take charge of the Government on the 1st of April, and will avoid war, if it be not left him as a legacy. In the interim of the month of March it is more than likely that the resolution of Congress to bring the State to terms, "by war, if necessary," will not be enforced, or be delayed, and then, Antioquia, finding herself alone, will scarcely insist upon flying in the face of the Constitution and laws, at the commencement of a new Presidential term under a new man.

abstract: Probabilities of Fighting
lead_paragraph: Since the battles of Chattanooga and Knoxville, in the last week of November, more than four months ago, there has not been a serious conflict between the Union and the rebel arms, with the single exception of SEYMOUR'S faux pas at Olustee, an affair which don't deserve a military name. There have been raids -- SHERMAN's, AVERILL's, KILPATRICK's, and two or three minor ones -- which have inflicted considerable damage upon the railroads and other material interests of the rebels, but even these were attended with almost no effusion of blood. This general quiet has not come simply from the fact that the season of the year has been unfavorable for military operations. During the two previous Winters, battles were numerous. During the four months previous to April, 1862, we had Mill Springs, Roanoke Island, Fort Donelson, New-Madrid, Pea Ridge, Winchester, and the fight between the Monitor and Merrimac. During the four months previous to April, 1863, we had Prairie Grove, Stone River, SHERMAN's attack on Vicksburgh, Arkansas Post, Fredericksburgh, and a great number of smaller fights. In fact, probably quite as many blows have been struck heretofore during the cold months as during any other season of the year. But during the present year there has been almost an absolute suspension. And what is more, it is probable that this suspension will continue through this mild month of April.

abstract: License Bureau, a Flagrant Abuse at
snippet: License Bureau, a Flagrant Abuse at
lead_paragraph: One of the flagrant, and, because of its flagrancy, almost amusing instances of the way in which the public moneys go, has been unearthed, among hundreds, by the Citizens' Association. The License Bureau is what is referred to, which is a bureau made solely for political paupers, and about as useful as the seventh -- not the fifth -- wheel to a cart. The incumbent takes from the City Treasury $2,500 a year, and does not one cent's worth of work. If he does, let him deny the assertion. He has drawn this amount ever since the bureau was created, and has not returned one cent's worth of service. It is a sinecure of the most shameful kind. The entire work of the License Bureau is and always has been done in the Mayor's office, at one-half the cost contemplated in the bill lobbied through the Legislature for this License Bureau. How Comptroller BRENNAN can sign monthly warrants for pay for duties which he well knows are not and never have been performed, puzzles those who attribute to him the characteristic of jealously watching the interests of the City and his own fair fame. This bureau will receive further attention, as will other departments whereby the "good old goose" has been and is being most scandalously plucked.

abstract: Meeting of Workingmen against Pending Bill; Strikes, Meeting against Bill on
snippet: Meeting of Workingmen against Pending Bill; Strikes, Meeting against Bill on
lead_paragraph: A grand mass meeting of the mechanics and workingmen of this City was held yesterday afternoon at Tompkins-square, for the purpose of protesting against a bill now pending in the Legislature, for the suppression of strikes. More than fifty Associations and workingmen's Unions sent delegates to this meeting, and men in all parts of the City stopped work at noon and gathered in Tompkins-square, to assist at a meeting which they consider will tend to preserve their rights and liberties. At three o'clock in the afternoon, when the Chairman called the crowd to order, there could not have been less than ten thousand people present, which number was increased before the close, by fresh arrivals, to nearly twenty thousand.

abstract: Fagnani's Portrait of Hon. H. J. Raymond
snippet: Fagnani's Portrait of Hon. H. J. Raymond
lead_paragraph: -Mr. FAGNANI, well known as one of the ablest and most successful portrait painters we have ever had, has painted a very excellent likeness of the editor of the TIMES, which may be seen for a few days in the window of SCHAUS' superb Gallery of Fine Art in Broadway below Eighth-street. We have already mentioned the handsome gift of Mr. FAGNANI to the Metropolitan Fair of his superb portrait of RICHARD COBDEN. We understand that one of our prominent bankers offered $1,000 for it, intending to present it to the Chamber of Commerce. It ought certainly to be secured for some public gallery.

abstract: Advocates Postponement of Convention
lead_paragraph: The Independent swells the chorus for a postponement of the Union National Convention. It fears the effect of too long a Presidential canvass. It is afraid the North will be divided by a contest lasting from the 7th of June until the 1st of November. But it is quite willing to have the Union party divided from June till September, by a sharp, bitter personal controversy about candidates. It sees, or acknowledges, no danger in this.

abstract: By way of Cairo and the Mississippi, we have news from New-Orleans to March 29, two days later than that previously received. The election in Louisiana, on the 28th, for delegates to the Constitutional Convention, resulted in the complete triumph of the Free-State party. The steamer J.H. Russell, with 700 bales of cotton and a quantity of cattle and hogs, was consumed by fire at night, at Plaquemine.
lead_paragraph: By way of Cairo and the Mississippi, we have news from New-Orleans to March 29, two days later than that previously received. The election in Louisiana, on the 28th, for delegates to the Constitutional Convention, resulted in the complete triumph of the Free-State party. The steamer J.H. Russell, with 700 bales of cotton and a quantity of cattle and hogs, was consumed by fire at night, at Plaquemine. The steamer was on her passage from Vicksburgh to New-Orleans, and took fire from the sparks of her torches. The mails from Alexandria, together with the dispatches of Gen. LEE to the headquarters of the Department of the Gulf, were also burned. The rebel ram Tennessee was struck by a squall on the 1st inst, while lying near Grant's Pass, below Mob le. Her armament will prove a heavy loss to the rebels. It consisted of six 100-pounder Parrotts. At Alexandria, on the 27th, it was reported that all was quiet. The rebel force near there was reported to be twenty thousand strong. It was supposed that their intention was to fall back about fifty miles, and there await an attack from our forces. Our gunborts bound for Shreveport had succeeded in getting over the shoals. A land force left Alexandria on the 27th, destined for Shreveport. The force was under the command of Gen. SMITH.

abstract: Kavanagh vs. Tieman for Championship
lead_paragraph: For many years there has been no event in the billiard world which has occasioned so much excitement among the devotees of the game, as this match for the championship, which occurred at Irving Hall last evening It will be remembered that each party has long been considered invincible in their respective localities; and, after KAVANAGH's victory over S[???]EITER, of Detroit, in October last, the universal expression was, "now, if he can vanquish TIEMAN, it will be hard to wrest the championship from his grasp." This match was made immediately after the above was decided, and was at first set down for the 11th February last, but owing to unusual circumstances it was forced to be postponed until last evening.

abstract: -We are amused to find the NEW-YORK TIMES really vexed at our pleasantries on the subject of the arrangements for the fair in that City; and although the irritation thus betrayed might be regarded as proof that satire on the grandiloquent language of the New-York Press upon the subject was not out of place, yet, as jesting is dangerous with those too dull to see the point of a joke, we may as well declare in explicit terms that we do not believe there is a human being in Boston who does not honor the ladies and gentlemen in New-York for their patriotic exertions, and who does not feel a keen and unalloyed joy to hear of the magnificent degree of success likely to attend their great fair in behalf of the best of causes -- one in which not only America, but all humanity is interest. -- Boston Advertiser, Thursday.

abstract: Hospitals, Government Plan of, Statistics, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: There is not only an impression, but a firm belief, widespread through the community, that the General Government neglects its wounded and sick soldiers, as well by inadequate general hospital accommodation as by insufficient medical and hospital supplies, and supplies of food and clothing. The latter has been shown, in a general way, to be erroneous. The first is equally so. Indeed, there is scarcely an individual in the length and breadth of the land, who, in making such a charge, would not be guilty of ingratitude; for there is scarcely any one who has not felt, directly or indirectly, the generous beneficence of the Government in all of these particulars.

abstract: Mr. COLLINS has returned to Washington, after nearly two years' absence in Russia and England. abstract: IMPORTANT IF TRUE.  A party of refugees, just arrived, bring late intelligence from Richmond. They report daily augmentations to LEE'S army by large numbers of conscripts from various portions of the Confederacy, rebels are increasing their armies very quietly, but effectively and rapidly; and they expect to start LRE out on the Spring campaign, with not less than eighty or ninety thousand men, without weakening other armies in the field.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, among the bills introduced, was one authorizing the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company to increase its capital stock three millions of dollars, for the purpose of completing its double track to Albany, and to authorize the holders of the mortgage bonds of said company to convert their bonds into stocks; and another to increase the New-York riot, bounty, military and damage fund, created under the Act of Feb. 8, 1864, from $200,000 to $900,000. Bills were reported relative to docks in the Nineteenth Ward, Brooklyn; relative to the New-York Magdalene Benevolent Society. Bills were passed incorporating the Corn Exchange Warehouse and Secutity Company; the New-York Croton Water Works Reservoir Bill.

In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Prise FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. GRIMES reported favorably the resolution to repeal the joint resolution authorizing the transfer of seamen from the army to the navy. Mr. HALE, from the Naval Committee, reported adversely on the petition of the warrant officers of the navy for assimilated rank. On motion, of Mr. DOOLITTLE, the bill to let Indian refugees return to their homes, was taken up. The bill appropriates $200,000 for the benefit of the Indians who fled into the frontier States a year ago from the Indian Territory, on account of the rebellious position taken by some of the tribes. The bill was passed. The Anti-Slavery Constitutional Amendment was taken up, and discussed by Messrs. HENDRICKS, HENDERSON, HOWARD and COLLAMER, when the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. GRIMES reported favorably the resolution to repeal the joint resolution authorizing the transfer of seamen from the army to the navy. Mr. HALE, from the Naval Committee, reported adversely on the petition of the warrant officers of the navy for assimilated rank. On motion, of Mr. DOOLITTLE, the bill to let Indian refugees return to their homes, was taken up. The bill appropriates $200,000 for the benefit of the Indians who fled into the frontier States a year ago from the Indian Territory, on account of the rebellious position taken by some of the tribes. The bill was passed. The Anti-Slavery Constitutional Amendment was taken up, and discussed by Messrs. HENDRICKS, HENDERSON, HOWARD and COLLAMER, when the Senate adjourned.

abstract: -- Whatever temporary grievance may have been anticipated at the up-town Stations -- Yorkville in particular -- from the Postmaster's very praiseworthy desire to extend the house-delivery system, has been very speedily and satisfactorily remedied. It seems that no sudden change was contemplated, either in the withdrawal of the box privilege, or in the augmentation of the price of box accommodation. This much is due to the judgment and forecast of Mr. WAKEMAN, who, no doubt, properly understood the position of suburban residents, with many of whom prompt delivery is of the utmost importance. It is due, beside, however, to Mr. PEASE, who has the important station of Yorkville under his charge, to say that universal testimony is borne to the admirable facilities afforded both at the office, and by means of really trustworthy carriers, for an early and safe delivery of the mail. Nothing can possibly be better than the present local management, whether as regards the urbanity of the officers, or their desire, so far as superior orders and the exigencies of the Department will permit, to meet the pressing, and sometimes unreasonable, calls of the public.

abstract: Business was active again yesterday in Flour, Corn, Whiskey, Tallow and Provisions, at the Produce Exchange. Prices generally favored sellers decidedly. Cotton was firm, but less freely dealt in. Petroleum was in good request, as were also Hay, Leather and Wool, at buoyant rates. A fair inquiry prevailed for Groceries, Fish, Fruit, Laths, Lime, Spices and Tobacco. The freight market was very dull, and rates much depressed. Trade in Dry Goods has been more active within the past few days, especially with the jobbers, who have had an excellent run of custom from country buyers. Stocks of desirable fabrics have been much reduced, and in view of the rise in the value of raw materials, prices have been very firm, the tendency toward the close having been decidedly upward on all favorite styles of dress goods. The week's importations have been comparatively moderate.

abstract: Report analyzed, No. 10
lead_paragraph: When the flood came which swelled the Chickahominy on the 29th of May, and left the two wings of the Union Army separated by an apparently impassable barrier, the Confederate commander, JOE JOHNSTON, concluded the time had come to assume the initiative, and fall upon the exposed wing of the Union Army. The situation was such that he might hope, not merely to defeat, but to destroy that portion of our force. Two corps -- to wit, those of KEYES and HEINTZELMAN -- were on the right or Richmond bank of the Chickahominy, the other three corps -- to wit, those of SUMNER, FRANKLIN and PORTER -- were on the left bank. The great flood gave the rebels hope that it would sever the two portions of our army, leaving the right wing on the left bank helpless spectators of the destruction of the left wing on the right bank. With this view, Gen. JOHNSTON made the following dispositions: Gen. HILL, (D.H.,) supported by the division of LONGSTREET, to advance by the Williamsburgh road and attack in front; G.W. SMITH to move to the junction of the New-bridge road and the Nine Mile road, to fall on KEYES' right or cover LONGSTREET's left. HUGER, with his division, to move down the Charles City road, in order to attack in flank, cut off our retreat by Bottom's Bridge, and force the left wing into White Oak Swamp, where unconditional surrender would have been inevitable.

abstract: Speech at Sanitary Fair, N. Y.
snippet: Speech at Sanitary Fair, N. Y.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the fifth day of the great fair, was even more pleasant than the preceding day, and the crowd, if possible, greater. As usual, the building was besieged at least an hour before the time for opening and as usual it was immediately uncomfortably filled. The fact of the price being again $1 seemed to have no effect, or, if it had any, it was but to increase the interest of all parties. Nothing has occurred in this City for years which has created half the excitement caused by this the Sanitary Fair.

abstract: Popular, Louis Napoleon and Mr. Chase
snippet: Popular, Louis Napoleon and Mr. Chase
lead_paragraph: The device now known as "popular loans," of which LOUIS NAPOLEON was the originator, was probably the happiest and shrewdest mode of strenthening and consolidating a government that ever was adopted, and there is very little question that whatever security his dynasty may possess, as well as a large portion of the tranquillity which France has enjoyed during the last thirteen years, are due to it. It effected a complete revolution in financiering, adding one more, and this no small one, to the list of democratic triumphs. The practice of all governments, ever since governments first began to borrow, has been to obtain their loans from a few great capitalists, and, until very recently, this was the only course open to them. Up to the beginning of the present century accumulation, on ever so small a scale, was almost unknown among the poorer classes. What with ignorance, social and political degradation, and insecurity, the desire of saving was generally wanting, even if the power of saving existed. There is probably no surer indication of the extent to which the working classes have risen in the scale, mentally and morally, than the extent to which they accumulate money and invest it; and the plan of offering government stock in such sums as to place it within their reach, was all that was wanted to inspire them with the same conservative feeling which, in all previous ages, has been the characteristic of the rich exclusively.
headline: {'main': 'Popular Loans.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Popular Loans.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -We have a few details of the destruction, by a squall, of the great rebel ram at Mobile, of which we have so often heard during the last two years. It is said that she was an extremely powerful concern, her iron plating being six inches in thickness, and her armament consisting of six 100-pounder rifled Parrott guns, while her submarine horn or spear was of immense size and sharpness. This casualty adds another to the long list of defunct and unfortunate rebel rams, with whose horns JEFF. DAVIS hoped to split the Union.

abstract: The Boston Traveller says: "We understand the Treasury Department sells no gold certificates at any other place than New-York.
lead_paragraph: -- The Boston Traveller says: "We understand the Treasury Department sells no gold certificates at any other place than New-York. As the effect of the gold certificates has been to reduce the duties on imports. New-York importers are specially favored. The consignees of goods by the steamer at Portland have been obliged to go to New-York and buy their certificates. This is an evil which calls for an immediate remedy. So much favoritism to New-York is decidedly unjust to the importing interest in all other parts of the country."

abstract: Taylor, >amp;c. vs. Hutton, >amp;c. Fourth National Bank Case
snippet: Taylor, >amp;c. vs. Hutton, >amp;c. Fourth National Bank Case
lead_paragraph: Robert S. Taylor, Richard D. Lathrop, Charles S. Anthony and Joseph Stewart vs. Benjamin Hutton, O. De Forest Grant, Freeman Clarke, David Dows, William H. Webb, William Whitewright and the Fourth National Bank. -- Two of the plaintiffs in this action are Directors of the Fourth National Bank of the City of New-York, the others are stockholders in the bank, the defendants are all Directors of the same institution. Plaintiffs applied for an injunction to restrain the defendants from removing Mr. George Opdyke from the Presidency of the Bank, and from doing any other acts in relation to the business of the Bank, except to receive deposits, to pay checks and to make exchanges, until after a meeting of all the stockholders should be held.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. TRUMBULL reported from the Judiciary Committee the pro  posed amendment to the rules of the Senate, requiring nominations to be acted upon in open Senate, with a recommendation that it do not pass.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. TRUMBULL reported from the Judiciary Committee the pro posed amendment to the rules of the Senate, requiring nominations to be acted upon in open Senate, with a recommendation that it do not pass. The report was adopted. Mr. SHERMAN introduced a bill, which will come up in place of the defeated House bill relating to national banks. On motion of Mr. WILSON the Secretary of War was directed to communicate information touching the arrest of Capt. C.B. FERGUSON, Quartermaster United States Army, and Capt. WILLIAM STODDARD, Assistant Quartermaster, lately in charge of the military depot at Alexandria, Va. Mr. HALE called up the bill to repeal the first section of the joint resolution of Feb. 24, 1864, relating to the transfer of persons from the military to the naval service, which was passed. The joint resolution to amend the Constitution by prohibiting Slavery came up, and, after a long and elaborate speech by Mr. SUMNER, and further discussion by Messrs. POWELL, DAVIS and SAULSBURY, the resolution, as amended by the Judiciary Committee, was adopted by a vote of 38 to 6. The amendment provides that the additional article thus proposed to the Constitution shall be valid when ratified by the Legislatures of three-fourths of the States.

abstract: At the Fair Buildings on Union-square, another delightful entertainment was given last evening, Mr. and Mrs. WATKINS having volunteered to repeat their Photographiana for the benefit of the Sanitary Commission.
lead_paragraph: At the Fair Buildings on Union-square, another delightful entertainment was given last evening, Mr. and Mrs. WATKINS having volunteered to repeat their Photographiana for the benefit of the Sanitary Commission. The concert-room was of course, crowded to excess, not even a place to stand on being left anywhere in sight of the stage. After much discussion of the question, the committee have resolved to admit the holders of tickets to these entertainments without extra charge. This conclusion is just and reasonable, and, without doubt, will do away with at least one cause of complaint against the management of the fair in regard to admission to the side shows.
