abstract: the Union, Strength of, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: What with bounties, and drafts, and reenlistments, an enormous number of men are now in the service of the United States. We believe we state a fact, when we say that at no period of the war have so many names been on the pay-rolls of the Government as during this month of April. The effective force, also, of the United States is, at the present time, immensely large, and of a high order. The soldiers are more hardy, vigorous and inured to campaigning than ever before, and their discipline and drill are far superior to what they were in the first years of the war. Unworthy officers have been weeded out to a great extent, and those in command have been tested by battle and danger, so that our troops will be better commanded than they have ever been. The Government is able now to concentrate heavy and efficient bodies of veteran soldiers wherever it desires them. Coming down next to such details as have been published, it is said that an army of formidable dimensions is being gathered at Annapolis. We observe also that an officer of tried service and great skill, Gen. SMITH, is placed over the military forces of Gen. BUTLER's Department. We note furthermore that Gen. MEADE still keeps his position on the Rapidan, with an army increased in number and refreshed after the Winter's rest and the liberal furloughs. Gen. GRANT's presence at these various points in Virginia indicates that he is preparing for some stroke, and that he himself intends to guide and direct it. The very silence and inaction through the whole Union, under a Commander-in-Chief of such well-known energy as GRANT, is ominous of great blows in preparation. It is generally understood that Gen. THOMAS has an immense army at Chattanooga, which can, when the word comes, march with overwhelming force into Georgia.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented from HAWLEY D. CLAPP, representing that he is confined in Fort Lafayette, by order of Major-Gen. Dix, for the purpose of extorting from him information which he does not possesss. The petition was laid on the table. CLAPP was the chief of the Lafayette Hall bounty-brokers Among the bills reported was one authorizing the Harlem Railroad Company to increase its capital stock three millions of dollars and convert its mortgage bonds into stock; against the Bloomingdale and Broadway Railroad Bill; against the Thirty-second-street Railroad Bill; against the Broadway Tunnel Bill; against imposing a tax of ten per cent. on the New-York City Railroad Bills for the benefit of the City Treasury. These reports were all laid on the table. The Soldiers' Voting Bill; to tax the dividends of Massachusetts stockholders in corporations of this State; incorporating the Dime Savings Bank of New-York; authorizing the New-York authorities to convey land to the Catholic Orphan Asylum on Ward's Island; relative to the investment of surplus profits of Fire Insurance Companies. The Albany Bridge Bill and the Bill amending the charter of the Hudson and Harlem River Canal Company were ordered to a third reading.

abstract: Surrender of
lead_paragraph: -- That fierce and untameable tribe of redskins, the Navajoes, whom we have been fighting for the last eighteen years, are reported to have lately surrendered to our forces in New-Mexico; and on the heels of this news, we have the announcement from Washington that an appropropriation of one hundred thousand dollars is asked from Congress for the subsistence of the tribe. It is thought in official circles, we are informed, that it will be more economical to support the Navajoes than to fight them. We doubt the accuracy of this theory; though on grounds of humanity, we might concede the wisdom of giving these galloping wretches rations of bread and beef rather than of bullets and cold steel. In the meantime, our soldiers, who have just got through with a big fight with the Navajoes, are dividing their daily rations with them, being themselves put on short commons for the purpose of feeding the savages. This is certainly very nice. In future it is proposed to give each individual of the tribe, numbering seven thousand in all, a daily allowance of one pound of flour and one pound of fresh meat, which, if they consume it all, will, it is thought, leave them little stomach for the fight. But the Navajoes are very treacherous, and pay little regard to treaties or agreements with white men. Col. DONIPHAN beat them and made a treaty with them in 1846, but they soon forgot it; Col. WASHINGTON did the same thing in 1849, with the same result; Col. (subsequently Major-General) SUMNER repeated the operation in 1851, but we have heard of their depredations almost every year since. The fact is, fighting has been the ceaseless and immemorial occupation of the Navajoes; and we fear that the bread and beef now furnished to them will only give them strength and muscle to fight us again the coming Summer.

abstract: COUPONS DETACHED. -- A few days ago one of the banks or this city received, in the way of business, a fifty-dollar United States Treasury Note, dated December 1st, 1863, payable two years after date, with interest at five per cent. per annum, the latter payable semi-annually. Subsequently it was ascertained that the interest coupons had been detached from the note. The United States Treasurer at Washington was thereupon inquired of as to the effect on the value of the note by the detachment of the coupon, and replied as follows; "The coupons having been detached, it ceases to be a legal tender until the 1st of June, 1865, at which time it will be received for its full face value." This is an important fact to all persons receiving treasury notes with coupons attached. -- Baltimore Sun, April 8.

abstract: The imperative demand for high speed in shipsof-war is leading some of our builders and engineers to make exertions to accomplish in this respect all that can be desired.
lead_paragraph: The imperative demand for high speed in shipsof-war is leading some of our builders and engineers to make exertions to accomplish in this respect all that can be desired. Fast vessels of light draft may not be able to carry a sufficiently heavy armament to cope successfully with the Alabama, but they may be armed with another weapon which would settle the Alabama's case much quicker than a broadside, viz., a ram. This, with sea-going qualities, and power, would render a light vessel the equal of a much larger one, whose strength lay entirely in her armament. The numerous blockade-runners that have been captured and brought to this port, have attracted much attention for their models and peculiar construction, with reference to the chief quality -- great speed. We have lately seen a model of an iron-clad vessel, constructed on the combined principles of speed to be found in these blockade-runners, and in the fast steamers on the Mississippi, and possessing, moreover, great power, as well as sea-going qualities, with a formidable ram as a leading feature of its offensive character. The dimensions of this craft are: Length, 216 feet; depth of hold, 16 feet; beam, 20 feet; condensing engines, cylinder 60 inches in diameter, 30 inches stroke, direct acting, connected at right angles with the boilers, one forward and the other aft of the engine, with sufficient power to produce 60 pounds of steam to the square inch; propeller, 16 feet in diameter, with 30 feet pitch; the ram to project 12 feet from the stem, in the form of a lance, and three feet thick in the centre. The bow is so constructed that, when a ship is struck by the ram, she is keeled over by the blow, and the sharp blade of the ram crashes into her bottom. The natural return roll of the ship then following, aided by the backing of the ram's engines, would completely disengage the blade. The sea-going qualities consist in placing the boilers, engine, coal, provisions and everything but the armament below the waterline, in the bottom of the ship. The model is exceedingly beautiful, and seems fully adapted for the attainment of the very highest speed. The most experienced judges, who have examined it, pronounce twenty knots an hour as undoubtedly possible, while some place it even three and four knots higher. The designer of the model is DANIEL MERRICK, Esq., formerly superintendent of the construction of nonclads on the Mississippi. The construction of a vessel of this character would be a great feat in naval architecture.

abstract: SAMUEL COLEMAN, JERVIS MCENTEE, and A.D. SHATTUCK, three of our most popular artists, have jointly made a collection of pictures, numbering some seventy-five, which are to be sold at auction on the evening of Tuesday next, at the gallery of JOHN SNEDECOR, No. 768 Broadway, where they are new on free exhibition. The mere mention of the names of these artists will be sufficient to attract a host of eager buyers. COLEMAN, whose romantic subjects and delicate and sympathetic handling are so deservedly admired, contributes several of his choicest as well as his more recent works.

abstract: -- On Easter Day the congregation of the Church of the Holy Apostles, corner Twenty-eighth-street and Ninth-avenue, Rev. Dr. HOWLAND, Rector, made their Easter offerings to remove the church debt. They amounted in the morning to $9,760, which has since been increased to $10,500, thus relieving the parish from all embarrassments, and making in all nearly $20,000 contributed within a very short time for this object entirely from within themselves. When the present Rector assumed the charge of the parish, about 17 years ago, it only contained 20 communicants, now they number upward of 400. While thus providing for home they have not neglected their duties outside. For several years they have maintained a missionary for the neighborhood, and another very flourishing parish in the vicinity owes its start and first support to generous hearts in this church, the two; arishes now consisting of 600 communicants. The prospects for a future prosperous career are very bright. With a large congregation at unity within themselves and zealous in good works; a good choir composed of communicants of the church, and therefore interested in their part of the religious services; a Rector and Associate Rector beloved by their congregation and endeared to them by many years of service; with two faithful missionaries to assist in reclaiming the lost sheep; a church property valued at $40,000, without an incumbrance, (not even a pew sold;) an edifice unpretending in its exterior, but within one of the most chaste and pretty that adorns our City -- all together form union of elements of success seldom to be met together in a changing and busy metropolis. To appropriately mark an event so gratifying to the congregation, services suitable to the occasion will be held in the church on Sunday morning next.

abstract: Paris Election; Elections of Libergis
lead_paragraph: Paris has again registered her protest against Caesarism. At the recent elections in the First and Fifth Districts, she has returned the Opposition candidates, MM. CARNOT and PAGES, by an overwhelming majority. These gentlemen are something more than Constitutionalists. Both of them were members of the Provisional Government of '48, and both of them are still republicans, so staunch that for twelve years they have steadfastly refused to take the oath of allegiance to the Empire, and merely take it now in obedience to the call of the democracy. There is not a little of significance in the election of such men. Though several worthy candidates of liberal views and undoubted honesty, had come forward to contend for the honor of representing the districts named in the Corps Legislatif, yet the ex-members of the fallen Republican Government were preferred before all. By this preference, the Parisians at once paid a tribute of respect to the principles of liberty, and marked their indignation at the arbitrary dispersion of the electoral meetings. The popular victory is the more notable, because it was won under every disadvantage, and over the nominees of the Court; for the Government did, at the eleventh hour, bring out its candidates, and contest the election, notwithstanding the general impression which prevailed to the contrary. The fact is, that the Emperor, from the first, was determined to give his opponents battle, and only held back his men to throw the enemy off their guard, so as to have the better chance of carrying the day by a coup de main. But the trick failed. The appearance of the Court candidates in the field was the signal for the concentration of the popular forces, and NAPOLEON sustained, in both districts, a Waterloo defeat -- M. PINARD, his candidate for the First, receiving only 4,888 votes out of 18,497, and M. FREDERIC LEVI, his candidate in the Fifth, only 6,430 out of 20,936. From the conquerors in this encounter His Majesty must expect a more earnest opposition, and more radical demands, than from those representatives of obsolete factions and obsolete ideas, who have hitherto made their way into the Legislature in defiance of the Government, and who would be content with a partial modification of the present system. The new deputies are the representatives of the opinions and desires of the populations of the great cities of France -- of those populations who, from the period of the old Revolution, have been always thorough republicans at heart, and who chafe at the restrictions which absolutism has imposed on them. The new deputies are enemies of Caesarism, and, saving their allegiance, will do all they can to undermine and destroy it. M. CARNOT's address to the electors of the First District embodies the initiatory programme which they mean to put forward. They will proclaim that France aspires to regain those lost liberties which are so dear to her. They will demand greater freedom for the citizen in his individual capacity; greater freedom for the elector in the exercise of his political rights; greater freedom for the operative in the regulation of his industrial interests; greater freedom for writers in the expression of their thoughts, and a more perfect system of education for all. There is here certainly no indication of anarchical designs -- no open declaration of war against the Empire; nothing, in short, of which the eloquence of a THIERS or a BERRYER cannot undertake the advocacy. But let these concession be denied, let "the crowning of the political edifice" be postponed, let the outrages of power against liberty continue, and who can foretell the ultimate result? The Emperor may contemn the numerical feebleness of the Opposition, and influenced by evil counsellors, may hold on in his present course -- nay, may be able to control the elements during the residue of his reign. His Majesty is, however, advanced in years, his constitution is broken, his reign cannot last forever; and it is when he is laid in his grave -- when a weak and inexperienced boy guides the helm and wields the sceptre, that the tempest whose mutterings we now hear may burst forth and sweep away Imperialism and the BONAPARTES from France.

abstract: Vicksburgh advices of the 3d instant say that the rebels attacked Rooch's Plantation at 2 o'clock on Friday morning. The plantation is situated seven miles above Snyder'S Bluff, on the Yazoo River, and is one of the largest in the State. It had extensive cotton works and splendid buildings, all of which were destroyed.

abstract: -- Letters from Munich give us some additional particulars of the last moments of the King of Bavaria. The original cause of the King's death was a trifling wound which he accidentally inflicted upon himself with his breast-pin while hurriedly dressing. This injury produced a small abscess beneath the skin, which, in the King's delicate state of health, who was always complaining, very susceptible to the slightest influence of temperature, and subject to great excitement, rapidly assumed a dangerous character. The King took no notice of the wound, however, and had, at 9 o'clock, his customary bath, having his person well rubbed with flannel towels. By this fatal operation, it appears, the poison beneath the skin was communicated to the blood. At noon, on the 9th inst., he had an interview with Archduke ALBRECHT, and then received his Ministers. By that time the pain in the chest had become so excessive that he sent for his physician, Dr. GIELL, who immediately recognized the dangerous character or the case, and called for four other physicians to consult with them on the subject. It was found that the King was afflicted with pyramy, with a strong addition of erysipelas. Toward midnight the physicians became aware that the cure was hopeless. The Queen, the Princes and Ministers were at the Royal sufferer's bedside during the whole of the night. At 5 o'clock in the morning of the 10th, while prayers were being read in all the churches for the King's preservation, the dean of the cathedral, BEINDEL, presented himself to the King, in order to prepare him for the approaching transition. The King, it appears, had even then no idea of his position, and it was only on being asked by the priest whether he would take the Sacrament, that he remarked, "Is my case so bad as that?" Soon afterward he became delirious, and consciousness was not restored for a moment until 10 o'clock, when His Majesty took leave of the Queen and Crown Prince; lockjaw then ensued, and the King was no more.
lead_paragraph: -- Letters from Munich give us some additional particulars of the last moments of the King of Bavaria. It was found that the King was afflicted with pyramy, with a strong addition of erysipelas. Toward midnight the physicians became aware that the cure was hopeless. The Queen, the Princes and Ministers were at the Royal sufferer's bedside during the whole of the night. At 5 o'clock in the morning of the 10th, while prayers were being read in all the churches for the King's preservation, the dean of the cathedral, BEINDEL, presented himself to the King, in order to prepare him for the approaching transition. The King, it appears, had even then no idea of his position, and it was only on being asked by the priest whether he would take the Sacrament, that he remarked, "Is my case so bad as that?" Soon afterward he became delirious, and consciousness was not restored for a moment until 10 o'clock, when His Majesty took leave of the Queen and Crown Prince; lockjaw then ensued, and the King was no more.

abstract: -- WM.E. WOODRUFF, a well-known citizen of Little Rock, Ark., took the oath of allegiance not long ago, and then wrote in a letter to a friend in the South, which was intercepted, unfortunately for him: "Well, 'the deed am done' and I am now a loyal citizen of the United States -- if the taking of the oath of allegiance can make me one. I took it on yesterday as my only alternative to keep from starving. Please place me right on the subject with my friends South. Tell them I am not less a sympathizer with them than heretofore, but feel mortified and chagrined at the necessity that compelled me to do an act that my conscience revolted at. The next order on the subject, I presume, will be requiring all who have not taken the oath to come up and take it or go beyond the lines." Gen. STEELE very promptly and very properly ordered WOODRUFF and his family to be put outside the Federal lines in order not to keep him separated from his sympathies.

abstract: Shakespeare Tercentenary at Stratford
lead_paragraph: Little has been heard for several weeks of those literary faction fights in London, which promised to bring to a farcical conclusion the movement for marking the tercentenary of SHAKESPEARE by some National Memorial worthy of the subject. These fights, we may say, would have been a primary feature in any project emanating from the rival cliques and circles, which together give tone and temper to Cockney literature. Thus, the coteries which own the leadership of HEPWORTH DIXON and WENTWORTH DILKE and their fellows, would find it as impossible to agree with the Punch clique on the question of doing homage to the great dramatist, as they have always found it to agree on the merits of SHAKESPEARE's most notable living interpreter on the British stage. SHAKESPEARE affords them as good a subject for mutual vituperation as ever Mr. CHARLES KEAN has done. In any case, let the subject have been who or what it might, the world would have been invited to witness a clamorous row, terminating, doubtless, in a free fight.

abstract: The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 7th inst., at 3  P.M., WM. B. CROSBY, Esq., V.P., in the Chair, assisted by BENJ, L. SWAN and...
lead_paragraph: The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 7th inst., at 3 P.M., WM. B. CROSBY, Esq., V.P., in the Chair, assisted by BENJ, L. SWAN and FRANCIS HALL, Esqs., V.P. The decease of PELATITAH PERIT, Esq., one of the Vice-Presidents, being announced, the Rev. Dr. TYNG, by request, read the 90th Psalm and offered prayer. Five new auxiliaries were recognised, of which two are in Colorado, one in Kansas, one in Connecticut, and one in New-York. Interesting communications were received from Rev. LEVI THORN, conveying a vote of thanks from the Board of Army Colportage in North Carolina for 100,000 volumes, granted at their request for that State; from Rev. JAMES HICKEY, Monterey, with highly encouraging reports of Bible distribution in Mexico; from Rev. A.G. SIMONTON, Rio de Janeiro, as to the labors of colporteurs under his supervision; from Rev. L.S. JACOBY, Bremen, with annual financial account and statement of printing and distribution in Germany; from Rev. E.E. HALL, Florence, and Rev. W. CLARK, Milan, showing increasing call for Bible dissemination in Italy. Several letters from China -- as Dr. S. WELLS WILLIAMS, Pekin, Rev. CHARLES HARTWELL and Rev. S.L. BALDWIN, of Fuh Chau, and Rev. E. DOTY, Amoy -- with valuable information as to the work of this society in that immense Empire; from Rev. Dr. KING, Athens, in regard to printing the Modern Greek Testament in Athens; from Rev. E.P. HASTINGS, Ceylon, with financial account, and in regard to labors of the Colporteur in Ceylon. The total number of books granted is 74,535. of which 52,000 were to the Christian Commission; 1,260 for Japan; 96 for the Island of St. Thomas; 315 for Uruguay; 335 for Hayti; several grants for Freedmen; 34 volumes in raised letters for the blind. Besides these, $264 99 worth were granted, not included in the above number; $500 were appropriated for printing the Syriac Testament in Oroomiah; and it was resolved to make plates for the Hawaiian family Bible, and for the Ancient Armeman Psalms, at the Bible House. An agent was appointed for Brazil, one for Mexico, and a temporary agent for Italy. These arrangements were made for extending the foreign work. An agent was also appointed for Western Virginia. JAMES LENOX, Esq., of New-York, was unanimously elected President of the society, in place of the late Hon. LUTHER BRADISH. A vast amount of important business was transacted, well benefitting the last meeting of the financial year.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Soldiers' Vating Bill was taken up and made the special order for Tuesday next. Among the bills passed was the Albany Bridge bill; and a bill to amend the charter of the Home Insurance Company of New-York. A bill was introduced authorizing the Brooklyn authorities to raise money for an armory in the Eastern Districts. The New-York Court-house Bill was recommitted to amend it by providing that the accounts shall be approved by the architect of the building. The bill, as amended, was then passed.

abstract: Address to Arkansas people; Address to People
snippet: Address to Arkansas people; Address to People
lead_paragraph: CITIZENS OF ARKANSAS : I address you because you have been so far deprived of the privilege of aiding in the restoration of civil government in the State, by the occupation of your section of the State by the rebel army. In January last, a Convention of Delegates, elected by a portion of the people, met at Little Rock, remodeled the Constitution of the State, and appointed me for Governor. The new Constitution differs from the old in this -- that it abolishes Slavery in Arkansas forever. The members of the Convention were sober, earnest men, on whom events had made a deep impression. They were tired of war, and the desolation that war produces: they remembered the security and happiness that they enjoyed when law and order prevailed, and the flag of the free was the only emblem of their nationality. They remembered, too, when in an evil hour, a combination of insane politicians, forced their State into rebellion against their own Government. Not one of the traitors had been wronged -- not one of them had ever been deprived of a right. On the contrary, they had always been protected in their special and exclusive rights -- especially in their right to hold slaves. Yet, in their insane madness, they rejected that protection, and sought to overturn the Government that protected them in the possession of their slaves.

abstract: --An elevator is to be soon erected at Milwaukee, which will eclipse in size and capacity any grain warehouse in the world. Its length to to be 280 feet; width, 88 feet; height, 132 feet; height to lower eaves, 78 feet.
lead_paragraph: -- An elevator is to be soon erected at Milwaukee, which will eclipse in size and capacity any grain warehouse in the world. Its length to to be 280 feet; width, 88 feet; height, 132 feet; height to lower eaves, 78 feet. It will contain 112 bins, capable of holding 11,000 bushels each, without heaping, making the whole capacity of the warehouse 1,300,000 bushels in round numbers. In the Winter this would be increased to a million and a half by filling the bins as they are filled in other warehouses. This warehouse will be provided with nine receiving and five shipping elevator, capable of taking in 45,000 bushels, and giving out 25,000 bushels per hour.

abstract: Yesterday, the sixth day of the fair, was another beautiful day, and the buildings were, as usual, crowded -- not quite so full in the morning, however, as on the previous days. This was a great advantage to the parties who were present, for it gave them a chance to walk through the buildings comfortably, and examine the goods at their leisure; a great advantage, and one which can be well appreciated by parties who visited the fair on any of the previous mornings. About 1 o'clock, however, the crowd increased, and from that time to the close of the fair the crowd was as large as usual and the enthusiasm and interest as great. The price of tickets still remains at $1, the Managers finding that no objections are made to it, and that at that price the buildings continue crowded.

abstract: British Policy on; Ionian Isles, British Policy on
snippet: British Policy on; Ionian Isles, British Policy on
lead_paragraph: A recent debate in the British House of Commons on the Septinsular Republic has given fresh interest to the subject, and placed the shameless conduct of England in relation to that little State in a new and more striking light. The foreign policy of England is characteristic. She observes one rule of action when dealing with the powerful, and another when dealing with the feeble, cringing to the former and crushing the latter. She keeps a kind of balance-sheet, in which her concessions to the Brobdignagians of the earth are set off against the outrages which she perpetrates on its Lilliputians. But among the small States that have suffered wrong at her hands, none has had more reason to complain than the Ionian Commonwealth. In 1809, when she took possession of said islands, her Government proclaimed that she came not as a conqueror, but as an ally, and formally recognized in official dispatches the independence of the Republic; and the treaty which constituted her its protectress by no means authorized her to overthrow the popular government, and to establish her own supremacy on its ruins. This usurpation, and their being deprived of the right of self-rule and subjected to the dominance of a foreign race, were the original sources of the discontent of the Ionians. The incessant bickerings between the British and their proteges which this abnormal state of things naturally gave rise to, at length fairly wore out the patience of the former, and when the Prince of Denmark offered to accept the crown of Greece in consideration of the Ionian Isles being annexed thereto, the British Government assented to the transfer. This act, had it been performed in a decent spirit by England, would have made her respected by both Greeks and Ionians. But England cannot perform even an honest act gracefully, and though the Treaty of Vienna contained a distinct recognition of the right of the islanders to the fortresses of Corfu, though Earl RUSSELL in the debate of last July on the cession of these islands, admitted that it was only the people of the new kingdom who could rightfully decide whether the fortresses in question should be dismantled, though the Ionian Legislature had from time to time voted over 200,000 for their repair and restoration, it was yet suddenly, capriciously and in open defiance of treaties, determined that, ere the islands were surrendered to King GEORGE, the Corfu fortresses should be blown up. This shameful and perfidious resolution was adopted out of complaisance to Austria. FRANCIS JOSEPH, it seems, would not consent to the cession of the islands to Greece if the fortresses of Corfu were not destroyed. They command the entrance of the Adriatic; and were Italy to get possession of them, what damage might she not do, perhaps, to the commerce and marine of Austria? Italy, be it remembered, could not seize those fortresses without attacking Greece, which would rouse the indignation of Europe, therefore the apprehension of Austria does not seem to have been very well founded. England, however, took a different view of the matter, and concluded that it would be better to do a grievous wrong to a feeble people, than to reject the counsel of her circumspect ally.

abstract: A highly important General Order has been issued from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, which is intended to clear the decks generally for active operations. All civilians, sutlers and their employes, are ordered to the rear by the 16th. Members of the Sanitary or Christian Commissions, and registered newspaper correspondents only, can remain. All property for which there is no transportation, also goes to the rear, and the authority of Corps Commanders to grant furloughs is revoked, and none to be granted save in extreme cases, or in case of reenlisted veterans.

abstract: A YOUNG WOMAN FATALLY INJURED. -- At about 9 o'clock yesterday morning a fire occurred in the two upper floors of the four-story building No. 7 Cedar-street, which were occupied by JOHN DRAPER, cotton dealer; and before the flames could be extinguished, the floors were entirely burned out. Mr. DRAPER's loss on stock is estimated of $6,000. He is insured for $12,000, as follows: Corn Exchange, $7,400; Park, $1,600; St. Marks, $2,000; and Pacific, $1,000. The second floor is occupied as sample-rooms by THOS. LYNCH, wholesale liquor dealer, in the front, and by E.L. & A. CHRISTIANSON, also liquor dealers, in the rear. Their loss will amount to about $1,000; no insurance. The first floor is occupied by FREDERICK Mock as a lunch room. Damage by water $250; no insurance. The building is owned by B.F. WHEELER, and is damaged to the extent of $2.000; insured. When the fire broke out MARY RILEY, a young woman who had been picking cotton on the fourth floor, while attempting to escape by the roof, fell from the top of the building to the sidewalk, and was fatally injured. She was taken to the New-York Hospital, where she died in about half an hour. The origin of the fire is unknown.

abstract: A few days ago, ISAAC JOHNSON, a sailor residing at No. 92 Baxter-street, appeared before Justice HOGAN at the Tombs Police Court, and entered a complaint against THOMAS HADDEN and PATRICK WADDLETON, charging them with kidnapping and robbing him.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, ISAAC JOHNSON, a sailor residing at No. 92 Baxter-street, appeared before Justice HOGAN at the Tombs Police Court, and entered a complaint against THOMAS HADDEN and PATRICK WADDLETON, charging them with kidnapping and robbing him. He alleges that he called on WADDLETON and was desirous of shipping as steward on board the schooner Prince of Wales, bound for Porto Rico. WADDLETON shipped him for $35 a month and one month's wages to be paid in advance. JOHNSON signed articles as he supposed of the above import, and instead of receiving his advance pay was given some clothes of small value, and that he left a trunk of clothes valued at $185 in the possession of the accused. When he got ready to leave, WADDLETON took him down to Peck-slip, where he fell in with HADDEN, the notorious "shangaeher." who advised him to go on board without delay. They all got into a small boat and rowed alongside the British vessel Lydia, bound for Callao and thence to Valparaiso. On reaching the side of the ship, JOHNSON, finding that he had been deceived, refused to go on board, when he was seized by the accused, who struck him on the head with a billet of wood, which rendered him powerless. A rope was then passed about his body and he was hauled up to the deck of the ship. When he returned to consciousness he informed the mate of the vessel that he had been kidnapped, but the mate held him and refused to allow him to go ashore. After he got out to sea he found that his chest was on board the ship, but that it had been sold by WADDLETON to one of the crew. JOHNSON claimed his trunk but received a severe thrashing in answer. He also alleges that WADDLETON received advance pay of $100 for him, which he had appropriated to his own use. After being three weeks at sea, the Lydia returned in a leaky condition, when the complainant called on WADDLETON and found HADDEN there, and HADDEN made all manner of violent threats toward him and would give him no satisfaction.

abstract: -- The recent heavy rains have partially stopped the workmen engaged in sinking the shaft of the Lake Tunnel at the Water Works, owing to the consequent large amount of surface water, which has soaked down through the quicksand and forces its way up from beneath the cylinder. A steam pump has been rigged and the water pumped out, but until the head of surface water is all removed no further excavation will be made. The workmen have reached a depth of sixteen feet and two of the cylinders have been placed in position. The contractors say that by excavating some four feet more, they will come to a strata of thick blue clay, and when once the excavation is completed in this, there will be no further trouble to contend with. The cylinders are bolted together in a cement formed of iron filings, sulphur and other chemicals, forming a joint perfectly impervious to water. -- Chicago Tribune, April 7.

abstract: This Association gave their first Annual Fancy Dress and Civic Ball, at Irving Hall, on Monday evening, 4th instant. Numerous ladies and gentlemen connected with the various Theatres, were present during the evening, and by their presence, not only added to the brilliancy of the occasion, but also gave encouragement to the excellent objects of the Association. The arrangements were perfect, and nothing occurred to mar the pleasure of the evening. The Association is now in a very prosperous condition, its objects are good, and they have by this ball, added a handsome sum to their fund. They are a hard working class of men, never prominently brought to notice, and deserve the good will and support of the public.

abstract: On Tuesday evening, 5th inst., the Union Association of the Seventh Ward held a meeting at their headquarters in Henry-street. After the regular business had been transacted, a motion was made to form a Lincoln Club, which was adopted unanimously. On motion, Mr. THOMAS B. BILLS was called to the chair, and Mr. ROBERT S. MENAMIN was elected Secretary pro tem. A committee was then appointed to recommend permanent officers and suggest the best mode of conducting the Presidential campaign. A meeting of the club will be held at the Union Headquarters in Henry-street on Tuesday evening next. All Union men are invited to attend.

abstract: Tieman vs. Kavanagh, Champion Match
lead_paragraph: Irving Hall was never so completely crowded as on Thursday evening, during the contest for the championship between KAVANAGH and TIEMAN. At least eighteen hundred persons were present, and this immense assemblage remained until the match was concluded in the small hours of the morning. In some instances parties were greatly interested pecuniarily, and thus remained to see their fate, but by far the great majority of the audience remained solely from their love for this scientific game.

abstract: A poor boy, who for some time past has been an occupant of the News boys' Lodging-house, yesterday picked up a pocketbook in Fulton-street, containing $15. The boy was penniless and greatly needed assistance. Shortly after finding it, a little girl came along crying bitterly, and looking anxiously for her lost treasure. The lad went to her, asked what was the matter, and was told she had lost her money. How much had you the boy inquired. Fifteen dollars was the reply. Putting his hand in his pocket, he took it out and handed it to her at once. This is an incident worthy of record. Cases similar often occur at the Lodging-house. The boy who acted so honestly, has been all day at the fair selling, without profit to himself, the Spirit of the Fair. He will, if he continues as he has begun, make a man among men. It would be a good idea for the friends of these lads to contribute so as to treat them with a visit to the fair.

abstract: Naval Officers, Bill to Equalize Grade of
snippet: Naval Officers, Bill to Equalize Grade of
lead_paragraph: -- A measure of importance to naval officers has just passed the House of Representatives, and progressed as far as a second reading in the Senate. It is amendatory to an act approved July 16, 1862, the object of which was to establish and equalize the grade of line officers of the United States Navy. This act, which now bids fair to become a law, provides that no line officer of the navy upon the active list, below the grade of Commodore, nor any other naval officer, shall be promoted to a higher grade until a board fully empowered to make the necessary investigations shall be satisfied regarding his mental, moral, and professional fitness to perform all the duties likely to devolve on him at sea. A Board of Surgeons is to pass upon his physical qualifications, and all officers who may not be recommended for promotion by both these boards are to be placed upon the retired list. It is also provided that all officers not recommended for promotion under the fourth section of an act entitled "An Act to Establish and Equalize the Grades of Line Officers of the United States Navy," approved July 16, 1862, shall have the right to present themselves for examination, according to the provisions of this act, and if found duly qualified, and such finding be approved by the President of the United States, they shall be promoted to the same grade and place as if they had been recommended by the Board, and shall receive the corresponding pay, according to the service which they have performed from the date of their rank to that of their promotion. And no further promotions shall be made upon the active list until the number in each grade is reduced to that provided by law. Some such measure as this could hardly fail to benefit the service. A bill substantially the same was passed at the last session of Congress, but at so late a day that it did not receive Mr. LINCOLN's signature. This one is too far along to fail of becoming a law for that reason.

abstract: Municipal Reform--The Citizens' Association
lead_paragraph: It has always seemed that one of the most practical methods for gradually reforming our City Government would be by instructing its constituency. The reader must remember that the game of peculation and plunder which is going on continually with the property of our citizens is, in fact, played by comparatively few persons. The "Ring" is not a large or crowded body. In every ward there are a few shrewd and good-natured men, either American corrupt politicians or Irish who have "worked up" from degradation. These persons have become thoroughly familiar with the machinery of local politics. They know the chances of every candidate and almost the vote of each voter. As liquor-sellers, or agents of houses, or "City contractors," or Aldermen, they are able to do favors to a few individual workingmen, and impress the others with their great desire to serve them. Gradually, from "jobbing" and managing in a petty district, they come to have a share in the great City jobs. They have no especial sense of character or position. Their constituents will back them in everything which is not open and legal robbery. They have acquired great skill in their iniquitous schemes, so that they have little to fear from any interruption from whatever source. The upper and respectable classes can seldom be induced to combine against a particular candidate, and if they do, the immense vote of ignorant people which these politicians can command insures them success. Thus they go on, from year to year, shamelessly cheating and plundering the City. They give us the most ill-governed and uncomfortable City in the world, at the highest cost. Nothing seems to influence them or to check them. The property-holders simply bear it, and appear as if bound hand and foot. If it were only the plundering of the non-voting rich by the voting poor, we could hope for no cessation until both democracy and the wealth of the City came to an end. But it should be remembered that this is, in the long run, merely putting into one pocket of the laboring class of the community by taking out of the other; or, more definitely, it is enriching a few politicians and contractors, with their followers, by plundering all the rest of the working people. The jobs of the "Ring" are paid for in the rents of the poor and middle classes. For every dollar jobbed from the City, stolen from the Treasury, squandered in junketings, wasted by non-performance of public duties, each man, woman and child of all classes has to pay. Those who pay the taxes on real and personal property must, of course, raise the price of real estate, and the rent of all houses and lands to meet their diminished profits. Every petty dealer whose rent is raised, or who buys of those paying higher rents, must make up the deficiency by charging more for his wares. Every house agent must ask a higher price for the rooms of his tenement houses. There is no "corner grocery" which does not charge upon the laborers some of the expenses which the iniquities of the Common Council lay upon the City. It is this great fact in economics which gives us our hope for future reform.

abstract: Yesterday was the eighteenth successive day that the wind has blown from the eastward -- from E.N.E. to S.S.E. -- except on Friday, when it shifted to the southwest for a couple of hours, then to the northwest, and then settled back in the old quarter. The number of arrivals during this period have been very few. A very large number are due from European and Southern ports.

abstract: The first week of the great fair has passed, and its success is decided and unequivocal. Not a day has passed since its opening but it has been crowded to overflowing, and all visitors have been both ...
lead_paragraph: The first week of the great fair has passed, and its success is decided and unequivocal. Not a day has passed since its opening but it has been crowded to overflowing, and all visitors have been both pleased and astonished at the perfection of its arrangements, the beauty of its ornaments, the value and magnificence of the goods displayed, and the perfect order maintained And all have been also pleased and gratified at its great success. Nothing unpleasant in the slightest degree has occurred. The general distribution of stands to different parties was made with care, and so as to add to the beauty of the building. The arrangement for the sale and taking of tickets is perfect, and has prevented all confusion. The precautions against fire are complete, and remove all apprehensions, and the police arrangements are so thorough that not a theft as occurred.

abstract: Bushnell, Horace. Work and Play
lead_paragraph: This volume takes its name from the first article of its contents, an oration delivered before the Ph Beta Kappa Society of Harvard University in 1848. It is mainly composed similar addresses, called for by different public occasions, and now collected together in a shape that secures their preservation, in obedience to the frequent calls that continued to be made for them in the original fugitive form. We are not surprised at this steady demand for these papers, for if any one can be relied on for new applications of old topics, Dr. BUSHNELL is the man. He may be regarded as a man of letters first among the class that is most typical of the American mind, in its highest stage of development. The light of his clear, fresh and vigorous intellect diffuses itself over every subject he touches. He could not if he would take a common-place view of any question presented to him. Remote analogies become near and obvious, consequences undreampt of before, are seen to be inevitable, and a wider range of thought opens out to the reader, while under the influence of a style always nervous and animated, and often rising to true eloquence that mirrors without a shadow the bright and sharply defined conceptions of the author. If any one wishes to see the novelty a man of genius can evolve from what is generally called a worn-out theme, let him compare "The Founders, Great in their Unconsciousness," an address before the New-England Society, with his recollections of the usual platitudes current about the Pilgrim Fathers, and it is impossible to avoid being struck with the difference. Like smoke before the breeze, he dissipates in a moment the popular theory that what they sought was political liberty and general freedom to worship God. He is not afraid to own their intense and conscientious intolerance, their perfect identification of the Church and the State as a joint power having dominion over the bodies and souls of men, and the utter distastefulness for anything like democratic principles that their whole theory of life and its relations inculcated. Accepting in their widest extent these facts, Dr. BUSHNELL eloquently shows how much we still owe them, because the end of the Pilgrim movement "was religion, simply, and only religion;" but a religion that required the cultivation of intellect -- a personal matter that demanded of every one the independent exercise of thought and reflection; and that the true paternity and spring of our institutions must be sought --

abstract: Speculative purchases of Flour, Provisions, Tallow and Whisky at the Produce Exchange on Saturday were quite extensive, and prices were generally higher. Wheat was held above the views of buyers, and was inactive. Corn, Cotton, Wool and Groceries were in fair request and advancing. Most other kinds of merchandise were held with increased firmness, and were generally in good demand, chiefly on speculation. The Freight market continued dull and heavy.

abstract: MEYERBEER'S grand opera of "Robert le Dlable" will be given here to-night for the third time, with its magnificent distribution, which embraces nearly all the leading artists of Mr. MARETZEK'S company. The work is one of the most popular in the repertoire, and has drawn two of the finest houses of the season.
lead_paragraph: MEYERBEER'S grand opera of "Robert le Dlable" will be given here to-night for the third time, with its magnificent distribution, which embraces nearly all the leading artists of Mr. MARETZEK'S company. The work is one of the most popular in the repertoire, and has drawn two of the finest houses of the season. We may safely anticipate a brilliant and fashionable attendance to-night. On Wednesday "Faust" will be repeated. The manager intends, after a few more performances, to close the Academy, in order that the regular forces may devote themselves exclusively to the proper rehearsal of MEYERBEER'S "Huguenots." which will be produced as the concluding attraction of the Spring Season. Visitors, therefore, would do well to remember that their chances of hearing Mr. MARETZEK's company are but few.

abstract: TERESA CARRENO's PRIVATE MUSICAL SOIREE. -- On Saturday evening we attended a very select and elegant private musical entertainment, given by this wonderfully gifted child pianist. The interval of some months since her last performance has been diligently employed in improving her physique and perfecting her already almost unrivaled powers of execution. It certainly is no discredit to our best and most matured artists to assume that few, if any of them, excel in delicacy of touch and grasp of conception this infant, scarcely ten years of age. We can well imagine how, by mechanical drill and incessant laborious application, a child even of that age may achieve flippant rapidity of scale movement, and even a ready and remarkably superficial brilliancy of execution, but in TERESA CARRENO we see a precociously learned thoughtfulness of style that cannot be taught, and will not be drowned in the most terrific application of forte, and which Mme. DE STAEL ascribes as the specialty of the German musical mind. But in TERESA CARRENO this underlying gift is relieved and alternated by that sympathetic vivacity which belongs to her sex and her childhood, and which enlivens the deeper moods of her inspiration, and popularizes their brooding German tendencies. This union of the thoughtful and the spirited goes to make up BURKE's definition of genius, when he calls it the freshness and enthusiasm of childhood, carried into the thoughtfulness and maturity of manhood.
lead_paragraph: TERESA CARRENO's PRIVATE MUSICAL SOIREE. -- On Saturday evening we attended a very select and elegant private musical entertainment, given by this wonderfully gifted child pianist. It certainly is no discredit to our best and most matured artists to assume that few, if any of them, excel in delicacy of touch and grasp of conception this infant, scarcely ten years of age. We can well imagine how, by mechanical drill and incessant laborious application, a child even of that age may achieve flippant rapidity of scale movement, and even a ready and remarkably superficial brilliancy of execution, but in TERESA CARRENO we see a precociously learned thoughtfulness of style that cannot be taught, and will not be drowned in the most terrific application of forte, and which Mme. DE STAEL ascribes as the specialty of the German musical mind. But in TERESA CARRENO this underlying gift is relieved and alternated by that sympathetic vivacity which belongs to her sex and her childhood, and which enlivens the deeper moods of her inspiration, and popularizes their brooding German tendencies. This union of the thoughtful and the spirited goes to make up BURKE's definition of genius, when he calls it the freshness and enthusiasm of childhood, carried into the thoughtfulness and maturity of manhood.

abstract: In the Senate, Saturday, the Soldiers' Voting Bill was taken up and made the special order for Tuesday next. Among the bills passed was the Albany Bridge bill; and a bill to amend the charter of the Home Insurance Company of NewYork, A bill was introduced authorizing the Brooklyn authorities to raise money for an armory in the Eastern Districts. The New-York Court-house Bill was recommitted to amend it by providing that the accounts shall be approved by the architect of the building. The bill, as amended, was then passed.

abstract: The exhibition by the pupils of the Public Schools of the Seventeenth ward, in aid of the Sanitary Commission, came off at Cooper Institute on Thursday evening, 7th inst., and was in all respects one of the best that has been given this season.
lead_paragraph: The exhibition by the pupils of the Public Schools of the Seventeenth ward, in aid of the Sanitary Commission, came off at Cooper Institute on Thursday evening, 7th inst., and was in all respects one of the best that has been given this season. The exercises commenced at 7 1/2 O'CLOCK, and concluded at 11, without the least interruption or mistake, and the audience frequently expressed their pleasure and satisfaction by hearty applause.

abstract: Tax Levy; Explanation by Aldermen
lead_paragraph: In the discussion which has arisen in regard to the Tax Levy, the Aldermen thus explain their action. By ordinance, the Comptroller is directed to submit the Budget to the Common Council on the 1st November. This year it was found impossible to submit until Jan. 15. It was then sent to the printers, where, between corrections and the necessary delay, it was detained until about the 28th February, when it was again placed in the hands of the Board of Aldermen. On the 9th March the Finance Commute reported the Budget substantially the same as received from the Comptroller, and it was passed on the 11th. The Comptroller had reduced the amount called for by the different Departments over one million and a half of dollars, and the Board of Aldermen reduced appropriations to sundry Departments and Commissions, as submitted by him, nearly $200,000. But certain additions were made by the Board for matters deemed of special importance, such as $100,000 for the improving of the Russ pavement; $40,000 for a parade ground, recommended by the Mayor and Special Committee of the Common Council; $40,000 for resetting monument stones, and $100,000 for reception of regiments and burial of soldiers. The 20th March was the last day for presentation to the Legislature; the Board of Councilmen had prepared amendments making appropriations from the departments far in excess of what the Aldermen would assent to, and all efforts to induce them to unite on the Aldermanic budget failing,they ceased to be consulted, and it was forwarded to Albany. In regard to the non-submission to the Mayor, it is stated that the matter of doing so was discussed, but it was known that he would return it with his objections, and therefore to avoid a delay which might prove fatal, it was not presented to him.

abstract: Counsel and Comfort from a City Pulpit; Ten Acres Enough
snippet: Counsel and Comfort from a City Pulpit; Ten Acres Enough
lead_paragraph: The promise of the title is well performed in the execution of this excellent little book. There is an air of good sense and simplicity about the author that recommends strongly to the reader this story of his experience. He has something to tell, and he tells it clearly and without affectation. Though at this present moment he is not likely to meet with many willing listeners -- if all auguries are true -- the time may return when the details here set forth will afford hope and consolation to those who may find themselves in like circumstances with the writer, Ten Acres Enough will naturally be compared with another recent book, My Farm at Edgewood, equally good and true in its way, but representing an opposite end of the agricultural scale; one giving the experience of a gentleman farmer who employs means derived from other sources in the improvement and embellishment of a favorite site, satisfied if the outlay returns a small interest on the capital expended; the other, "one of that numerous band of patient tollers in city, town and village, who have struggled on from year to year, anxious to break away from the bondage of the desk, the counter or the workshop, to realize in the country even a moderate income, so that it be a sure one." Harassed almost to death, and his business prospects destroyed by the rapid succession of commercial "crises" and "revulsions," the writer in 1855 converted his stock into cash; and after settling up his affairs, found himself, with a wife and six children, in possession of four thousand dollars -- "the net gain of many years of most laborious toil." Half this sum secured him, by good fortune, the possession of a garden farm, within a few miles of Philadelphia, near a railroad that opened to him the markets of that city and of New-York. The raising of fruit and vegetables for these great centres of consumption was the business he devoted himself to, and the energy and success with which it it was pursued in the subject matter of the book. The statement of annual cash profits for the first three years may be given as a specimen of the information conveyed in the work, where each item of outlay and profit is separately enumerated. The result was. First year's net gain, after deducting all expenses, $336; second year's gain, $1,025 05; third year's gain, $1,327 02, without reckoning the portion of the family's support derived from the farm. The author says:

abstract: -Yesterday afternoon, at about three o'clock, as a squad of recruits, in charge of Capt. KEELEY, were passing down Broadway, one of them, named MICHAEL WATERS, who had enlisted at Albany, under the assumed name of MCGOWAN, attempted to escape, and ran into Broad-street, followed by Capt. KEELEY and Sergts. O'HARA and WILLIAMSON, who ordered him to stop. WATERS paid no attention, and kept on his flight up New-street into Exchange-place. Near the corner of Broad-street he was overtaken by the officers, who fired their revolvers, a shot from one of them entering the back of WATERS' head, coming out under his eye, causing his immediate death. The body was conveyed to the First Precinct station-house, where it now awaits coroner's action. The Captain and the sergeants are also detained until after the action of a coroner's jury. The soldier shot, to-night, was a member of the One Hundred and seventieth New-York, just recruited.

abstract: A highly important General Order has been issued from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, which is intended to clear the decks generally for active operations. All civilians, sutlers and their employes, are ordered to the rear by the 16th.
lead_paragraph: A highly important General Order has been issued from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, which is intended to clear the decks generally for active operations. All civilians, sutlers and their employes, are ordered to the rear by the 16th. Members of the Sanitary or Christian Commissions, and registered newspaper correspondents only, can remain. All property for which there is no transportation, also goes to the rear, and the authority of Corps Commanders to grant furloughs is revoked, and none to be granted save in extreme cases, or in case of reenlisted veterans.

abstract: Railroads, Underground The, at Albany
lead_paragraph: The defeat of the Underground Railroad in the Legislature, coupled as it was with the rejection of Mayor GUNTHER'S proposition to compel the street railroads to pay ten per cent of their receipts to the City Treasury, is a fresh and alarming illustration of the enor mous power over our property and comfort which is now wielded by the omnibus proprietors, railroad corporations and political jobbers. The Legislature on which we have been in the habit of relying, seems to have surrendered itself completely to their hands. No remonstrance, or protest, or expression of opinion from the public seems to have the slightest influence in preventing the sanction of every fraud or imposition which any board of speculators in the City may take it into their heads to attempt. The facility with which charters have for some time been granted to proprietors of street railroads, without the exaction of a single guarantee for either their responsibility or good faith, has been scandalous enough, but it is hard to find an epithet strong enough to characterize the indifference to public comfort and decency evinced in the resolute and steady refusal to enact a single clause for the regulation of the conveyances to be run under the grants -- their size, cleanliness, number of passengers, and times of running. The streets are handed over remorselessly to hordes of speculators, and they are left to work their placers with a single eye to their own profit, which is enormous. The taxation has reached a point which threatens the whole property of the City with depreciation, and seems not unlikely before very long to drive business away to other parts; the poor are suffering severely from the consequent high rents and high prices of clothing and provisions, and yet it is impossible to secure the sanction of the Albany legislators to a measure so eminently just and expedient as the levy of a tax of ten per cent. upon the receipts of the companies who have obtained the monopoly of our streets, and are reaping enormous gains from carrying us up and down on them in cattle-boxes. As soon as anything likely to interfere with their profits is proposed, they rush up to Albany, and though these operators are never visible, we see the result in after days in the tabling of the obnoxious bill.

abstract: New-York Sanitary Fair Art Gallery
lead_paragraph: The exhibition of works of art in the spacious galleries of the Sanitary Fair, in Fourteenth-street, is, beyond all comparison, the most extensive, the most choice and the most elegantly arranged that has ever been seen in New York City. It comprises nearly four hundred oil paintings, including specimens of almost every American artist of note, together with a very large number of the works of distinguished foreign painters, some of which are of great excellence, and which are rarely or never seen away from the galleries of their princely owners. Objects of great pecuniary value, they have been intrusted to the dangerous keeping of the fair, with a sacrificing liberality that deserves the warmest commendations of all lovers of art. The private galleries of the wealthiest collectors of New-York and vicinity have been liberally drawn upon to enrich this collection; and it now stands a superb monument of the art wealth of our metropolis, and a school in which the student at a glance can trace the progress of art in his own country, and compare it with the finest examples of the Old World.

abstract: Red River versus the Rapidan Army
snippet: Red River versus the Rapidan Army
lead_paragraph: -- OUR GREAT ARMY OH THE RED. Not a few men and women may be supposed to be cudgeling their brains about this time, to see if they cannot strike out some light concerning the meaning of the extensive military manoeuvres going on in Western Louisiana. Beside the heavy force, military and naval, which Gen. SMITH took down the Mississippi and up the Red River, capturing Fort De Russey and pushing on to Natchitoches, we have had news that Gen. BANKS, with a very large cavalry force and a small infantry accompaniment, had passed up once more through the deserted Opelousas country, and was trying to effect a junction with SMITH, when he was attacked by the rebels on Cane River. In addition to these two columns on the Red River, or trying to get there, we are informed by our correspondent with the Army of the Frontier, that eight regiments and a battery, under Gen. THAYER, left Fort Smith, Arkansas, on the 21st ult., destined also for the Red River; and this body was to be joined in Southern Arkansas by a fourth army, from Little Rock, under Gen. STEELE, who was also bound for Red River. The entire force of these four armies, when combined, will, we understand, number about forty thousand men.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WADE, from the Committee on the Conduct of the War, made a report, with evidence in the case, in relation to the late military expedition into Florida, which was ordered to be printed. He submitted a resolution, also, for printing 5,000 extra copies. The Senate considered the Naval Appropriation Bill, with the amendments as reported from the Finance Committee, the most important of which strikes out an appropriation of $520,000 for the purpose of building floating dry-docks for monitors at the New-York and Philadelphia Navy-yards. The amendments were all concurred in with the above exception.

In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council met yesterday. Both boards adopted an ordinance providing that all disputed questins of elections in fire companies shall be referred to the Commissioners of the Fire Department, who shall examine and decide them, and whose decision shall be final. The Board of Aldermen adopted the resolution to present a stand of colors to the Eightyfourth Regiment N.Y.N.G. The Council Board laid it over under the rule.
lead_paragraph: Both Boards of the Common Council met yesterday. Both boards adopted an ordinance providing that all disputed questins of elections in fire companies shall be referred to the Commissioners of the Fire Department, who shall examine and decide them, and whose decision shall be final. The Board of Aldermen adopted the resolution to present a stand of colors to the Eightyfourth Regiment N.Y.N.G. The Council Board laid it over under the rule. A resolution previously adopted by the Aldermen, to widen the avenue across the Park, in front of the City Hall, twenty-five feet, for the benefit of military parades and reviews, the Councilmen discussed as to its wording, which appeared to be peculiar and somewhat indefinite, and finally referred it to the Committee on National Affairs. The Mayor sent a veto message to the Councilmen on bills of CONKLIN & BUTTS, for carriage hire, his objection being that they were not verified by affidavit. Both boards adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. next Monday.

abstract: Fair
lead_paragraph: The success of the Fair as a purely fiscal auxiliary of the Sanitary Commission, is fully established. It does not need a statement in detail from the Treasurer to prove that the contributions in money and in goods exceed the most sanguine hopes of its promoters. It is not premature, then, to ask, as we do with the utmost deference to the management, whether there is any element yet wanting to what may be called a perfect success? We hear, for instance, with a mixed feeling of pleasure and disappointment that, with admission fees exceeding in the aggregate $2 for a single visit to the different departments of the fair, the building is yet crowded to excess on each successive day. From this simple fact we gather a sure intimation that the visitors, thus far, have been mainly, almost exclusively we may say, the well-to-do people of the City, or, peradventure, still better dressed folks from the surrounding country.

abstract: -- The State Senate at Albany, yesterday, had the good sense not to agree to the report of the Committee on Railroads, which would have defeated this vitally necessary measure, and the report will come up in Committee of the Whole, where the merits of the project will be fully discussed. Senators, it seems, expressed the opinion that "the project was purely chimerical," in which opinion they differ greatly from the capitalists avd property-holders of New-York. We should not wonder if they were the same fogies who laughed at FULTON when he built his steamboats.

abstract: The Czar's Proclamation of Emancipation in; the Czar's Proclamation of Emancipation in Poland
snippet: The Czar's Proclamation of Emancipation in; the Czar's Proclamation of Emancipation in Poland
lead_paragraph: The middle of this month will witness in Europe another of those grand events which, like the President's Proclamation of Emancipation in America, are to make these years forever illustrious in history. On the 15th of April, by a recent ukase of the Czar, every serf in Russian Poland is to be at once and forever set free from all bondage. He is to own the cottage and the plot of ground which he has been occupying, his time and labor are to be his own, and he is liberated from all claims to service and obligations of labor which his master may have possessed over him. For this great emancipation, he has only to pay to the Government a tax, by which "loyal masters" are to be remunerated. More than this, the Polish serf is to become at once a self-governing citizen. He is to elect his own village officials, his mayor, and sheriff, and justice of the peace -- a privilege which Prussia has never yet granted to the Prussian Poles.
headline: {'main': "The Czar's Proclamation of Emancipation in Poland The Epoch of Liberty.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Czar's Proclamation of Emancipation in Poland The Epoch of Liberty.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Western Metropolis from Port Royal April 9, we have later news from the Department of the South. On the morning of the 1st inst. the transport-steamer Maple Leaf, while passing down the St. John's River, from Pilatka to Jacksonville, Fla., ran on ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Western Metropolis from Port Royal April 9, we have later news from the Department of the South. On the morning of the 1st inst. the transport-steamer Maple Leaf, while passing down the St. John's River, from Pilatka to Jacksonville, Fla., ran on a rebel torpedo, which exploded and sunk the vessel. The steamer, cargo and five of the crew (colored) were lost. Among the cargo was the camp and garrison equipage of three regiments, and those on board lost all their effects, among which was $20,000 worth of sutler's stores. An expedition up the river, soon afterward, captured and sent down to Jacksonville several of the torpedoes. The United States bark Kingfisher, which had been on blockade duty off Otter Island, coast of Florida, for fifteen months, had been blown ashore and wrecked. The vessel will be a loss, but her armament was saved. A recent reconnoissance from Jacksonville, by Col. HENRY, discovered the rebels in force six miles out of Jacksonville. Skirmishing ensued, in which the rebels lost thirty killed and wounded; our loss, only four wounded. There was nothing new in the fleet. It was the opinion in naval circles that Admiral DAHLGREN would not return to the command of the Blockading Squadron.

abstract: Mr. JOHN SCOTT RUSSELL, the originator of the "wave line" theory of ship building, to whom are due most of the scientific formula that have placed on a sure basis the art of naval construction, ...
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. JOHN SCOTT RUSSELL, the originator of the "wave line" theory of ship building, to whom are due most of the scientific formula that have placed on a sure basis the art of naval construction, has in preparation a large and expensive work that is expected to be ready in the course of the present year, entitled, The Modern System of Naval Architecture for Commerce and War. It will comprise three divisions: Part I. -- Naval Design; Part II. -- Practical Shipbuilding; Part III. -- Steam Navigation. No more copies will be issued than are subscribed for, and the steel and copper plates will be destroyed, so as to insure at once the absorption of the entire impression, which cannot be reproduced, and the work is thus effectually secured from ever falling in price.

abstract: not Employed in Government Department
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Vice-President laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Treasury, in reply to a call for information as to the amount of money expended and the number of men employed to carry out the act for the collection of direct taxes in the insurrectionary districts. The Secretary submits a tabular statement giving all the information required. Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill for the establishment of a Bureau of Freedmen's Affairs, providing for the appointment of a Commissioner, with a salary of $4,000, and two clerks of each class. The bill for a State Government for Nebraska was taken up, but after discussion laid over. The Senate proceeded to the consideration of the Naval Appropriation Bill. An amendment was adopted changing the location of the Naval School from Newport to Annapolis, after the year 1865. Mr. POWELL offered an amendment to repeal the bounties given to vessels engaged in cod or other bank fisheries, which led to an excited debate between himself and Mr. CHANDLER. The amendment was lost by a tie vote. The Senate adjourned till Thursday.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Virginia at this port, yesterday, we have three days later news from Europe -- to March 30. The steamship City of New-York, which arrived off Queenstown on the 29th, struck on Daunt's Rock when rounding Cork Head, and the latest dispatches report that she will prove a complete wreck. GARIBALDI was expected at Southampton on the 2d of April, and great preparations had been made to receive him. The Queen of England has officially announced her intention to hold a court at Buckingham Palace April 6, at which Her Majesty will receive the principal members of the Diplomatic Corps; and a second court on the 13th of April, to which a limited number of distinguished persons will be invited. Political affairs in England during the Parliamentary recess were quite unimportant. The allies had made an attempt to take the fortified position of Duppel by storm, but were repulsed, after five hours fighting. The Danish loss was one hundred killed and wounded. It was stated that the Conference on the Danish question would begin in London on the 12th of April. It was stated that on the ground of difficulties which have arisen as to the presumptive succession to the Austrian throne, the Archduke MAXIMILIAN has deferred the reception of the Mexican notables who were deputed to request his acceptance of the Mexican Crown.

abstract: On Monday evening Sergeant POLLEY, of the Twenty-first Police Precinct, was attacked by a gang of desperadoes, at Third-avenue and Thirty-third-street, while he was on duty. They beat him with clubs and stones and fired a revolver at him. He drew his revolver and fired three times at his assailants, fatally wounding, it is supposed, JAMES SPENCER alias "Jigger," and severely wounding "Bully Mahon." Sergeant POLLEY was severely injured and greatly disfigured. The desperadoes are said to be members of Engine Company No. 12. None are yet arrested.

abstract: Taylor, >amp;c. vs. Hutton, >amp;c. Fourth National Bank Case
snippet: Taylor, >amp;c. vs. Hutton, >amp;c. Fourth National Bank Case
lead_paragraph: Robert L. Taylor et al. vs. Benjamin H. Hutton et al. PECKHAM, J. This is substantially an application for the continuance of an injunction to prevent the alleged illegal removal of the President of the Fourth National Bank, threatened by two-thirds of the directors, defendants herein. It is charged in the complaint that the defendants entered into a combination shortly after the election of the President. to "drive him from his office, with the view of putting a more pliable person in his place, and using the funds of the bank to aid in stock operations, instead of employing them in legitimate commercial and banking operations." The suit is commenced by two of the directors and two stockholders of the bank, the President not being a party.

abstract: Yesterday, the eighth day of the Fair, was like the previous day, in the morning very unpleasant. This, however, did not deter the people from coming, and the attendance was fully as good as usual. lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the eighth day of the Fair, was like the previous day, in the morning very unpleasant. This, however, did not deter the people from coming, and the attendance was fully as good as usual. About 2 o'clock the sky cleared up, and from that time till the close of the fair, the buildings were crowded. It seems as though nothing can weaken the interest taken by the people in this great fair. Day after day it is crowded to its utmost, and day after day the immense crowds of visitors go away, satisfied that in one day they cannot half see its beauties, and determined to pay it another visit. All the departments and stands were very well patronized, and the lady attendants in consequence were as happy and smiling as little fairies.

abstract: The Inman steamer Etna, from Liverpool March 30, and Queentown, March 31, arrived at this port yesterday, The steamer Peruvian, from Liverpool March 31 and Londonderry April 1, was reported at Portland, thus bringing two days' later news. The latest dispatches via Queenstown concerning the steamship City of New-York, are to the effect that she will undoubtedly prove a total wreck. But the Captain of the Etna reports that the ship was lying easy and being lighted, and would undoubtedly be floated off. There had been no further fighting before Duppel. The loss in the terrible fight reported by the previous steamer are contemptibly small, and prove it to have been a very small affair. The Conference was certainly to be opened in London on the 12th of April. It was reported that Austria, Russia, France, Prussia and Denmark had accepted it. The Court of Assize of the Seine, France, sitting without a jury, has condemned MAZZINI by contumacy to transportation, for participating in the conspiracy against the life of the Emperor. The latest dispatches report that it was asserted that negotiations between the Archduke MAXIMILIAN and the Emperor of Austria had terminated favorably. The health of His Holiness, the Pope, was much improved.
