abstract: Grant, Lieut.-Gen., Report of his Last Victory
snippet: Grant, Lieut.-Gen., Report of his Last Victory
lead_paragraph: Gen.GRANT'S later official reports differ from his earlier ones in somewhat the same kind and degree that his later operations differ from his earlier ones. Those who have in mind his first essays in military chronicling will remember in them something of the same crudity that marked his first battles. The report which we to-day present of the grand series of operations in Tennessee exhibits, on the contrary, the same calm, incisive, mature manipulation that characterized the combinations that drove BRAGG, broken and routed, from before Chattanooga.

abstract: We have important news from Kentucky this morning. The robel forces under the ubiquitous FORREST have again turned up, and yesterday made a simultaneous attack on Fort Halleck, at Columbus, Ky., and on Fort Pillow, some distance below on the river, in Tennessee. The
lead_paragraph: We have important news from Kentucky this morning. The robel forces under the ubiquitous FORREST have again turned up, and yesterday made a simultaneous attack on Fort Halleck, at Columbus, Ky., and on Fort Pillow, some distance below on the river, in Tennessee. The attack on Columbus was by the rebel Gen. BUFORD, who first sent a demand for a surrender, which was refused by Col. LAWRENCE, of the Thirty-fourth New-Jersey, in command of the post. The women and children had all been sent away. BUFORD, in his demand for a surrender, said he could guarantee no quarter to the black troops, even after they got in his possession. The fortunate arrival of three thousand veterans going home on furlough, however, would somewhat interfere with the rebel arrangements. The attack on Fort Pillow was going on all day during the 12th; and when the steamer passed a flag of truce was visible, though fighting was afterward resumed.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBELLION', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBELLION', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the following bills were passed: Amending the charter of the Port Morris Land Improvement Company; extending the time for the completion of the South side Railroad; authorizing the construction of storage reservoirs in Croton River; the Soldier's Voting
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday the following bills were passed: Amending the charter of the Port Morris Land Improvement Company; extending the time for the completion of the South Side Railroad; authorizing the construction of storage reservoirs in Croton River; the Soldier's Voting Bill was passed by 29 yaes, no nays; empowering the New-York Infirmary for Indigent Women to confer the title of M.D. A communication was received from Gen. DIX, relative to the imprisonment of HAWLEY D. CLAPP, stating that CLAPP is under arrest for being implicated in the most atrocious frauds upon recruits at Lafayette Hall, he being the chief bounty-broker. Gen. DIX states the amount of such frauds to be $400,000. The Supply Bill was considered during the afternoon session.

abstract: Sub-Treasurer, and the Hunter Fraud Case
snippet: Sub-Treasurer, and the Hunter Fraud Case
lead_paragraph: -- Confidence in one's own judgment is a very excellent thing, in spite of the fact that it sometimes leads to a degree of dogmatism that seems very much like arrogance. Our excellent Sub-Treasurer, Mr. CISCO, in some testimonywhich he gave the other day as to the genuineness of the signature to a check whichhad been paid at his office, carried this confidence to an extent that would seem, to saythe least, a little dangerous. He swore thatthe signature was genuine -- that it was impossible for him to be deceived as to the handwriting of Mr. HUNTER, whose name was signed to the check -- that the opinions of anynumber of experts on the subject would not in the least shake his confidence in his own -that Mr. HUNTER's sworn statement would not affect it, -- and that if a man should turn State's evidence and swear that he forged the signature, Mr. CISCO would not believe him.This certainly is a very strong statement, -- so strong as inevitably to suggest a suspicion that Mr. CISCO must have some very strong motive for proclaiming, under oath and with such extraordinary emphasis, his belief in the absolute infallibility of his own judgment in a matter concerning which, as everybody knows, the most skillful men in the world are constantly misled.

abstract: Police, Increase of Salaries
lead_paragraph: -- We hope the Legislature will not overlook the bill now before them authorizing an increase in the salaries of the members of the police force in this City. They are entitled to it by every consideration of justice, and they certainly need it quite as much as any other portion of our fellow-citizens. We know that the increase, though not large for each person, still amounts to a large sum in the aggregate; but the City is willing to pay liberally those who really serve and protect its interests with fidelity and success. We hope the bill will receive the prompt and favorable action of the Legislature.

abstract: The trial of DANIEL BROOKS, the negro indicted for the murder of WILLIAM SMITH, a barkeeper in MCKINLEY's saloon on South-street, was continued yesterday. The entire day was occupied in examining the witnesses for the defence. Several of these who were with BROOKS when the shooting took place, testified that SMITH, the deceased, threw three tumblers at BROOKS and his friends, one of which hit the prisoner; that SMITH then tried to push prisoner out of the room, and kicked him several times. SMITH had an ice-pick in his hand when he struck BROOKS.

abstract: Why will not the City authorities pull up the hideous little posts stuck up over the Park, like pins on a cribbage board? They are neither useful nor ornamental, and only help to disfigure still further what is quite ugly enough for all practical purposes already. Besides, they divert the attention of strangers who are admirers of art from the statue of WASHINGTON. Let the poor have them for firewood.

abstract: The Captain of the Inman steamship Etna, just arrived from the scene of the accident to the City of New-York, reports that she is lying fast on Daunt's Rock, just outside Queenstown Harbor, and that there is every probability that the vessel will be got off again safely. The fore and after compartments are uninjured, and nothing but a gale of wind from the southeast can do her any harm. Every effort is being made to lighten her and float her off, so as to set her inside Queenstown Harbor.

abstract: In the Senate, yeaterday, 5,000 copies of the report of the Committee on the Conduct of the War, in reference to the late Florida expedition, were ordered printed. A bill to regulate commercial intercourse in insurrectionary States was introduced. The resolutions of the Legislature of the State of New-York, asking that troops who served honorably two years may be entitled to receive the $100 bounty, were presented by Mr. MORGAN. Mr. WADE called up the bill to enable the people of Nebraska to form a Constitution and State Government, which was passed. The Naval Appropriation Bill was called up, and after sundry minor amendments it was passed. Mr. SHERMAN reported a bill from the Finance Committee, to restrict speculation in gold coin, bullion and foreign exchange. The bill prohibits sales on time, or in any place except the actual place of business of the dealer, and upon no terms save those of actual delivery of the coin sold.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yeaterday, 5,000 copies of the report of the Committee on the Conduct of the War, in reference to the late Florida expedition, were ordered printed. abstract: The Lincoln Association held its regular meeting at Hope Chapel last evening. The attendance was not numerous, and the proceedings were informal. Dr. SHEPPARD remarked that he favored the reelection of Mr. LINCOLN, because he thought it the most prudent and safe course amid the perils that were upon the country -- it was, in fact, the reelection of Gen. GRANT as Commander of our armies. Our military organization was, with Gen. GRANT at the head, the very best we could have. He believed the President and Gen. GRANT understood each other; and that Gen. GRANT would not permit himself to be made a political candidate until the war was over. Any change from our present arrangements would most likely be for the worse.

abstract: Gold, early yesterday, was at a premium of 89; but in the course of the day Mr. CHASE, having come to town, took a walk down through Wall-street, and it at once tumbled till it reached 75. If such was the effect of Mr. CHASE's perambulating down Wall-street, we think he had better stay in town permanently, and take a walk among the bulls and bears every morning. Gold would possibly soon be at par -- who knows?

abstract: The
lead_paragraph: -- This is the day on which the draft was appointed to take place throughout the country, under the President's March call for troops. It is postponed as usual we suppose on account of the weather. It will now positively take place on the first of May very positively. That being "moving day," it will furnish an excellent opportunity to catch recusant conscripts when they are out of doors.

abstract: The Example of England
lead_paragraph: In the day of England's trouble the Government firmly pursued the policy of providing for the current, expenditure by adequate concurrent taxation. Of the total revenue of the period of war with NAPOLEON and with the United States, about seventy per cent. was raised by the annual taxes, and the remaining thirty per cent. by loans, permanent and temporary. In the year 1815, the ratio was still higher; the expenditures reached five hundred and fifty-five millions of dollars, of which, not more than one hundred and ninety millions were raised by loans, or as three by taxes to two by loans. Specie payments had been been suspended for 18 years, and gold was at a premium of from 30 to 41 1/2 per cent. for three consecutive years. Is it wonderful that gold in our money market should command so high a premium as its range for some months back, while our revenue is raised at the rate of but one-sixth from taxes and five-sixths from loans? Need we look' further for the cause of the condition of our money market, than the prolonged delay and the manifest hesitation of Congress to call upon the ample resources of the country for a contribution fairly proportioned to the outlay demanded by the sustenance of our vast forces in the field? In the face of such irresolution and postponement as the present Congress has shown, the credit of the Government is a marvel, and the gold price of its demand notes is anything but a marvel.

abstract: It seems that MAXIMILIAN has now a new trouble about his Mexican crown, and there has consequently been another postponement in his acceptance of it. The ceremony of offering the thing to him was to be gone through with on Easter Sunday, by the so-called Mexican notables; but in the meantime difficulties arose as to the presumptive succession to the Austrian throne. So we are again on the tenters as to the day of his emigration. It is a solemn thing to give advice to emperors or imperial aspirants; but we might advise MAXIMILIAN that it would be well for his neck if he could create sufficient trouble on the question of the Austrian succession to detain him forever in Austria.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- GOUNOD's opera of "Faust" will be given here to-night for the last time but one. Mr. MARETZEK intends closing the Academy next week in order to devote himself and forces to the first performance and rehearsal of MEYERBEER's greatest work, "Les Huguenots." It may not be out of place to intimate mildly to the public that the prices of admission will be slightly increased for the next performances -- we mean those commencing with the "Huguenots." Those who would pay little and hear much should go to the "Faust" or "Robert le Diable" performances.

abstract: -The meeting of the Citizens' Association convened last evening, at No. 206 Eighth-avenue, was largely attended. The President, Mr. LE GRAND LOCKWOOD, being absent, Mr. B.L. SOLOMON presided. The object of the meeting was to hear the report of the delegation sent to Albany "to oppose the passage by the Legislature of the Tax Bill of the City and County of New-York." Mr. SOLOMON, as Chairman of the Committee, made a brief report. He stated as the result of the labors of the committee that over $2,000,000 had been saved to the tax-payers of the City. At the conclusion of Mr. SOLOMON's remarks, it was moved and seconded that the committee's report be adopted. The motion was carried unanimously. It was further moved that the committee be "continued." The motion was carried without a dissenting voice. After some further business of minor importance the meeting adjourned.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Creole, at this port yesterday, we have New-Orleans advices to April 6th, though the news has been mostly anticipated via Cairo. Admiral FARRAGUT was in the city. The Era stated that the Liberals, under CORTINAS, had defeated VIDUARRI at Monterey, Mexico. French war-vessels were taking soundings at the mouth of the Rio Grande. CORTINAS had returned to Matamoras, and expressed his determination to defend it to the last extremity.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Creole, at this port yesterday, we have New-Orleans advices to April 6th, though the news has been mostly anticipated via Cairo. Admiral FARRAGUT was in the city. The Era stated that the Liberals, under CORTINAS, had defeated VIDUARRI at Monterey, Mexico. French war-vessels were taking soundings at the mouth of the Rio Grande. CORTINAS had returned to Matamoras, and expressed his determination to defend it to the last extremity. A force had been sent to Bagdad, at the mouth of the Rio Grande, to oppose the French and throw up defensive works. Ten thousand bales of cotton had been ferried over the river at Eagle Pass within a month, and were being hauled down to Matamoras for shipment. Eagle Pass is now in our possession and this trade is stopped.

abstract: Detective Officer DEVOY, of the Astor House arrested, Saturday afternoon, a noted hotel thief, named BENJAMIN GRAIG. The culprit had been loitering about the establishment for several hours, when the attention of the officer being drawn toward him, a close watch was kept upon his movements. The result was, about 4 o'clock, GRAIG picked up a carpet-bag belonging to one of the guests, and while he was in the act of carrying it off, was taken into custody by the officer, and conveyed to the Sixth Ward Station-house.

abstract: The steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall, April 5, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing the California mails of March 23, and $269,000 in specie. The news from the Pacific coast is unimportant. The fear of war between Chili and Bolivia on the boundary question did not perturb matters much in those countries. A party of engineers, under direction of HENRY MEIGGS, Esq., the eminent railroad builder, had discovered a new and practicable pass through the Andes, in the State of Peru, which would admit of the construction of a railroad with no heavier grades to be overcome than those on which steam is already used in Peru. Capt. PYM's British railroad project has been accepted by the Government of Nicaragua. Mr. DICKINSON, the American Minister to Nicaragua, is to have a conference of all the Ministers in the Central American States from the United States, for the purpose of having them unite in a protest against the French occupation of Mexico, after the style of the Ostend manifesto.

abstract: The steamship Asia arrived at Halifax, yesterday, with two days' later news. The latest advices from the wrecked steamship City of New-York were more encouraging. Most of her cargo had been got out, and preparations to lift her were almost complete. If the weather remained pleasant she would soon be afloat again. The rebel cruiser Georgia is refitting in the Gironne, not being allowed to anchor in front of Bordeaux, in consequence of the port regulations excluding ships with powder on board. The correspondence between Secretary SEWARD and Lord LYONS, in the Chesapeake case, had been published. Both parties express gratification at the amicable settlement of the matter. In regard to the Mexican question, several French journals assert that the difficulty relative to the departure of MAXIMILIAN for Mexico will shortly be arranged. The Prussians had laid regular siege to Duppel. They opened their first parallel on the night of the 29th of March, without resistance from the Danes. The London Times gives partial credit to the report of an extensive attempt to revolt among the Hungarian troops arrayed against Denmark. The Austrian army broke up from before Fredericca in an unaccountable manner, and the disaffection of the troops may have been the cause. There was a report of a wholesale execution of Hungarian troops in consequence. The conference had been finally accepted by all parties, and hopes were entertained that it might lead to a settlement of all disputes, unless passions were too much inflamed by events transpiring before Duppel.

abstract: Congress met nineteen weeks ago. Gold, which is the only real barometer of national credit and public confidence, then sold fiftytwo per cent. over the money of the Government. It now sells at seventy-four per cent. over. What has been the cause of this weakening of the national credit? Not disaster in...
lead_paragraph: Congress met nineteen weeks ago. Gold, which is the only real barometer of national credit and public confidence, then sold fiftytwo per cent. over the money of the Government. It now sells at seventy-four per cent. over. What has been the cause of this weakening of the national credit? Not disaster in the field. We have had none. Not any loss of our military strength. Our armies have never been stronger than to-day. Not any new strength of the rebellion. It has gained nothing. Not any fear of foreign intervention. Foreign intervention was never less feared than to-day. Not any diminution of the resources of the North. Northern industry was never so active or so profitable. What, then, is the cause of it? The cause is to be found in the south wing of the National Capitol -- there and nowhere else. It lies in the flagrant unfaithfulness of those who were sent there to be the Representatives of the people.

abstract: Cavalry Action at of 14th N. Y. Cavalry
snippet: Cavalry Action at of 14th N. Y. Cavalry
lead_paragraph: Pensacola advices report a fight between Capt. SCHMIDT, Company M, Fourteenth New-York Cavalry, and fifty rebels, under Maj. RANDOLPH, of the Sixth Alabama Cavalry, near that place. After a ten minutes' hand-to-hand fight the rebels fled. Their loss was fifteen killed and wounded and eleven prisoners. Our loss was three slightly wounded, including Lieut. VON LUGERECKE.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, among the bills reported were the following: To provide an armory for the Eighth Regiment National Guard; against the bill relative to the West Shore Railroad in Rockland County; in favor of the Assembly bill to regulate the passenger and freight tariff on the Hudson River Railroad. Among the bills passed were the following: Providing for the extension of the Chenango Canal, and appropriating $150,000 for the present year; for the improvement of the Champlain Canal. This appropriates $65,000.

abstract: -- Mr. GEORGE TICKNOR's Life of Prescott, the historian, has met with a fitting and favorable reception from the English Press. As a beautiful specimen of the mechanical art of bookmaking, it challenges comparison with the choicest productions on foreign presses, and, as the Reader observes, "In the elegance of its exterior, not less than in the weightier matters of good feeling and good taste, the volume is a worthy counterpart of the gentle, graceful and refined existence it records."

abstract: But while we speak thus of the hideous words and deeds of the rebel butchers, we are sure there is also an account to be settled with some of our own officers in that locality. Who commands in West Tennessee? How is it that with an idle army of such magnitude, of infantry, cavalry and artillery as we have in that department, and with fortifications of such immense strength as line the Tennessee and Mississippi Rivers -- how is it that that whole country is ceaselessly traversed, trampled upon, and its inhabitants butchered by rebel bands? How is it that the guerrilla, FORREST, with a few thousand freebooters, has been allowed to ride to and fro for six weeks, capturing towns, capturing forts, and playing havoc wherever he chooses? It is the most infamous thing to our arms that has ever occurred in the course of the war. Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, who commands all our armies and every department, will doubtless at once now look after his own responsible subordinates, as well as these irresponsible rebels.

abstract: The steamer Continental, from New-Orleans on the 8th instant, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The George Washington, with New-Orleans dates to the 9th, also arrived yesterday. snippet: Maloney vs. Butterby; Bill of Lading Binding; Potts vs. Steamship W. A. Burden; Collision
lead_paragraph: Charles G. Beardsley et al. vs. The Steamboat Metamora. -- This was a libel filed by the owners of the sloop Catlin to recover the damages occasioned to her by a collision with the steamboat in the harbor of New-York. The collision happened in full day light. The sloop was going on a southwesterly course across the East River from South Ferry toward Bedloe's Island, the wind being light from the southwest by west. The steamboat was coming out of the North River into the East River, thus crossing the general line of direction which the sloop was pursuing. There was the usual conflict of testimony as to the circumstances of the collision.

abstract: Richter, Jean Paul F. Campaner Thal; Smith, Philip, B. A., History of the World, Part II
snippet: Richter, Jean Paul F. Campaner Thal; Smith, Philip, B. A., History of the World, Part II
lead_paragraph: This elegant volume is a continuation of the series undertaken by Messrs. TICKNOR FIELDS, with the object of placing the best works of RICHTER within the means and knowledge of English readers. It forms the fifth volume of the set, commencing with Mr. BROOKS'S version of "Titan;" and will be followed by a new translation of "Hesperus," so there is ground to suppose. JEAN PAUL does not lack readers and admirers among us at the present day. The contents of the volume are varied, and have the advantage of presenting the author in different moods. It opens with "The Campaner Thal," or discourses on the immortality of the soul, translated by JULIETTO BAUER. This work, which RICHTER was employed in enlarging and remodeling, when under the visitation of recent and almost total blindness at the time of his death, is pronounced to be "the life of his whole philosophy, glimpses of which look forth on us from almost every one of his writings." The two following articles are: "Life of Quintus Fixlein," and "Army Chaplain Schmelze's Journey to Hatz." The version of these works, characterized by RICHTER himself as "Portraits or little sketches of character, voluntary or involuntary comedy pieces," is by THOMAS CARLYLE, and will be remembered by all his readers as among the most remarkable attempts to transfer, not the matter only, but the manner of an author from one language to another, that has ever been made. "Ansled from Richter" and "Miscellaneous Pieces," translated by the English Opium Eater, THOMAS DE QUINCY, conclude the volume, and present us with some of JEAN PAUL's highest and brightest thoughts, interpreted by one of the greatest masters of the English language.

abstract: In one respect the recent action of the stage proprietors in raising their prices from six to ten cents has conferred a positive and very decided benefit on the riding public. The lines of omnibuses which have taken this course are no longer overcrowded. There is no more treading on people's toes, sitting involuntarily in their laps, and pitching about helter-skelter, as if the stage were a ship at sea in a high gale, for lack of seats. Every passenger now can get a seat -- and even if he has to pay something extra for it, the boon is worth having.

abstract: A. Hamilt on on; on the One Term Principle
snippet: A. Hamilt on on; on the One Term Principle
lead_paragraph: The argument for the reelection of Mr. LINCOLN, drawn from the confusion likely to be caused by a change in the Administration at present -- certainly one of the strongest that can be used -- has a good deal of light thrown upon it by the defence offered by the authors of the Federalist for the Constitutional reeligibility of the President. It appears, in fact, that it was provision for precisely such a crisis as that through which we are now passing, that the convention mainly had in view when they permitted the President to serve for more than one term. HAMILTON says, in No. 72:

abstract: There seems to be such a general feeling that there should be at least one cheap day at the fair, that I venture a suggestion how it might be arranged. When season tickets were issued it was believed that the fair would close at the end of this week; if, therefore, it is kept open a longer time, and holders of season tickets are still allowed to use them, would it not be quite just that on one day of the extra time they should not be "good" for admittance? That on that day every one should pay twenty-five cents. Ticket-holders who have probably already visited the fair many times, could surely afford to miss one day or else pay twenty-five cents extra. Thus the rooms would not be crowded with persons who go daily, and a chance would be given for the many to go once. Can you think of any other plan to give more general satisfaction? A LADY.

lead_paragraph: At the close of last year, a resolution passed both Houses of Congress, calling upon the Secretary of the Navy to communicate all official reports and dispatches and papers in the Navy Department, relating to actions in which any of the armored vessels have been engaged. Under date of the 11th inst., Secretary WELLES responds to this call in a letter accompanied by documents, embracing reports from Admiral DUPONT, Rear-Admiral PORTER, Rear-Admiral GOLDSBOROUGH, Brig.-Gen. BARNARD, Gen. HUNTER, each one of the iron-clad Captains engaged in the attack on Charleston, and many other distinguished naval and military officers and functionaries. Secretary WELLES, in his letter transmitting these documents, says:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There will be a grand matinee here to-day -- the last of the season, for Mr. MARETZEK intends closing early in the ensuing week -- at which "Robert le Diable" will be played. The entertainment is in all respects a remarkable one. Ordinarily the feeblest operas are selected for morning; performances. Here we have a three-decker carrying so many guns that even "Faust," that modern iron-clad, cannot materially injure it. The cast is admirable, and introduces four of the best members of the company in four of their best roles. If the weather be fine, we would advise our Sanitary Fair friends to include the Academy in their rounds of sight-seeing. If Mr. MARETZEK plays the opera next season, it will be at increased prices -- for the prices are to be raised after the recess. Mr. MARETZEK has discovered to his chagrin that even crowded houses do not pay at the present tariff of admission. We assured him that he would make that discovery when he first returned from Havana. Every article about the opera, from a voice to a yard of calico, has increased in price, and it is, considering the small margin at the best of times, folly to pretend, in the face of this fact, to preserve the old rates of admission.

abstract: The omnibusses of the lines which have exorbitantly raised their fare to ten cents did a small business yesterday. For once, the public seem aroused to a determination not to submit to extortion, and they shun the objectionable stages. What few people occupy them are gazed at as though weak victims or necessary ones. Meantime, the lines which have not raised are doing a thriving business, and the receipts of the different railroads have increased one-third. It is to be hoped that citizens will adhere to their determination.

abstract: Improvement in Manufacture
lead_paragraph: We have received a small pamphlet describing a new and improved method of manufacturing gas, for lighting and heating purposes, which is likely to be of marked benefit to every class of the community. It seems to be very simple in its character, and, according to the evidence furnished by experience, and the opinions of the most skillful and scientific judges, there can be no question of its practical value. It is not proposed to produce gas from any new material; bituminous coal is still used for this purpose. But at a particular stage of the manufacture a supply of hydrogen and other gases, produced by the decomposition of superheated steam introduced into a retort containing anthracite coal, is conveyed to the retorts charged in the common way with bituminous coal; and in this way, while the quality of the gas produced is decidedly improved, its cost is reduced more than twenty-five per cent. This fact rests on the testimony of Mr. JOSEPH BATTIN, who is widely known as the constructing engineer of a great number of gas-works in various sections of the country, and on the experience of the City of Elizabeth, in New-Jersey, where it has been thoroughly tested by experiment.

abstract: The Horrible Massacre by Forrest
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Cairo bring us a story almost too horrible in its details for human belief, but which comes with such directness as to leave no doubt of its truth. The attack on Fort Pillow by the rebels under FORREST, which was announced yesterday, was followed up by frequent demands for its surrender, which were refused by Major BOOTH, who commanded the fort, but while these flags were being sent FORREST took occasion to make more favorable dispositions of his forces. The flags being refused, the fight was kept up until 3 P.M., when Maj. BOOTH was killed, and the rebels, in large numbers, swarmed over the intrenchments. Immediately upon the surrender ensued a scene which baffles description. Up to that time comparatively few of our men had been killed; but, insatiate as fiends, the rebels commenced an indiscriminate butchery of the whites and blacks, including the wounded. Both white and black were bayonetted, shot or sabred; even dead bodies were horribly mutilated, and children of seven and eight years and several negro women killed in cold blood. Soldiers unable to speak from wounds were shot dead, and their bodies rolled down the banks into the river. The dead and wounded negroes were piled in heaps and burned, and several citizens who had joined our forces for protection, were killed or wounded. Out of the garrison of six hundred, only two hundred remained alive. The steamer Platte Valley came up at about half-past 3 o'clock, and was hailed by the rebels under a flag of truce. Men were sent ashore to bury the dead, and take aboard such of the wounded as the enemy had allowed to live. Fifty-seven were taken aboard, including seven or eight colored. Eight died on the way up to Cairo. Six guns were captured by the rebels, and carried off, including two ten-pound Parrotts, and two twelve-pound howitzers. A large amount of stores was destroyed or carried away. They seemed to be moving toward Memphis.

abstract: The thirty-ninth annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design was thrown open to the public yesterday, at the Derby Gallery, No, 625 Broadway. There are less than the average number of paintings upon the walls, and the display, as a whole, strikes us as below the average degree of excellence. There are few very striking pictures, and we are glad to say no very bad ones. CONSTANT MAYER's "Dying Soldier," ANDREWS' "Blacksmith's Shop," GIFFORD's "Sunset" and BENSON's "Dissecting Student," are among the most noteworthy works. The "Blacksmith's Shop" is full of excellence. It is far superior to anything of the kind, in many particulars, that we have seen from an American artist.

abstract: the Steamer, Wreck in 1853
lead_paragraph: -The terrible wreck of the steamship San Francisco ten years ago, just after she had left this port on her way to California, must yet be fresh in the memory of hundreds of thousands of people. It will be recollected that the San Francisco left here on the 22d Dec., 1853, having aboard some eight hundred souls, among whom were the Third Regiment of United States Artillery. On the night of the 22d she encountered a furious storm, which rendered her unmanageable, and on the morning of the 24th she was struck by a violent wave, which shattered her quarter deck, her hurricane deck and carried away her upper saloon, and all the officers and soldiers, (some 200,) who had taken shelter in it from the storm. The ship was so damaged by this shock that it required the utmost efforts of all on board to save themselves from going to the bottom. While in this perilous condition, within the next few days three vessels -- the Kilby, Capt. Low; the Three Bells, Capt. CREIGHTON, and the Antarctic, Capt. STAUFFER -- hove in sight; and though they had suffered greatly themselves from the storm, they tendered assistance and succor to those on board, and promised to stand by the wreck at all hazards. They did so faithfully; and a report on the subject, presented to the Senate by JEFF. DAVIS, thanked and praised one of these officers, who, "for six tempestuous days and nights, in a spirit of disinterested humanity, and at the imminent peril of himself and crew, stood by the sinking steamer until her gallant Commander, the last man on board, abandoned the doomed and deserted vessel."

abstract: In the Court of Sessions, yesterday, DANIEL BROOKS, who was convicted of manslaughter in the third degree, was brought up for sentence. His Honor said that the facts of the case showed that BROOKS might have avoided the affray with SMITH. There were no mitigating circumstances, and the sentence of the court would be as heavy as the limitation of the law allowed. He was sent to the State Prison for four years.

abstract: Outbreaks in
lead_paragraph: The Italian journals stated some months since that revolutionary movements were brewing in Hungary. About the middle of March -- on the anniversary of Hungary's deliverance from Austrian rule -- a formidable riot occurred in Pesth, of which the Vienna papers were careful to say very little. The crowd shouted "Effin Kossuth!" and even attacked the police. Arms, it is said, had been introduced from Poland and Galicia; and there was great popular ferment.

abstract: You will have received intelligence, ere this, of the close of our Illinois civil war. It is now proposed to turn over the Cole County prisoners some twenty-five in number to the civil authorities for trial on a charge of murder and riot the position of affairs not being deemed such as to justify the holding them under the United States laws, either for treason, or resistance to the Federal authorities.

abstract: -For the comfort of sick and wounded soldiers, hospital cars have been placed on the New-York and Boston Railroad. They are of new and improved style, and should be placed upon all the railroads. Resembling in the outside the ordinary first-class car, the inside is fitted up with nine comfortable stretchers hanging by rubber bands, so that the patients may rest undisturbed by the motion of the car. Twelve easy chairs and several regular passenger seats are provided, and there are also attached to the car a complete cooking apparatus, a large medicine chest, and a wash-room. The design of the gentlemen superintending this through line of railway without change of cars, was to provide all the conveniences and comforts of a hospital, and it has been very successfully carried out under their management. Two experienced hospital stewards and two nurses have been appointed by the Government to take charge of the patients, and everything has been provided to secure their safe and easy passage over the road. One of these cars leaves New-York every morning at 8 o'clock, and one leaves Boston every evening at 8 1/2 o'clock. The number of sick and disabled passengers from New-York averages twenty a day; a register of their names and complaints is kept by the stewards. These cars were manufactured in Springfield, Mass., for the New-York and Boston Express Line of Railway, composed of the following companies, viz.: the Boston and Worcester, E.B. PHILLIPS, Esq., Superintendent; the Western, HENRY GRAY, Superintendent; the Hartford and New-Haven, E.M. REED, Esq., Superintendent; and the New-Haven and New-York, JAS. HOYT, Esq., Superintendent -- all of whom, with their full staff of officers, have done everything possible to alleviate the suffering of the soldier in his transit.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, considerable interest was taken in the news of the massacre of troops at Fort Pillow; and, on motion of Senator HOWARD, a resolution was adopted instructing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire into it, and whether Fort Pillow could have been reinforced or evacuated, and that said Committee be instructed to report at as early a day as possible. Earnest speeches were made by Messrs. Howard, Wilson, Johnson, Conness and Grimes, in favor of strict measures of retaliation, man for man, or two for one. The Senate then took up the bill to provide for the collection of direct taxes in the insurrectionary districts, as reported from the Judiciary Committee. The amendments were agreed to. The bill was laid over, and the Senate proceeded to the consideration of the bill prohibiting speculation in gold and foreign exchange.

abstract: Suggestions for Movement Against
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the guerrilla FORREST had entered Kentucky, we suggested that, if necessary for his capture, it would be cheap to send against him all the infantry, cavalry, artillery, gunboats, horse-marines and negro soldiers in West Tennessee; and if all these were not sufficient for the work of catching him, that our army at Chattanooga should be ordered to send ten or twenty or thirty thousand additional reinforcements to help them. We foresaw what was foreseen by every one familiar with things in that locality, that while, on the one hand, FORREST might only be on a gallopade which would be comparatively harmless, yet, on the other hand, it might be within his power to perform acts that would actually thwart our great operations pending in Georgia and even in Virginia.

abstract: -- The Wheeling Intelligencer tells a curious story of a widow by the name of Mrs. BRIGGS, who formed an attachment for a guerrilla named GEORGE DUSKY, now confined in jail at Wheeling. She supplied him with delicacies of all kinds, until the jailor caught her trying to send in contraband articles, when he forbade further communication. The other night, he heard a noise under DUSKY's cell, and on going out a package dropped to the ground. As he stooped to pick it up, a woman, Mrs. BRIGGS herself, suddenly alighted on his back, having jumped from a wall twelve feet high, to the top of which she had climbed in order to pass the package which had been dropped to the prisoner, DUSKY. In jumping from the wall, the woman broke her right leg just above the ankle, but she nevertheless struggled violently for the possession of the parcel, and during the struggle a small bottle containing nitric acid was broken, and the contents spilled upon the jailor and Mrs. BRIGGS, both of whom were stained and burned by the liquid. Mrs. BRIGGS at last sunk to the ground in an exhausted condition, when she was taken into the jail, where medical attendance was called, and where she still lies in a suffering condition. The jailor, upon examining the parcel, found that it contained a bottle of chloroform, a bottle of nitric acid, a chisel, a box of steel pens, and two love letters from a Mrs. BRIGGS, a copy of the Freeman's Journal, and a copy of the Cincinnati Enquirer. Mrs. BRIGGS had the package attached to the end of a long pole, and was endeavoring to put it in the cell occupied by DUSKY, which she would doubtless have succeeded in doing had not the appearance of the jailor startled her and caused her to drop the package. DUSKY, the Intelligencer says, appears to entertain a sincere attachment for the woman who has risked so much to secure his liberty. He told the jailor that he hoped he alone would be made to suffer for what had occurred, and he offered him a thousand dollars to release Mrs. BRIGGS, and say nothing about the adventure of Wednesday night, but the jailor scorned the bribe. DUSKY is a very powerful built man, and it was doubtless intention after having everything else prepared, to seize the jailor when he came to the cell, administer the chloroform by force, and make his escape.

abstract: Plunder by
lead_paragraph: The stage proprietors, who have added 67 per cent. to their fares within the past week, supply the latest illustration of the illicit combinations which have sprung into existence in nearly every branch of the retail business of the City within the past year. These proprietors have followed the profitable example of the butcher, the petty tea and coffee merchant, the green-grocer and the general furnishing dealer; and as they constitute the most recent notable instance of the total depravityof those who have marketable commodities to dispense, they come in temporarily for an almost exclusive share of popular censure. Let us not, however, be supposed to offer any palliative for the extortions of the stage men, or to deprecate in any degree the opprobrium they have earned, if we turn aside for a moment to look at the position in which the combinations known to exist among other crafts has placed the honest householder who desires to live in even the most moderate comfort, and pay his lawful debts. The invariable reply to any protests, however temperate, against the butcher's and grocer's and general dealer's bill, is an appeal to the currency. Yet, every one who takes leisure to reflect, knows that during February and March, 1863, the market value of gold averaged almost the same, counting one week with another, as it has done in the months of February and March, and the first two weeks of April, 1864. During these last-named months, however, almost every necessary of household consumption -- we speak, of course, mainly, with reference to the larder -- is from 75 to 100 per cent. higher than it was a year ago. Thus, taking the average quality of the following articles, we find butter advanced within the twelve months from 25 and 28 cents a pound to 50 and 54 cents; cheese from 14 cents to 22 cents; eggs from 20 and 25 cents per dozen to 30 and 36 cents; coffee from 40 cents as pound to 56; sugar from 14 cents to 20 and 22 cents; roasting meat, from 16 to 25 cents; pork from 10 and 12 to 18 and 20 cents; vegetables of every description from 60 to 100 per cent.

abstract: Postal Money Order System Bill; Bill for
snippet: Postal Money Order System Bill; Bill for
lead_paragraph: On Friday two measures of great importance passed the House of Representatives, and the public will wait with hopeful expectancy to hear that they have become law. The first is a bill establishing a postal money-order system; the second is one providing a subsidy of $150,000 a year for the establishment of direct steamship communication between the United States and Brazil, subject to the appropriation of a similar amount for the same service by the Brazilian Government.

abstract: The sick and wounded soldiers sojourning at De Camp United States Hospital, David's Island, N.Y., desire to unite with their Chaplain in a public acknowledgment of the favor extended to them by the kind friends who have participated in the excellent course of lectures just closed at our chapel. During four months we have enjoyed every week an evening full of religious and moral instruction, true intellectual culture, or cheerful recreation, and feel warmly indebted to the following gentlemen for contributing so generously to our improvement and relaxation: Chaplains Devan, Scudder and Jas. B. Merwin, U.S.A.; Surgeons Van Norden and Priestley, U.S.A.; Rev. Messrs. Bliss, C.H. Payson, B.F. Stead, E.W. Syle, D. Stuart Dodge, W.S. Coffey and Edward Taylor, Mr. Wm. E. Dodge, Jr., and John Fowler, Jr., Esq.

abstract: Armand Case the, and French Justice
snippet: Armand Case the, and French Justice
lead_paragraph: French justice can only find its parallel in French freedom. As gagging the press, coercing electors, and prohibiting political meetings, are deemed quite consistent with the one, so disregarding the evidence of witnesses, reversing arbitrarily the verdicts of juries, and imposing penalties by mere caprice, are held to be equally compatible with the other. But it is easier to illustrate the anomalies of French criminal procedure than to describe them.
headline: {'main': 'French Justice.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'French Justice.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- In the District Court, on Saturday, Judge HARE delivered the opinion of the majority of the court, in a case involving the question of a tender of United States notes in payment of a ground rent, the covenant of the deed being "lawful silver money of the United States, each dollar weighing seventeen pennyweights and six grains." When the half-yearly ground-rent became due the payment was tendered in United States notes. This was refused, and suit was brought against the party. The defendant pleaded this tender, to which the plaintiff replied that the deed required silver dollars. The defendants to this filed a special demurrer, setting up that the notes tendered were lawful money of the United States, and a legal tender in payment of all debts. The court decides this to be a good payment, and therefore entered judgment for the defendant. Judge SHARSWOOD delivered a dissenting opinion. -- Philadelphia Ledger, April 11.

abstract: James Scott vs. Lynch, Sheriff. -- The plaintiff, who is a clothing merchant, claimed to recover the contents of a saloon at No. 239 Broadway, which had been levied upon under an execution in favor of E.V. Haughwout and others against Lurad C. Heath, about the 17th of March, 1863. The plaintiff claimed, under a bill of sale dated March 14, 1863. It appeared that there had for a long time existed intimate business relations between the plaintiff and Heath, and plaintiff claimed that at the time the bill of sale was executed Heath owed him about $9,000. That on the 15th of April Heath also conveyed to him a house and lot in Eleventh-street, and two houses in High-street, Brooklyn. The origin and nature of the indebtedness, and the conduct of the parties after the sale were closely investigated. The jury were ordered to bring in a sealed verdict, and this morning reported that they had been unable to agree.

abstract: Rev. B.F. MORRIS, a most excellent gentleman, has recently published a work to show the influence of Christianity on American institutions. I was recently turning over the correspondence of some of our statesmen, and could not help thinking that he could make a still more interesting work by tracing out the irreligion of most public men, and the great improvement which has taken place in that respect since the period of the Revolution.
lead_paragraph: Rev. B.F. MORRIS, a most excellent gentleman, has recently published a work to show the influence of Christianity on American institutions. I was recently turning over the correspondence of some of our statesmen, and could not help thinking that he could make a still more interesting work by tracing out the irreligion of most public men, and the great improvement which has taken place in that respect since the period of the Revolution. Some of my readers may be surprised at this declaration -- but it is an unquestionable fact. Even the rebels are very devout people; and Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS abounds in fasts and prayers. I must confess I think he is right, on the principle of the Vermont clergyman. One of the most excellent ladies in New-York told me that a Vermont parson, in the days of JEFFERSON, felt it his duty to pray for the Government, but, being a Federalist, he had a hearty detestation of JEFFERSON, and when the proper time came in his prayer he said: "Now, Lord, bless thy servant JEFFERSON -- for, Lord, thou knowest he needs it!" I think the rebels are proper subjects of prayer, by us as well as themselves -- for surely nobody ever needed it more.

abstract: Yesterday was the last day of the second week of the great Fair. The interest has not abated in the least; the enthusiasm is as great as ever. The receipts have been very large, it being estimated that nearly $800,000 have been received since the opening of the fair. Everything, in fact, has been as prosperous and favorable as could be wished, and the third and last week, it seems probable, will be even more profitable than the previous ones.

abstract: Post vs. Martens, >amp;c. Leases by Agents
snippet: Post vs. Martens, >amp;c. Leases by Agents
lead_paragraph: Jehial J. Post vs. Henry Martens and Robert Cross. -- This action was brought to recover balance due for rent of premises No. 9 First-street, under a lease dated Nov. 28, 1859, to commence May 1, the ensuing, for three years at $300 per annum, and croton water tax, and keep premises in repair. The lease was signed by James H. Thorne, as agent for plaintiff. The defendants answered separately -- Martens averred that another lease bearing date Feb. 17, 1860, was executed by Thorne, as agent, and for the same terms and upon the same conditions as the lease sued on, to the defendant Cross individually, and that he was ousted from the possession of the premises by reason of the letting to Cross. Cross on the other had averred the execution of the second lease, and that he was kept out of possession by reason of the defendant Martens, having possession. Thorne swore that he was agent for the plaintiff, and had authority to execute the lease in suit, but had no authority to execute the lease to Cross. On his cross-examination he stated that he executed the lease to Cross, as plaintiffs' agent, but held both defendants under the lease in suit. A receipt was shown him dated Nov., 1861, for $75, received from Cross on account of rent of the premises in question. He admitted the money was received from Cross. Thorne was cross-examined at much length. The lease to Cross was offered in evidence, and ruled out on the ground that Thorne had no authority to execute it.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, sundry petitions were presented asking for increased pay to the Metropolitan Police Force, in view of the high prices of the necessaries of life. Bills were reported relative to the Excelsior Fire Insurance Company of Kings County; authorizing the Supervisors of Kings County to provide relief for the families of volunteers; incorporating the International Land Company, for the consideration of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, sundry petitions were presented asking for increased pay to the Metropolitan Police Force, in view of the high prices of the necessaries of life. Bills were reported relative to the Excelsior Fire Insurance Company of Kings County; authorizing the Supervisors of Kings County to provide relief for the families of volunteers; incorporating the International Land Company, for the consideration of the Senate. The Supply Bill was also reported, giving rise to debate on the proposition to fill in the names for Quarantine Commissioners. It was finally decided to give one commissioner each to the Counties of New-York, Richmond and Kings.

abstract: I heartily agree with "P.I.L.," in yesterday's TIMES, that there should be at least one "cheap day." at the fair, when those who can afford but twenty-five cents, should have the pleasure of giving that sum for the triple purpose of aiding the enterprise, of enjoying the sights, and of cultivating their patriotic impulses. I would even have one "shilling day," to draw in and enlist the sympathies of the poorest sewing girls and laborers.

abstract: -- The Pacific Mail steamship Constitution, Commodore WATKINS, yesterday completed her armament, in mounting a hundred-pound Parrott rifled gun, in addition to her two Dahlgren rifles. This monster piece of ordnance is placed forward on the main deck, and its working gear is so arranged that it will have full play when called into action. It carries a solid shot of sixty pounds, and has a range of four miles. Her Dahlgrens are twelve-pound rifled guns, carrying a solid shot of sixteen pounds. With this armament, Commodore WATKINS entertains no fear of piratical cruisers, and taking into consideration the vast size and speed of the Constitution, even if he should encounter the Alabama, he could easily capture or sink her. These guns are to be manned by the crew, who are au fait at artillery practice. Few, if any, vessels afloat can equal the Constitution and Golden City; and, now that they are completely armed, no fears need be entertained of a safe and speedy voyage -the great desiderata of travelers. The Constitution is in splendid order, and all who will travel on the leviathan will certainly enjoy their voyage. -- Alla California, March 17.
lead_paragraph: -- The Pacific Mail steamship Constitution, Commodore WATKINS, yesterday completed her armament, in mounting a hundred-pound Parrott rifled gun, in addition to her two Dahlgren rifles. abstract: -Secretary CHASE, it is said, bowed himself out of Wall-street yesterday; and by the polite nodding of his head, produced an old-fashioned panic among the speculators in gold, stocks, andproduce. The alarmed adventurers made desperate efforts to realize on their purchases, and, in doing so, effectually burst the bubble, which they had been so long and so arduously laboring to inflate. Let loyal citizens rejoice.

abstract: -There are certain indications that the rebel Gen. LEE would like to anticipate Gen. GRANT in the opening of the campaign in Virginia, and to take the initiative himself. We have some reasons not proper to make public for this statement. In addition, there are indications apparent enough that the rebels are brewing mischief. Among them, the fact that not a line of intelligence has reached us from Richmond directly for nearly a month, is not without meaning. The flag-of-truce boat went up last week to City Point to bring down the remainder of our prisoners at Richmond, but after waiting two or three days, was obliged to return without them, the only reason assigned being that the water in the James River was so high that communication could not be had with Richmond. That's a new theory in navigation that won't stand criticism. Whenever the rebels are about to initiate a movement, they act just as they do now -- close-lipped and cautious -- and it is quite reasonable for them to argue that the departure of a thousand Union prisoners of war might possibly betray information of what is going on.
lead_paragraph: -There are certain indications that the rebel Gen. LEE would like to anticipate Gen. GRANT in the opening of the campaign in Virginia, and to take the initiative himself. abstract: Chenango Explosion; Further on the
lead_paragraph: The terrible catastrophe which happened to the Chenango, last Friday, opposite Fort Hamilton, is being thoroughly investigated. Efforts are being made by Government officials, to ascertain the cause of the disaster. A visit to the steamer is the most convincing proof of the destruction that followed the explosion. The port side of the vessel, from the deck to the engine-room is completely demolished. The wheel-house over the exploded boiler is a blackened wreck. On every side the evidences of destruction are apparent. The deck between the centre-house and port-wheel, is torn asunder, and the evidences of the powerful effect of the explosion is seen in the warped planks, the started bolts, and the almost entire disruption of every portion of the vessel. The appearance of the furnace under the exploded boiler, is one of the strongest proofs of the force of the concussion occasioned by the explosion. Pieces of coal were imbedded into the sides of the vessel, making holes like round shot. The imminent danger of the ship's being fired was only prevented by the coolness and bravery of the few men on duty uninjured by the explosion. Conspicuous among the number of those who were foremost in their efforts to assist the wounded, and extinguish the flames, was Capt. FILLEBROWN. During the excitement occasioned by the catastrophe, several men jumped overboard, but all, except in one case, that of a man named MARTIN, were rescued from drowning. To add to the confusion and horror of the scene, the steering apparatus of the vessel broke, and the helmsman lost all control of the ship. As soon as the wounded men could be conveyed from the engine-room to the deck, the fire-pumps were put in motion, and the conflagration which would undoubtedly have followed, was avoided. The shrieks of the dying and wounded men, as they lay prostrate on the gundeck, are described as most heartrending. Dr. D.P. GOODHUE, the Surgeon of the ship, was prompt and untiring in his attentions to the injured men. Every remedy known to medical skill was applied, and the anguish of the sufferers was relieved as far as the extent of the physician's skill could go. The timely appearance of the revenue-cutter Bronx was most fortunate. As the accident, happened late in the afternoon, it could hardly have been noticed by outward-bound steamers, as most of them sail early in the day. The wounded men were, as soon as possible after the explosion, removed from the Chenango to the Bronx and other vessels near by, and taken to the Naval Hospital. The sight at that institution was heartrending. The agony of J.A. CAHILL and JOHN WHITE, First and Second Assistant Engineers, is described as excruciating. The poor men writhed in agony, literally flayed alive, till relieved from their sufferings by death. Fireman BEMAN BOYLE could hardly be recognized. The flesh was stripped front his bones. Second-class fireman ARCHIBALD FLEMING met with a similar fate. Of the nineteen who died on their passage from Fort Hamilton and at the Naval Hospital, all came to their death from scalding. Those injured by the explosion, and who did not meet their death by scalding, were comparatively few. Most of the deceased were engaged in the Engineers department. At the Naval Hospital, the scene was most painful. In the different wards at the Naval Hospital, where the wounded men were lying, nurses were seen administering to their relief. For some distance from the Hospital the shrieks of the wounded could be distinctly heard. Almost every hour some one of the unfortunates would pass away. The attention of Surgeons FREELAND, RHODES, LYMAN and SMITH were unremitting. Valuable assistance was rendered by Stewards MCGURK and KIRBY. Many of the friends of the wounded residing in New-York and Brooklyn were admitted to the wards, and did all that lay in their power to relieve the sufferings of the wounded men. It is stated that, before Engineer CAAILL died, he exclaimed: "Doctor, thank God, the boiler was full!" -- a dying evidence of his faithfulness. Several of the men were recently enlisted, many of them resided in Brooklyn, and leave large families unprovided for. The Second Engineer, Mr. ROOT, of the vessel, was a resident of Brooklyn, and leaves a widow and three children. He has been in the United States service during the rebellion, and was for several months Chief Engineer of the Potomska. Mr. WHITE, the Third Assistant Engineer, who died on Friday night, was also a married man, and leaves a large family. He died a few hours after being admitted to the hospital. Mr. MURRAY, one of the Second Assistant Engineers, who died from the effects of his wounds almost immediately after being removed to the Bronx, was a resident of Baltimore.

abstract: English Influence in the Orient
lead_paragraph: If we may credit the Constantinople correspondent of the London Times, England has achieved a great triumph in the East. Sir HENRY BULWER, the British representative at the Porte, has been away on vacation, and has been devoting his leisure to the promotion of English interests in Turkey and Egypt. He has had repeated interviews with the Emperor of the French, and the result has apparently been that NAPOLEON is perfectly willing to let PALMERSTON have his way in the East, if PAM. will only consent to allow his Majesty to do what he likes in Mexico. The programme in relation to the East is as follows: A conference of the guaranteeing Powers is to be immediately assembled to settle the questions appertaining to the Principalities. This conference will base its proceedings on the act of secularization recently passed by the Roumanic Legislature, and on the second article of the Treaty of Paris, and it will compel Prince COUZA not merely to equitably indemnify the convents for their secularized territories, but also to reduce the military force of his little State to the measure prescribed by the said treaty. Hence, it is evident that, so far as the Principalities are concerned, the requisitions of England and Turkey are to be carried out.

abstract: -The Confederate steamer Florida arrived at Tenerine, from Madeira, on the 4th inst., and having taken in coals, proceeded to sea again on the following day. On the 6th, the Federal war-steamer St. Louis arrived also from Madeira, where, our readers will recollect, she attempted to blockade the Florida. It is now thought the Florida intends cruising in the vicinity of the equator, and that the Georgia, which has not beenheard of since leaving Cherbourg, is for the West Indies. Nothing has been heard of the Alabama since January, when, it may be remembered, she was reported off Bombay, and the United States steamer Wyoming, on the look-out for her, was, by latest advices. at Amoy. -- Liverpool Courier.

abstract: Two weeks of continued and uninterrupted success have passed, and to-day commences the third and last week at the great fair. There is no statement of the interest the people take in it; the first few days of last week were very rainy and disagreeable; it did not, however, affect the crowds in the least, the buildings were just as full and the greenbacks just as plenty as on the clear and smiling days.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks of continued and uninterrupted success have passed, and to-day commences the third and last week at the great fair. There is no statement of the interest the people take in it; the first few days of last week were very rainy and disagreeable; it did not, however, affect the crowds in the least, the buildings were just as full and the greenbacks just as plenty as on the clear and smiling days. The price of admission being reduced to fifty cents, thousands now attend who did not think they could afford to pay $1, and as they each and every one wish, as a matter of course, to purchase something to keep in remembrance of the greatest fair this City ever knew, the receipts for sales have been very satisfactory. The receipts thus far are estimated to be about $800,000, and if this week is as successful as is anticipated, the total receipts will be over $1,000,000.

abstract: NEW-YORK CITIZENS' ASSOCIATION. We understand delegations, composed of our most influential citizens, will continue to visit Albany all the week, for the purpose of securing such a reduction in the tax-levy as can be made, not only without an injury to the efficient working of any of the departments but with great benefit to the community.
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK CITIZENS' ASSOCIATION. -- We understand delegations, composed of our most influential citizens, will continue to visit Albany all the week, for the purpose of securing such a reduction in the tax-levy as can be made, not only without an injury to the efficient working of any of the departments but with great benefit to the community. The Citizens' Association does not aim at the reduction of salaries. They wish every man paid fully and liberally for all services actually performed, but they do believe that the employes of the different departments exceed all their necessities. Our citizens now have an opportunity of correcting abuses by earnestly going to work concertedly in this matter. A majority of the Legislature at Albany are in favor of doing New-York justice, and our citizens should go to Albany this week in large numbers, and by their presence and influence do all in their power to diminish the useless burden of taxation. Much has already been accomplished by the various delegations who have visited Albany, but much now remains to be done. It is among the things possible to put a stop to this annual squandering of millions.

abstract: On Friday a body of rebel cavalry made an attack on our pickets at Bristow Station, killing one man and wounding two others of the Thirteenth Pennsylvania Regiment. They were driven off after a few shots had been exchanged, but carried their wounded with them. Lieut. Gen. GRANT had passed the spot in the car only a few moments before the attack, and the supposition is that the rebels designed to make him prisoner.

abstract: NEW TEMPERANCE ORGANIZATION. -- An assemblage of about 3,000 persons was gathered yesterday afternoon at the corner of Union-avenue and India-street, Greenpoint, to witness the inauguration services of Father Mathew T.A.B. Society No. 6. The society was organized on Monday evening last, and numbers ninety members. A procession half a mile long, with bands and banners, paraded the streets, and speeches and singing were had at the open air stand. The following gentlemen briefly addressed the throng: George J. Campbell and Christopher Stalvey, of Greenpoint; Isaac Marsland, Ira Buckman, D.A. Sutton, of Brooklyn; John McGrath, James Bagley, Robert Wilson, and Messrs. Dickinson and Kearney, of New-York. The temperance cause has recently been strongly reinforced in Brooklyn, E.D.

abstract: In the Senate Saturday, considerable interest was taken in the news of the massacre of troops at Fort Pillow; and, on motion of Senator HOWARD, a resolution was adopted instructing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire into it, and whether Fort Pillow could have been reinforced or evacuated, and that said Committee be instructed to report at as early a day as possible. Earnest speeches were made by Messrs. Howard, Wilson, Johnson, Conness and Grimes, in favor of strict measures of retaliation, man for man, or two for one. The Senate then took up the bill to provide for the collection of direct taxes in the insurrectionary district, as reported from the Judiciary Committee. The amendments were agreed to. The bill was laid over, and the Senate proceeded to the consideration of the bill prohibiting speculation in gold and foreign exchange, which, after discussion, was passed by a vote of 23 against 17.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate Saturday, considerable interest was taken in the news of the massacre of troops at Fort Pillow; and, on motion of Senator HOWARD, a resolution was adopted instructing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire into it, and whether Fort Pillow could have been reinforced or evacuated, and that said Committee be instructed to report at as early a day as possible. abstract: JUVENILE WARFARE. -- A boy named ALFRED H. BARRETT, aged 17 years, was arrested by Officer DUHAM, of the Forty-ninth Precinct Police, on Saturday, for throwing stones at other boys, in the vicinity of Broadway and Myrtle-avenue. This boy is said to be the leader of the gangs who are in the habit of meeting in that vicinity daily, for the purpose of waging juvenile warfare, the weapons being stones. To such an extent has this been carried on, that the lives of the residents, as well as passengers on the railroad cars, have been jeopardized. Regular pickets having been established, it was impossible for the police to come upon them in uniform; consequently disguise had to be assumed, by which means the officer was enabled to make the arrest.

abstract: One more victim was added yesterday to the already fearful list of those whose death was caused by the explosion of the port-boiler on the United States gunboat Chenango, making thus far 22 out of 35 injured. There are 13 still remaining in the United States Marine Hospital, where everything possible is done in their behalf, the surgeon, steward and apothecary having neither allowed themselves rest or sleep since Friday evening, devoting all their time and attention to the survivors, of whom it is not expected that more than six or seven can possibly recover. On Friday ten died, and the remainder since Saturday morning. The following is a corrected list of those who were killed on board the ill-fated vessel, those who died at the hospital and those who were still alive yesterday afternoon, as furnished by the apothecary of the hospital. Mr. HENRY K. DONOVAN:

abstract: Wells, D. A. Annual of Scientific Discovery; North American Review, April; National Almanac, 1864; Mayhew, Edward. Illustrated Horse Management
snippet: Wells, D. A. Annual of Scientific Discovery; North American Review, April; National Almanac, 1864; Mayhew, Edward. Illustrated Horse Management
lead_paragraph: Though the present volume is but the second issue of this truly named "National" work, it is established in public favor, firmly and substantially. Its appearance has been retarded, slightly, by the difficulty of obtaining skilled workmen, in the printing as well as in other branches of business; but the public are gainers by the delay, and are amply compensated for it, by the later date of the statistics, and the careful revision that the whole work has undergone in the interval. The National Almanac for the past year fairly took people by surprise -so evident was the vast labor bestowed on the volume, so rich its body of information, and so moderate the price at which it was afforded. The sale of fifteen thousand copies furnished a gratifying proof to Mr. GEO. W. CHILDS, the projector and publisher, that his exertions were appreciated by the public, and he has thrown all his customary energies into the task of making the new volume superior to its predecessor. It is claimed, and with undoubted justice, to be an advance on that, in several particulars. Old statements, formerly repeated on trust, have been rigorously scrutinized and verified from the original authorities. Direct application has been made, regardless of toil or expense, in every quarter where trustworthy statistics were to be obtained, and an unusual degree of intelligent labor and care has been bestowed in tabulating and condensing these statistics, so as to exhibit the valuable results in a form proportioned to the scale of the work. The topic that, per force, touches every one -- taxation -- is one on which the fullest information is afforded. Our internal revenue system, the laws that govern its operation, and the returns showing their proceeds, as levied on the various branches of industry in the shape of ad valorem excise duties, licenses, &c., are here for the first time brought together, and afford materials of the highest importance to the statesman, the historian, and the statistician: Thus, would it be believed without the figures to prove it, that the number of retailers who sell liquor is more than one-half that of all the retail traders in the country. Yet such is the fact, the. Ten dollar retail dealers' license producing $1,227,912; while the twenty dollar liquor retail license is credited for $1,477.754. The most costly article in the ad valorem tax list, diamonds, contributes to the national revenue $65,948. This, at the rate of three per cent, shows that more than two million dollars worth of that precious stone was manufactured in jewelry of various kinds, and absorbed into use during the past year. A thousand similar curious facts might be deduced from this portion of the "National Almanac" alone. In all that relates to the great military and naval operations of the country, equal care has been exercised in bringing down the information to the last minute. Here will be found, in condensed detail, the description, tonnage, number of guns, station, &c, of each of the ships that compose our grand national armada. In the Military Department an entirely new feature has been introduced, a mass of special intelligence concerning the volunteers of the United States armies, of the same character and extent as that heretofore mainly confined to the regular troops. This was only to be obtained by a most extensive correspondence and a laborious compilation from scattered and voluminous State official returns, and cannot be found in any other shape. The editor rightly says: "As a permanent record of the marvelous development of the military power and resources of the United States, and of the patriotism of its citizens at the hour of need, it is worth more than the price of the whole volume." The record of the events of the war gives a full diary of every prominent occurrence connected with its progress, and also a special history of each of the national armies and its services in its own theatre of action, in a separate division. The statistics of mortality and sickness in the army and the obituary list of deceased officers are matters of engrossing and painful interest to thousands. For the politician, the returns of electoral votes, &c., for each Congressional District of the different States are given with great fullness; the lists of the Judiciary, Executive officers, Legislatures, &c., of each State and Territory, are minute and exhaustive, embracing every particular of general interest. Seventy-five pages devoted to foreign countries, their sovereigns, governments, ministries, areas, populations, finances, armies, navies, commerce, navigation and affairs generally placed within the reach of the reader, -- a great summing up of the world's progress, the result of all man's labors, the reward of all his toil, condensed by the skill of the statistician into a nutshell. For an intelligent American citizen, whose privilege it is to think and act on all questions that affect the interests of his country and fellow-men, we can imagine no companion more indispensable than the "National Almanac for 1864," and the oftener he consults it, the fitter will he be for the exercise of his civic functions.

abstract: Mr. MARETZEK'S season at the Academy of Music will end with the present week, and to-night GOUNOD's opera of "Faust" will be played for the thirty-first and last time. These two facts should go a long way toward securing crowded houses for the short term that remains. But there is yet another circumstance worth placing on record for the benefit of those whose purses are not plethoric.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARETZEK's season at the Academy of Music will end with the present week, and to-night GOUNOD's opera of "Faust" will be played for the thirty-first and last time. These two facts should go a long way toward securing crowded houses for the short term that remains. But there is yet another circumstance worth placing on record for the benefit of those whose purses are not plethoric. The prices of admission at the Academy of Music, and, indeed, at all places of amusement in the City will shortly be raised. Mr. MARETZEK, with the best of intentions and the largest of companies, finds it impossible to pay expenses, even with more than average houses, at the present rates of admission. Many of his artists are paid in gold, and those who are not, demand, like every one else, an increase of currency, so that there is not much difference. The orchestral and choral forces have long since raised their prices. They can do it with impunity, because they cannot be replaced and have the power in their own hands. Every article used in the mimic scene has more than doubled its value since the commencement of the Fall (1863) season. This increase in fact is so onerous that nothing but the most extraordinary run of luck in the matter of operas has enabled Mr. MARETZEK to struggle to the end without a positive loss. Early in May he intends resuming operations, devoting the interval to rehearsals of "Les Huguenots," which he will then produce in a style of great magnificence. It would be impossible to give this superb work at the present prices; hence an advance must and will be made. We are persuaded that no legitimate admirer of Italian opera will object to it, whilst those who simply go there for curiosity will take no heed of the extra quarter or half dollar that is demanded of them. It should be remembered, too, that Mr. MARETZEK has been the last to think of making a change. All the other theatres in the City have quietly tacked on an extra twenty-five cents for reserved seats in the balcony circle, and we do not remember to have heard a single complaint on the subject. It has been paid cheerfully, the houses have been crowded to their greatest capacity, and the managers have reaped the full benefit of the advance, without, we are afraid, always having shared it with their companies. It is clearly Mr. MARETZEK's turn. Whoever wants opera must pay for it -- not extravagantly as in Europe, or in any proportion with other imported luxuries, but at a fair valuation, so that the manager may be able to fulfill all his duties to the public and to the company. The performance of "Faust" to-night is, therefore, the last of that opera at cheap prices -- the last, too, for many months. To-morrow the company appears at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, playing for the first and only time "Robert le Diable." The rest of the week will be set aside for benefits.

abstract: -Soon after 2 o'clock, yesterday morning, flames were discovered issuing from the fourth floor of the building No. 97 Cliff-street, occupied by WM. CHANDLER & SON, silver-platers. Their loss by fire is about $1,000. They are fully insured in City companies. The front portion of the same floor was occupied by Messrs. KING & KELTON, machinists. Their loss is over $1,500; fully insured. Vulcanite Jewelry Company occupied the fifth floor. The damage to their stock by fire and water is about $4,000. They are partially insured. SMITH & Co., occupants of the third floor, lost about $1,000 worth of their machinery. Messrs, BOCKLEN & STOCKLEN, machinists, occupied the second floor. Their loss on stock, fixtures, &c., is about $1,000. They are insured for $2,000 in the Astor, St. Nicholas and Grocers' Insurance Companies. The building. No. 99 Cliff-street, occupied by HENRY A. BURR, manufacturer of hat bodies, was also extensively damaged by fire and water. Mr. BURR thinks that $4,000 will cover the damage on his stock. He is fully insured. Messrs. WOOD & HUGHES, jewelers, occupied a portion of No. 99. Their damage by water is about $500. The buildings are owned by H.A. BURR, are damaged about $3,000, and are fully insured.
