abstract: We feel greatly indebted to our neighbor, the World, for the pains it takes to keep the community thoroughly posted as to the Presidential movements of the Union party. Its devotion is the more praise worthy because it is wholly disinterested. It can make no difference, of course, to the World and its political friends, whether our National Convention is held in June or in September, -- whether LINCOLN is our nominee, or FREMONT; -- we feel, therefore, all the more sensibly the zealous interest of the World in the solution of these and other questions of a kindred nature.

abstract: Forrest's Threats Against; Massacre, the
lead_paragraph: -- THE REPORTED REBEL MASSACRE. Both the Senate and House passed a resolution, on Saturday, calling for immediate inquiry into the circumstances of the Fort Pillow Massacre. Even before this action, the Secretary of War had appointed officers to make investigation into the matter. It is essential that this should be done, and it is well it should be done very promptly. The black soldiers reported to have been butchered in cold blood to the number of three hundred, were men regularly and legally enlisted into our army. They were in the National uniform, defending the National flag and the National integrity, and were fully entitled to the protection guaranteed to all our soldiers. We cannot permit the rebels to massacre them. We cannot pass over this and like massacres by FORREST's rebel gang -- if the circumstances be as they have been represented. JEFF. DAVIS has undertaken to dictate to us very often in this war; but we cannot possibly permit his insolent dictation to go as far as this. The blood of these slaughtered men is on our skirts as well as on the skirts of the rebels, if we permit them to be killed while we stand by, when it is in our power to protect them; and Heaven and history will hold us responsible.

abstract: The Albany Atlas & Argus very adroitly represents us as ridiculing the substance and sentiments of the minority report on national banking in the State Assembly. This may be sharp, but it is neither fair nor just. We concur heartily in the reasoning, the conclusions and the recommendations of that report; and Mr. BRANDRETH is entitled to very great credit for the forcible manner in which he has vindicated the system of national banking against the attempt of State bankers to override and destroy it. We took the liberty to laugh a little at some of the spread-eagleism which the ambitions patriotism of the writer of the report had infused into it, but that is simply a matter of taste, and does not in the least affect the intrinsic and substantial merits of of the document itself. The State Assembly did itself credit in giving the positions and sentiments of this report their sanction.

abstract: [ELEVENTH ARTICLE.]  The last article of this series left Gen. McCLELLAN established with what remained of his shattered army on the banks of the James, at Harrison's Landing. If the army had sustained itself nobly throughout the sad campaign on the Peninsula, it cannot be denied that so much fruitless toil and so much disaster had impaired its morale, while the losses in battle and the epidemics of the region had frightfully thinned its ranks.
lead_paragraph: [ELEVENTH ARTICLE.]

abstract: In the Senate Saturday, sundry petitions were presented asking for increased pay to the Metropolitan Police Force, in view of the high prices of the necessaries of life. Bills were reported relative to the Excelsior Fire Insurance Company of Kings County; authorizing the Supervisors of Kings County to provide relief for the families of volunteers; incorporating the International Land Company, for the consideration of the Senate. The Supply Bill was also reported, giving rise to debate on the proposition to fill in the names for Quarantine Commissioners. It was finally decided to give one commissioner each to the Counties of New-York, Richmond and Kings.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate Saturday, sundry petitions were presented asking for increased pay to the Metropolitan Police Force, in view of the high prices of the necessaries of life. The Supply Bill was also reported, giving rise to debate on the proposition to fill in the names for Quarantine Commissioners. It was finally decided to give one commissioner each to the Counties of New-York, Richmond and Kings.

abstract: It is ascertained that the schooner Patter, which sailed in ballast for the Colorado River, on Sunday, clangestinely took as cargo, after clearing from the Custom-house, three thousand kegs of blasting powder. It is believed that this powder is destined for Northern Mexico for mining purposes. The authorities having prohibited such shipments, the mines of Sonora must be closed unless means are devised to introduce powder clandestinely.

abstract: the New Bill to Promote
lead_paragraph: The danger of our people in attempting any useful measure of legislation, is always that they will overdo the thing. Nothing could be more wise, for instance, at the present time, than the encouragement of immigration. The introduction of laborers is an import of the richest source of wealth. No commerce in which this country is engaged is so entirely profitable to us as the commerce (if commerce it may be called) in labor. We never needed it so much as we do now, when a million of producers have been withdrawn from the labor market. It is this stream of foreign laborers, which, with the wonderful alluvial soil of the central West, has caused production to be on such a rich and gigantic scale in this country.
headline: {'main': 'The New Bill to Promote Emigration.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Bill to Promote Emigration.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -FORREST's guerrillas have certainly been successful to a degree disgraceful enough to our arms; but when they threaten to take Memphis, we rather think they overestimate their powers -- we mean of course if the place is defended by an officer at once sober, vigilant and courageous. They would not only come in contact with the missiles from the iron-clad and tin-clad gunboats in front of the city, but they would have to take Fort Pickering before they could hold Memphis. Fort Pickering is an immense earthwork, or series of earthworks -- for there is more than one line to it -- touching on the Southern outskirt of Memphis, and is more than a mile and a half long, the whole of it properly mounted with the heaviest artillery. Indeed, one of the temptations to take the place would be the enormous amount of siege and other great guns the rebels know they would obtain if once it was in their hands. The outer series of guns on Fort Pickering sweeps all the lines of approach to Memphis from the east or the south, and commands, if it does not entirely cover, the city. The fort has a large garrison, which ought to be able to hold out against all the rebel forces West of the Tennessee, even though they were reinforced by the army of Rev. Gen. POLK, which they probably will be, unless speedily driven out.

abstract: The orders to be ready for the draft to-day, it is likely were designed as nothing more than a spur to more rapid recruiting. The machinery for a draft is complicated, is not in order, and before it could be put so and at work, the Volunteer Committee, at the present number per day, would have all the men wanted. There is no likelihood of a draft as there is no necessity for one. The City has responded pretty promptly to the calls made, and will complete her quota under the last with little trouble and delay. But 4,912 men are required. In answer to an inquiry from Mr. BLUNT, as to whether men raised by the committee after to-day will be counted on the quota, Gen. HAYS makes the following response:

abstract: Vive la Reine ! The long and dreary mourning is over. Queen VICTORIA once more takes her place at the head of her Court and Kingdom. The skies brighten at the announcement. Joy irradlaten London, and its gleam penetrates the most distant provinces. The Queen herself will hold a drawingroom reception next Wednesday. Court balls, con  certs, and receptions are to follow. The world of fashion and the world of trade, are alike delighted.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Saturday, April 2, 1864.

abstract: Gen. Washburne to Command
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. C.C. WASHBURNE, lately on duty in the Department of the Gulf, has been appointed to the command of the Department of West Tennessee, in the stead of Gen. HURLBUT, who has been relieved and ordered to report by letter to the Adjutant-General at Washington. We trust and believe that this appointment will prove an excellent one. Gen. WASHBURNE has seen service in Tennessee before, and has an excellent repute both as a soldier and administrator. There is no secondary department which requires more eminent capacity and a more honorable character for its proper management than this. It is most tempting ground for the rebel Generals, both for such operations as those now being carried on by FORREST, and for larger movements such as have been threatened by Dr. POLK. Unless the rebels are driven entirely out of the department, they can give us great annoyance, and neutralize a very large body of our troops. Beside his important and difficult military duties, the Commander at Memphis has great labor of an administrative kind. In the first place, Tennessee is undergoing the process of political reorganization, which has been almost entirely baulked in the western section of the State by the everlasting irruptions of rebels. In the second place, Memphis is the seat and centre of the great speculative and cotton-trading operations on the Mississippi River, and a commander whose integrity is less than perfect is apt to become the tool of knaves. In the third place, the City of Memphis itself, which at the present time has a population of between thirty and forty thousand, is under military rule, and requires firm and just executive direction.

abstract: Chivalry and European Admirers
lead_paragraph: We commend the accounts of last Tuesday's massacre at Fort Pillow, now confirmed in its important features, to the attention of the enthusiastic defenders of the Rebel Confederacy in England and France. For some years, Mr. SPENCE, and his co-laborers in the Anglo-rebel Press, have been picturing to an admiring public the gallant and heroic chivalry of the South struggling for independence, and the slave bound by a thousand ties of affection and respect to his patriarchal master. The aristocratic class of England and the polished circles of France have been appealed to for sympathy with "the only aristocracy" on the Western Continent. The North has been painted as sordid, vulgar and low-born; the South as chivalrous and noble. The sympathies of a large part of the aristocracy of Great Britain are now with the South, in part because they believe that the Confederacy is an association of gentlemen, and the North a mob and a vulgar Democracy.

abstract: The steamship Glasgow, from Liverpool April 3. via Queenstown April 4, and the Saxonia, from Southampton April 6, arrived at this port yesterday. In the House of Commons on the 5th, Lord CLANRICARDE moved for the correspondence relating to the dismissal of British Consuls from Southern ports, when Earl RUSSELL, in reply, defended the action of Lord LYONS, and showed that the said Consuls had been dismissed for a good and sufficient reason -- for using their official positions to aid the rebels. Mr. STANSFELD had resigned his position in the Government, as Junior Lord of the Treasure, because of the connection of his name with MAZZINI and the Greco conspiracy. GARIBALDI, with his two sons, arrived at Southampton on the 3d, and was received with great enthusiasm. He received an address from the corporation, to which he responded in very badly broken English. Afterward he embarked for the Isle of Wight on a visit to Mr. SEELY, M.P. He would enter London April 11 as the guest of the Duke of Sutherland. It was rumored in London that an attempt would soon be made to oust the Ministry, and proceedings in Parliament for the next few weeks would probably be very animated. The steamship Great Eastern had been taken up by the contractors, Messrs. GLASS, ELIOT & Co., to lay the Atlantic cable next year. The bombardment of Dybbol continued, and one-third of the town of Sonderborg had been burned. The latest dispatches from allied sources represent their forces as making gradual but certain advances. All the Powers that signed the treaty of 1852 had consented to send representatives to the conference, but no answer had been received from the Germanic Diet. The basis of the conference would be an effort to restore peace, but no armistice would take place. Rumors that MAXIMILLIAN'S acceptance of the Mexican throne were doubtful were again in circulation. It was reported that the Courts of London, Rome, Vienna, Berlin, St. Petersburgh, Spain and France have agreed to recognize the Emperor of Mexico immediately on his accession. The Pope's health had entirely recovered.

lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of the Shareholders of the Fourth National Bank was held yesterday afternoon in the main room of the banking-house. The attendance was large, and the business transacted of considerable importance. At the last meeting of the shareholders, held on the l4th instant, it was resolved that the Directors be requested to resign. Yesterday six of them made a proposition to the remaining three, namely, Messrs. GEORGE OPDYKE, ROBERT TAYLOR, and R.D. LATHROP, that if they would resign in accordance with the expressed wish of the shareholders, they, the six gentlemen making the proposition, would also resign. For a time the debate ran, high, members taking ground for and against the proposed resignation of the Directors. Several resolutions were passed, showing that the majority of the shareholders present were in favor of their resignation. Mr. OPDYKE having frequently expressed himself as not only entirely willing, but anxious, stated that he had declined doing so only for the purpose of getting an expression of the majority of the stockholders concerning the propriety of his resigning. After the subject had been fully discussed, Mr. OPDYKE arose and stated that he, for himself and on behalf of Messrs. LATHROP and TAYLOR, respectfully tendered their resignations.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamer Fulton at Fortress Monroe on Saturday, we have later advices from the Department of the South. She brings the intelligence of the capture by the gunboat South Carolina, of the rebel blockade-running steamer Alliance, in Callibogue Sound, Savannah River, where she had got aground. She is a fine Clydebuilt steamer, with a cargo of assorted groceries, the value of which, with the steamer, was estimated at $200,000. The Captain and crew were captured asleep. Gen. PATTON ANDERSON, commanding the rebel forces in Florida, had sent to Gen. HATCH, commanding our forces at Jacksonville, a full list of our soldiers wounded at Olustee, and now in the hands of the enemy. The list will be found elsewhere.

abstract: Currency and Congress
lead_paragraph: The reluctance to tax heavily which Congress has displayed ever since the war began, and, we regret to say, is still displaying, is very remarkable, and is fast becoming incomprehensible. The voice of the public, as expressed through the press, is now strongly in favor of the imposition of as heavy burdens as may be necessary to meet at least the larger portion of the public expenditure; but the indisposition of the House of Representatives to comply with this demand seems now fully as great as ever it was. The Tax Bill is postponed till the latter half of the session -- is introduced slowly and heavily, and apparently with much groaning and moaning; and when ready for action, it is made to stand aside for that most unprofitable of all occupations, the discussion of declamatory resolutions. Moreover, the rapid depreciation of the currency, involving as it inevitably does irretrievable injury to the public credit, and threatening us with national bankruptcy -- the calamity which we have all of us always most dreaded, which our enemies have steadily predicted, and on which they now most rely for our overthrow -- though it sends a thrill of alarm and anxiety throughout the entire country, seems to produce no more impression on Congress than a railroad accident or a Copperhead riot.

abstract: Wall-street Blue Monday
lead_paragraph: -Yesterday was an awfully "blue day" in Wall-street. The liberal subscriptions for the Government Ten-Forties, the heavy payments for duties at the Custom-house, the calling in of loans and the rapid contraction of the volume of circulating notes by the banks, all tended to increase the stringency in the money market and the panic in stocks and merchandise. At the various sessions of the Stock Boards, as well as in the open Street, stocks were thrown on the market unreservedly, and prices were depressed -- lightly on Government securities, but most fearfully on nearly the whole list of "fancies." Principals were mercilessly sacrificed by their brokers, margins wiped out, contracts repudiated, abusive epithets lustily interchanged, and some lively pugilistic exercise indulged in, much to the entertainment of disinterested and patriotic spectators of "the slaughter of the innocents." At the close of the day's festivities lame ducks were a drug in the market, and the erstwhile much envied stock gamblers could find none so poor as to do them reverence. They have sowed the wind and have reaped the whirlwind.

The
lead_paragraph: That any insurance corporation should possess a capital of One Million Dollars is in itself an aston hing fact, so greatly does this sum exceed the capital ordinarily employed. But when such a corporation increases its capital at one bound from one to TWO MILLIONS, it simply astonishes the observer, and makes him more than ever inclined to inquire into the grounds and the methods of such prosperity. The secret of this remarkable success consists in the fact that the officers of the Home determined at the outset to make their company the foremost undertaking in the nation -- to make it known, and trusted, and esteemed, and admired everywhere. And they have faithfully labored for the attainment of this end. They increased their capital from $500,000 to $1,000,000, and they found that the million capital would pay, and now they have increased it to two millions! When we state that during the year 1863 the Home received in premiums the sum of $1,286,000; that the dividends declared on its capital stock of $1,000,000 amounted to $100,000; that it has a gross surplus of $1,210,487 09, the intelligent reader perceives at once that its Directors were wise in trusting to the principle of doing business on a large and constantly increasing capital. The officers were unanimous for the increase; and experience demonstrates that they were right, and that the attributes of success reside in a large stock capital, when well managed!

abstract: -The grand vocal and instrumental concert to be given this evening at Irving Hall. for the benefit of the cause of Poland, deserves to be a success, as well on account of the eminence of the artists who are to take part in it, and the distinguished committee of ladies under whose patronage it is given, as of the charitable object it is intended to subserve. There are few programmes that can show a more powerful array of names than this, and we are quite sure that the public will give the grand concert the great success it merits.

abstract: Lecture on Public Affairs
lead_paragraph: She said that eighty-nine years ago, shot were fired on Concord bridge that echoed round the world. Then commenced a contest which was declared to be for white men only. Massachusetts spilled the first blood on the soil of the North, and she also spilled the first blood on the slave soil of the South, and as the blood flowed over her feet she virtually said that blood shall wash away the stain of Slavery from the soil. [Cheers.] She then proceeded to trace the history of the rebellion, saying, with emphasis, that we did not see what we had to encounter until we met with defeat at the battle of Bull Run. We now know that cannon are radical, and whatever stands in their way will be battered down. To-day we complete three years of this warfare. This is the anniversary of the murder of Massachusetts soldiers in the City of Baltimore. We have passed through the ordeal of battle. Thousands have been slain and thousands are crippled for life, and, after all, have we reformed?

abstract: Speculators in butter had to succumb yesterday. The heavy receipts, restricted consumption, mild weather, and tight money market, proved too much for them. Prime State butter was sold as low as 33 cents in the open market, as against 48@50 cents lb., a few weeks ago; and other grades declined proportionably. Even these comparatively low rates did not tempt buyers to make very liberal purchases, as a further material reduction was deemed inevitable. The tendency of prices was unmistakably favorable to a restoration of this desirable article to the tables of all loyal citizens. Middlemen, hucksters and extortionists should be taught how to read the signs of the times.

abstract: Commissioner OSBORN yesterday decided to discharge JOHN E. COOK, first mate of the ship Victory, who was charged with the homicide of a steerage passenger on a voyage from Liverpool to this port. The evidence for the Government in this case showed that the accused, at most, was only guilty of manslaughter, and he was released on bail several weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: The testimony of the officers of the ship, who were examined for the defence, showed that the accused acted in obedience to the orders of his Captain in attempting to quell what threatened to be a serious mutiny among the steerage passengers, and that violent means and determined action was necessary, in the opinion of the master, for the safety of the ship. This evidence completely justified the mate, and the Commissioner was compelled to discharge him.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Pacific Railroad Bill was reported, with important amendments. The disagreement on the Montana Territorial question came up, but was not disposed of before the morning hour expired. The General Appropriation Bill was considered, and after a few unimportant amendments the bill was passed. The bill for the repeal of the Fugitive Slave Law was called up and read a third time, and the yeas and nays on its passage ordered, when a debate sprang up, and an adjournment was effected without further action on the bill.

abstract: Owing to the extraordinary demand for "greenbacks" on Monday and yesterday, to adjust bank, Sub-Treasury and Custom-house balances, together with the heavy drain in the way of subscriptions to the Ten-forties, Government currency was at a premium of from one to two per cent., and inconveniently scarce even at these rates. Certified checks on local banks, as well as City and State bank bills, were at a discount equivalent to the premium on "greenbacks."

abstract: Sec. Chase's Letter on Price of Gold; Letter on Price of Gold
snippet: Sec. Chase's Letter on Price of Gold; Letter on Price of Gold
lead_paragraph: The two bills now before Congress -- that which taxes the circulation of State banks, and that which prohibits the sale of gold "on time," are intended to remedy these evils; but Mr. CHASE acknowledges that they will be, after all, but partial remedies; that "nothing short of taxation to one-half the amount of our current expenditures, and a reduction of these expenditures to the lowest point compatible with efficiency, will secure financial success to the Government." And he adds that without military success, "all measures will fail." This is the whole matter in a nutshell.

abstract: ITALIAN OPERA. Sig. BELLINI, the favorite baritone, takes his benefit this evening, on which occasion the ever welcome opera of "Faust" will be produced, with KELLOGG, SULZER, MAZZOLENI, BELLINI and HEEMANNS in the cast. To-morrow (Thursday) "La Traviata" will be given, together with the second act of "Un Ballo in Maschera," for the benefit of Mme. ORTOLANI BRIGNOLI.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- "Camille" was written to prove that a woman will sometimes make a sacrifice for love; the "Marble Heart," (produced here on Monday,) to show that she more often does it for money. They are both powerful plays, and when acted with anything like passion, are sure to excite the attention of the public. Mr. BOOTH was, we believe, the first to introduce the "Marble Heart" to an American audience, playing the principal role during his California engagement, and, by the popularity he obtained in it, sweeping all before him. The fanciful and interesting frame work of the play exhibits a remarkable amount of skill and imagination; the situations are frequently intense; the contrasts always effective, and the dialogue generally good and sharp. The character of Raphael affords a fine scope for Mr. BOOTH's powers. In its earlier phases of subdued, but consuming passion, and in the more painful culminations of frenzy and death, with which the piece terminates, it requires exactly the poetic earnestness and giddy grief that he infuses into it. The scene of the interview in the fourth act, and of his return home in the fifth, illustrate these extremes, and we can hardly recall better instances of the range and elevation of this admirable artist's style. It is a poor compliment to say that he is the best Raphael we have ever had in New-York; but it may serve the purpose of directing attention to what must be regarded as a very remarkable performance.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a remonstrance was received from the North Atlantic Steamship Company relative to encroachments upon their pier at the foot of Canal-street, New-York. The following reports were presented: Against the bill relative to planting oysters in the waters of Queens County. Agreed to. The Metropolitan Police Salary Bill was reported, amended by abolishing the office of Excise Commissioners in New-York, Kings and Richmond Counties and vesting the power of granting licenses and enforcing the excise law in the Police Commissioners; abolishing the twenty freeholder requirement, and making the sale of intoxicating liquors on Sundays a misdemeanor. The bill was ordered to a third reading. Against increasing the salary of the Surrogate's Clerk in New-York. The Seventh-avenue Improvement Bill, giving the Park Commissioners control over the same from the Central Park to the Harlem River was passed. The Brooklyn Armory Bill was passed.

We must say we are very glad of it. When men have made up their minds to perpetrate an egregious wrong, the less said about it the better, and a grosser wrong than this it would be hard to imagine. There is not a single argument in its favor, except that we save money by it; and this may be said in favor of any fraud we might take it into our heads to commit.

abstract: -The  Legislature of 1857 appointed a commission, consisting of Messrs. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD,  WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES and ALEXANDER W. BRADFORD,  to prepare, in conformity to the direction of the Constitution, a complete code of the law of this State, other than that relating to the mere procedure of the courts.
lead_paragraph: These gentlemen have just presented to the Legislature their annual report, in which they state that they have prepared and are submitting to the examination of the various judicial officers of the State the draft of a Penal Code, defining all crimes punishable by the State. It is excellently arranged, and in general prepared with remarkable skill and fidelity. It is truly refreshing to a layman to read a proposed statute of which he can understand every word, and which contains none of the useless repetitions, involved sentences and cumbrous provisos, which so generally disfigure our statute books.

abstract: Dispatches from Cairo and Washington report another battle on the Red River, severely contested, in which the rebels were finally beaten, with a loss of 2,000 prisoners and 20 cannon. Our force seems at first to have been repulsed, but Gen. FRANKLIN, with the Nineteenth ...
lead_paragraph: Dispatches from Cairo and Washington report another battle on the Red River, severely contested, in which the rebels were finally beaten, with a loss of 2,000 prisoners and 20 cannon. Our force seems at first to have been repulsed, but Gen. FRANKLIN, with the Nineteenth Army Corps, coming up, the rebels were decidedly repulsed. The reports of a defeat published yesterday, doubtless arose from the fact above stated. The news is very meagre, and is mainly derived from private letters received by Fleet-Capt. PENNOCK, at Cairo, from Grand Ecore and Alexandria, on the 11th and 12th inst.

lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac has now had a long period of rest from battle. It is over nine months since it fought a general engagement, and that was on the soil of Pennsylvania. These nine months it has mainly passed in camp, though in October last, and the two months following, it did some heavy marching and countermarching, and parts of it had encounters with bodies of rebels. But its achievements since last July have been inconsequential, and it is now planted near the position it assumed after the victory of Gettysburgh.

abstract: The examination in the case of John W. Hunter, charged with defrauding the Government, was continued yesterday afternoon. abstract: The steamship Australasian arrived at this port last evening, with news from Europe to Apri1 10  three days later. The Cap  tain of the United States steamer Kearsage had adressed a letter to Lord CLANRICADE, denying ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Australasian arrived at this port last evening, with news from Europe to Apri1 10 three days later. Several later attempts had been made to raise the steamship City of New-York, but so far they had been unsuccessful. The Cap tain of the United States steamer Kearsage had adressed a letter to Lord CLANRICADE, denying that he had enlisted any British subjects, and remarking that his complement of men was always full, with a large number of idle American sailors in British ports ready to ship at any time. In the House of Commons, on the 8th, Mr. LAYARD said, in answer to a question, that the British Government was taking measures to investigate the alleged kidnapping of Irish emigrants into the service of the Federal Army. The particulars of the rebel cotton scheme are published. A large company has been formed with a capital of $1,000,000, to purchase steamers and run the blockade, for the purpose of bringing out cotton to redeem the rebel loan. COLLINS J. MCRAE is the rebel agent in the matter. The Financial Budget was announced in the House of Commons on the 7th, by Mr. GLADSTONE, and made a very favorable impression. The estimated expenditure for the past fiscal year was 68,283,000, but the actual expenditure was 67,056,000. GARIBALDI was still at the Isle of Wight, where he had been treated with the greatest consideration. The freedom of the City of London had been accorded to him, and on his arrival Lord PALMERSTON would entertain him at a banquet. The Danish war was being vigorously prosecuted by the Germans. On the 7th the Prussians opened a terrible bombardment on Duppel and Sonderborg, and it is stated that in the latter place 80 women and children were killed, they not having had notice to leave. The German steamer Rembrandt had been captured by a Danish man-of-war. The Conference would meet in London on the 13th. Another positive announcement was made that MAXIMILIAN's troubles were all settled, and that he would positively leave Trieste for Mexico on the 13th. A very valuable and fast blockade-runner, called the Matilda, had been lost at sea off Landy's Light. She was valued at $300,000.

abstract: The Boston Traveller of Monday evening, says: "Mr. GREEN, the murderer of young CONVERSE, was arraigned at Lowell, this morning, and pleaded guilty to murder in the second degree. He was informed that this plea was not possible under the indictment. After consultation with Messrs. SWEETSER and GRIFFIN, he pleaded guilty in the first degree. Judge HOAR postponed sentence till Monday next. The accused manifested no unusual emotion. The court-room was crowded with spectators."

abstract: Opposition to National Union Convention
lead_paragraph: The New Nation, the newly-established organ in this City of the Presidential interests of Gen. FREMONT, says: "We advise every one at once to give up all idea of taking part in the Baltimore Convention, as that convention is a nonentity." Ordinarily, nobody thinks of pricking up the ears at the sound of a little trumpet. But, in this case, it is well to give a little attention, as we have here an outgiving of a spirit which unquestionably animates some, at least, of the supporters of Gen. FREMONT. It discloses the animus of much of the clamor that has been raised against the assemblage of the National Convention in June rather than September. It is from the very extreme wing of the Union party which has been most obstreperous for a postponement of the convention that is now heard the fanfaronade that the convention itself is "a nonentity" -- which, being interpreted, means that inasmuch as it is settled that the convention cannot be managed, it shall be repudiated.
headline: {'main': 'Factious Opposition to the Union National Convention.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Factious Opposition to the Union National Convention.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Chevalier M. on France, Mexico and the Catholic Faith
snippet: Chevalier M. on France, Mexico and the Catholic Faith
lead_paragraph: MICHEL CHEVALIER, who has of late assum ed the position of Chief Pamphleteer to the Emperor of the French, has just published a remarkable work in two volumes, entitled Mexico, Ancient and Modern. It adds little or nothing to what we already know of Mexico, its main object being to explain and justify the Imperial policy with regard to that country. He undertakes to show that, in interfering in Mexican affairs, France, so far from being guilty of innovation, simply gives force and result to tendencies already existing. He maintains that the "monarchical principle," as it is now the fashion of continental publicists to call it, so far from being extinct in Mexico, is the only one which retains much vitality, and that it has exercised a powerful influence on all Mexican revolutions. It raised ITURBIDE to the imperial throne; kept a strong party round his son FELIX after his own deposition, and led SANTA ANNA to try to induce some European prince to assume the crown. Having, to his own satisfaction, proved the existence of a desire for a monarchy, M. CHEVALIER next proceeds to prove its necessity, and he does this, of course, by simply dwelling on the failure of republican government. As to who the monarch ought to be, it appears that he may be anybody but a Frenchman or Spaniard, and this condition satisfied, nobody answers as well as the Archduke MAXIMILIAN.
headline: {'main': 'France and Mexico The Catholic Faith and the Catholic Powers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'France and Mexico The Catholic Faith and the Catholic Powers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

The bill empowering the authorities of New-York to convey the lands on Ward's Island to the Society for the Care of Destitute Catholic Children, was lost, as also was the bill authorizing the State Banks to form under the National Banking law. The general charity appropriation bill was ordered to a third reading.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the House bill providing for a National currency, secured by the pledge of United States bonds, was reported by Mr. SHERMAN, with several amendments, of which the most important was a striking out of the provision relative to taxation by States of the capital, circulation and business of ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the House bill providing for a National currency, secured by the pledge of United States bonds, was reported by Mr. SHERMAN, with several amendments, of which the most important was a striking out of the provision relative to taxation by States of the capital, circulation and business of banking associations, and the substitution of provisions making these institutions pay half-yearly taxes to the United States. Mr. VAN WINKLE addressed the Senate at length on the bill repealing the Fugitive Slave Law, mainly confining his argument to the point that West Virginia is a legally constituted State in the Union. Bills were passed providing for the printing of the official reports of the armies of the United States, and extending relief to Postmasters who have been robbed by rebels and guerrillas. The bill establishing Assay offices at Garson City, Nevada, and at Dallas City, Oregon, was called up, and after some discussion, the amendment for a branch mint was adopted, and the bill laid aside.

abstract: -- A new and somewhat cunning method of robbery was discovered yesterday afternoon by Officer LEE, of the Second Precinct. A lad, apparently about 14 years old, poorly clad, and having the manners of a rowdy, stationed himself at the front window of Messrs. S.S. LAWRENCE & Co., Bankers, at No. 164 Nassau-street; by means of an ice-pick and a chisel, he, quite unobserved to the clerks in attendance, made a small hole between the class and the sash, and although great numbers of persons were constantly passing along the street he was engaged in his work for nearly halt an hour, during which time he inserted a wire through the small orifice he had made and took from the shell in the window a $50 coupon Treasury note. Had he been content with this booty, he could easily have made his escape with it, but while using his wire in getting a $500 note through the hole he was caught. He was taken to the Station-house, were he gave his name as AUGUSTUS FITZPATRICK. The police succeeded after several searches, in finding the stolen $50 note, where he had secreted it on his person. He was committed to the Tombs for trial.

abstract: Condition of Union Soldiers Exchanged
lead_paragraph: -We have not heard as much of late as we formerly did of the maltreatment of our prisoners at Richmond. It must not be supposed, however, that rebel inhumanity has abated. Nay, their diabolism will never abate as long as it is in their power to exercise it. The slaveholder is born to tyranny and reared to cruelty, and whether he exercise them, as of old, upon his own slaves, or whether, as a rebel, they lead him to perpetrate such massacres as that at Fort Pillow and those of free laboring blacks upon the Mississippi, or whether they instigate him to such a course as that persistently pursued toward our helpless prisoners -- each and all these acts are but manifestations of the same character, inborn or acquired.

abstract: A correspondent of the Chicago Journal, writing from Chattanooga, states that four hundred men from the North, employed as Government laborers on the railroads in this department, have been paid off and discharged for turbulent conduct, and are said to be consigned, under a guard, ...
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Chicago Journal, writing from Chattanooga, states that four hundred men from the North, employed as Government laborers on the railroads in this department, have been paid off and discharged for turbulent conduct, and are said to be consigned, under a guard, to the regions beyond the Ohio. Undoubtedly the most of them are persons who left their homes for the purpose of avoiding enrollment and the draft, and Gen. STEEDMAN has very properly caused a list of the ignoble four hundred to be prepared and forwarded to the Provost Marshals for their consideration. The same writer says that since Feb. 26, thirty-two regiments of reenlisted veterans have had their furloughs and returned to the front.

abstract: Mr. ISHERWOOD, the Engineer-in-Chief of the United States Navy, and Mr. MARTIN, inventor of the Martin boller, have arrived in town, and both visited the Navy-yard and inspected the machinery of the gunboat Chenango. Neither was of opinion that the disaster was caused by any defect in the boiler, but believe that some unexplained agency in the engineroom occasioned it. The distinguished visitors will leave for the National Capital to-day.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ISHERWOOD, the Engineer-in-Chief of the United States Navy, and Mr. MARTIN, inventor of the Martin boller, have arrived in town, and both visited the Navy-yard and inspected the machinery of the gunboat Chenango. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details ...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of fall military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: and the Administration
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead journals have recommenced their old trickery of pretending that the Administration embarrasses and obstructs the movements of the Army of the Potomac. This has been their game from the time MCCLELLAN was in command. The object is two-fold -- first to foment all the jealousy and ill-will possible between the army and the Government, and again to cast all the responsibility of military failure upon the Aministration, at the same time forestalling all credit to the Administration for military success. There never was such impudence as in the pertinacity with which this system of misrepresentation was maintained during the fifteen months of MCCLELLAN's leadership. Subsequent developments have shown that the Administration, during that period, never ceased to urge upon MCCLELLAN the extreme importance of the most vigorous action, and that it furnished every possible facility to that end; and yet these unscrupulous sheets Kept up an incessant clamor against the Administration for standing in the way for the triumphant march of the eager MCCLELLAN! Precisely as they abused the Administration for the delays of MCCLELLAN, they abused it for the advance and defeat of BURNSIDE at Fredericksburgh, not flagging in that abuse until that General, over his own signature, demonstrated that the Washington authorities were free from all blame in the premises. Upon no one subject has their vilification of the President expended itself more recklessly than upon his alleged interference with the plans of the Commanders of the Army of the Potomac. It is simply in keeping with this vile game that the World of yesterday says: "By retaining Gen. HALLECK as his chief military adviser, and keeping Secretary STANTON at the head of the War Department, Mr. LINCOLN retained in his hands the means of quietly thwarting the new General-in-Chief whenever it should suit his purpose," and predicts that Gen. GRANT will not be suffered to strike a blow until after the Baltimore Convention, so that there shall be no failure of GRANT which would damage the Administration, and no success which would bring into the Presidential field a dangerous competitor.

abstract: There has been quite a "flurry" in the wool market during the last week on the line of the Michigan Central Railroad. The wool buyers have been very active in trying to make purchases. Mr. TAYLOR, of Dexter, has bargained for 10,000 lbs., to be delivered the coming week, engaging to pay 68 to 70 cents, and a higher price, if the market will warrant it. The Messrs. NOBLES, of Albion, have engaged to take 15,000 lbs. at the same rates. Mr. R. ALDRICH, of Parma, the managing agent for the Wool Growers' Association of that place, (who have 60,000 lbs. on hand,) received a telegram from his agent in Boston, on Wednesday, that he had sold 23,000 lbs. on Tuesday, for 81 cents, and that he had an offer of that price for the balance. The agent had been instructed to sell at 80 cents, and in his telegram states that he could get 81 cents for the balance, but deemed it prudent to hold on. At Jackson the wool buyers are offering from 73 to 76 cents for good to fair wools. -Detroit Free Press, April 17.

abstract: These Bonds are issued under the Act of Congress of March 8, 1864, which provides that in lieu of so much of the loan authorized by the Act of March 3, 1863, to which this is supplementary, the Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to borrow, from time to time, on the credit of ...
lead_paragraph: These Bonds are issued under the Act of Congress of March 8, 1864, which provides that in lieu of so much of the loan authorized by the Act of March 3, 1863, to which this is supplementary, the Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to borrow, from time to time, on the credit of the United States, not exceeding TWO HUNDRED MILLION DOLLARS during the current fiscal year, and to prepare and issue therefor Coupon and Registered Bonds of the United States; and all Bonds issued under this Act shall be EXEMPT FROM TAXATION by or under any State or municipal authority. Subscriptions to these Bonds are received in United States notes or notes of National Banks. They are TO BE REDEEMED IN COIN, at the pleasure of the Government, at any period not less than ten nor more than forty years from their date, and until their redemption FIVE PER CENT. INTEREST WILL BE PAID IN COIN, on Bonds of not over one hundred dollars annually, and on all other Bonds semi-annually.

abstract: --Two young men, who gave their names as CHARLES PARKER and THOMAS PARSONS, were arrested on Wednesday afternoon, by Roundsman FERRIS, of the Broadway Squad, on the charge of stealing $350 worth of silk and other goods from the store of Messrs. ESCHER & DORLER, NO. 9 Warren-street. One of the accused made a small purchase, and tendered in payment a $100 Treasury note. While the clerk went out to obtain change, the goods were pocketed by the thieves. After arrest they were searched, and the whole of the stolen property was found upon them. Justice DOWLING committed them both to the Tombs.

abstract: A force of from ten to fifteen thousand rebels marched upon Plymouth, N.C., last Sunday, and opened an impetuous attack upon its defences. Fort Gray, about one mile from the town, was vigorously bombarded, and twice attempted to be carried by the bayonet. In each instance, however, the enemy were repulsed with great slaughter, and the town is considered impregnable to their assaults.
lead_paragraph: A force of from ten to fifteen thousand rebels marched upon Plymouth, N.C., last Sunday, and opened an impetuous attack upon its defences. Fort Gray, about one mile from the town, was vigorously bombarded, and twice attempted to be carried by the bayonet. In each instance, however, the enemy were repulsed with great slaughter, and the town is considered impregnable to their assaults. Our gunboats are said to have borne the brunt of the fighting, and did effective work -- not, however, without suffering to some extent; one report says that the Whitehead was sunk by the rebel shot. Four of the enemy's gunboats and one iron-clad came down to the obstructions in the Roanoke River, six miles from the town, to cooperate with the land forces. Simultaneously with this attack, the rebels are reported to have made a demonstration against Newbern.

abstract: The provision made by Congress, and to which, it is said, immediate effect is to be given by the proper department, for the issue of penny and two-penny bits of almost pure copper, offers, we fear, no remedy against the hoarders of nickel. The more valuable the coin is, intrinsically, the more it will be run upon by the dealers in small change. A large issue of the new coinage might release a portion of the nickel now stowed away. But the principal gainer thereby, after all, would not be the long-suffering public, but the petty speculator. A new denomination of the postal currency, corresponding to the three-cent postage stamp, is the only feasible means of relief.

abstract: The presence here of the Governors of Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Iowa and Wisconsin, has reference to the defence of those States against rebel raids. They are urging upon the President the necessity for a call of two hundred thousand six months' volunteers for special service.
lead_paragraph: The presence here of the Governors of Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Iowa and Wisconsin, has reference to the defence of those States against rebel raids. They are urging upon the President the necessity for a call of two hundred thousand six months' volunteers for special service. Four of the above-named Western States propose to furnish one-half. These troops, if raised, are to be placed along the Ohio River, and will be used to perform duties which are now performed by efficient and experienced regiments. The President has expressed himself favorable to the proposition.

abstract: Prospect of Increased
lead_paragraph: The people will breathe the freer now that there is the prospect of good stiff taxation. Their faint-hearted representatives at last understand that longer evasion of their duty will not be tolerated, and are fairly buckling to the work. They are showing, too, an independence in resisting the appeals of lobbyists for special favor, that is worthy of praise. It seems to be well apprehended that it is a public wrong to comply with these appeals, however plausible. If the House sticks to the interests of the people in this style for a week longer, it will excite the liveliest astonishment and gratitude.

abstract: Torpedo Corps
lead_paragraph: -The rebels have succeeded in destroying another of our steamers in Florida by a torpedo. We refer to the General Hunter, a stout, handsome, very fast light draught transport vessel, which has been on service about a year and a half in the Department of the South. She was plying in the St. John's River when she was blown up, and the affair occurred just at the point where the Maple Leaf was recently destroyed by the same means. It is just as well that there will be no further occasion for our vessels to navigate that stream at present. It is always perilous for our boats to navigate rebel streams whose banks are not commanded by our troops. Even if so commanded there is peril, but much less than otherwise.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, among the bills which passed was the Metropolitan Police Bill, as amended by the Conference Committee by striking out the clause abolishing the office of Excise Commissioners in New-York, Kings and Richmond Counties, and inserting the clause "that upon the general resumption of specie payments, the pay of the Force shall be the same as before the passing of this act."
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, among the bills which passed was the Metropolitan Police Bill, as amended by the Conference Committee by striking out the clause abolishing the office of Excise Commissioners in New-York, Kings and Richmond Counties, and inserting the clause "that upon the general resumption of specie payments, the pay of the Force shall be the same as before the passing of this act." The substitute for the Assembly Militia Bill was adopted. It appropriates $350,000, for arming, equipping and uniforming the militia, and leaves the organization of the National Guard as under the law of 1862. A bill was passed providing for the sale of the Quarantine lands. The resolution requesting Representatives in Congress to vote for the law repealing the act exempting Government securities from State taxation was referred to the Finance Committee by a party vote. The following bills were passed: Incorporating the Long Island City Water Works; empowering the Commissioners of Emigration to sell unclaimed baggage; making appropriations for the canal expenses for the fiscal year; the General Charity Appropriation Bill; incorporating the Greenpoint and Williamsburgh Railroad Company; authorizing the extension of the Hoboken-street Pier, New-York; authorizing State Banks to organize under the National Banking Law (Assembly bill.) Yeas 14, Nays 8 -- the Democrats voting in the negative.

abstract: The great sword contest will close to-day. It has been as entertaining as meaningless, and as profitable as exciting. It has brought close upon twenty thousand dollars to the treasury of the fair, and to the relief of sick and wounded soldiers. The fact that one person could cast as many votes as he pleased, by simply paying a dollar for each, rendered the voting worthless in the way of ascertaining the popular preference between the two Generals who were in nomination. But still, the plan was a good one; for the primary object of the whole thing was to raise money for the cause, and not to learn who was the greatest General in popular estimation.

abstract: and D. C. Delegates
lead_paragraph: -- We see that a small quarrel has sprung up in the District of Columbia, over the election of delegates to the Union National Convention. There is a "split" in the party. Two organizations claim to be regular, and each warns the loyal public against being deceived by the other. The first query that occurs to us, in pondering this matter, is why the District of Columbia elects delegates to the National Convention at all. That Convention is expected to nominate a President, and to represent, in the selection of a candidate, the opinions and wishes of those whose votes are to elect him. There is to be a certain number of deligates for each State, or for each district of a State, that has votes to cast; and a majority of these delegates is to select a candidate whom all pledge their constituents to support. But the District of Columbia has no votes to cast for President. The wishes and preferences of the citizens of that District have no weight in the election of a President: why should they have in the nomination? They may prefer one man, while those whose votes are to decide the result prefer another. What justice or wisdom is there in thus allowing those who cannot vote to select the candidate for those who can?

abstract: DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN ANN-STREET DAMAGE OVER $30,000, Soon after 5 o'clock yesterday morning, Officer STRONG, of the Second Police Precinct, discovered flames issuing from the machine-shop of WM. McKENZIE, situated in the rear of No. 45 Annstreet, between Nassau and William streets.
lead_paragraph: DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN ANN-STREET -- DAMAGE OVER $30,000, -- Soon after 5 o'clock yesterday morning, Officer STRONG, of the Second Police Precinct, discovered flames issuing from the machine-shop of WM. McKENZIE, situated in the rear of No. 45 Annstreet, between Nassau and William streets. The firemen were promptly on the ground, but owing to the combustible nature of the contents, the building, stock and fixtures, were entirely destroyed in a short time. Mr. MCKENZIE estimates his loss at over $15,000. Unfortunately for him, he was entirely uninsured. Mr. WM. FULLER was the owner of the building. His loss is about $5,000; fully insured in City companies. The fire extended through to Beekman-street. The drug-store of Messrs. H.C. & W. FULLER, situated at No. 13 on the latter street, was very badly damaged by water. Their loss will probably amount to between $8,000 and $10,000; fully insured. The wholesale drug-store of Mr. EDWARD H. TEUX, No. 15 Beekman-street, took fire several times, but the flames were speedily extinguished. The damage to their stock is several thousand dollars, principally by water. The origin of the fire is as yet unknown. Marshal BAKER is making an investigation.

abstract: Van Winkle, Senator, and Buncomb Speeches
snippet: Van Winkle, Senator, and Buncomb Speeches
lead_paragraph: Mr. VAN WINKLE, of Western Virginia, on Thursday, in the Senate, when the bill for the repeal of the Fugitive Slave law came up for consideration, opened the debate by saying that, "The remarks he would make, though not particularly applicable to the bill under consideration, would not be inappropriate." He then proceeded to make a speech, in which he discussed the loyalty of the Border States; the absurdity of the Copperheads; the constitutionality of the admission of Western Virginia to the Union, and the circumstances attending that event; the extent to which the new State had contributed men to the army; the consequences that would have followed her failure or refusal to do so; and it was only at the close of his long speech, if we are to judge from the summary, that he found time and opportunity to say a few words upon the subject before the Senate. That "these remarks were not particularly applicable to the bill under consideration," so far from being a matter of no great moment, as Mr. VAN WINKLE seems to think, did, in fact, render them peculiarly inappropriate; and the erroneous notions of the nature and objects of parliamentary discussion, which he seems to entertain, are so widespread, and are just now doing so much mischief, that we seize this opportunity of protesting against them. Congress is not a debating club, in which discussions are carried on for the sake of discussion. It is an assembly for the prosecution of serious and important business -- just now the most serious and important that was ever laid before any deliberative body. There are a great number of questions before it, all of them of the highest moment, and each of them, every time it comes up, demands the serious and undivided attention of every member present. This cannot be given, and will not be given, as long as anybody who has possession of the floor is permitted to make long, rambling speeches upon everything that comes into his head, except the subject that is legitimately before him. The waste of time which this practice causes, the restless, scatter-brained, indolent style of thinking which it inevitably produces, the extent to which it protracts the debates on every measure, are just now evils of the first magnitude, and something ought to be done to put an end to them. The practice itself is a legacy bequeathed to us by the old times -- for they are now old times -- before the war, when the one subject of discussion was Slavery -- and when everybody knew so well what everybody else would say about it, that it made little difference what he said, particularly as Congress had little else to do than to listen to him. As there was plenty time, and no other means of keeping himself before the public, every member felt it his duty to give, at least once in every session, a full history of the Slavery controversy from the foundation of the Government down to the year 1850; then to castigate his opponents severely, and finally to expose the immorality, cruelty and waste of slaveholding, ending with some caustic remarks upon the trouble and dismay that would be caused amongst the European aristocracies, by the prospective growth of the Republic.

abstract: Information respecting the attack upon Plymouth, N.C., is not as full or as satisfactory as we could wish. The dispatches say that a ram came down to within a few miles of the town and attacked the fleet, sinking the gunboats Bombshell and Southfield, and one other gunboat, the name of which was not learned.
lead_paragraph: Information respecting the attack upon Plymouth, N.C., is not as full or as satisfactory as we could wish. The dispatches say that a ram came down to within a few miles of the town and attacked the fleet, sinking the gunboats Bombshell and Southfield, and one other gunboat, the name of which was not learned. This report is discredited, however, by very good authority. North Carolina (rebel) journals contain intimations of the rampant and widespread disaffection which exists toward the Confederate Government throughout the State. The Governor's Council which convened at Raleigh, had declined calling the Legislature together, fearing that it would array the State against the Confederacy.

abstract: Magazines for April
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly Magazine, for May, makes its appearance in advance of the usual time, no doubt in kindly consideration for New-Yorkers, who, in obedience to immemorial custom, devote the first days of that month to pursuits far other than literary, and for "moving incidents" have no need to turn to the pages of history or fiction. It opens with an interesting sketch of "Life with the Esquimaux," condensed from Mr. C.F. HALL's narrative of his "Arctic Research Expedition" for the recovery of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN, in 1860-62, about to be published by Messrs. HARPERS. The paper abounds with illustrations, of unusual merit, that depict nature in some of her wildest moods. The other matter-of-fact article is "A Visit to the convent of Sittna, (Our Lady) Dameane," by Rev. G. LANSING, American Missionary at Cairo. The trip it records is entirely out of the usual beaten track of Egyptian travel. The convent is in the Delta, near the ancient city of Bulestes, and its patroness is identified by curious coincidences with the Goddess Latona, formerly worshipped there. With the exception of two short articles, "The Second Division at Shiloh," and "A Suppressed Princess," occupied with the claims of an English pretender to royal blood, the remainder of the number is entirely dedicated to fiction: TROLLOPE's "Small House at Allington," and the second instalment of THACKERAY's post-humous story, "Denis Duval," being the pieces de resistance, interspersed with several novelettes, mostly of American life, and an Italian sketch, of more pretensions, "Psyche." The "Editors Table and Drawer" offer their usual variety.

abstract: Spencer, Herbert. Illustrations of Universal Progress; Cleveland, W. S. Hints to Riflemen
snippet: Spencer, Herbert. Illustrations of Universal Progress; Cleveland, W. S. Hints to Riflemen
lead_paragraph: Mr. SPENCER occupies at this time a position entirely unique and exceptional among philosophical thinkers not only of England, but also of the people of English speech in the New World. A marked want of comprehensiveness and breadth of thought has been always alleged by continental writers as characteristic of English inquirers into the mysteries of nature. Each man has worked in the sphere of his selection, polishing some corner-stone of the Temple of Science, but unable or scarcely seeking to realize the grand ideas that dominate and define the all-embracing relations of the structure itself. This exclusive devotion to limited practical views, and actual shrinking from the generalizations that more brilliant geniuses might draw from them is deplored by some writers, as Dr. WHEWELL and others who have pointed out the positive benefits of theory and hypothesis, even if not the truth itself, yet as an arrangement and coordination of ascertained facts, lending support to each other, and leading, when studied in this light, to results that isolated observation could never attain. Mr. SPENCER, however, alone among his countrymen, belongs the distinction of aiming to grasp in one grand symmetrical arrangement the two worlds of Matter and Spirit. He proposes no less a task than to unfold a complete philosophy of nature, physical, organic, mental and social, such as science now, for the first time, made possible -- such as, if successfully executed, will constitute a momentous step in the progress of thought.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to amend the Pacific Railroad Act was made the special order for Thursday next. The wool-growers of Addison County, Vermont, sent in a remonstrance against the tariff on wool, characterizing it as a double failure, which neither would raise revenue nor afford protection.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to amend the Pacific Railroad Act was made the special order for Thursday next. The wool-growers of Addison County, Vermont, sent in a remonstrance against the tariff on wool, characterizing it as a double failure, which neither would raise revenue nor afford protection. The House bill to establish a Bureau of Military Justice was taken up and passed. It authorizes a bureau consisting of a Judge Advocate and two Assistant Judge-Advocates -- the former with the rank of Brigadier-General and pay of $4,000 per year, and the latter with rank of Colonels and pay of $3,000. The Army Appropriation Bill was taken up and the amendments of the Senate Finance Committee were agreed to. This bill puts colored soldiers on the same footing with white.

abstract: - Quite an excitement was caused yesterday noon, by an alarm of fire proceeding from Public School No. 19, corner of South Second and Tenth streets. Brooklyn, E.D. Many imagined that the children would be much injured in escaping, if lives were not lost; but, as the pupils had just been dismissed at noon, no panic was created A defect in one of the heaters was the cause of the fire, which was extinguished with merely nominal damage.

abstract: The sale of this remarkable collection will commence on Monday the 2d of May next, at the auction rooms of Messrs. BANGS, MERWIN & Co., in Broadway, and will most likely occupy the whole of the evenings of that and the succeeding week, as, in addition to the books, the catalogue includes the collection of engravings, autographs, mineral specimens, snuff boxes, old silver plate, china, paintings, and miscellaneous curiosities difficult to reduce to any special arrangement. All who knew the late Mr. ALLAN must regret the breaking up of this, one of the last remaining vestiges of old New-York, and will dwell with pleasure on the remembrance of the snug and cosy little house in Vandewater-street, a true Knickerbocker abode, crammed to overflowing with all sorts of literary and graphic treasures, now about to be ruthlessly dispersed by the fiat of the auctioneer. The owner, too, was worthy of, and in keeping with, the collection for more than sixty years, before the commencement of the present century, his slight, active form, and shrewd, intelligent face, that seemed to bid defiance to the ravages of time, was never absent when choice articles that attracted his taste were to be procured; hardly a day, indeed, passed in all that period, in which he did not "pick up" some rare coin, some brilliant old etching to insert in his illustrated volumes, some curiosity, artistic or literary, recommended to him by associations connected with his native or adopted country. There was no pretence of connoisseurship about Mr. ALLAN; he was, indeed, the first to joke upon his own pursuits, but they were genuine and unaffected. The pastime and employment of along life, his books were the continua solace and delight of his lengthening years, and to the last his affection for them continued unabated. The result of the sale will no doubt prove that his tastes were far from singular, and that fellow amateurs exist in sufficient numbers to cause the most lively competition for the objects of his enduring affection.

abstract: Yesterday, the sixteenth day of the fair, and the first on which tickets were sold for 25 cents, was an excellent day. The buildings were kept constantly filled. Over fourteen thousand tickets were received at the door, the largest number taken on any one day since the opening of the fair, and the receipts were very satisfactory. The season tickets were not used yesterday, and the buildings in consequence, though crowded, were not jammed.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- The grand gala matinee to-day concludes Mr. MARETZEK's present season. The programme is of extraordinary interest. It opens with "La Somnambula," which will be played entire; after the opera comes the "Wedding March," by MENDELSSOHN, played by the fine orchestra of the establishment; then the grand duet from the "Merry Wives of Windsor," (with HERMANNS and WEINLICH,) and then the celebrated duet from "Otello," (by Signor MAZZOLENI and BELLINI.) This is indeed a sumptuous bill for SHAKESPEARE's birthday, and when it is remembered that all over the expenses will be handed over to the fund to erect the monument in Central Park to the memory of the bard, there will, we hope, be an ample margin for that meritorious undertaking.

abstract: Massacre the, and Jeff. Davis' Policy
snippet: Massacre the, and Jeff. Davis' Policy
lead_paragraph: -There is now an overwhelming and painfully minute mass of proof of the truth of the first reports of the rebel massacre of our troops, black and white, at Fort Pillow. We have had, and have given, the evidence of eye-witnesses, the evidence of victims offered in their last moments, the evidence of persons who visited the scene of the butchery immediately after it, and we have had other evidence not less conclusive, such as the arrival at Cairo of some of the bodies, which bore upon them marks of the worst barbarities charged against the rebels. It now only requires the official statement of the officers appointed to investigate the matter, to furnish irrefragable proof for history. It was superserviceable labor on the part of any one to deny the massacre, in behalf of the rebels. JEFF. DAVIS officially proclaimed this to be his policy, and he was backed up in his ferocious proclamation by the whole rebel press. To deny that the rebels would carry out their measure is preposterous to the perception of all of us who know that, atrocious as rebel threats have been, their deeds have always been more bloody than their threats. We have not yet had the Southern defense of the massacre and their jubilations over it; but their organs in the North have already justified it as a perfectly proper act of war.

abstract: Bryan, Mr., Donation of his Picture Gallery to N. Y. Hist. Soc.
snippet: Bryan, Mr., Donation of his Picture Gallery to N. Y. Hist. Soc.
lead_paragraph: The surprise and delight exhibited by the thousands of all degrees, who have visited the Picture Gallery of the Metropolitan Fair, have suggested to many, for the first time, and renewed in other minds more emphatically, the need, desirableness and practicability of a permanent and free gallery of art in this City. The third metropolis of the civilized world should not longer be without such a benign provision for and promoter of high civilization. Within the last few years the advance of public taste and the increased recognition of art in this country, have been among the most interesting phenomena of the times. A score of eminent and original landscape painters have achieved the highest reputations, private collections of pictures have become a new social attraction, exhibitions of works of art have grown lucrative and popular, buildings expressly for studios have been erected, sales of pictures by auction have produced unprecedented sum-of money, art-shops are a delectable feature of Broadway, artist-receptions are favorite reunions of the Winter, and a splendid edifice will soon be completed devoted to the academy, and owing its erection to public munificence, while a School of Design is in successful operation at the Cooper Institute. Nor is this all; at Rome, Paris' Florence and Dusseldorf, as well as at Chicago, Albany, Buffalo, Philadelphia, Boston and New-York, there are native ateliers, schools or collections, the fame whereof has raised our national character and enhanced our intellectual resources as a people. These and many other facts indicate, too plainly to be mistaken, that the time has come to establish permanent and standard galleries of art, on the most liberal scale, in our large cities. Heretofore the absence of fire-proof buildings has prevented many Americans of wealth and taste from contributing to such institutions as include the Fine Arts in their objects. Only last week a fire occurred in Boston, whereby several invaluable historical portraits were destroyed, and the risk of such catastrophies deters prudential lovers of artistic treasures from indulging at once their public spirit and private taste, by presenting works of art to such institutions as already exist. No sooner did the New-York Historical Society possess a fire-proof edifice than valuable donations began there to accumulate; the Nineveh marbles, the Egyptian museum, the Audubon collections, portraits, statues and relics were gratefully confided to this secure and eligible institution. It was soon found inadequate as to space, and the late President, with some of the more enterprising members, obtained a charter from the Legislature for a museum of art and antiquities, to be erected in the Central Park, and open to the public, as are similar institutions in Europe, As a nucleus for the statuary department the casts from CRAWFORD's Roman studio are most appropriate and valuable; they are already stored in the old Arsenal. It has been proposed that a permanent collection of arms and trophies, such as have attracted such crowds of delighted visitors at the fair, should constitute another feature. But our present object is to call attention to the munificent donation of THOMAS J. BRYAN, of his rare and costly gallery of pictures to the New-York Historical Society. It numbers two hundred and fifty pictures, and is valued at one hundred thousand dollars. It is no casual gathering of odds and ends, such as may be brought together in any European capital by the mere expenditure of tasteless ambition. During many years of residence abroad, Mr. BRYAN collected, one after another, of these interesting works. To him it was a labor of love. At Paris he enjoyed signal advantages; and there are many exquisite specimens of the early French, Flemish and Italian schools in his gallery, such as are now not to be obtained at any price. As a collection it is remarkable for the number of small master-pieces -- those gems which the amateur loves to hang in library, boudoir and salon, and contemplate habitually, and with unsated relish. We remember pictures of TENIERS, RUYSDAEL, WALTCAN, WOUVERMAN, etc., which discover new charms the more they are studied; add to these the fine examplars of Italian masters, and several valuable historical portraits acquired in this country -- such as a WASHINGTON, by STUART, and PRIESTLEY, and JEFFERSON, by PEALE -- and its not easy to estimate the importance of such a collection as the basis of a Metropolitan gallery. We remember when Mr. BRYAN first brought his pictures to New-York, that a call upon him was like visiting a venerable burgomaster of Holland, or a merchant prince of Florence, in her palmy days. He had collected his treasures in the second story of a building corner of Broadway and Thirteenth-street; and seated there a vigilant and enamored custode, in an old arm-chair, with his snow-white hair, gazing round the walls covered with mellow tints, delicious figures vivid or picturesque landscapes -- chef d'oeuvres or pictorial art, hallowed and endeared by memorable names -- he seemed to belong to another sphere, and we to have wandered from Babel to Elysium in thus entering his gallery from bustling and garish Broadway. And now that he has bestowed these treasures on our City, let us appreciate the gift by making it the starting point of an enterprise worthy of a cultivated people in a prosperous republic. There is an essential element to every national gallery, and that the most difficult to supply; we mean a series of the earliest pictures down to the highest phase of the art in the fifteenth century -- in other words, a chronological series. By a remarkable coincidence one of our countrymen, through years of vigilant activity in Italy, succeeded in making such a collection at a cost of sixty-six thousand dollars. This collection is about to be broken up and sold piecemeal, unless it can be secured by the contributions of our citizens, to be added to Mr. BRYAN's splendid donation, whereby a complete and invaluable gallery would be formed. A committee of the Historical Society has been appointed to receive subscriptions, in order to accept the very generous offer of Mr. JARVES to present his collection to the institution provided it is relieved from a mortgage of twenty-five thousand dollars. We cannot doubt that a sum so insignificant compared to the value and importance or the acquisition, will be at once forthcoming when the project is made known to our wealthy and art-loving citizens. We subjoin the names and address of the committee:

abstract: Shakespeare Tercentenary in New-York
lead_paragraph: Yesterday awoke lowering and gloomy, and so continued until ten A.M., when the clouds gave way, the sun shone brightly, and the first beautiful, genial and glorious day of Spring was born. It was fitting. It was, the day on which America paid homage to the memory of SHAKESPEARE, and sought to honor his genius and give tangible and permanent form to the demonstrations. Certain Dramatic circles had decided upon a monument, and yesterday being the three hundredth anniversary of his birth, was selected as the time on which to lay the corner stone. The design, it is supposed, will be intrusted to our accomplished countrywoman, Miss HOSMER; the desire is that the monument shall be purely American. The location given, and cordially given, by the Par[???] Commissioners, was at the southeast corner of the Ma[???]l, a most prominent and beautiful one. The hour designated for the ceremonies was 12 M., and at the moment they began. A not very large but indisputably a very elegant and intellectual audience was assembled; very many ladies, fair, beautiful and bright; the poet, the sculptor, the painter, the historian and the jurist, the ministers to the mind and those to the body; those famed and honored in the profession, which to the Bard of Avon owes so much, and those who seek fame and honor in it; critics of the keen yet just, generous pen; the journalist and the literateur -- some of all were there.
