abstract: If it be the enormousness or the enormity of our tax-levy for the coming year that hinders the Common Council from making the appropriation of two or three dollars that would be necessary to pull up the hideous half-rotten posts that are stuck over the City Hall Park and imperil the limbs of pedestrians after dark -- if the motive for retaining them in place be an economical one, we can commend the motive, even while we give the opinion that it is not founded upon perfect knowledge. For we feel sure that the removal of the posts might be made a source of revenue instead of expense. Let the privilege of removing them be sold by the City to the highest bidder. At the rate kindling-wood is selling, there must be at least twenty dollars worth of these posts, and some industrious poor man might pull them all out and chop them up in a day, and make a good thing out of the job, even though he had to pay ten dollars into the City Treasury for the privilege of getting it.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. BAILY made a majority report on the Low vs. Niven contested seat case, awarding the seat to Mr. Low by ten majority, Mr. SHAFFER made a minority report in favor of Mr. NIVEN, awarding him the seat by twenty-five majority. Both the reports were laid on the table. The following were among the bills passed: The New-York County Tax Levy, appropriating $30,000 for monuments to the New-York soldiers slain on the fields of Gettysburgh and Antietam; authorizing the erection of a public market in the Eighteenth Ward; amending the law enabling convicts to work commutation of sentence; the State Tax Bill of 5 1/2 mills; the New Capitol Bill -- it appropriates $10,000 for plans and specifications; Relative to the Common Schools in the City of New-York; Relief of the Peoples' Gas Light Company; Conferring additional power on Marshals in New-York; to amend the Brooklyn Charter; a resolution of thanks to Lieut.-Gov. JONES for the ability, dignity and unswerving impartiality with which he has presided over the Senate, passed unanimously. Gov. SEYMOUR sent in a message in favor of paying the interest to all State creditors in coin, which was tabled by a vote of 14 against 13.

abstract: The examination in the case of JOHN W. HUNTER was concluded yesterday afternoon, and resulted in establishing Mr. HUNTER's entire innocence of fraud or complicity with the parties who forged the checks. The District-Attorney and Mr. GERARD, counsel for the Government, terminated the case by declaring themselves perfectly satisfied that Mr. HUNTER was free from even a suspicion of guilt, and expressed a wish that reparation might be made for a wrong unintentionally done him. A full report will be found in the law column of this paper.

abstract: St. Lawrence Canal Tolls
lead_paragraph: -Our lake traders are interested in the report that the Government of Canada have conditionally reduced (by about one-half) the tolls on the most important articles of freight passing through the Provincial canals. The object of this reduction appears at first sight to be, to offer a premium upon international trade. A closer examination shows it to be the very reverse. The purpose the new Ministry have in view is to divert as much as possible of the trade of the West from the ports of northern New-York to Montreal. The canal tolls are to operate hereafter differentially in favor of the St. Lawrence route. Thus, shippers in passing through the river canals will have the tax they paid on the Welland Canal refunded. The Oswego shipper, of course, loses the benefit of all this. He pays his full toll for the Welland Canal privilege, as heretofore, and must be content to see a premium offered for carrying the Western trade past his door.

abstract: JOHN W. DOBBINS, a deserter from the United State army, was hanged at Dayton, on Friday, for the murder, on the 14th of February 1863, of a farmer named LINDENMOOD, who had wandered out of town with DOBBINS, both being intoxicated, when the latter killed him and robbed him of his money. DOBBINS was arrested soon after, and tried in the June following. The jury failed to agree; was tried in November and convicted.
lead_paragraph: JOHN W. DOBBINS, a deserter from the United State army, was hanged at Dayton, on Friday, for the murder, on the 14th of February 1863, of a farmer named LINDENMOOD, who had wandered out of town with DOBBINS, both being intoxicated, when the latter killed him and robbed him of his money. DOBBINS was arrested soon after, and tried in the June following. The jury failed to agree; was tried in November and convicted. The case was then carried to the Supreme Court on a writ of error, when the verdict to the court below was sustained and sentence ordered to be executed. The Journal says:

abstract: About a year ago, Mr. WM. B. BARBER, well known on 'Change as a grain and provision speculator of somewhat fickle fortune, but of invincible energy, bought of the executors of the late ALFRED LARGE the splendid mansion, known as "Large's," fronting on Clinton-street, west side, between Union and President, South Brooklyn, for the sum of $40,000. Mr. BARBER made it his residence during the year. A few weeks ago he exchanged it for the very handsome house and grounds of Mr. AUGUSTUS E. MASTERS, running through from First to Second-place, also in South Brooklyn, Mr. MASTERS paying to Mr. BARBER $25,000 cash to boot. Very speedily Mr. BARBER found a buyer for the Masters property at $40,000 cash, just the price paid a year ago for large mansion and grounds on Clinton-street. Mr. BARBER thus netted $25,000 for a year's investment of $40,000. Since he sold the Masters property he has purchased of the executors of the late EDWARD KELLOGG the first-class extra wide three-story and attic brick house, No. 166 President-street, south side, with three lots of ground, handsomely laid out, for the sum of $21,000.

Mr. BARBER made it his residence during the year. A few weeks ago he exchanged it for the very handsome house and grounds of Mr. AUGUSTUS E. MASTERS, running through from First to Second-place, also in South Brooklyn, Mr. MASTERS paying to Mr. BARBER $25,000 cash to boot. Very speedily Mr. BARBER found a buyer for the Masters property at $40,000 cash, just the price paid a year ago for large mansion and grounds on Clinton-street. Mr. BARBER thus netted $25,000 for a year's investment of $40,000. Since he sold the Masters property he has purchased of the executors of the late EDWARD KELLOGG the first-class extra wide three-story and attic brick house, No. 166 President-street, south side, with three lots of ground, handsomely laid out, for the sum of $21,000.

abstract: The Senate was not in session yesterday. In the House, a bill was passed creating an additional Supervising Inspector of Steamboats for New-Orleans and Boards of Local Inspectors at Portland, Oregon, and at Memphis, Tenn, A resolution was adopted amending the fourth section of the Act of March 2, 1793, empowering United States Commissioners to take bail in criminal cases and providing them with a seal. The committee who investigated the charges against Representative BLAIR, of Missouri, of speculating in liquors, while in military command in the Department of Missouri, reported that Mr. BLAIR had not violated any law. Some remarks followed of a personal character from Mr. BLAIR and his accuser, Mr. MCCLURG. The consideration of the Internal Tax Bill was then resumed, the House having resolved itself into a committee for that purpose.

abstract: A case of unusual interest, and, so far as we have been able to obtain the evidence in the matter, also one of unusual turpitude, was brought to light yesterday afternoon at the Essex Market Police Court.
lead_paragraph: A case of unusual interest, and, so far as we have been able to obtain the evidence in the matter, also one of unusual turpitude, was brought to light yesterday afternoon at the Essex Market Police Court. Mr. JOHN D. LEWIS, of the firm of J.D. LEWIS & CO., wholesale dry goods merchants, doing business at No. 101 Chambers-street, corner of Church, was arrested on the charge of having conspired to murder a respectable merchant of this City, named JOHN H. ANDERSON. For the purpose of effecting his designs, it seems that LEWIS made an agreement with JEREMIAH MCCARTY and a man named ACKERMAN to put ANDERSON out of the way. The sum of $50 was paid down by LEWIS when the arrangement was made, and a promise of a much larger compensation if the object was effected.

abstract: The expectations which were lately entertained of the re-discovery, at Constantinople, of valuable relics of the celebrated library of King MATTHIAS CORVINUS, of Hungary, have terminated in disappointment. Baron PROKESCH VON OSTEN, the Austrian Internuncio to the Porte, who is known not only as a distinguished diplomatist, but as a learned and brilliant author, has sent to the Hungarian ...
lead_paragraph: -- The expectations which were lately entertained of the re-discovery, at Constantinople, of valuable relics of the celebrated library of King MATTHIAS CORVINUS, of Hungary, have terminated in disappointment. Baron PROKESCH VON OSTEN, the Austrian Internuncio to the Porte, who is known not only as a distinguished diplomatist, but as a learned and brilliant author, has sent to the Hungarian Academy an elaborate list, taken by permission of the Sultan, of all the manuscripts from that library in the possession of the Ottoman Government. There are, in all, but twenty-three volumes, and they are chiefly works of the fathers of the Church. Nothing has been found of the character so fondly anticipated by the Hungarian antiquaries, who dwell on the collection of national ballads said to have been made by the orders of King MATTHIAS. It is hoped that the collection, scanty as it is, may have been rescued from the fire which recently destroyed the palace of the Seraglio.

abstract: Shakespeare Tercentenary in New-York
lead_paragraph: It would be a hasty conclusion to infer, from the apparent absence of concert among the promoters of the Shakesperean Memorial in different parts of the world -- and to which a cordial, though only moderately demonstrative, tribute was yesterday paid in this City -- that there was either lack of appreciation in the public sentiment of our time, or indifference as to the results sought for. Even had no accidents arisen to mar the effects of the plans and devices of the original London Committee, the mere magnitude of the subject presented obstacles in the way of unitary action. And thinking men everywhere, we believe, are fully content if the simple effect of the cotemporaneous observance of the Tercentenary is attained, of transmitting to after times a clear record of the estimate which this generation has placed upon the genius of "the Protagonist on the great arena of modern poetry and the glory of the human intellect."

abstract: Legibility of, and Accidental Poisoning
lead_paragraph: There is no imaginable limit to the ingenuity of certain Coroners' juries. As an instance, we have the late painful case of accidental poisoning at Yorkville, to which reference is made in a communication from Dr. STUDLEY, published in another column. Here, the evidence went to show that a local apothecary, almost blind from old age, mistaking the text of a prescription, made up a dose of rank poison for a patient suffering from kidney disease. The patient swallowed what she supposed was the remedy prescribed by her medical attendant, and as a consequence, died in great agony a few hours afterwards. To find the cause of the unfortunate victim's death was not difficult; to determine justly the measure of blame which belonged respectively to the apothecary and the practitioner, might have puzzled other tribunals. The Yorkville inquest seems to have reached the ends of justice by a quick and almost supernatural sagaciousness. The verdict, as it came from Coroner COLLIN's jury, deserves to be put on permanent record for future reference. It stands thus:

abstract: The forty-eighth anniversary of the New-York Female Bible Society was celebrated in the Room of the Board of Managers of the American Bible Society, on Astor-place, on Thursday, the 14th inst. Rev. JOSEPH HOLDICH, D.D., one of the Secretaries of...
lead_paragraph: The forty-eighth anniversary of the New-York Female Bible Society was celebrated in the Room of the Board of Managers of the American Bible Society, on Astor-place, on Thursday, the 14th inst. Rev. JOSEPH HOLDICH, D.D., one of the Secretaries of the Parent Society, presided; the devotional services were conducted by Rev. ALBERT S. HUNT, of the First-place M.E. Church, Brooklyn; an excellent report, prepared by the Secretary, Mrs. Dr. OLIN, was read; and addresses were delivered by Rev. WM. ADAMS, D.D., of this City, and Rev. WM. J.R. TAYLOR, D.D., one of the Secretaries of the American Bible Society. The exercises throughout were of an exceedingly instructive and interesting character. The receipts of the society for the year amounted to $6,877 97; of which $4,659 64 was appropriated for the support of Bible-readers; and the remainder was paid over to the Parent Institution; for Bible distribution, $885 24; and as a donation, $1,333 68. The character and the benevolent design of this noble association may be seen from the following extracts from the annual report: "Having added to the work of collecting money, the personal oversight of its distribution, we can follow our Bibles, not only in imagination to the far off nations crying for help, but to the crowded tenement houses of our own City, where the sight of the eyes affects the heart. The monthly reports of our Bible-women, now twenty-seven in number, give us the 'Missing Link' to these homes of poverty and privation. We see them brighten under the influence of patient, persistent effort; neglected children, with newly-awakened ideas of order and neatness, learning to make the garments purchased by their own industry and economy; weary spirits strengthened, and darkened minds illumined by the entrance of God's Word. Visits are made to forlorn ones, overlooked even by the comprehensive sweep of our benevolent societies; and we trust that the records of eternity will bear the names of many ransomed ones, who have gained their heavenly home through the helping hands we have been enabled to extend to them." The report throughout is exceedingly able and interesting, and will amply repay a careful perusal. No person can read it without devout gratitude to God for raising up an institution of this kind in the heart of this great Metropolis. It contains an eloquent appeal to all the friends of the Bible to aid in the work. Affecting incidents are stated, which give a vivid idea of the work of the Bible reader. The report concludes in this wise: "We send light-bearers into the darkest places, and seek to help those for whose aid no hand is stretched out. We need increased means for the work; and we appeal with confidence to the great heart of the public to aid us in supporting and enlarging it." The officers of the society are: Mrs. David Codwise, First Directress; Mrs. Wm. B. Astor, Second Directress; Mrs. James Brown, Third Directress; Miss Cornelia L. Westerlo, Recording Secretary; Mrs. Dr. Olin, Corresponding Secretary and Mr. Jacob Le Roy. Treasurer.

abstract: The advance sheets of the Missionary Herald for May contain an important statement of the condition of the treasury of the Board of the A.B.C.F.M. From it we learn that for the first seven months of the year, (to April 1,) the receipts have been $210,334 -- but little more than $6,000 in advance of those for the same time last year. Yet to give promise of an advance for the whole year necessary to meet only the appropriations, the increase for these seven months should have been $28,000, and to promise the whole sum called for by the Board, it should have been $53,000. But to meet the appropriations merely, the income for the remaining five months must be $241,000, while to secure the amount desired, and so important with reference to progress in this work, ($500,000,) it must be about $200,000. Yet for the same months last year, it was less than $193,000. To this must be added the large sum necessary to pay the high rate of exchange, which will probably amount to $40,000 more than was estimated at the commencement of the year; so that $490,000 will be wanted to meet the sum appropriated to the several missions, and requiring the income for the next five months to be $281,000, in order to prevent a debt.

abstract: The London Conference on Danish Question
snippet: The London Conference on Danish Question
lead_paragraph: The conference for the settlement of the Dano-German imbroglio is now sitting in London. It is composed of the representatives of all those Powers which were parties to the Treaty of May, 1852. But it Federal Germany also is not represented there, what does this conference resemble, save the play of "Hamlet" with the Prince of Denmark omitted? The Treaty of 1852 was of little more validity than so much waste paper, because the Federal Diet refused to sanction its provisions; and if that Diet declines to participate in the debates or the decisions of the present conference, how can the diplomats effect the object which they have in view? Prussia and Austria are indeed members of the conference, and may make what concessions they please, but it is the Teutonic Confederation which is the real respondent in the pending case, and without its assent no compromise on the part of the Cabinets of Vienna and Berlin can avail. The note of M. DROUYN DE LHUYS to the French Ambassador in London, explanatory to the position which France meant to take in the Conference, shows very plainly that the Emperor, was fully aware of the existence of this difficulty, and intended to obviate it, if possible. Notwithstanding the alleged revival of the entente cordiale between the allied Governments, it would appear that NAPOLEON has no notion of making the Treat of '52 the basis of operations. Were all the other Sovereigns disposed to respect the provisions of this instrument, the mere inspiration of His Majesty's traditional sympathies with Denmark would, of course constrain him to do likewise. But "in presence of the diversity of opinions which exists touching the validity of that treaty," it becomes his duty "to examine the interests concerned in the war, without preoccupying himself exclusively with the letter of said convention." In other words, the Emperor proposes to throw the obnoxious treaty overboard, and to substitute "the wish of the populations as the basis" of action. He would take the business completely out of the hands of the diplomatists who have so sadly mismanaged it heretofore, and would consign its settlement to the ballot-box and the Schleswig-Holsteiners. Now, this mode of disposing of the question will certainly not meet with much favor from Prussia, Austria, Denmark or England. The two former Powers will oppose its adoption, since it would establish a precedent which, if followed in their non-German provinces, would prove fatal to absolutism. While the two latter will be equally averse to it, because that, under present circumstances, it would inevitably lead to the dismemberment of the Danish monarchy. But the scheme has been tried in Italy with the sanction of England, and has succeeded there; why then should it not be alike applicable, and alike successful, in the Danish Duchies? In no other way can the objections of the Germanic Confederation be obviated, and in no other way can the parties most interested -- the Schleswig-Holsteiners themselves -- be conciliated. The impossibility, therefore, of arriving at a satisfactory arrangement diplomatically, may contribute to overcome the opposition to the Napoleonic suggestion, and to secure its author a triumph at the expense of England. The protest of the Holstein estates against the anticipated encroachment of the Conference on the rights of the Duchies and of the Prince of Augustenburg, will likewise operate not a little in favor of the Emperor's proposition, by reminding the Plenipotentiaries that the popular voice cannot be safely disregarded.

abstract: The news respecting the attack on Plymouth, N.C., the sinking of the gunboats Southfield and Bombshell, and the death of the brave Captain FLUSSER, of the Miami, is abundantly verified by the accounts which we publish this morning.
lead_paragraph: The news respecting the attack on Plymouth, N.C., the sinking of the gunboats Southfield and Bombshell, and the death of the brave Captain FLUSSER, of the Miami, is abundantly verified by the accounts which we publish this morning. Our Newbern correspondent writes that the rebel ram had come down the Roanoke River below the town, thus cutting off communication with the garrison, and well-grounded fears were entertained of the capture of the place and the troops. Several of the officers and men of the Southfield are missing, and are supposed to be prisoners in the hands of the rebels. A gentleman who arrived in the City last evening, having left Roanoke Island on Thursday, says that the last boat from Plymouth arrived at the Island on Wednesday, when fighting was still in progress, but there was no hope that the garrison would long hold out. The ram is described as being somewhat like the Merrimae in appearance, and to be very heavily plated. Admiral LEE has sent a large naval force to try and destroy her. Numbers of women and children, refugees from Plymouth, had arrived at Roanoke Island.

abstract: During the day the excitement was not very great, though the votes came in very rapidly. At 2 o'clock, the time the books were closed in the Arms and Trophies Department, Gen. MCCLELLAN had a majority of 2,256. The ballot-box was then placed at Stand No. 10, in the main hall. The votes commenced to come in even faster, and the excitement rapidly increased. At 8 o'clock the boxes were taken to the committee room, the committee opened them and commenced to count the ballots. Meanwhile the enthusiasm outside was growing greater and greater and manifested itself in various ways. Cheers upon cheers were given for each of the Generals. Jokes were cracked by each party at the expense of the other, but, notwithstanding the great excitement, the best of feeling prevailed throughout.

abstract: A case of unusual interest was brought to light on Saturday afternoon at the Essex Market Police Court. Mr. JOHN D. LEWIS, of the firm of J.D. LEWIS  Co., wholesale dry goods merchants, doing business at No. 101 Chambers-street, corner of Church, was arrested on the charge of having conspired to murder a respectable merchant of this City, named JOHN H. ANDERSON.
lead_paragraph: A case of unusual interest was brought to light on Saturday afternoon at the Essex Market Police Court. Mr. JOHN D. LEWIS, of the firm of J.D. LEWIS & CO., wholesale dry goods merchants, doing business at No. 101 Chambers-street, corner of Church, was arrested on the charge of having conspired to murder a respectable merchant of this City, named JOHN H. ANDERSON. For the purpose of effecting his designs it is alleged that LEWIS made an agreement with JEREMIAH MCCARTY, and a man named ACKERMAN to put ANDERSON out of the way; that a sum of $50 was paid down by LEWIS when the arrangement was made, with a promise of a much larger compensation if the object was effected. The two men quarreled in regard to a division of the $50, were overhead by a policeman, were arrested and made confession. Mr. LEWIS was taken into custody and held in $5,000 bail.

abstract: Case, Termination of
lead_paragraph: -The investigation in the case of Mr. JOHN W. HUNTER came to a sudden and gratifying, but not an unexpected, termination on Saturday. Its close was as extraordinary as its origin and progress. It grew out of the fact that two checks, one for $5,200, and the other for about $700, signed J.W. HUNTER, were presented and paid at the office of Mr. CISCO, the Assistant Treasurer, and the money not paid over to the Government. When the fraud was discovered, some days afterwards, Mr. HUNTER, on seeing the checks, pronounced them forgeries. The District-Attorney, however, took the very unusual step of making an affidavit, accusing Mr. HUNTER of having drawn them fraudulently, and appropriated the money to his own use. On this affidavit Mr. HUNTER was arrested. The District Attorney associated with him Messrs. O'CONOR and GERARD, two of the most eminent counsel in the City, to aid him in the prosecution. Mr. CISCO, sworn as a witness, testified in the most positive and peremptory manner that the signatures were genuine, -- that he was not and could not be mistaken, -- that Mr. HUNTER's denial, under oath, would have no weight with him, and that if any person should turn State's evidence and swear that he himself signed Mr. HUNTER's name, he would not believe him.
headline: {'main': 'CLOSE OF THE HUNTER CASE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'CLOSE OF THE HUNTER CASE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Senate was not in session Saturday. In the House, a bill was passed creating an additional Supervising Inspector of Steamboats for New-Orleans and Boards of Local Inspectors at Portland, Oregon, and at Memphis, Tenn, A resolution was adopted amending the fourth section of the Act of March 2, 1793, empowering United States Commissioners to take bail in criminal cases and providing them with a seal. The committee who investigated the charges against Representative BLAIR, of Missouri, of peculating in liquors, while in military command in the Department of Missouri, reported that Mr. BLAIR had not violated any law. Some remarks followed of a personal character from Mr. BLAIR and his accuser, Mr. MCCLURG. The consideration of the Internal Tax Bill was then resumed, the House having resolved itself into a committee for that purpose.

abstract: Our correspondent at Washington telegraphs that the President has accepted the eighty thousand troops tendered for six months' service by the Governors of Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Iowa and Wisconsin. These men compose a part of the militia force of these States, and, being armed, equipped and paid by the United States Government, they will be used to garrison posts, thus relieving veteran soldiers from such duty, and permitting them to engage in the more arduous work of the field. Gov. BROUGH has ordered the National Guard of Ohio to report for duty on the 2d prox., and Gov. MORTON, of Indiana, has called for 20,000 volunteers to supply the quota that State.

abstract: Re d' Italia; American built Italian frigate
snippet: Re d' Italia; American built Italian frigate
lead_paragraph: After the many unsuccessful attempts of European iron-clad vessels to encounter the rough ocean weather, we were scarcely prepared to hear of so triumphant a success for an American-built cuirassed ship, as has signalized the late voyage of the frigate Re d'Italia. In a letter from an officer on board, which we published yesterday, most reliable testimony was given as to her great sea-going qualities. Her whole passage from New-York to Naples seems to have been beset by weather that tested to the fullest degree her speed and strength. With a wind, and in a sea which has always caused the English and French iron-clads to roll and plunge to a degree that threatened their instant destruction, the Re d'Italia sailed pleasantly along, not only without apprehension of danger, but with an amount of comfort to her crew, and an avoidance of the disagreeable vicissitudes of a mid-Winter Atlantic voyage, known only to the larger class of steamships. She seemed, as this officer expresses it, "rather a yacht sailing with a fair breeze, than such a monster ironclad of over 6,000 tons burden." And, although it is rare for ships of any kind to encounter such weather without leaking, it appears that during this whole long, stormy passage she took in no water, and there was no use whatever made of the pumps. This is the strongest evidence possible of her great and sufficient strength, and places her at once and indisputably far in advance of all other wholly iron-clad ships that have been hitherto tested. Her speed is also very satisfactory. Indeed, it would have done credit to any war-steamer, or even a first-class passenger-steamer, to perform the voyage from New-York to Gibraltar -- a distance of three thousand five hundred miles -- in fourteen days and twenty hours. From Gibraltar to Naples she averaged thirteen miles an hour, and at times, during the voyage across the Atlantic, she moved, with steam and, sail, at the rate of fifteen miles an hour. We believe this to exceed any iron-clad's time yet reported. Letters have been received from Capt. COMSTOCK, and from Mr. ROBESON, her efficient engineer, confirming the statements of the Italian officer, whose enthusiastic report we have printed. Capt. COMSTOCK says she behaved as well as any ship he was ever in, that she rolled no more than ordinary ships, and that her seagoing qualities are in no wise impaired by her heavy armor.

abstract: We have a "Grover & Baker" up at our house. It is a wonderful machine, difficult to comprehend -- less a man had taste for the finer machanics, and strange in its motions from its very irregularity. It stands in our front chamber, in the north-east corner, between two windows. The earliest beams of the morning gild the black walnut casket which encloses it, and the red shadow of the sunset linger among its steel axles and cunning contrivances. It stands where all its clock-work and ever curious spring are open to the daylight, and yet we have studied it long without being able to understand more than these two facts -- that it does our family sewing, and saves us much in our household economy. But we have no skill in mechanics. We could hardly construct a cheese-press without a plan and a working-drawing. And this machine which seems so strange to us, may be plain and simple to a man who deals with steam-engines. We only see that here is a wheel, and there is a pulley, and here again are things that go up and down, and shoot across, and bob around generally, and there again, is a shirt, or pillow-case, or what-not, skillfully compacted and put together in every seam and gusset, and deftly made as by fingers expert in needle-work. We look at results -- and in the light of results, we have sat and contemplated our "Grover & Baker." Content to admire the faculty, we leave to sharper wits the contrivance and the philosophy.

abstract: DAMAGE $35,000. -- About 9 o'clock last evening, the machine shop and foundry of D.D. BADGER & Co., corner of Avenue C and Fourteenth-street, took fire in the office from some unknown cause, and was entirely destroyed. The company had a large stock of ornamental iron goods on hand, besides a very large number of nine and eleven-inch shells intended for the Government. The damage is estimated at about $35,000. Fully insured in some twenty different City Insurance Companies. The firm will suffer the greatest loss in the interruption of the contracts which they had with the Government. The fire broke out in the office of the building, and the wood work was so saturated with machine oil as to cause the flames to spread with great rapidity and cause a great light. The gas works directly opposite were in great danger, but the gas was drawn off from one of the gasometers, and the exertions of the firemen prevented it from taking fire. Capt. Mount, of the theSeventeenth Precinct, and Capt. CAMERON, of the Eighteenth, with detachments of men, were on hand and rendered efficient service.

abstract: Both branches of the Legislature adjourned sine die, on Saturday night, after speeches from the presiding officers in reply to the usual resolutions of thanks for the impartial administration of their offices. In the Senate Mr. BAILY made a majority report on the LOW vs. NIVEN contested seat case, awarding the seat to Mr. Low by ten majority. Mr. SHAFFER made a minority report in favor of Mr. NIVEN, awarding him the seat by twenty-five majority. Both the reports were laid on the table. The following were among the bills passed: The New-York County Tax Levy, appropriating $30,000 for monuments to the New-York soldiers slain on the fields of Gettysburgh and Antietam; authorizing the erection of a public market in the Eighteenth Ward; amending the law enabling convicts to work commutation of sentence; the State Tax Bill of 5 1/2 mills; the New Capitol Bill -- it appropriates $10,000 for plans and specifications; Relative to the Common Schools in the City of New-York; Relief of the Peoples' Gas Light Company; Conferring additional power on Marshals in New-York; to amend the Brooklyn Charter; for the improvement of Avenue B. Gov. SEYMOUR sent in a message in favor of paying the interest to all State creditors in coin, which was tabled by a vote of 14 against 13. A resolution was adopted authorizing the committee in the contested seat of NlVEN and Low to sit during recess. The Assembly bill taxing the income of citizens holding United States securities was announced, and referred to the Bank Committee.

abstract: the three days' Fighting on
lead_paragraph: It is now possible to get some idea of the late operations on the Red River, regarding which we have had such contradictory reports. In addition to the accounts we have already published, we give in this issue a concise statement from our New-Orleans correspondent. There were three days' fighting of varied character and magnitude, and each of them with strikingly different results. The first day (the 7th inst.) there was only heavy cavalry skirmishing, such as generally occurs when two hostile armies are approaching each other; and our horsemen whipped the enemy handsomely after a stiff fight, and chased them far from the field. The next day, other portions of our troops having joined the advance, they attacked the enemy again, and fought till two o'clock, about which time another portion of Gen. BANKS' army came up and took part in the struggle. Gen. BANKS himself now arrived on the field, and dispatched an order to Gen. FRANKLIN to bring forward his command. Fighting had been going on with great fury for three hours, when FRANKLIN, in person, came up, and took part in the battle. But things were continuing to go against us, when EMORY'S division of FRANKLIN's corps, also in its turn joined the previously mentioned bodies, and the battle raged until night closed in upon them all. But we had lost very heavily in officers and men, very heavily in artillery, and had lost the field. The morning of the third day Gen. BANKS had fallen back to Pleasant Hill, where Gen. ANDREW JACKSON SMITH, the hero of Fort De Russey, had arrived with his troops. An excellent disposition of our forces was now effected, and when the rebels advanced to the attack, and fell upon our lines, they were met with courage and intelligence, but continued to push our advance until they reached nearly the summit of a hill behind which SMITH was posted, when suddenly and unexpectedly he sprang up with his whole force, poured a tremendous volley with artillery and musketry into their lines, and this was quickly followed by a charge which drove the whole rebel force in rout. Having effected this sanguinary success, our army fell back to the line of the Red River, and took up position at Grand Ecore, near Natchitoches.
headline: {'main': "The Three Days' Fighting on the Red River.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Three Days' Fighting on the Red River.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Flusser, Commander Charles W.; Benedict, Col. Lewis L, of N. J.
snippet: Flusser, Commander Charles W.; Benedict, Col. Lewis L, of N. J.
lead_paragraph: The reported death of Col. LEWIS BENEDICT is confirmed by letters from Grand Ecore, near the scene of the engagement. He was pierced by five balls, and instantly killed, while gallantly leading his brigade in the final charge. LEWIS BENEDICT was born in Albany Sept. 2, 1817. He graduated at Williams' College, and studied law, in Canandaigua, with JOHN C. SPENCER. After his admission to the Bar, he became a partner of MARCUS T. REYNOLDS, of Albany. He was Judge-Advocate-General on the Staff of Govs. YOUNG and FISH; was subsequently elected to the office of Surrogate of the County, and also to the Assembly of the State.

abstract: It was found in discussion of the Morrill Tariff resolution this evening, that opinions were too numerous to render practicable any attempt to discriminate even in a few important points, and STEVENS' substitute was seized upon, that the Government might at least have the benefit of fifty per cent. increase of duty on the heavy orders for importations which have already gone forward. The vote on the amendments of the original resolution showed a strong determination to check the frauds on the revenue in wool imports, and afford the wool-growing interest incidental protection. The resolution, as passed, is acknowledged to be a crude measure, but better than increase of tariff revenue while a general bill is being perfected.

abstract: "Is Plymouth taken or not?" one hears everywhere anxiously asked about our streets. We have had no direct communication from there since Monday, and so we know but little of what has occurred, and what the result of the battle. I stated in my last communication that probably Plymouth was in the hands of the enemy, and the most reliable information confirms the supposition.
lead_paragraph: NEWBERN, N. C., Friday, April 22, 1864.

abstract: The third and last week of the great fair has passed, and its success has been unparalleled. The enthusiasm and interest was as great at the close as at the commencement.
lead_paragraph: The third and last week of the great fair has passed, and its success has been unparalleled. The enthusiasm and interest was as great at the close as at the commencement. The buildings have been crowded every day since it was opened, and the sales have been very large. The total receipts will be over one million dollars; but it is impossible as yet to tell the exact amount. Several of the stands have not yet handed in their returns to the Treasurer, and the auction sales are not yet finished.

abstract: When the produce merchants transferred their business from the old Corn Exchange to the new Produce Exchange, it was decided that the hours of business should be from 10 o'clock A.M. to 1 P.M.
lead_paragraph: When the produce merchants transferred their business from the old Corn Exchange to the new Produce Exchange, it was decided that the hours of business should be from 10 o'clock A.M. to 1 P.M. It was soon found that the majority of the merchants never made their appearance before noon, and that the bulk of the sales of produce effected on the floor were made in the half hour immediately preceding the formal adjournment or each day's meeting. Several merchants have of late been in the habit of lingering on the floor, for a quarter to half an hour alter the last whacking of the sonorous gong, protracting business hours to 1 1/2 o'clock, and not infrequently to 1 3/4 o'clock P.M., leaving only from an hour and a quarter to an hour and a half to "bolt down" what is oddly called "lunch," to write letters for the early afternoon mails, and to finish up banking and other incidental details of business. It has also been found that a reform in this matter was imperatively called for; that Change should be adjourned earlier, and that there was no valid reason why all sales and purchases of produce could not be made before, as well as after the hour of noon. Memorials have been in circulation for some days past, urging the directors of the institution to open the doors punctually each forenoon at ten o'clock, and close them promptly at twelve o'clock, midday. These memorials have been very extensively signed by the produce merchants. Including nearly all the leading receivers of breadstuffs, provisions, &c., and the great majority of the regular purchasers for home use and shipment. It is obvious that the contemplated change is generally approved of, and it is believed that, in response to the memorials of their subscribers, the Directors of the Produce Exchange will decide to inaugurate the reform with the incoming month of May. We feel convinced that, on a fair trial, it will prove advantageous to all interested parties.
headline: {'main': 'Reform in the Business Hours at the Produce Exchange--A Movement in the Right Direction.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Reform in the Business Hours at the Produce Exchange--A Movement in the Right Direction.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We rejoice to inform the citizens of New-York that, through the well-directed efforts of Hon. E.C. BENEDICT, one of our City representatives in the late Assembly, the following most efficient and salutary provision was inserted in the act for the City tax levy, and now forms part of the permanent law of the State. Apart from the easy legal remedy which it accords to every resident tax-payer, to restrain at once by injunction every threatened waste or misapplication of the "property, funds or effects" of the City, it also imposes such direct and heavy personal responsibilities on every member of the Common Council, that they will be practically compelled to desist from the spoliations which the vigor of the courts, aided by the vigilance of the oppressed tax-payers, will be quick to detect and prevent, and, if necessary, to punish by heavy legal damages:

abstract: Operations; Significance of Minor Ones
lead_paragraph: While LEE's army was encamped on the Rappahannock last year at this time, and just prior to his breaking camp in May and June to take up his march into Pennsylvania, quite a number of small, dashing movements were made upon minor Union poets by the rebels, both in the East and the West. They took care that, as far as possible, each of these little operations should be a success, and, indeed, they made extravagant exertions to secure success to all of their outpost operations, whether acting on the offensive or defensive. We recall this fact for the purpose of adding to it another one -- that the rebels have of late set on foot several small, dashing, and unfortunately successful operations analogous to those of last year, both in the East and in the West. As the most notable and the latest of these, we instance the operations of FORREST at Fort Pillow and other points in Tennessee, the operations of BUFORD in Kentucky, and the operations of HOKE at Plymouth, in North Carolina.
headline: {'main': 'The Large Significance of Little Operations.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Large Significance of Little Operations.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The tax-levies, so-called, but really the enabling laws to levy taxes of certain appropriations amounts having been passed by the Legislature. Comptroller BRANAN is already beseiged with claims on both City and county accounts. This purpose is to pay salaries, first of all; because the local government officials have been without pay now nearly four months; but even this be cannot do, until he has received certified copies of the Tax Laws, and raised money on revenue bonds. Aside from salaries, he will not assume to pay out money on City account until he is warranted in doing it by the passage of the proper appropriation through the Common Council. On county account most of the items of ordinary appropriations stand just as they were passed by the Board of Supervisors and approved by the Mayor, and such appropriations the Comptroller will not hesitate to pay from, as soon as he gets money into the treasury to pay with.

abstract: -- The desperate attempts being made by sundry disreputable boarding-house keepers to entice girls from Castle Garden to houses of questionable character, has excited the suspicion of the General Agent of the Emigrant Commissioners. Recently a close watch has been kept upon all suspicious characters, and the last "dodge," that of importing girls, has been effectually stopped. Yesterday an emigrant runner was detected in the act of representing himself as a "friend" of two girls. They were "consigned" to him, so he said, but the General Agent learning that the "friend" was a noted keeper of a house of ill repute, declined to allow the girls to leave Castle Garden. This new species of villainy, that of contracting for "help" in the old country, will be effectually stopped.

abstract: Craik, G. L. English Language and Literature
snippet: Craik, G. L. English Language and Literature
lead_paragraph: If there is one subject of a purely literary nature that proves attractive to every person of ordinary culture -- a common ground where members of all sects, and parties meet on an equal footing, induced by an instinctive taste for the study -- it is certainty our vernacular tongue, and the wide range of inquiry connected with its mechanism, etymology and distinctive characteristics, compared with other, languages of the earth, as an organ of national thought and expression. An aptitude for these pursuits has long been shown by Americans. Acute minds have always found pleasure in dwelling on them. The number or works on grammar produced in this country during the present century far surpasses what England has done; nay more, that the mother country is indebted to them for its standard vocabulary and the generally accepted rules of its speech is proved in a moment when the names of NOAH WEBSTER and LINDLEY MURRAY are recalled; while in the higher learning of modern philology the works of GEORGE P. MARSH, though but recently written, at once took acknowledged rank among the most valuable contributions ever made to the history and philosophy of the language.

abstract: Orders have been transmitted to the commanding officers of the different Navy-yards to expedite work on the various vessels in course of preparation for sea, and others are to be taken in hand forthwith.
lead_paragraph: Orders have been transmitted to the commanding officers of the different Navy-yards to expedite work on the various vessels in course of preparation for sea, and others are to be taken in hand forthwith. The fine steam frigate Susquehanna, which accompanied the Niagara on the cable expedition, is to be placed at the wharf of the Brooklyn Navy, yard immediately, to receive the necessary fitting for commission, The steamers Augusta, R.R. Cuyler, Mendota and others are to be hurried up; and the steam frigate Ticonderoga, which arrived here recently, will be sent to sea in few days. Such of the double-enders remaining at New-York as can be manned will be put in commission the moment they are ready. Five more iron-clads will be finished next month, and, together with convoys, are to be detailed for active service. Besides these large vessels, an entire squadron of small steamers is nearly ready to leave our Navy-yards for different points on the Southern coast.

abstract: The capture of Plymouth, North Carolina, with its garrison of 1,500 men and 20 pieces of artillery, is now fully confirmed by official advices both from national and rebel sources.
lead_paragraph: The capture of Plymouth, North Carolina, with its garrison of 1,500 men and 20 pieces of artillery, is now fully confirmed by official advices both from national and rebel sources. The Richmond papers of the 22d contain a dispatch from the rebel Gen. HOKE, announcing that the place was carried by storm on the 22d. Gen. PECK, commanding the District of North Carolina, has also issued an official order from his headquarters at Newbern, announcing the surrender of the garrison, after a most gallant defence. A report also comes from Newbern, to the effect that after the surrender two companies of the Second North Carolina Regiment (Union) were taken out and shot, and also that all negroes found in uniform were shot. This report is yet unconfirmed, but in view of recent occurences in the West, it is quite likely to be true.

abstract: Russia, the late Reforms in
lead_paragraph: We have spoken already of the great Act of Emancipation, offered by the Russian Government to Poland, as showing both the wisdom and liberal spirit of the Emperor. But the more silent and less revolutionary reforms inaugurated in Russia itself, since the emancipation of the serfs, are a more convincing evidence. On the 1st of January last, according to the Russian Calendar, (the 13th of ours,) a ukase of the Emperor established and perfected a system of municipal reform, begun in 1861, which is among the most wonderful instances recorded in history of governmental and political improvement. A population of nearly fifty millions of people in European Russia -- the greater part just emancipated from serfdom -- are endowed with the most minute and extended system of municipa reform.
headline: {'main': 'The Late Reforms in Russia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Late Reforms in Russia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -Our readers will have noticed that the bill establishing certain important reforms in the public school system of this City, introduced into the State Assembly by Mr. BENEDICT, and which we published and commented upon favorably some weeks ago, passed both branches of the Legislature and has become law by the signature of the Governor. The most material change introduced by the bill is in the manner of appointing and removing the teachers employed in the Ward Schools. The principal and vice-principals will be appointed or removed by the concurrent action of the Board of Education of the City and the Board of Trustees for the Ward, while the assistant teachers will be appointed, as now, by the latter body. The Board of Education will have full power to remove any school officer guilty of corruption or of immoral or disgraceful conduct, and it is made the duty of the board to investigate, by testimony taken under oath, every charge against a school officer, made by a school officer or a tax-payer. Corruption in office is also to be punished as a misdemeanor. Another excellent change is the provision by which the Commissioners, who are the officers forming the Board of Education, are not, after the present year, to be members of the Boards of Trustees in their respective wards. Each ward has now twelve elective school officers, being a total for the City of 264; but the bill provides for a reduction in the number of about one-half. The Board of Education, when completely formed under the new law, will consist of twenty-one members, seven being chosen each year to serve three years from the seven districts into which the City is formed. Hereafter, by this law, only one trustee a year will be elected in each ward, and in this manner the Ward Board will ultimately be reduced to five members, instead of ten. It provides that the inspectors shall consist of three for each district, instead of two for each ward, and that they shall no longer be elected by the people, but shall be appointed by the Mayor and Board of Education. The most comprehensive power is also given by the new law to the Board of Education to regulate and limit the expenditures of the trustees.
lead_paragraph: -Our readers will have noticed that the bill establishing certain important reforms in the public school system of this City, introduced into the State Assembly by Mr. BENEDICT, and which we published and commented upon favorably some weeks ago, passed both branches of the Legislature and has become law by the signature of the Governor. The most material change introduced by the bill is in the manner of appointing and removing the teachers employed in the Ward Schools. The principal and vice-principals will be appointed or removed by the concurrent action of the Board of Education of the City and the Board of Trustees for the Ward, while the assistant teachers will be appointed, as now, by the latter body. The Board of Education will have full power to remove any school officer guilty of corruption or of immoral or disgraceful conduct, and it is made the duty of the board to investigate, by testimony taken under oath, every charge against a school officer, made by a school officer or a tax-payer. Corruption in office is also to be punished as a misdemeanor. Another excellent change is the provision by which the Commissioners, who are the officers forming the Board of Education, are not, after the present year, to be members of the Boards of Trustees in their respective wards. Each ward has now twelve elective school officers, being a total for the City of 264; but the bill provides for a reduction in the number of about one-half. The Board of Education, when completely formed under the new law, will consist of twenty-one members, seven being chosen each year to serve three years from the seven districts into which the City is formed. Hereafter, by this law, only one trustee a year will be elected in each ward, and in this manner the Ward Board will ultimately be reduced to five members, instead of ten. It provides that the inspectors shall consist of three for each district, instead of two for each ward, and that they shall no longer be elected by the people, but shall be appointed by the Mayor and Board of Education. The most comprehensive power is also given by the new law to the Board of Education to regulate and limit the expenditures of the trustees.

abstract: Retaliation for Rebel Cruelties
lead_paragraph: Probably a more perplexing or more painful responsibility has never devolved upon the President than that of making good his order threatening retaliation for any violation of the laws of war upon our colored soldiers. Military justice and military expediency -- to say nothing of personal consistency -- alike demand that this order shall be made to apply to the Fort Pillow massacre. He himself, in his Baltimore speech, has declared that it would be so applied when the facts of the case were established. Yet it is the hardest thing in the world to determine how to apply it acceptably as regards the North and yet effectually as regards the South.
headline: {'main': 'How Will the President Retaliate?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How Will the President Retaliate?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have to-day another of those horrible tales of rebel butchery of our troops -- this time in North Carolina. A telegram from Newbern narrates that after HOKE had captured Plymouth last Wednesday, two companies of loyal North Carolinians were shot, and several hundred negro troops were slaughtered. We shall refuse to give full credit to this case, as we did in that of the Fort Pillow massacre, until it is established on indubitable testimony. Not, as we formerly said, because we believe the rebels incapable of such deeds; for their guilt, in other similar cases, is fully proven, and, moreover, they are but carrying out the bloody threats uttered by JEFF. DAVIS; but because we are unwilling to believe that the rebels are going to reduce massacre to a general system. If the truth of this massacre is confirmed, it will be utterly impossible for our Government to delay much longer taking cognizance of such deeds.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. A resolution was adopted requesting the Harbor Commissioners to remove a sunken hulk from the North River, near Bethune-street.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. A resolution was adopted requesting the Harbor Commissioners to remove a sunken hulk from the North River, near Bethune-street. A request of Gen. DIX for permission to erect temporary hospital quarters on the Battery, for the use of sick and wounded soldiers arriving here en route to the established hospitals was sent in by the Mayor, with a favorable recommendation, and a copy of his letter to the General on the subject, conceding the request, so far as his power in the; matter is concerned. The Board referred the subject to the Committee on National Affairs, with instructions to report at the next meeting. The board concurred to give a stand of colors to the Eighty-fourth Regiment N.Y.S.N.G., at a cost of $800. After considerable discussion, arising from a desire of a small minority to limit the number of Manuals for 1864 to two or three thousand, the resolution to print nine thousand copies was passed, with the direction that Mr. VALENTINE distribute 2,000 copies, and that 3,500 copies be given to each Board of the Common Council. A resolution to sell fire engine No. 31 to the U.S. Government was introduced and laid over. This engine is at Fortress Monroe, where it has been for some time past, and the Government wish to retain it. The board adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M., on Thursday.

abstract: The friends of JOHN D. LEWIS, merchant, of No. 101 Chambers-street, point to the papers on which the charge of conspiracy to "murder" was made, as not at all sustaining it. Those papers, even if true, indicate nothing further than an attempt to have Mr. ANDERSON beaten, thrashed, flogged or pummeled in some manner -- a very improper and disorderly proceeding, of course -- but certainly do not indicate a design to have him murdered. Thus much can be said without expressing any opinion pro or con on other points.

abstract: The announcement of a trot for a purse of $100 on this track, for which there were no less than twelve entries, and in which the much-talked-of gelding, General Grant, who, it will be remembered, was most ignominiously defeated last week by Stonewall Jackson, although at starting the odds were 3 to 1 on the former, attracted a few adventurous sportsmen...
lead_paragraph: The announcement of a trot for a purse of $100 on this track, for which there were no less than twelve entries, and in which the much-talked-of gelding, General Grant, who, it will be remembered, was most ignominiously defeated last week by Stonewall Jackson, although at starting the odds were 3 to 1 on the former, attracted a few adventurous sportsmen to the Fashion Course yesterday, despite the lowering aspect of the weather, and the probability that a large majority of those present would suffer from a severe pluvial discharge are they reached Gotham again. The existing doubts as to whether the advertised trot would come off or not, precluded the attendance of any but those who were interested in the event on the tapis, and the result was, that the whole affair was far more like a private trial than a public trot.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HALE introduced a bill which provides that no naval officer shall be retired under the age of sixty-two, and whose name shall not have been borne upon the Navy Register forty-five years after the age of sixteen. Mr. WILSON introduced a joint resolution appropriating $25,000,000 for the arming, equipping, and pay of the one hundred day troops from the Northwest. Mr. WILSON also introduced a bill for the increase of the number of cadets at West Point. The bill establishing a postal money-order system is a law. The National Currency Bill came up as the special order, and was discussed until the adjournment, without action.

abstract: U. S. vs. G. W. Railway Shares. Wiley Confiscation Case
snippet: U. S. vs. G. W. Railway Shares. Wiley Confiscation Case
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. 1,756 Shares of the Capital Stock of the Great Western Railroad Company of 1859. -- BETTS, J. -- Process in this action was issued Aug. 25, 1863, returnable and returned in court Sept. 15, thereafter. On that day, counsel appeared in representation of the property proceeded against, and at their instance, and with the assent of the United States, further proceedings in court were "laid over," or deferred one week. Intermediate steps in court in relation to the suit continued to be taken betweenthe libelants and parties seeking to contest the action, until April 5, 1864, when on motion of the United States Attorney for a final decree of condemnation and forfeiture of the property named in the suit, the court decided that the course of practice followed by the libelant in obtaining a decree by default in the cause, was not adequate in law to authorize the final adjudication prayed for, because (1) Leroy M. Wiley, the party charged in the libel of information with a violation of the acts of Congress referred to, had not been proved by competent evidence, guilty of the offences alleged against him; and (2) because legal proofs were not furnished to the court that the property proceeded against and attached under the process in court, belonged to the said Wiley. But those matters being incidental to the regularity of practice in a cause not defended in court, it was ordered by the court that the libelants be allowed twenty days within which to supply proofs by depositions filed in court that the proceedings in the action had been regular, and authorized final judgment and decree prayed for by the libelants.

abstract: Fighting Piecemeal
lead_paragraph: We have made, during the past two years, an ample trial of the plan of subduing the South by fighting the Confederates with small and isolated detachments, and as it does not seem to work well, we presume there must be some flaw in it, and think it ought to be examined by the authorities. It was "inaugurated" by "Little Mac" on the Peninsula, and was not at that time criticised severely, as that gentleman was then looked on as a master in the art of war, and, consequently, at liberty to indulge in innovations. The main peculiarity of his battles was, that they were always fought by a small portion of his army against the whole weight of the enemy, and the result generally was that that small portion was well-nigh exterminated, and the survivors covered with unfading renown before assistance reached them. It must be confessed, however, that the plan of always being weakest at the point of attack, however fruitful in glory, proved singularly barren in substantial results, and we abandoned "the siege of Richmond" with the somewhat diluted satisfaction of knowing that if, on certain days, we had had thirty thousand men when we had only fifteen, or if we had been there when we were here, or if it had been sunny when it was rainy, or if the marshes had all dried up, or Mr. LINCOLN had been Queen VICTORIA and Mr. STANTON had never been born, Gen. MCCLELLAN would certainly have captured JEFFERSON DAVIS alive, and destroyed his entire army down to the drummer boys.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mr. MARETZEK'S announcement for the coming supplemental season will be found to-day under the proper "amusement" column. It states officially what we have already announced semi-officially, namely, that the attraction will be the " Huguenots," and that the prices of admission are to be slightly raised, to meet the exigencies of the times.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. MARETZEK's announcement for the coming supplemental season will be found to-day under the proper "amusement" column. It states officially what we have already announced semi-officially, namely, that the attraction will be the " Huguenots," and that the prices of admission are to be slightly raised, to meet the exigencies of the times. No one will dispute with Mr. MARETZEK that the price of all kinds of labor has greatly increased since he first introduced his magnificent company to our notice. He states the bare fact honestly and plainly. There can be no issue on the subject, and we shall not provoke one by a useless discussion. Mr. MARETZEK's record is clear. He has given us opera cheaper and better than any other manager. With opportunities that may never be equaled of raising the prices, he has steadily refused to do so. Who doubts for a moment that he could have made a marked increase in the rates of admission when he first came from Havana? We had been plodding through a series of brief seasons with the meanest of resources; had heard ad nauseam, the oldest of operas. He came with a double company -- a company so admirable, be it observed, that it has swept away every fragment of opposition -- and a new repertoire. Either we paid too much for the old prices or too little for the new. Which was it? There can be no doubt on the subject, unless indeed, we freely admit that we pay top little for any kind of a company. The present advance will not place Mr. MARETZEK in a better pecuniary position than the meanest of his predecessors. It is the child of necessity; the offspring of a monetary moment where to hesitate is to be lost. Without it the opera must be suspended; with it there is a possibility of going on until a further advance is rendered imperative. This is the state of the case. We are persuaded that no true lover of music will breathe a word of objection to the course taken by Mr. MARETZEK. If he were to double the rates of admission he would still offer us a cheaper entertainment than can be found either in Paris or London.

abstract: -The auction sale of the machinery exhibited at the fair took place this morning, Mr. J.H. DRAPER, auctioneer A steam pump, presented by SECOR, of Jersey City, brought $390. The flax machine brought $340; the cotton gin, $150; the oscillating engine, $280; Austin's embossing press, $100; the Ericsson caloric house-pumping engine, $215; the planing machine, $240; one of Brown's scales, $45. The articles were all sold at prices much less than their actual value. The prices brought have in all instances been so very low that it is probable many of the departments, including the Library and the Curiosity Shop, will send their goods to auction rooms to be disposed of. At eleven o'clock to-day the auction sale will commence at the Union-square buildings.

abstract: Reports from Plymouth have it that our flag still floats over our fortifications in that place, though the enemy have possession of the town and river. It is said that Gen. On the arrival of more gunboats we shall be able to reach Plymouth and ascertain the facts.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday and transacted a large amount of business. An ordinance appropriating $800,000 (making $2,000,000 in all) for the construction and completion of the new County Court-house was adopted. The money is to be raised on a six per cent loan, upon bonds to extend twenty-one years, as authorized by a recent act of the Legislature. The Mayor sent in two veto messages, one in regard to bills...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday and transacted a large amount of business. An ordinance appropriating $800,000 (making $2,000,000 in all) for the construction and completion of the new County Court-house was adopted. The money is to be raised on a six per cent loan, upon bonds to extend twenty-one years, as authorized by a recent act of the Legislature. The Mayor sent in two veto messages, one in regard to bills for iron-work upon the building put up for a drill-room, and used at present for the Sanitary Fair, in Fourteenth-street, amounting to $4,931 66. The work covered by these bills could have been done, he shows, for $2,660 66 less than is charged. The other veto was on the Harlem Bridge bill. Both messages were laid over. The message, written a fortnight or so ago by the Mayor, upon the high prices paid for iron used in and on the new Court-house, was referred, without reading, to the special committee in charge of that work. The Committee on Annual Taxes were directed to report the changes in the county appropriation ordinance made at Albany, "at the instance of the Taxpayers' or Citizens' Association," and also to examine the Tax Commissioner's assessment lists, now being made out for the year, with a view to realizing the burden of taxes. It was intimated by Mr. PURDY and also by other members, that Mr. A.T. STEWART, who was active in support of the Citizens' Association efforts at Albany, is not assessed for anything like the amount of personal property he really possesses. The board adjourned to Tuesday next.

abstract: C.L. Carty, sworn -- Am engineer in the United States navy; kept watch on the Pawtuxet on her trial trip of ninty-six hours; did not notice anything wrong except that she lifted her water slightly, but not sufficient to inconvenience the working of the ship; the water-guage is not a true indicator of the water in the boiler, if the boiler foamed; a guage must indicate two and a half cocks, and the boilers may have more or less; but the Brooklyn's boilers were the same as the Chenango's; have had about sixteen or seventeen months' experience with the Martin boiler, and do not know that they require more care than other marine boilers; a foaming is hardly safe for marine or other purpose; the most prominent causes of foaming are caused by the different waters -- salt and fresh -- one requiring more temperature to boil than the other; it is rather more difficult to keep a fresh supply of water that foams than any other; have always felt safe; never had sufficient trouble to make me feel otherwise; think the boilers of the Chenango had been injured by cold water pressure, making it unequal to the task intended for it; would consider myself safe with a boiler that had stood a pressure of 60 pounds cold water at the steam pressure of 35 pounds; should think if the lead outside the boiler had melted, that there had been fire in contact with it; I would, taking the piece shown as a sample, think that it had been soldered. The piece of felting shown seems too much scorched to have been done by solder; think the boiler could be injured by a cold water pressure and not be noticed at the time.
lead_paragraph: C.L. Carty, sworn -- Am engineer in the United States navy; kept watch on the Pawtuxet on her trial trip of ninty-six hours; did not notice anything wrong except that she lifted her water slightly, but not sufficient to inconvenience the working of the ship; the water-guage is not a true indicator of the water in the boiler, if the boiler foamed; a guage must indicate two and a half cocks, and the boilers may have more or less; but the Brooklyn's boilers were the same as the Chenango's; have had about sixteen or seventeen months' experience with the Martin boiler, and do not know that they require more care than other marine boilers; a foaming is hardly safe for marine or other purpose; the most prominent causes of foaming are caused by the different waters -- salt and fresh -- one requiring more temperature to boil than the other; it is rather more difficult to keep a fresh supply of water that foams than any other; have always felt safe; never had sufficient trouble to make me feel otherwise; think the boilers of the Chenango had been injured by cold water pressure, making it unequal to the task intended for it; would consider myself safe with a boiler that had stood a pressure of 60 pounds cold water at the steam pressure of 35 pounds; should think if the lead outside the boiler had melted, that there had been fire in contact with it; I would, taking the piece shown as a sample, think that it had been soldered. The piece of felting shown seems too much scorched to have been done by solder; think the boiler could be injured by a cold water pressure and not be noticed at the time.

abstract: Wiley Confiscation Case, the
lead_paragraph: THE WILEY CASE AGAIN. -- We had occasion, some days ago, to speak of a decision of Judge BETTS in reference to the confiscation of the property of LEROY M. WILEY as a rebel, in which, before condemning the property, the Judge required further proof that it belonged to WILEY, and that he had notice of the suit, and was a rebel. We publish this morning the final decision of the Judge in the case, directing the confiscation of the property. The District Attorney was able to furnish proof, which established beyond a doubt, that the stock in question was WILEY's, he being one of the original corporators of the company, and never having transferred it.

abstract: no Postponement
lead_paragraph: Certain members of our State Senate, with a few other gentlemen, have taken it upon themselves to address the National Executive Committee of the Union and Republican, parties, by a joint letter, requesting a postponement of the National Convention. The letter is dated a month ago. It is a little singular that the Tribune, and other presses which favor the movement, should now, for the first time, bring the document to light. It is now hardly better than waste paper. Since its date, the sentiment of loyal men generally has been manifested so decidedly against the postponement that the committee have in fact hardly been able to consider it an open question. As representatives of the loyal cause, they are not the men to override popular opinion.

abstract: The Committee of Citizens who visited Albany to protest against certain appropriations in the Tax Levy, although they have not reduced the aggregate amount much, if any, have succeeded in diverting large amounts from useless to legitimate purposes. This is the initiative of the work which will hereafter be performed. The increase of salary to the police, a matter heartily approved of by all our citizens, and which largely increased the levy, should be taken into consideration when the work performed is discussed. The influence of the new organization for good has been shown, and as its single object is the benefit of the City, the decrease of taxation and consequent burdens to citizens, it cannot but daily gain strength and be prospered in the future to do still more beneficial and decisive work.

abstract: There has been no little regret evinced in regard to the manner in which the preliminary acts for the laying of the corner-stone of the Shakespeare Mounment, on last Saturday, were committed or omitted. Mr. HACKETT, who for so many, ever so many, years has made us laugh at Falstaff and love sack, had, as is understood, charge of the matter.
lead_paragraph: There has been no little regret evinced in regard to the manner in which the preliminary acts for the laying of the corner-stone of the Shakespeare Mounment, on last Saturday, were committed or omitted. Mr. HACKETT, who for so many, ever so many, years has made us laugh at Falstaff and love sack, had, as is understood, charge of the matter. While he is en-titled to the utmost credit for the active and zealous part he has taken, yet there seems to have been a lack of consideration as to preliminaries, and an unfortunate exclusiveness and haste in regard to them. SHAKESPEARE belongs to all the dramatic world, and so belongs he equally to all the literary. He is of the other quite as much as he is of the one; and in this contemplated tribute to him, the feelings, interest and enthusiasm of both should have been enlisted. Instead of that, the one was only partially consulted and invited, and the other not only was not consulted or invited, but was, if information be correct, purposely ignored. Now this is not referred to in any other than a suggestive war. As above stated, Mr. HACKETT deserves the utmost credit; but errors will occur "in the best regulated families." Had there been an appeal to all the dramatic and literary world hereabouts, had their joint interests been enlisted, had their joint enthusiasm been aroused, we have no doubt that, instead of a gathering of some two hundred at the Central Park on Saturday last, there would have been as many thousands; and that, instead of the laying of the corner-stone with the prospect that it will stay laid and unsurmounted during the present generation, there would have been the certainty that in a short time the funds would be ample for the rearing and the rearing perfected or a structure worthy of the genius it was intended to honor. As the matter stands now, isolated from the general interest of the two circles which should feel most interested in it, it looks as though the corner-stone was destined to be a buried fact, and the monument a myth. Messrs. WHEATLEY, WALLACK, HOYM and BARNUM, who have equal share with any in the honor of the movement, have most generously responded to the appeal for the fund; they should not be asked to do more and yet the munificent sums they have given would scarce raise a monument beyond Falstaff's shoulders. Now the suggestion is, that this matter be made not an exclusive but a general one. In the dramatic circles there is not one from him who nervously hurries on to tell "My Lord, the carriage waits," to him who suppositiously lords it in the carriage, who would not give his mite if he felt he was desired or expected to do so. Nor is there one in the literary, (and art circles, too, we imagine,) whether renowned or no, who would not do likewise. That neither have been taken into proper consideration, inconsiderately, we believe, seems to be true. But all can be remedied, and the monument can be made a fact, if only it be chosen that it shall. Entertainments could be gotten up which would swell the funds beyond fund-swelling precedents, and the Treasurer, whoever he may be, no one knows yet, would soon be plethoric with the means for the proposed object. These are mere hints, which are believed to be worthy of note. But it is unjust to expect any one man to carry a monument upon his back, and it is no refection upon the will, strength or endurance of Mr. HACKETT, to believe that he will entirely fail if he attempts to.

abstract: Maximilian's Speech to Mexican Deputation
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool, April 13, via Queenstown, April 14, and the steamship Bremen, from Southampton, April 13, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing three days' later news. GARIBALDI had entered London, and had been received with great pomp and considertion by both nobility and people. He had been entertained by the Duke of Sutherland, had called on Lord PALMERSTON, and was soon to dine with him. In the British House of Lords the Government had been defeated on an unimportant question. The Conference on the Danish question had not yet met, and the opponents of the Government were predicting no favorable results from it. The siege of Duppel was progressing slowly. Several assaults had been made by the Prussians, in which the Danes claim to have repulsed them. The allies, however, assert that some of the Duppel batteries are silent, and that the Danes are preparing to evacuate the intrenchments. MAXIMILIAN had received the Mexican Deputation at Miramar, and in a speech accepting the Mexican Crown expressed his belief that the tender of the sceptre of Mexico was by the wish of an over-ruling majority of its people. The steamship City of New-York still lay on Daunt's Rock, all efforts to raise her having been unsuccessful.

Between the French Commander of the naval stations and the Liberal Government of the State of Tabasco negotiations were entered into.
