abstract: The Coming Campaign
lead_paragraph: Those most unreliable of news-bearers, the deserters, are now passing to and fro, in large number, from one army to the other. The Northern papers from time to time contain the stories of those who pass hitherward from the rebel lines, and the Southern papers, in like manner, contain the information conveyed by those who decamp from our lines. The Southern deserters, not infrequently, have been confidential friends of Gen. LEE, who took care to tell them just before they left, all his plans and purposes. And some of the deserters from our army, if we may judge by what they tell the rebels, were on such intimate terms with Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, that he could unbosom himself in their presence, and tell them all the secrets of his inmost soul. If we might judge, however, of the accuracy of the ordinary rebel deserter's news, by the inaccuracy of that ordinarily conveyed South by the Union deserters, we should not be inclined to credit it implicitly. But by applying to all of it the ordinary rules of evidence and criticism, it is occasionally possible to fasten upon a few facts.

abstract: Freaks and Follies of Congress
lead_paragraph: The people of the North can, we are firmly persuaded, bear with ease twice as great burdens in the shape of debt and taxation as were ever imposed on any other people of the same size, as long as these burdens are fairly and equitably imposed, as long as proper pains are taken to avoid violent changes of policy, and violent disturbances of trade and industry. We are, therefore, still far from doubting our ability to pay all we now owe and a great deal more, if the National Legislature only displays common sense, and even third-rate business capacity. But if anything could lead us to fear a financial crash it would be such bits of legislation as the resolutions adding fifty per cent. to the import duties for sixty days, without even two days' notice to the public. There is hardly a single rule of taxation which this does not violate. There is a suddenness and capriciousness about it, which entitles it rather to be classed amongst the means of raising revenue resorted to by Turkish Pachas than those of an enlightened Constitutional Government. It deranges the whole course of foreign trade, without the slightest warning; destroys the calculations of all those who have already sent their orders abroad, as well as of those who have cargoes on the way home; fills the minds of home dealers with confusion and uncertainty as to the stock they have on hand; leaves them totally unable to decide what they had better ask for it, or when, or on what terms they can renew it; and what is worse than all this, it fills the whole community with apprehension and doubt about the future -a feeling which does more than any other to paralyze industry; for there is no telling what freak a body which has been guilty of this one will be guilty of next. In short, these resolutions bring in a state of things bearing the closest resemblance to the rule of a military dictator given to raising forced loans by fits and starts.

abstract: The splendid collection which Mr. BROOKING has purchased during the past six years, principally from the artists' studios in Europe, are to be sold at auction this evening, at the Dusseldorf Gallery. In the collection are to be found many very choice and valuable pictures, among them Courturier's "Evening Prayer," a scene on the Campagna, representing an Italian goatherd engaged in prayer; Duval's "Calvary," Koek-Koek's "Landscape, with cattle and figures," an elaborate cabinet gem which has long been the admiration of connoisseurs and artists. Le Poltevin, represented by three pictures, severally entitled "Seashore, coast of Normandy," with the tide coming in; "The Pilot Boat" and "Boucher Sketching," a French pastoral, one of a series illustrating the peculiar style of the artist depicted. Goyer's "Meditation" and the "Watchers" are two fine specimens of this artist. Ten Kate's "Enrolment," Carl Becker's "Something Wrong," Tassaert's "Homeless and Friendless," Boddington's "Sheep Washing" and "Gipsy Encampment," Couturier's "Chickens," Professor Hildebrandt's "Summer Afternoon," and Springil's "Dutch Town."

abstract: Yesterday Comptroller BRENNAN obtained certified copies of the City and County Tax Laws for 1864, which he sent a messenger to Albany to get, who was obliged to make the requisite copies in the office of the Secretary of State to secure them early, and to-day they will be submitted to the Common Council, accompanied with appropriate ordinance, in conformity with the figures contained in them.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday Comptroller BRENNAN obtained certified copies of the City and County Tax Laws for 1864, which he sent a messenger to Albany to get, who was obliged to make the requisite copies in the office of the Secretary of State to secure them early, and to-day they will be submitted to the Common Council, accompanied with appropriate ordinance, in conformity with the figures contained in them the Board or Aldermen are to meet specially at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The Comptroller's estimates were -- for the City, $8,013,263 88; for the County, $5,484,963 65 -- total, $13,498,227 53. The Tax Levy, to be imposed by the Board of Supervisors in July, exclusive,of the three per cent, authorized by law to be added for fractional and other deficiencies, or of judgments for which the Tax Laws provide admission, will be $14,467,419 88, or $959,192 35 in excess of the Comptroller's estimates, made up as follows: City, already appropriated by authority of laws previous to 1864, $4,610,745 21; authorized by the Tax Law of 1864, $3,801,417 02 -- total, $8,412,162 23. County, already appropriated by authority of laws previous to 1864, $4,736,917 49; authorized by the Tax Law of 1864, $1,308,340 16 -- total, $6,045,257 65. Grand total of City and County, as above, $14,457,419 88. The rate of tax last year was 2,035, or $2 35 on each $100 of valuation. The rate for 1864, as premised in the TIMES early this year, will be full 2 1/2 per cent.

abstract: The controversy which has for some time existed between the City authorities and the Commissioners of Emigration, concerning a proper supply of water at Castle Garden, has been determined by an agreement on the part of the Corporation Counsel to allow any reasonable but for laying a main from the Battery to the service pipe running under State-street. For several months the only water used for sanitary purposes at Castle Garden was received from a fire hydrant. The Emigrant Commissioners' dock, which was partially destroyed by the steamer Leary in the early part of the month, has been repaired. Yesterday there were no emigrants at Castle Garden. Several vessels are expected, and the influx of foreigners during the month of May will probably exceed that of any other previous month this year. There are now agents for eleven railroad companies in the City who have made applications for men at Castle Garden. In this manner over 10,000 laborers are called for.

abstract: There was a considerable muster of the leading men of the trotting turf at the Union yesterday, perhaps the large majority of whom were far more interested in ascertaining the form of the equine candidates than any direct interest in the trot for the purse of $60. The advent of Cardinal, a green horse on the trotting turf, and the fair show of quality he had previously made, excited considerable interest among trotting men, which was heightened by knowledge of the fact that in the interim of his last and present appearance he had changed owners -- Mr. PETTY having purchased him for $1,500, and placed him under the fostering care of HIRAM WOODRUFF. That Cardinal had done and could do his mile under 2:35 seems to be a recognized fact, and that he could reduce it to "the twenties," when brought into working trim, was confidently predicted by his adherents. Lady Blake, also a comparatively fresh aspirant for trotting honors, had also numerous and warm supporters -- and the result was that the trot was reduced to a match between these two, the rest withdrawing from the contest.

abstract: Mr. MEMMIMGER's coffers are empty, for once, to the amazement of his clerks and the dismay of his creditors. Army officers are walking about town dead broke, with their descriptive lists in their pockets and no satisfaction as to when they can get rid of them in the usual way. The new issue is a slow concern. Machine oil and elbow grease must be scarce.

abstract: The investigation into the causes of the boiler explosion on board the United States gunboat Chenango, was continued before Coroner NORRIS and a jury, yesterday, in in the Governor's Room of the Brooklyn City Hall Only two witnesses were examined, and one of them occupied nearly the entire afternoon, and the whole evening until after 11 o'clock. Mr. JOHN MAXSON, a boiler maker, and employed in the Navy-yard, testified to examining the boiler with the view of ascertaining the extent of damage done; he found 32 braces proper, and but 36 all told; there were 64 stays in the upper part of the boiler; the height of the water in the one that exploded was 16 inches below the bottom of the tube-box, which was caused by the rent running so far down on the sides Mr. EDWARD N. DICKERSON then commenced giving testimony, and explained at great length the theory of steam as applied to boilers, and its effect under certain circumstances. To-day Mr. ISHERWOOD, the Engineer-in-Chief of the United States Navy, will give his evidence, also Mr. MONTGOMERY and perhaps one or two others. The Coroner announced that the testimony would be completed in the evening, and that on Friday he would deliver his charge to the jury.

To-day Mr. ISHERWOOD, the Engineer-in-Chief of the United States Navy, will give his evidence, also Mr. MONTGOMERY and perhaps one or two others. The Coroner announced that the testimony would be completed in the evening, and that on Friday he would deliver his charge to the jury.

abstract: A female spy by the name of GAGE, who came down by the Gulf Road in Savannah, under suspicious circumstances, was arrested on her arrival, and taken to the barracks. She is a Northern woman, and gave to passengers a number of conflicting accounts of where she came from and her destination. Parties who came through the lines from Jacksonville state that they saw her on board a Yankee vessel.

abstract: Speculators are once more turning their attention to the coat market, and preparing to manipulate it, so as to inflate prices, impose on consumers, and enrich themselves at the public expense. In commercial circles, and through the press, representations are being made, with suspicious industry, to the effect that though there is no lack of coal at the mines, great difficulty is experienced in ...
lead_paragraph: Speculators are once more turning their attention to the coat market, and preparing to manipulate it, so as to inflate prices, impose on consumers, and enrich themselves at the public expense. In commercial circles, and through the press, representations are being made, with suspicious industry, to the effect that though there is no lack of coal at the mines, great difficulty is experienced in transporting it to market, because of the deficiency of boats on the rivers and canals, and of rolling stock on the railroads communicating with the principal mines. This deficiency of transportation facilities is attributed to the withdrawal of a large number of coal-barges from regular traffic for the use of the Government, and the scarcity of labor, which prevents the railroad companies from obtaining an adequate supply of engines and cars, to meet the increased and increasing demands of railway traffic. Much stress is also laid on the depreciation of the currency, as justifying high prices for everything, more particularly for coal, in which the authors of this theory feel so direct an interest.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Miss AVONIA JONES is not fortunate in the selection of her pieces. Her ambition is creditable in itself, but it soars in so murky a sphere that it is productive of no result. Plays like "Judith" and the "Sorceress" cannot elevate her to any position in art. Indeed, they are so infinitely beneath her powers that we are compelled to ignore their existence when speaking of her merits. The "Sorceress" produced here on Tuesday evening is probably from the French. The question of its paternity is of no importance. It is -- so far as Miss JONES is concerned -- essentially a bad piece. The role of the Sorceress is long-winded, verbose and monotonous. It has no relief. From the opening to the close it presents nothing but words. There is but one phase of emotion -- maternal solicitude -- and but one passion -- revenge. Properly handled, these grand elements of human life and struggle might be made effective; but they are not properly handled. They are word-drawn to the uttermost tenacity of human patience. If a good sentence occurs it is immediately marred by a dozen sentences that are bad. In two words, the play is duil, and the leading part monotonous. We shall, therefore, ignore in a great measure its existence, and repeat our praises of Miss JONES despite the adverse circumstances that surrounded her performance. The lady has unquestionable talent. Her appearance is pleasing, her bearing self-possessed and easy, her style well-disciplined, if not large. The discipline, to be sure, has to some extent been in a wrong school, but it is still discipline, and teaches her the absolute proprieties of the stage. Better than this meagre catalogue of merit is the fact that Miss JONES is thoroughly intelligent, and invariably makes more of the part intrusted to her care than the author contemplated in writing it -- otherwise how wretched would have been her fate. In the "Sorceress," she saves herself by voice and discretion. There are so many speeches to deliver, that any enexpected burst of passion is out of the question. It is praise, therefore, to say that she succeeds in making little culminations in all these very little speeches, and leaves us with a better opinion of her powers than before they were uttered. The piece succeeded last night by reason of Miss Jones' excellent performance, and because there are two or three scenic situations of great potency with the audience, although of little relative value to the play. The scenery and dresses, we may add, were very good -- although in the working of the former there were many misnaps.

The "Sorceress" produced here on Tuesday evening is probably from the French. The question of its paternity is of no importance. It is -- so far as Miss JONES is concerned -- essentially a bad piece. The role of the Sorceress is long-winded, verbose and monotonous. It has no relief. From the opening to the close it presents nothing but words. Properly handled, these grand elements of human life and struggle might be made effective; but they are not properly handled. They are word-drawn to the uttermost tenacity of human patience. If a good sentence occurs it is immediately marred by a dozen sentences that are bad. In two words, the play is duil, and the leading part monotonous. We shall, therefore, ignore in a great measure its existence, and repeat our praises of Miss JONES despite the adverse circumstances that surrounded her performance. In the "Sorceress," she saves herself by voice and discretion. There are so many speeches to deliver, that any enexpected burst of passion is out of the question. abstract: American Journal of Science and Arts; McWhorter, G. C. Church Essays
snippet: American Journal of Science and Arts; McWhorter, G. C. Church Essays
lead_paragraph: The May number of this standard periodical contains an unusual amount of interesting and valuable scientific intelligence. The different papers are quite brief -- and while there is, therefore, a greater variety of subjects discussed, the topics are in general of a popular nature. The leading article is a translation by Baron OSTEN SACKEN, of a lecture on the "Diptera, or Two-winged Insects of the Amber Fauna," delivered some months since at a meeting of the German naturalists in Koenigsberg, by Director LOEW. Herr LOEW sums up hastily in this lecture the results of seventeen years labor in this fascinating field of scientific research, during which time no less than 850 species of Diptera in amber have passed under inspection. It is noted as a remarkable fact that all these specimens belong to the division of the Diptera proboscidea, while, so far, not a single species of the Diptera eproboscidea has been found to occur. Of these 850 species, however, there are only 656 in so complete a state of preservation that their specific characters can be determined with absolute certainty. These are distributed over 101 genera, of which 50, with 395 species, belong to the Diptera nemocera, and 51, with 261 species, to the Diptera brachycera. In the case of the latter, Director LOEW remarks that the chemical decomposition of their larger bodies, the more vigorous resistance which they have made to their entombment in the yet soft resin, the slighter development of their antennae and legs, (organs which furnish such important characters for the ready distinction of the Diptera nemocera.) and still more, the few characteristics points in the neuration of the wings in most of them, for the distinction of species, of genera, and even of famines, all conspire to render the proportion of fragments quite useless for exact determination much greater among the Diptera brachycera than among the Diptera nemocera. If such specimens could be turned to account, the above-mentioned proportion of species would be greatly increased on the side of Diptera brachycera. While the conclusions at which Director LOEW arrives in this article are of high scientific value, the manner in which be discusses the subject gives it a really romantic interest. Prof. H.A. NEWTON, of Yale College, submits the first part of an elaborate paper upon "The Original Accounts of the Displays in former times of the November Star-Shower; together with a Determination of the Length of its Cycle, its Annual Period, and the Probable Orbit of the Group of Bodies around the Sun." A number of curious translations, from ancient writers describing these phenomena as far back as A.D. 902 are given. Mr. JAMES D. WHELPLEY, of Boston, in a letter to Prof. SILLIMAN, which finds a place in the Journal, gives a description of a new process for preparing quartzose ores of gold for amalgamation. The hardest copper ores of Vermont and the quartz of Nova Scotia have been ground in the pulverizing mills described by Mr. WHELPLEY. Among the other papers are contributions to chemistry from the Lawrence Scientific School and from the Sheffield Laboratory of Yale College; a summary of MEISSNER's Researches on Oxygen, Ozone and Antozone; a discussion of Glacial Action about Penobscot Bay, by Dr. LASKI; a description of the Cretaceous and Superior Formations of West Tennessee, by JAMES M. SAEFORD, of Lebanon, and an account of the Influence of Ozone and some other Chemical Agents on Germination and Vegetation. The summary of scientific intelligence is even fuller and more satisfactory than usual, and in every respect the May number of the Journal is the best that we have had for months.

abstract: Massacre, Need of Moral Police of Society
snippet: Massacre, Need of Moral Police of Society
lead_paragraph: One occurrence connected with the massacre at Fort Pillow, has aroused a more than usually deep feeling of indignation through all the loyal States. It is related that a United States officer, coming on a flagof-truce boat to take away the wounded, after the butchery, was so far forgetful of his position and honor, as to entertain in the most cordial manner, these barbarians just red with the blood of their horrible murders. We notice this reported fact here, not to remind the Government of its duty -- as we know that no one would be quicker than Gen. GRANT or the Secretary of War to punish such disgraceful connivance with crime in an army officer -- but to call attention to a broader fact, of which it is an indication.

lead_paragraph: We have gained possession of the important letter published below, and give it to our readers, who, after perusing it, will know more of the temper and character of the commander of the Grand Military Division of the Mississippi than they have known heretofore. abstract: A correspondent of the Charleston Mercury says that the inhabitants of Society Hill, S.C., have received the refugees from Charleston with the greatest hospitality; they have rented houses at the lowest rates, and sell them bacon at 45 cents per pound; butter at $1 per pound, and other things at the same generous rates. One gentleman employs a servant to catch shad, and sells them to refugees at 50 cents each, allowing every family to purchase two. By their acts they prove themselves patriots and Christians, no Yankees there. We are one Confederate family, and it is the duty of every one of us to use his heart, head and hand to serve his country and his neighbor as himself, and particularly those who have given up their homes for the honor and welfare of the State and Confederacy.

abstract: The regular Commercial Brokers are much exercised by what they denounce as the oppressive and invidious tax, which the framers of the amended Tax Bill, now before Congress, propose to impose on their particular interest. It is charged that in addition to license, stamp, income, and other arbitrary taxes, the remodeled tax bill contemplates direct tax of at least an average of 80 per cent of all commissions derived from the sale or purchase of produce and merchandise; and that according to the bill, no such burthen is to be imposed on any other, glass of business men.

abstract: By the arrival of the Champion from Aspinwall April 18, we have some unimportant items of news from the Pacific coast. The Ecuadorian Congress was in session, and had received the message of President MORENO. The document urges with much persistence the approval of the concordat celebrated last year with the Pope of Rome. Senor CARVAJAL had been declared to be legally elected Vice-President of the Republic. MOSQUERA made his triumphal entry into Carthagena Feb. 29, and was received with enthusiastic demonstrations. Rumors from Cauca were to the effect that a movement, sanctioned by MOSQUERA, had been commenced against Gov. PAJAN, under the leadership of Gen. JOSE SANCHEZ. In Panama everything was quiet. The Panama Star contradicts a rumor which had gained currency that the old United States ship Falmouth, which was sold last year at Aspinwall, had been put under the British flag, and fitted out as a pirate. The vessel in question is now engaged in the very innocent occupation of taking coal from this port to Aspinwall.

abstract: These Bonds are issued under the Act of Congress of March 8, 1864, which provides that all Bonds issued under this Act shall be EXEMPT FROM TAXATION by or under any State or municipal authority. Subscriptions to these Bonds are received in United States notes or notes of National Banks. They are TO BE REDEEMED IN COIN, at the pleasure of the government, at any period not less than ten nor more, than forty years from their date, and until their redemption FIVE PER CENT. INTEREST WILL BE PAID IN COIN. on Bonds of not over one hundred dollars annually, and or all other Bonds semi-annually. The interest is payable on the first days of March and September in each year.

abstract: The rebels seem to be de[???]ous with joy over their recent great little successes. The Richmond Examiner raves like an idiot about them. It says that FORREST, in butchering 400 negroes, has "undone in an hour the year's work of GRANT," that is to say, has given the rebels control of the whole Mississippi Valley, for GRANT's work was nothing less than its conquest. HOKE's Affair in North Carolina was hardly less grand and peculiar. It not only shows the "prowess" of the rebels, but "evinces that striking superiority of elan which most signally elevates them above the Yankee soldier," just as such a style of writing evinces the striking superiority in bosh which most signally elevates the rebels above all the rest of mankind. But the wildest assertion of this wild rebel is when he says, in speaking of HOKE's storming of the fortificatious at Plymouth, that "not an instance in the war can be mentioned of the Yankees having driven the rebels from intrenched positions." Is it possible that this rebel has not yet got the news of GRANT's operations at Chattanooga, Lookout Mountain, and Missionary Ridge, last November?

abstract: Letter to Col. Hodges; Frankfort Commonwealth
snippet: Letter to Col. Hodges; Frankfort Commonwealth
lead_paragraph: The letter of President LINCOLN to the editor of the Frankfort Commonwealth is a new and admirable specimen of his ingenuous character, and of his remarkable aptness in stating the truth. No one can wonder, after reading this letter, that Gov. BRAMLETTE, who had previously seriously contemplated organized resistance to the enlistment of colored troops in Kentucky, was so completely disarmed by its spirit and sentiments, and from that time forward gave the President his confidence and support. It could not but satisfy any reasonable loyal man, whatever his feelings on the subject of Slavery.
headline: {'main': "President Lincoln's Kentucky Letter.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "President Lincoln's Kentucky Letter.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Rise of
lead_paragraph: The stage proprietors have backed down from their attempt to raise fares from six to ten cents. We are not surprised either at the attempt or at the failure. When everybody was putting everything up as high as they could get it, we don't wonder the stagemen resolved to try the experiment also. There was quite as much reason for doubling their prices, as for doubling those of butter, apples, kid gloves and soft soap. Oats, hay and wages had risen, the currency was just as "inflated" for them as for everybody else; why should they not take advantage of these circumstances as everybody else was doing? Naturally enough, they tried it: naturally enough, too, they failed. The railroad cars carried passengers for just half price, and could not combine in the attempted extortion because the law was peremptory. Then again, the stages are largely patronized by persons who live on salaries, and whose wages have not risen with the cost of living, and they suddenly discovered that they could walk.
headline: {'main': 'THE RISE IN PRICES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE RISE IN PRICES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Examiner Raves on Fort Pillow Massacre
snippet: Examiner Raves on Fort Pillow Massacre
lead_paragraph: The universal conviction that we are on the eve of important events in Virginia will probably be strengthened by the significant absence of definite intelligence from Gen. GRANT's army. The telegraph is permitted to tell us little more than that two Georgians, doubtless very worthy and reliable individuals, who left Augusta a fortnight since, report that the railroads had been entirely surrendered to the military authorities, who were hurrying forward every available soldier to strengthen Gen. LEE's army, in anticipation of the coming struggle. Gen. BUTLER is said to have expressed the opinion that most of the rebel troops recently operating in North Carolina, have left for Virginia. On Tuesday a considerable rebel cavalry force made its appearance near Fredericksburgh, as if anticipating an attempt on our part to occupy it; and on the same day, it is said, the rebels made efforts to sweep away several of our bridges by floating logs down the Rapidan.

abstract: West, the Glorious Patriotism of the
snippet: West, the Glorious Patriotism of the
lead_paragraph: The offer of the Governors of the Western and Northwestern States of a large number of men according to report, one hundred thousand to man the Union garrisons and forts, thus freeing for service an important force of veterans, is one of the most inspiriting events of this war. When one remembers that for three years these States have been pouring forth men with lavish hand, in communities where every man is of especial value -- Illinois alone having sent forth more volunteers, in proportion to her population, than any other State of the Union; and Illinois and Indiana having put into the field an army as large as that of a first-class European Power; and when we recall that at this season of the year every man is needed, and can hardly be spared, for the tilling of the ground, we shall appreciate the patriotism of this offer. A hundred thousand men taken from the West and Northwest now, are so many men withdrawn directly from the Spring labors of the farm. As almost every one either own farms or labor on them, they will in fact leave their plow in the furrow, even as last Summer in Indiana they left their "reapers" on the wheat-field. It is not only wealth but the very source of wealth, which these States thus offer to their country. Three years of weary war, defeats and disaster, incompetent Generals and blundering policy, have not in the least cooled the fire of the Western patriotism. The people are as determined as they were when the first Western soldiers occupied Cairo, that one Government, founded on Liberty, shall reach from Maine to the Gulf. For they belong especially to that vigorous race, who, having once undertaken a thing and set their will upon it, have it not in them to turn back, but, on the contrary, are inspired and spurred on by obstacles and delays.
headline: {'main': 'The Glorious Patriotism of the West.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Glorious Patriotism of the West.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING and may be had at the counter  of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents, in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: We are still without full official information of the brilliant affair of Plymouth. We learn, however, upon reliable authority, that skirmishing commenced on Sunday, continued briskly Monday and Tuesday, and on Wednesday the enemy's works were carried by assault in a most gallant manner. The Yankee Commander, Brig.-Gen. WESSELS, as will be seen...
lead_paragraph: We are still without full official information of the brilliant affair of Plymouth. We learn, however, upon reliable authority, that skirmishing commenced on Sunday, continued briskly Monday and Tuesday, and on Wednesday the enemy's works were carried by assault in a most gallant manner. The Yankee Commander, Brig.-Gen. WESSELS, as will be seen from a Richmond telegram in another column, was twice summoned to surrender, but refusing to do so, the place was stormed and captured. The number of prisoners taken is now stated to have been two thousand five hundred, besides the negroes who were taken. The same telegram states that a splendid two hundred pounder gun was also amongst the valuable articles captured.

abstract: The Italian Consul-General in this City, Signor ANFORA DE LICIGNANO, has received a letter from Capt. ISOLA, of the frigate Re Galantuomo, announcing the gratifying intelligence of the safe arrival of that vessel at Terceira, one of the Azores. Capt. ISOLA states that his veasel sustained fearful damage from the storm which prevailed shortly after her departure from this port, but fortunately not a singe life was lost.
lead_paragraph: The Italian Consul-General in this City, Signor ANFORA DE LICIGNANO, has received a letter from Capt. ISOLA, of the frigate Re Galantuomo, announcing the gratifying intelligence of the safe arrival of that vessel at Terceira, one of the Azores. Capt. ISOLA states that his veasel sustained fearful damage from the storm which prevailed shortly after her departure from this port, but fortunately not a singe life was lost. The officers lost nearly all their clothing, and were compelled to endure great hardships until their arrival at Terceira, which was thirty-eight days after their departure from this port. Capt. ISOLA endeavored to return to New-York, but, after a vain effort, was obliged to make for Terceira. Capt. ISOLA further states that he hailed an American ship while his vessel was in distress, and asked for assistance, which was refused. The Star of the West, to which Capt. ISOLA probably refers, failed to afford the assistance asked for simply because the storm prevailing at the time made it utterly impossible for her to communicate with the frigate.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, after the transaction of some unimportant business, Mr. FESSENDEN reported the House joint resolution, increasing the duties on foreign imports temporarily fifty per cent, with an amendment making the increase thirty-three and one-third per cent. and exempting goods in bond and in tran[???]. abstract: Gen. GRANT, it seems, has not yet fully completed his preparations for commencing operations, and our Washington telegrams report that it may be some days before the campaign is opened. BURNSIDE is said to have visited Gen. GRANT at his headquarters yesterday, and...
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT, it seems, has not yet fully completed his preparations for commencing operations, and our Washington telegrams report that it may be some days before the campaign is opened. A reconnoisance by a cavalry force under Gen. DEVENS to Madison Court-house demonstrates the fact that the rumors regarding a rebel force having crossed the Rapidan were unture. Gen. BURNSIDE is said to have visited Gen. GRANT at his headquarters yesterday, and the rebels are at liberty to draw their own inferences from a knowledge of the fact. The statement that a large rebel force was concentrating at Front Royal, is contradicted upon competent authority. The only force in that vicinity is EARLY'S Division, of EWELL'S Corps, the strength of which, with the scattered detachments of guerrilla cavalry under MOSBY and other partisan leaders, does not exceed six thousand men. It is significantly hinted that Gen. AVERILL may soon commence investigations into the condition of affairs in the quarter referred to. A rumor which had gained currency in Washington reaches this City only to be contradicted -- it is that Gen. HOOKER had arrived, at Harper's Ferry from Chattanooga.

abstract: Circular on Postponement
lead_paragraph: We have before us a new and supplementary circular-petition to the National Executive Committee for a postponement of the Union National Convention. It is dated on Wednesday last, a month later than the other, but adds nothing thereto of any account, save the statement that "as far as we learn, the desire is quite general that the Convention shall be postponed." The design of this, of course, is to impress the idea that public opinion demands the change. If the committee could be convinced of this they should, and no doubt would, comply, whatever their own personal judgment might be in the matter. But there is not the slightest evidence that there is any such "general desire" as these signers represent to exist. It looks very much as if the movers in this business were painfully uneasy under the exposed fallacy of their first reasons, and had put in this supplementary plea, at this eleventh hour, as simply a desperate expedient.
headline: {'main': 'The Movement to Postpone the Convention The Last Expedient.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Movement to Postpone the Convention The Last Expedient.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Congress, and sundry of our public men, seem to be growing sensitive to the abuse of eminent public men by public officers. Gen. FRANK BLAIR made, lately, a very vituperative speech against Secretary CHASE, in very bad taste, unjust, and utterly unjustifiable in every respect; and it happened soon afterward that the President returned him his commission as Major-General, and ordered him into the field to fight rebels instead of staying at home to fight loyal men. For this, Congress seems inclined to call the President to account, as if he had committed some great wrong against the Secretary of the Treasury, This sensitiveness to the proprieties of official life is encouraging, though it comes somewhat late. For months past persons, holding conspicuous official positions, have made it their business to abuse the President without stint, but they have neither been dismissed nor denounced in Congress therefor. Is it treason to assail a Secretary, and no offence at all to attack the President -- or are we really to have a new order of things in this respect?

abstract: U. S. vs. Poynton--Counterfeiting
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. William T. Poynton. -- The prisoner in this case pleaded guilty to an indictment against him for passing an altered Treasury note. He was brought up for sentence some days since, but made an application to the Court to suspend sentence, that an application might be made to the President for leave to enter the navy, and on this application he furnished affidavits of good character. The matter then stood over till this morning, when the District Attorney desired to be heard to contradict these affidavits. Instead, however, of furnishing affidavits in opposition, he proposed to put his witnesses on the stand before the Judge, which was done by the consent of all parties. Witnesses accordingly were called, one of whom was formerly the wife of the notorious Billy Mulligan, who testified that she had been living with Poynton here in this City and in Washington in houses of ill fame, and that he had, though having a wife living here, been guilty of various acts of immorality with various women.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. Mr. MARETZEK'S promised season cannot take place. No fault attaches to the empresario. He always keeps his word with the public, even when a ruinous pecuniary loss is involved. The trouble in this case rests with a few German chorus singers, and is not likely to end until they are weeded out of the company.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. MARETZEK's promised season cannot take place. No fault attaches to the empresario. He always keeps his word with the public, even when a ruinous pecuniary loss is involved. The trouble in this case rests with a few German chorus singers, and is not likely to end until they are weeded out of the company. These persons, although they have had the longest and best engagement under Mr. MARETZEK that they have ever had in this country, refuse to sing at rehearsals unless they are specially paid for the instruction they there receive. A proposition so preposterous cannot, of course, be listened to, and Mr. MARETZEK, smarting under many advances, prefers to close the Academy rather than have terms dictated to him that virtually govern his mode of producing opera. We think he is right. A close monopoly has grown up in the matter of instrumental players and chorus singers that must be fought and killed at some early day. The public will desire no better champion than Mr. MARETZEK, and will readily excuse that gentleman for standing on his rights and at once resisting an imposition that is as insolent as it is illiberal. For ourselves, we regret the contretempts, inasmuch as the indications were favorable to a brilliant Spring season.

abstract: Merrill vs. Hendrickson; Innkeeper's Liability
lead_paragraph: Morrill vs. Hendrickson. -- This was an action to recover $500 which was stolen from plaintiff at Coney Island, last Summer. Plaintiff, a resident of this City, while on a visit to Coney Island, stopped at the inn of the defendant, known as the "Pavilion." While there he determined to take a sea bath and with that view hired from the defendant the privilege of depositing his clothes in one of the bathing-houses which the defendant maintained in connection with his hotel. On leaving the water, plaintiff found the bathing-house unlocked, and his pocket-book, containing $500, missing. The defendant denied these allegations, and averred that he had posted notices to the effect that he would not be responsible for money and jewelry, unles they were deposited at the hotel. The defendant moved to remove this case from the Superior to the Supreme Court, and to change the place of trial to Queens County. He swore to six material witnesses in Hempstead. The plaintiff swore to six material witnesses in New-York. The motion was denied.

abstract: On Thursday, in the Chenango investigation, Mr. E.N. DICKERSON again took the witness stand and occupied the entire afternoon and a portion of the evening in giving his opinion upon steam boilers, the power of steam, and the cause of explosions. He was followed by Mr. GEORGE SEWELL, a Chief Engineer in the U.S. Navy. He testified that he was general inspector of boilers at the time those of the Chenango were about completed. They had been subjected to the required hydrostatic pressure, and returned to him by the local inspector as in good condition; saw them during the ninety-six hours and made a favorable report of their performance, so far as being tight and working well; never heard any complaints from the Chief Engineer of the vessel; some unimportant things were complained of after the vessel was taken to the Navy-yard, by Mr. Cahill, all of which were rectified, and witness believed well done, as he heard no further complaints on the subject; the boilers particularly had never been complained of in any manner; was on board the Matecomet on her trial trip; the engines and boilers are of the same class as those on the Chenango; they worked well; there was no unusual foaming, and no unusual amount of water let out of the cylinders through the valves; the engines made as high as 31 revolutions per minute for a short time, and the vessel went at the rate of 16 miles an hour; the damage to the boiler of the Chenango witness contended was simply a rupture; had it been an explosion the damage would have been one hundred times as great as it was; witness could give no definite opinion as to the caase of the explosion.

abstract: Maximilian's Heir-Presumptive
lead_paragraph: It is stated in a foreign paper that the Archduke MAXIMILIAN is endeavoring to have a Spanish Prince named his heir presumptive to the Mexican throne, in case he should die without children! This is cool, and considerably "presumptive" per se. We do not know what MAX's chances of dying without children may be, but if they are a tenth part as great as his chance of dying without a throne in Mexico, his progeny certainly does not promise to be very numerous. He had better make sure of his sceptre before troubling himself about somebody to wield it after he gets through. He may be a great man, but he would do well to study the admirable instructions of Mrs. Glass about cooking fish. The first thing to be done, in his case as in hers, is to catch the fish. In the troubled waters where he proposes to angle, he may find this a matter of some little difficulty. It certainly is not worth his while just yet to trouble his head about a "presumptive heir."

abstract: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Wednesday, April 20, 1864. We have exciting reports from Decatur. A  rebel force, variously estimated at from 8,000 to 10,000, with considerable artillery, has been hovering around there for several days. The Ninth Illinois Infantry (mounted) first discovered the enemy some miles out from Decatur, on the 14th, while scouting. They have had several skirmishes with the rebels, who have been ascertained to be REDDY's command...
lead_paragraph: Special Correspondence Chicago Journal.

abstract: MARK TOPLITZ was arrested on the 15th of February last by order of Capt. STEERS, of the Thirteenth Precinct, on the charge of setting fire to a hat and cap store situated at No. 386 1/2, Grand-street, owned at the time by the accused. Fire Marshal BAKER made an examination of the case, and on the strength of the testimony adduced, Justice MANSFIELD held him to bail in the sum of $5,000, to answer the charge of arson. The papers were transmitted to the District-Attorney, and the counsel for the accused took the case before Recorder HOFFMAN, who, on the affidavits presented, discharged the prisoner. It appears that there was other testimony that did not come before the Recorder, and yesterday the latter official issued a warrant for the rearrest of TOPLITZ. Officer TIMPSON, of the Thirteenth Precinct, took him into custody, and he was again held to bail in $5,000 to answer.

abstract: The Annual Income Tax, under the Revenue laws of the United States, will be due on the first Monday in May. The rate of taxation will be, according to the amended Tax Law, five per cent. on all incomes in excess of six hundred dollars, ex
lead_paragraph: The Annual Income Tax, under the Revenue laws of the United States, will be due on the first Monday in May. The rate of taxation will be, according to the amended Tax Law, five per cent. on all incomes in excess of six hundred dollars, except such parts of incomes as may be received from United States securities, which will be taxed at the rate of two and a half of one per cent.

abstract: The Park is fast becoming the most attractive feature of our City life. A promenade on Broadway or the Avenue no longer furnishes the needed post-meridian relaxation. The man of business forgets, for a few hours, the excitement of his calling, and lightens his cares by a drive over the smoothly kept roads, or a ride along the bridle-path. The lady of fashion finds a new source of enjoyment while a noble pair of prancing bays whirls her phaeton along the crowded drive. The reigning belle of the season completes the conquest begun at the last fete, amidst the opening beauties of the vernal groves or on the broad terraces of the Mall.

abstract: -Capt. MEADE, who has been in command of the receiving ship North Carolina, was on Thursday relieved of the command, which he has had for some three years, and is assigned to take charge of the Naval Rendezvous, Water-stret. Yesterday morning the officers and men of the North Carolina were assembled for a leave-taking. By all of them, Capt. MEADE is held in warm esteem. He made an address to them, in which he referred to his pleasant associations while in command, to the success, through their cooperation, of many reforms and improvements and thanking them for the valuable assistance they had rendered him, urged them to be faithful and true to the flag and the country, and render an honorable account of themselves in the future. He concluded by bidding them each and all farewell, and was honored with three hearty cheers, each given with an earnestness testifying the kindly feeling felt for him.

abstract: GRAMMAR SCHOOL No. 33. -- A few days ago an exhibition was given at the Academy of Music by the pupils attached to the Public Schools of the Twentieth Ward. Yesterday, in accordance with general desire, some of the performances participated in by the above-mentioned school were repeated, for the gratification of parents and others interested. It was certainly a great success. Some of the tableaux were beautiful exceedingly. To the very worthy Principal, Miss CLARA M. EDMONDS, assisted by Miss POURROY and Miss MAHON, is due the credit of having contributed to the pleasure and gratification of those who witnessed them.

abstract: Holbrook James, of Post-office Dep't.
lead_paragraph: Mr. JAMES HOLBROOK, who was for seventeen years special agent agent of the Post-office Department, died on Thursday afternoon, at his residence in Brooklyn, Conn. Mr. HOLBROOK attained the position he held at the time of his death entirely through his own exertions. He was in fact a self-made man. Previous to the time he entered the Post-office he was editor of the Norwich Aurora. He afterwards published Ten Years among the Mail Bags, and also edited and published the very valuable postal journal The United States Mail. His official duties connected with the Post-office were performed in a very prompt and efficient manner. As a detective he was specially successful, and aided very materially, both in the detection and prevention of fraud in the department. Most of the important cases of fraud brought to trial were either discovered by him or prosecuted through his exertions, and in every instance his services have been very valuable.

abstract: Sioux, Gen. Sully's expedition organization
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette writes that the largest Indian expedition ever fitted out on the continent is now moving toward Idaho, having for its object the subjugation or extermination of the Sioux Indians. The entire business of organizing, equipping and completing this mammoth enterprise has been conducted under Brig-Gen. SULLY -- headquarters in this city.

abstract: The steamer Fulton brought two hundred and fifty-seven sick and wounded soldiers from Fortress Monroe, arriving yesterday morning. She experienced severe weather on her trip up, end was somewhat delayed by this on the way. The Fulton is not a proper boat on which to carry the sick through; the men did not complain much of the accommodations. Two of the men died just as the boat reached this City, their names were HAMILTON CAPLE, Sixteenth New-York Battery, and EDWIN H. POND, GO. B, Twenty-fifth Regiment Massachusets Volunteers. Their effects were turned over to the Surgeon in charge of the De Camp General Hospital, David's Island. The men were buried by Mr. A.J. CASE, the Government undertaker. The Hospital steamer, Thomas P. Way, took the men to David's Island, where they will be most kindly cared for. About six o'clock last evening a train of cars arrived in Jersey City, having on board about eleven hundred sick soldiers which left Washington on Thursday morning. Five hundred were left at Newark; about one hundred at Central Park, and the rest were also taken to David's Island on the Thomas P. Way.

abstract: Mr. STEVENS, of Pennsylvania, (Union,) offered a substitute for the bill to provide for a republican government for States overthrown or subverted by rebellion, declaring that the Confederate States, by waging an unjust war, have no right to claim exemption from the extreme rigors and rights of war. That none of the States which have seceded with the consent of a majority of their citizens can be tolerated and considered as within the Union, so as to be allowed a presentation in Congress or take part in the political government. That they cannot participate in our amendments to the Constitution, and when amendments thereto are proposed they can be adopted by a two-thirds vote of the non-seceding states. Whenever the Federal forces conquer the seceding States, they shall be regarded as separate Territories, and be represented in the House of Representatives, the same as other Territories.
lead_paragraph: Mr. STEVENS, of Pennsylvania, (Union,) offered a substitute for the bill to provide for a republican government for States overthrown or subverted by rebellion, declaring that the Confederate States, by waging an unjust war, have no right to claim exemption from the extreme rigors and rights of war. That none of the States which have seceded with the consent of a majority of their citizens can be tolerated and considered as within the Union, so as to be allowed a presentation in Congress or take part in the political government. That they cannot participate in our amendments to the Constitution, and when amendments thereto are proposed they can be adopted by a two-thirds vote of the non-seceding states. Whenever the Federal forces conquer the seceding States, they shall be regarded as separate Territories, and be represented in the House of Representatives, the same as other Territories.

abstract: Report of Red River Operations
lead_paragraph: Admiral PORTER forwards to the Navy Department a very interesting report of his recent naval operations up the Red River. His fleet was large, consisting of a dozen vessels, several of them iron-clads, and thirty transports; and his orders were to advance as high as Shreveport, and cooperate with Gen. BANKS in his movement upon that point. The defeat of BANKS' army compelled a return of the fleet as far as Grand Ecore. Of his remarkable experiences, and of the remarkable fight between two of his iron-clads and a large force of drunken rebel infantry, he gives a vivid picture.

lead_paragraph: The purse of $100, best 3 in 5, to wagons, yesterday, had originally 13 entries, but the result of the last few days reduced the appearances at the score to a trio, it appearing to be foregone conclusion that from the power Stonewall Jackson had previously shown, and the easy style in which he had disposed of his competitors, that the race was his own. The advantageous change in the weather had not p>only a marked beneficial influence on the track, but on the attendance of the visitors, which embraced a strong delegation of the leading sporting-men of New-York and its vicinity, and the owners, trainers and patrons of the trotting-turf. It was presumed by some that the form, speed and bottom which had been previously exhibited by Stonewall Jackson was but an equine ephemera, liable to displacement at any moment. The admirers of the Jersey mare, Lady Collins, had time and again expressed their convictions that she was fully capable, not only of reversing all previous decisions, but of bringing Stonewall down to exceedingly short time; while the friends of Gen. Grant, who came out with such a rush, and so miserably disappointed his backers when the odds of 3 to 1 were laid on him, felt assured that he had overcome his perverseness, and could be brought down through exercise in the interim to a fair and square trot, without breaking up as recklessly as he had previously done.

abstract: Russia, the Influence of in Europe
snippet: Russia, the Influence of in Europe
lead_paragraph: A striking instance has been presented lately of the increasingly bitter feeling prevailing in Russian official circles toward France. The 31st of March was the fiftieth anniversary of the taking of Paris by the allies. An order was issued by the Government, ordering its celebration with especial brilliancy. A grand review of the Russian regiments in St. Petersburg was to be held, and they were particularly commanded to appear, not with their new banners, but with the old flags which had been tattered and soiled in their long struggle with the French.

abstract: Sterling vs. Kendall, >amp;c. Trade-marks
lead_paragraph: Henry H. Sterling vs. Edward Kendall and Robert Kellam. -- This was a motion to dissolve an injunction in the above case. Dr. Sterling, the proprietor of an article to promote the growth of the hair on bald heads, obtained an injunction against the proprietors of another article of the same nature, called Kendall's Amboline. The matter in controversy is mainly the right to use the portrait of a longhaired lady as a trade-mark. On the part of the defendants making the motion, it was shown that Sterling's Ambrosia never could have made the lady's hair grow to such a preternatural length, and an affidavit was read from a postmaster in the land of steady habits, who swore that he had known the lady in question in former times; that her hair had always been unusually long, but it was the natural growth of her head and not produced by the use of any lotion; that Kendall had an equal right to use her portrait for his "Amboline;" that it was common practices to use such pictures. All charges of fraud against Mr. Kendall was withdrawn, and the question turned upon the similitude of the trade-marks. On the part of Dr. Sterling affidavits were produced, from both Mrs. Brown and her son, showing that her hair had been short and thin, but that in 1858, she had been presented by her brother with some of Sterling's Ambrosia, which had caused her hair to grow to a great length, that after this she had been on exhibition at Barnum's Museum as a curiosity, and that her portrait was used as the disputed trade-mark. The court said that to maintain the injunction the case must be a clear one; that it would come on for trial soon on the merits, and that, therefore, the injunction must be dissolved.

abstract: In the beautiful City of Poughkeepsie, N., Y., on the Hudson, has grown up an institution of learning that has acquired such widespread reputation, and whose merits are so well established, that it deserves more than ordinary notice. We refer, of course, to Eastman's National Business College -- a report of which, prepared by George W. Bungay, Esq., of the New-York Tribune, occupies an entire page of our paper this week. The influence this institution is exerting upon the nation, and the growing favor of practical useful education, which is not to be overlooked, will cause this report to be read by young men, parents, and educators in general.

abstract: The Congressional Republican caucus this morning agreed to ask for the appointment of a Joint Committee of Congress to investigate charges made against Secretary CHASE by FRANK BLAIR. Senator HOWE will offer a resolution to that effect in the Senate tomorrow. This action is demanded by Mr. CHASE'S friends, who desire to give an official and effectual refutation to the slurs heaped upon him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Friday, April 29.

abstract: Soon after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a fire was discovered on the upper floors of the four-story house owned by ROBERT H. COFF, situated at No. 357 West Thirty-fourth-street. The premises were occupied by Mr. JOHN FRASER. His furniture is badly damaged by fire and water. The damage to the building is about $5,000. It is insured for $6,000 in the Mechanics' and Traders' Insurance Company. FRASER is insured on his furniture $1,500 In the Market Insurance Company. The adjoining building, No. 355, owned by Mr. GOFF, was damaged to the extent of $500. It is insured in the Peter Cooper Insurance Company for $6,000. Mr. GOFF's furniture was damaged about $2,000. Fully insured in the Globe Insurance Company.

abstract: Bond, Major, the Arrest of
lead_paragraph: It may be remembered that some weeks since we mentioned the arrest in Washington of Maj. F.S. BOND, one of the staff of Gen. ROSECRANS, for being in that city without proper leave, -- and that he was ordered to report to Gen. ROSECRANS for trial by court-martial at St. Louis. The St. Louis journals of the 14th bring the report of his trial.

abstract: -Some of the  PROSPECTS OF THE WHEAT CROP. Some of the  Western papers have said much about the effects of a bad Winter upon the growing wheat, but after careful inquiry the Cincinnati Gazette does not anticipate a diminution to exceed one-third, and even this is probably an excessive etstimate of the damage. The Gazette concludes an article as follows:

abstract: Com. S.C. ROWAN, of the South Atlantic Blockading Squadron, has forwarded to the Navy Department a communication from Capt. J. DE CAMP, written on board the United States steamer Wabash, off Charleston, S.C., under date of April 19, in which that officer relates the supposed sinking of the rebel torpedo boat which sunk the Housatonic. It appears that on the night of the 18th the deck officer of the Wabash discovered a dark object about 150 yards distant from that vessel, which corresponded in shape and movements to the torpedo boat. It moved rapidly up against the tide, till opposite the mainmast, and then turned and stood directly for the ship. The men of the Wabash quickly rushed to their quarters upon the beat of the gong, and when the supposed torpedo boat was about fifty yards distant round shot were fired at her from each of the spar-deck guns. A round shot is supposed to have struck and sunk her, as she was seen no more after the first fire, and the second volley struck in the immediate vicinity of the first.
lead_paragraph: Com. S.C. ROWAN, of the South Atlantic Blockading Squadron, has forwarded to the Navy Department a communication from Capt. J. DE CAMP, written on board the United States steamer Wabash, off Charleston, S.C., under date of April 19, in which that officer relates the supposed sinking of the rebel torpedo boat which sunk the Housatonic. abstract: The sub-Committee on the Conduct of the War are here investigating the Fort Pillow massacre. It is thought they will exonerate Gen. HURLBUT, as it is generally conceded the force at his command was inadequate to deal vigorously with FORREST.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS, Tuesday, April 26.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Red River disaster came up for discussion, in connection with a joint resolution offered by Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri, to provide for the printing of the report of the Cotton Speculation Investigating Committee, of which Gen. McDOWELL was President.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Red River disaster came up for discussion, in connection with a joint resolution offered by Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri, to provide for the printing of the report of the Cotton Speculation Investigating Committee, of which Gen. McDOWELL was President. Some exposition was made to the adoption of the resolution by Messrs. WILSON, FESSENDEN and others when, Mr. HENDERSON stated that letters he had recently read stated that the Red River disaster was attributable to the sending of the wagon rain advance with the cavalry, for the purpose of gathering cotton. Mr. CONNESS denied this insinuation most emphatically, and defended Admiral PORTER from charges casually made against him. The resolution was finally adopted. The National Currency Bill came up in order, and various amendments which were offered were defeated by decisive votes. Of the miscellaneous measures introduced, the most noticeable was a curious scheme to supply the Upper Mississippi with a medium stage of water throughout the Summer months.
